GAME: Race for the Galaxy
RANK: 47
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Interesting cardgame, reminds (a lot) San Juan, but much deeper. Brain-consuming! The icon system is not user-friendly, in my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A role-selection model is used as a scaffolding to build your own - intergalactic - victory points engine, with plenty (an I mean PLENTY) of choices, all in a single deck of cards. The number of possible combinations and viable strategies is very high, with every card that adds a little twist to your progress through the game. You have to adapt your strategy to the cards you are dealt, with a new, different engine to tinker on during every play, an engine that keeps opening new paths at every turn. 
The first impact on an inexperienced player can easily be overwhelming. The rules are clear and well designed (albeit a bit lacking in elegance, also due to the complexity of what the game is trying to portray), but the variety of ways by which different cards can interact with the basic rules and all the different icons used to describe those interactions need at least a couple of games to familiarize with. Then, another couple of games could help in making your gameplay fluent, so that you can finally begin to look at what the other players are doing, instead of trying to fit the last couple of cards in your masterplan. Even if a bit confusing, this learning process is usually really fun, even when you still don’t really understand the strategic implications of your choices. 
A whole game can be really fast (usually under an hour even among inexperienced players), fast enough to easily lure for a second play after the first one and quite surprising in itself, considering the amount of gameplay and possibilities that are crammed in such a short amount of time.
The fact that each player has his own deck of roles/strategies brings interaction between players near to zero. Sure, you have to guess the roles that are going to be selected by your fellow players and select your role in a way that maximize your advantage and minimize theirs, but it’s just another variable that you have to consider when planning your next turn.

Card quality is really good. Illustrations go from good to really good and the sci-fi theme is strong and well implemented. If you find all the icons and text on the cards to be a bit unfathomable do not worry, it’s much WORSE than it looks. Really, look at the player aid. I assure you it'll become of real aid after a couple of plays, but at first it seems as straightforward as an encyclopaedia in a foreign language. The iconography, to be fair, is actually really functional once you get it, but of course you have to get it first. The rulebook is well written and clear, no problems there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
The first couple of times I played Race for the Galaxy I thought it was a good game but not great. Then, I sat down with a few other guys who were big gamers (though they had never played this game before) and I taught them how to play. I discovered as I taught them all of the strategies involved with playing this game and really grew to love this game! It is a blast and I am now scoring twice as many points as I was before discovering the strategies. What a great game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
Fun game, but I would enjoy it much more if they didn't rely so much on all those obtuse symbols. Using the symbols is fine, but it would be [i]really helpful[/i] if the cards also told you what they did in straightforward text. There is plenty of room for a bit of text on most of the cards; they already have clarifying text on many of the cards, so it just looks lazy for the rest of the cards to have no text at all.

Some of the cards feel a bit abstract, too, but I guess that's to be expected in a card game like this.

Besides that, I think it's great game. It actually feels pretty thematic most of the time, and I love the setting of this game (and really don't care for the setting of Puerto Rico). Too bad its a chore to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favourite games of all time. Absolutely brilliant. Elegant design, fast and immensely fun to play. Works well with many different player counts and is very portable - a must game to take with you anywhere!

I first rated it 10, but later took the rating down a notch as the base game gets a bit dry after dozens of plays and once you learn it, the Consume-Produce strategy is the surefire way to go. The base game alone thus falls a bit short of the absolute perfection that is required of a 10.. I'd still give it [size=14][BGCOLOR=#00CC99][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][size=8][b]9.5[/b][/size][COLOR=#00CC99]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/size]

Expansions have added immensly to the game, however. The first one is great, the second one too, and the third one adds some very interesting cards to the mix.

However, the prestige rules of the third expansion completely break the game. They're so awful I never play with them anymore and have removed the cards and goals that deal with them from the game. The only things I use from the 3rd expasion are 3 start worlds, 1 goal and 28 cards. The deck is starting to get somewhat unwieldy after three expansions in any case.

Played with the best parts of the expansions (or even with just the first expansion), I simply cannot give the game anything but a [size=14][BGCOLOR=#00CC00][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][size=2][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][size=8][b]10[/b][/size][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][/size][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/size]

Keldon's AI (available online for free) is incredible and a great way to play the game against AI opponents. Helps tremendously in learning to play the game competitively too. I have probably around 1000 plays against the AI (I don't log these) and still never grow tired of playing this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I'm drawn to this again and again, yet don't fully appreciate the game. Have only played it solitaire, and that may indeed be a factor. The robot in the expansion is formidable, having won roughly 80%-90% of all games played... so it does appear to be quite the challenge to defeat.

I'm experimenting with several other solo options for this game -- those posted here on BGG are very good. They're more fun than the clobbering I endure at the hand of the robot, that's for sure.

;)

UPDATE: I consider myself very well experienced with this title at this point, and it's one of the finer titles in my collection. It's full of interesting decisions that matter, a short playing time, and the desire to say, "Let's do that again!"

RATING: 10

Without a doubt hard to learn (see San Juan below as a way to get your head around the basic mechanics before proceeding directly to takeovers in the 3rd expansion!). A wonderful 2 player game and the expansions only add more layers without unbalancing it (though the 3rd expansion does change the game). FYI - My gf normally wipes the floor with me at this game. :-(

EDIT - Upgraded the game to a 10 after first few multi player games Jan 2012.

RATING: 6
Very fun, love the sci-fi theme.  I would probably like it better if I hadn't played San Juan first, as it's not as elegant.  The multiple versions of some of the roles really irritates me.  However the added paths to victory and complexity of which decisions are best make it still a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Initial view after just one play, so too early to form any real judgement. Enjoyed the theme and the added complexity but it has likely lost the marvellous simplicity of SJ. It certainly felt pretty solitaire which was compounded by the fact that we couldn't easily see what cards the other players had laid. Contrast SJ where its easy to see who has played what, and how your choices will aid or constrain them. Clearly familiarity with the icons is necessary before giving a considered rating.

Played 2 players twice tonight - the icons are pretty much fine and it's a better game with 2 players rather than 4 I think. How the forthcoming expansions with added players will fare will be interesting to see. I still have a feeling that the game is a touch fiddly for what it is, and the player interaction (at least in the base game) remains limited. It's partly my advancing years that lead me to like vanilla best, so SJ will likely remain my favourite of the two!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have a very conflicted relationship with this one. The theme is great, the graphics are great, even the game-play is pretty great... and yet, the game is presented in a very user-unfriendly way - in my view, this game could have been a solid ten if they had used fewer icons and more text to convey the game-play information. As it is, I am mostly playing against Keldon's AI (which is great, by the way). 

Addendum: what's really great about the game are the many paths to victory - there are lots but you have to pick one and stick by it. Jacks of all trade will lose horribly. IMO, this is this game's unique selling point, most other games in the genre offer 2-3 and the rest is optimization... this game offers more, especially with the first expansions (more expansions make it bloated imo). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There are so many different strategies to winning this game.  The base game is great by itself and each expansion adds more depth and replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
This game just isn't that fun to play. At first, it was terribly difficult to grok, although after introducing it to a few folks, gamers seem to get it pretty quickly. In brighter light, the brown/orange color blind problem is much less although still annoying. But for me it reduces itself to a random puzzle game: you play the hand you're dealt and after that, it greatly depends on the cards you get with the advantage going not to skill, but knowledge of the deck - a trait I particularly dislike in a game. Yes, there are important decisions, but I believe it's much more based on luck favoring the prepared. It is Magic the Gathering without deck building. Is that a great game? I don't think so at all. Ironically, Dominion is the opposite: deck building without any difficult or interesting cards. Dominion works for me, this one simply does not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
The more you play, the better it gets. 

+ elegant and ingenious systems
+ simple rules, easy to learn, hard to master
+ very deep experience in a short playing time (best depth per minute ratio I've ever seen)
+ huge replay value
+ plays very fast
+ it's very addictive

+ It has a lot of expansions (all are good), but don't make the mistake to rush and get them all at once. Let the game take it's time, and gradually add them one by one. The game will tell you when it needs new twists.

- the first time you play it you'll need about 10-15 plays to get the iconography out of the way, but after that ... it flies

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
So, after watching my friends play this a couple of times, I finally had enough time today to join in (we played this during our lunch break at work.)

It is an interesting game with lots of good Sci-Fi names and elements that I recognize from a plethora of book series.  

Yes, the symbols are absolutely crazy and not exactly intuitive to get a grasp of, yet I managed fairly well.  There were questions the first time the different parts of play came around, but it wasn't that hard for me to grasp.

I started with a hand that was filled with military cards, so I ran with that.  And while I came in third place with 25 points, I didn't do completely terribly for my first time playing.  Especially since the winner had only 53 points from mining.  Next time I might try for mining.  If I get the cards.

Well, still haven't tried for mining as I just haven't gotten the cards.  Am getting slowly better as I understand what all the symbols and colors mean.  I ended last game with 29 points - a far cry from winning but clearly making steady progress!

OK, played again, and while I had a rough start (with many terrible cards) I ended up in second place with over 30 points!  Yes!  Clearly, understanding the importance of the 6-point developments changes the game dramatically!  I still feel I'd need a few more plays to really get the strategy down, but I'm feeling much better about this game overall.

I still totally suck, and when it comes out, I just play to try to become better, because I know there's no way I'm going to win against my group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.1
This "game" blows so many chunks that you could erect a Eurogame monument from those chunks, which, while gross, would be quite appropriate.

This game is no "race."  It has nothing to do with space.  Like most Eurogames' it has nothing to with anything.

Here, ya want to save a lot of money?  Go to Walmart and buy 4 sets of playing cards.  Have 3 friends come over.  Everyone play solitaire.  At the end, see who scored the highest.  That's it.  I just saved you about $30 (USD).  You're welcome.

Fun?  No.  If your Walmart decks of cards had pictures of dinosaurs on them, it would be WAY more fun than Race for the Galaxy, but that's not fair: dinosaurs do those things and this game has no dinosaurs.

You know what else sucks about this game?  I have a mighty military (also known as "red" cards).  You are a bunch of peace loving hippie beatnecks.  I come over and demand that you pay tribute and if not, then I will conquer some of your planets filled with long haired weirdos.  Huh?  I can't.  Why not?  I have lasers!  I have disruptors, photon torpedoes.  You have Joan Baez and a guitar.  I'm about to implement some Pax Instersellerica on you, but I can't do it.  Why?  Because the rules say I can't interact with you.  I guess we are on opposite sides of the galaxy or something.  Huh?  Then how are we able to play off of the same roles?  How can there be a victor?  Because this game just sucks.

Defenders of this corpse are quick to point out to me that if I go buy a bunch of expansions, THEN, I actually get to, you know ... interact with you.  Really?  That proves how much this game sucks.  It's an acknowledgement that you have to spend a bunch of money just to make it not suck as much -- AND THERE STILL AREN'T ANY DINOSAURS!!!!

So if you are a sad Eurogamer who can't break free, I'll help you out.  If you want a game using these mechanics, go play San Juan.  It's way more fun.  If you want something more challenging than San Juan, skip this turd and play Glory to Rome.  This game just blows, no matter what type of gamer you are.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of my favorites from the first time I played.  At first the game rules seem fairly complex but once you start playing things are fairly self explanatory.  Still, it definitely helped to have someone around who had played the game multiple times to explain things.  The game involves collecting cards, spending cards as money, and creating a tableau of up to 12 cards.  There is no direct player vs player conflict so this is a nice contrast to games where you are constantly fighting people over the same territory.  The game allows for multiple strategies to win which makes it quite fun to adapt to the cards you are dealt.  Each game takes about 1.5 hours.

RATING: 7
This is a good card game. It is quite eye-boggling at first; as many have said, the iconography is daunting. But if you seek out a youtube video or two of how to play this game, 15-30 minutes later you will be primed for an easy play through!
Two knocks...
1) I don't see much of the "engine" development. Card draws are pretty random. Maybe if I would do more "Look at 5 and Keep 1" Explore phases I would feel more in control of my destiny and less controlled by luck of the draw.
2) OH MY GOD THE TEXT ON THE CARDS IS FREAKING TINY. Seriously, reprint these cards, TODAY. How one earth did anyone think this was sufficient? -2 points off my Rating for this game due to terrible card font.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The game balance/card balance is a godsend.  We can really see the fruits of the efforts spent on design and playtesting.  It is really amazing that there are so many different cards with different powers, yet none seems too strong or too weak (for their costs).  In this aspect RtfG has surpassed even Puerto Rico and San Juan.  Because the card balance is good and the cards are so varied, you can play many intricate combos besides the obvious ones, so the game has lots of variations and hence, longevity.  Being a card game with admittedly some luck, this game may not be very good as a /competition/ (GIPF project games do that better, for example), but as a game and /entertainment/ I couldn't ask for more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game with immense replay value. Not too long either. Resource management, like San Juan, but with more depth and width. Excellent 2, 3 or 4 player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this game!  There are a number of subtle strategies and techniques.  There's a lot to be said for either using a strategy from which your opponent(s) can't leech or using a strategy that leeches from your opponent(s).  Some games, it really does become a race to win.  I'm enjoying this more and more and expect to keep enjoying it for the foreseeable future.  I'm also rather addicted to it.  (Race anyone?  Race?)

ADDENDUM:  While I understand Race may not be for everyone (steep learning curve, mucho symbology to learn, lots to figure out), it is definitely my game of choice.  Deep gameplay and the many, varied options and strategies keep me coming back.  At +100 plays, I will gladly play more and I feel like I'm still picking up various nuances.

I can't wait for the expansions!  (Seriously, I can't wait.  WTT [insert something extremely precious and valuable] for an advanced copy.  Void where prohibited by law, good taste or insobriety.)

This rating is for the base game (i.e., without expansions).  I played the base game a lot (looks like 224 plays) and came to enjoy it.  The expansions, even the first one with only 22 more cards, dramatically change the game.  The strategies, the directions, the feel -- they just play differently.  Some elements are improved while others are diminished.  (4/09/09)

NOTE (10/02/13):  Base game is excellent!  It really is fantastic on its own.  1st expansion is okay but not solid.  2nd expansion fleshes things out further and is very good.  3rd (final) expansion is the icing on the cake.  The combined product (base + 3 exp) is excellent!!!  Still, I rate the base a 10 and the others less (8-9) because the base alone is a complete, and wonderful, game all on its own.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is really growing on me, though I haven't played it much.  It's probably the game I'm most up for at the moment.

Update: still a lot of fun.  As for the expansions, I'm less sure about some aspects of them.  I can see the argument that goals (from The Gathering Storm) add to the necessary skill, but they don't make me jump for joy.  (It may be something as trivial as the fact they aren't printed on cards - I'm not normally a sucker for aesthetics like that, but I detect a trace of that feeling here.)  And so far takeovers (from Rebel vs Imperium) have been a bit of a dud.

Update: still enjoying this one a lot, though it's tailing back a bit.  I feel that diminishing returns have kicked in with RvI, especially with the takeovers mechanism which is generally a lot of fuss over nothing in a two player game (the number I generally play at).  In live play, base+tGS is about as fun and much less fiddly than the whole shebang (and I very much like just the base set along - it's very elegant).  Kudos to Tom Lehmann for okaying the dissemination of Keldon's AI, by the way.  Hopefully it's been a smart business decision.

Update: Unfortunately, the Brink of War expansion means this one isn't getting to the table with my group as often as it should.

Update: The base game, plus Gathering Storm, is a fine game that still holds up, but that's in part because we're not playing the bejinkers out of it.  RvI and BoW are expansions that only seem to come into their own if you scale further learning gradients and get everyone to roughly the same plateau; while I can see the fun there, my group aren't going to end up doing that.  Hopefully Alien Artifact will be accessible as well as a whole new arc...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Why I think you should play this:

*Effectively boils down the 'space opera' experience into a < 60 mins experience. There's diplomacy (role selection), military and industry (production). There's exploration, expansion (develop/settle), exploitation (trade/consume) and even extermination if you want it (takeovers). 

*The theme is immersive if you let it be. The art is original, slick and consistent. The backdrop gives intrigue to the development of personal fiefdoms without being overpowering. I actively enjoy linking my empire of random cards with a backstory. It's there. 

*The player dynamics are subtle, but also ingenious. The role selection mechanism allows players to gain from guessing opponent actions, but doesn't impede players from doing what they want without engaging in mindgames. 

*This is a quiet game of min-maxing, and I think it's relatively quick-playing time, combined with its depth of possibilities, has made me uninterested in exploring space operas or economic games in general. I've played thousands of times, and still very much enjoy it. 

Why I might not recommend this:

*The expansions add a lot to this game, and my sweet spot is somewhere between the first and second expansions (though all are good in different ways). While the cards aren't imbalanced, the expansions each prioritise different things, and sometimes it can be hard to find players who see eye-to eye on what sort of experience they want from this game. I find the 2-player game much, much different from the multiplayer.

RATING: 8

RATING: 10
I havent been this excited by a game in 2 years.  This is the real Puerto Rico card game, imo.  I feel it is better than San Juan in pretty much every way (And I really like San Juan).  I've only played a couple times so far but I'm desperate to play it more.  I love how much variety there is in the cards and theyre abilities, and how this wide variety of abilities is neatly expressed on the cards with simple and intuitive symbols.  I love the variety in the large scoring 'buildings', and how they do something cool as well, so its ok to build them earlier.  I like how there are different strategies in the game, but you cant just do the same one every time, you have to do one that works with the cards and homeworld that youve drawn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[i]2017/04/28 - 4 plays 2-3-5p[/i]

Masterpiece of contemporary game design. A dense, subtle engine building game packaged in a bundle of cards that you can take and play anywhere.

It plays fast and forces you to check what others are doing to beat them in the race. No direct take that, so great for conflict averse players (and for the others teach them to read their opponents).

The quintessential desert island game. And with the first expansion, it has a very innovative solo module. No game is perfect for everybody, but this one hits all the right buttons for me and fires on all cylinders.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game unquestionably makes San Juan redundant. I like it better for three reasons

1. The simultaneous action selection and resolution makes the game much faster.
2. The massive variety means there are many more options.
3. Unlike San Juan, I always feel there is something useful I can do.

The first time we opened this we played it four times in a row. That has never happened for any other game I've played. Then I played it a total of 19 times over a week and a half, without playing any other game in the interim. The last time I got that obsessed about a game was when I first bought Settlers of Catan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

Pro: I really enjoy games where cards are used as mana/resources, see Summoner Wars.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Race for the Galaxy is a game whereby players try to build and develop the most prosperous galaxy among the players.  Players are able to Explore, Develop, Settle, Consume and Produce actions to help them to build their galaxy.

In each round, players are able to choose 2 actions.  Only actions that are chosen by players are conducted in the round.  For players who chose the specfic actions, privileges are given to players during the action phase.  The game will end if all the victory chips are awarded or any player has played 12 cards.

Good points: Many different combination of cards that can help to earn victory points.

Bad points: The game depends too much on luck.  If the cards drawn cannot combine to what players have played previously, then the game can be frustrating.  If cards that are able to combine are drawn together, then players will have a hard time choosing which cards to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

Its a really hard game to learn since it is all about card combinations but if you see a copy get it for yourself and put some time into learning this superb game. You won't be disappointed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game that relies on symbols, so there is a big learning curve.  Once you learn them however, they appear simple.  Lot's of different strategies to win depending on the luck of the cards you draw vs. phases that do occur each round.  Like many card games your strategy changes based upon the cards you get.  So it's hard to follow the same strategy twice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I played Puerto Rico a total of two times before picking this game up. Having the base of Puerto Rico offered in such a refreshing theme and timely manner was amazing for me (and my gaming group). This is a game that has made it possible for my gaming group to return to Puerto Rico and start playing the game with out the head swirling-headache feeling they complained about in their first go around.

Part of this is because the learning curve on Race is so steep. The iconography is really something to be admired once it can be deciphered. It's elegant gameplay and multiple paths to victory make this game great.

The time in which you can achieve all of this depth in fun (30-45 mins) makes this a must have. We rarely play just one game of this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Hand Management
Simultaneous Action Selection
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Race for the Galaxy would've been a cozy 7 or 8 had the victory conditions not been pants-on-head stupid. But then, it would've had to be called "Galactic Empires" or something. It's a race, sure, but it doesn't exactly feel like a race so at no point during the several games I played of this did I feel any need to hurry.

In engine-builder games, you often want to end it a bit early before things just get swingy and out of control. This serves to make people want to play again as well as stop it from being unbalanced. Unfortunately, RFtG took this overboard and ends the game after it barely starts, at least for 2 players. Pretty much everything about this game lends itself to something with twice as many victory requirements, and even testing with those made it feel tight. So RFtG is less a tight game and more someone walking in on you masturbating at random--no one has fun and you're done way before you finish.

If not for this singular problem, RFtG would be one of the top games in my entire collection. And this is despite the "graphic design" looking like they paid a hobo in sandwiches to scribble in MSpaint. Which is a shame because the art is fi--hahahaha no I'm kidding, the art is dogshit too. Pretty much everything has been run through a disgusting photoshop filter to somehow remove all the color, or worse, change it to all one color. You'll be amazed at how lazy the colored strategy cards were.

I do think Settle-nonmilitary is one of the weakest things in the game, along with Explore's blatant and frankly disgusting lack of support. 

Overall, if you absolutely have to play this game, be open to the idea of your eyes bleeding and needing house rules for any enjoyment. Once you toss out the clearly untested end conditions, you'll find a really comfy tableau-builder waiting for you.

Easily gets an 8 if they ever release a rule anywhere, even on their website, that allows for a long game variant. Instant 10 if they also release an update that fixes the godawful card frames and monocolor art.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
SF
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.95
I'm not a sci-fi fan.
I'm not a card game fan.
I dislike games that are multi-player solitaire....and, hands down, Race for the Galaxy is the gold medal winner for multi-player solitaire.
Yet with those three major strikes against it (for me), RftG is still a very good game! Unlike a card game like Dominion, the theme actually works with the mechanics. And the art! My goodness, the art is beautiful.
So I rate it a 7.95. However, I suspect that if I were either a), a sci-fi fan, or b) a card game fan, my rating would be well past an 8. If I were BOTH a) and b), RftG would almost certainly be a 9 for me!
And, for the record, for those who compare Race for the Galaxy with San Juan and Puerto Rico, I have this to say: you don't play enough of a variety of games! RftG is similar to these two games in only the most general of ways.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fantastic game. After two plays I was hooked solid. I normally don't have a good filler option, since I don't much like the light fare, and the games of the weight I like usually take 2-3 hours (1-10 for extreme cases). This works as a filler, being so short, but also as a main game of a session, as it has plenty of both strategic and tactical thinking. Awesome, and most people I introduced it to were impressed. I believe it will be played many more times. Like RoboRally, it scales perfectly without prolonging the play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
If you play by the 12 card in-play limit, games can be very quick.  Seems to be little point in acquring VP's - instead, it's a rush for the end.  Perhaps that is the intention of the game, hence the name: Race for the Galaxy.  

First time we played (4 player) we didn't see the card in-play limit.  The game ended up being really long, as it took awhile to exhaust all the VP's in the pool.  We really felt like we were developing an empire though.  When we implemented the 12-card limit, everyone was a bit disappointed with how fast the game went.  I guess my group just likes long drawn out development style games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For the sake of brevity, I'll summarize here: Race for the Galaxy is pretty much the perfect game.  It's an unforgiving, thinky, brutal multi-use card game where you're trying to claw an engine together faster than your opponent and ride that engine to victory.  The cards are fantastically designed and well-balanced, and the gameplay leads heavily to trying to understand and take advantage of your opponent's phase calls.  Tons of indirect player interaction, and a good mix of strategy and tactics (though leaning towards tactics, there's definitely both).  Combine this with great art and visual design and a ten-minute playtime and we have a winner.

For plays, counting a combination of BGA, Keldon's, and offline in that order of quantity.  However, each component is still pretty sizeable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

If you play this game alot and have explored the various strategies available. Then you can make good decisions. The learning curve to get there however is long and steep. The base mechanics are fine and good, just a few too many and taken too complex.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
2-4(2,4)

The deck bloat is sort of getting to me. For this type of game, I'm actually gravitating toward San Juan, where you know all the cards and can form a strategy and actually have some expectation of getting the cards needed to execute the strategy.

With Race, not only is the iconography just an added wrench (not a problem for me, personally, but it makes it much tougher to introduce to others) but it's hard to know which cards fit into which strategy and the giant deck can be quite fickle.

I'm not sure how often this will be getting played these days.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Transplant the mechanics of San Juan to a galaxy far far away and give the cards some excellent, sci-fi artwork.  Increase the number of different cards in a similar-sized deck from 29 to 95. Add a touch of complexity; all that variety does come at a price.  The result is a game whose possibilities I'll happily be exploring for quite a while.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Clever action selection game where you can build some nice card combos. Having played Roll for the Galaxy first I think that is easier to understand and more streamlined.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Race for the Galaxy is a very good game that turns into a Masterpiece when you include the expansions and start correctly. (Correct start w/ Expansions: each player dealt 1 red and 1 blue start world + 6 other cards - keep 4 cards and 1 start world).  Without expansions I rate the game ~8.

Nuances (not really negatives): 
 - The game has a steep initial learning curve.
 - Many people take 5 to 10 games to explore and understand the main strategies.
 - With expansions there are a lot of cards to become familiar with (and deal). 
 - Player interaction is predominantly tied to action selection. 

Brilliance: 
 - No other game has as much strategic breadth, meaning that there are so many different ways to win.
 - Plays great with 2 players or a group.
 - Simultaneous player action selection keeps the game intriguing and fast paced.  
 - Balance of strategy (tied to start conditions) and tactics (tied to card drawing).  
 - So much variation that at 100+ games I'm still learning and exploring!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My Runaway Robots are Fembots.

Gameplay is a 10, but it loses a mark or two just because it's a steep ramp up to get there.  My guys are used to Magic cards, which tell you exactly how to play each card.  RTFG is the opposite.  I personally love the iconogaphy, but a lot of people, even pretty hard-core gamers balk a bit.  The cards are nice with great artwork.

RATING: 7
I picked this up (along with the expansion) in my quest to find a decent solo game that didn't take a ton of time to play or set up.

I find I go through phases with this game.  It'll be really hot for a while and I'll play it almost daily.  And there are times where it will sit weeks/months at a time without being touched.  

I've only played one game with another player (my wife - she was pretty lukewarm about it), so I can't speak too much about the multiplayer aspect of it.  I have played the PC version (by Keldon) quite a bit and have about a 50/50 win ratio vs the AI.  That's pretty fun, but I'd wager it's quite different than human opponents.

Overall, I think this one will be with me for quite a while.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
First, I do understand the icons, and have played probably 30-40 games.  This is definitely a solitare game, though I like the goals as they make you more aware of the other players (though you can ignore the goals and still win sometimes), not interacive mind you, just aware that there are others playing.  Action selection has the only interaction and it isn't that important most of the time.  also, you can look to make sure your opponent doesn't have the card you need already in his area.  
The luck of the draw wins for players of the same expeirence.  This ramdonmess can make long term strategy detremental.  Funny, the randomness in San Juan and St. Petersburg add tension... here they just frustrate because there are times when you need certain cards, or resources and they just don't come.
I do think it's fun in small though and like building the engine.

Iconography is ridiculously hard to understand at first.  Now that I have it down, the game isn't that impressive.
also, it is very easy to forget to do things in this game which will lead to losses.  That is, too much to keep track of and it's not really compartmentalized, your tableu is just a giant blob of icons.

RATING: 10

6/23/11 - Played my first game with the actual cards and it was pretty rough. I'm glad I played San Juan a lot before RftG, because I would have been completely lost. 7/8/11 - We're really getting the hang of this now and I kinda wish I didn't trade it away. This is becoming a lot of fun! Bumped up to a 9.

12/25/11 - Christmas 2011. HB

1/8/12 - Tried the two player advance game for the first time after playing the regular way for over 88 games. It makes the two player game so much better IMO, and I can't see playing the game without using the two player advance rules anymore.

RATING: 8.5
16/8/2011
Pros: 
- Very quick game
- Variety in the way it plays
- Good depth of strategy despite the fact that the decisions you make are mostly tactical.

Cons: 
- A little overpriced for the components you get (mostly cards which are very cheap), but ok otherwise.
- Very little player interaction.

Summary: A quick, balanced and deep game. What's not to like?

Update 4/8/2012
After playing many games with keldon's AI, things look a little one sided. Production/consume is more powerful without the expansions than other strats. 
Lowering Grade to 8. I still rate it a 9 with Gathering Storm.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Brilliant design.

It's not really unique, for it borrows most of the concepts from Puerto Rico/San Juan. But, IMO, it's the best of the three in terms of creating an experience with more options and paths to victory. 

The theme is sort of glued with bubble gum on this one, but it doesn't matter that much given the sort of experience it provides to the players in terms of strategy, options to piggyback on what your opponents are doing and the huge variety of cards provided by the expansions. This is one of those games in which the expansions really add a lot to the experience without bringing unnecessary complexity.

The only problem with this game when compared to San Juan or PR is that it's not easy for a newbie to absorb all the icons and what they mean for the gameplay. 
Because of this, this one definetly has a steeper learning curve than that of its other cousins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Lots of subtle decisions, yet there is never lots of AP and the large screw-factor like in Puerto Rico.  I still love PR, but I would rather get in 3 games of Race than one game of PR.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Okay, so it has a lot of symbols, but they are well done, so that doesn't cause confusion.  Fast-paced role-selector with a theme that fits.  At first it doesn't feel as interactive with the other players, but then you realize that's where your tactics are flawed.  You need to use the other players' role selections to your fullest advantage.

That said, I think later games have done this better, and are easier to teach or more complete in the base set.

RATING: 10
Talk about a card game, wow.  Race for the Galaxy is amazing.  In the age of deck building economy games trumping all (Dominion), this game shines as a counter example of true brilliance.  It is like San Jaun, only better.  The game is mad with a "build your own economy" theme and loads up on the quirky strategy.  The art and cards will easily make you a fan boy/girl too, they are goofy and inspiring.  The one problem: mind numbingly hard to learn, really.  The symbols on the cards could not be more confusing, however once you 'get it', things start to go smoother.  Warning: this may take three or more games, don't give up!  It is worth it.  Lucky for me, the amazing card art and story kept me plugging away at it till I learned.  Complex goodness it has.  It really does feel like a race to seize this lovable galaxy in 30 mins or less.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My initial thoughts were that this is a very well thought out engine-building game with beautiful cards, but more or less multiplayer solitaire.

It took me six games just to start appreciating the possibilities the phase selection has for player interaction, and to get a glimpse on different possible strategies.

As an example, take two 2-player games with my GF:

In the first game, I started with New Sparta (military world), and tried out a card-acquiring strategy (that is, get as many cards into my hands as quickly as possible, then see what I can do with them). I got an alien world pretty early (=goods I can exchange into many cards), and went with a military strategy that scored my 40 points and a clear victory.

In the second game, I started with Old Earth, which made it more interesting for me to produce and consume goods for VPs. However, I had some cheap but nice developments on hand that I hoped would help me later in the game (they gave me extra cards in development phases). As it turned out, I didn't play a single development after that, so those cards were wasted. Still, I had a good time settling worlds, and got a nice little production-consumption engine running. I ended the game by using up the VP chips, and ended up with 46 VPs, 6 more than in my previous military-oriented game. As it turned out, my GF, with a mixed military-production strategy got to 49 VPs!

One thing I noticed is that I had to select "Production" twice, to produce goods on windfall worlds. My GF with production worlds profited from that.
Another thing was that I used up goods for cards (lots of cards at least, but still), while my GF went "Consume 2x VPs" pretty early. I also would "Settle" very often (had a +2 on non-military worlds development), and my GF used those phases to settle cheap production or military worlds. Using the other player's phases really can make a difference between winning and losing!

In summary:

PROS:
+) Nice, colorful and well-illustrated cards
+) A symbol system that takes some getting used to, but once you know it, you know at a glance what a card will do for you
+) A good engine-building game, with a feeling of growth and achievement
+) Different strategies can yield good results
+) Subtle player interactions, that can still make a difference
+) The fact that cards can be used in two ways (as the card itself, and as generic "money") strongly reduces the problem of "card luck" - every card you draw is valuable, even if only to pay for other cards.

CONS:
-) No direct interaction between players, which turns off a lot of my friends
-) Only up to 4 players (but there are expansions...)
-) Some card luck is involved, especially whether you draw a good 6-point development that fits your tableau and yields you lots of VPs (that alone can make the difference between winning and losing in a tight game).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The game itself is very fun and very similar to San Juan with just FAAAAAR more options. The art on the cards is just breathtaking and the theme does actually flow into the game nicely.

RATING: 6
i think the basics, as reported all over the place, are sure to be at least close to correct.  similar to san juan, simultaneous, engine building, optimization, hand management, etc.  the art is pleasant but undistinctive, and i have difficulty quickly discerning what is on my opponents' boards.  i don't find the lack of interaction to be a problem at all, and i think player targeting via expansions sounds like a bad idea because it could force more board-reading and slow down the game.  i think the game has a ton going for it, but i'm still vexed at the obtuse iconography.  the worst part is going from learning curve to pat hand curve, though, as our group seems to have done.  some are easy to play, others hard.  it's all good for learning, and i have little doubt that expertise can fade it, but i'm still waiting for the part where we all get to sit down and play what i consider to be a fair game and it's frustrating to be teased with the idea of certain situations being tenable when it's entirely possible that they're not.  it makes me want to give san juan another shot.

RATING: 9.5
I struggled a little bit trying to come up with a score for this game. On the one hand, I often find myself incredibly frustrated by how random it can feel. Games can swing wildly from one turn to the next depending on what's drawn. On the other hand, as I've played more I've found that the random element seems to be favoring me more and more, which tells me there's more to it than "whoops, I drew the right 6-cost development! I win!"

Over the course of the week at WBC 2009, I went from not being particularly interested in the game to wanting to play it as much as I could. I wound up playing in the tournament and made the semifinals, winning three of my games in the qualifying heats and taking second in the fourth.

Short enough to squeeze in those times when we needed to kill some time waiting for someone's event to finish, but long enough to feel worthwhile (I'm looking at you, For Sale), I'm going to make sure to have this one handy whenever I travel with gaming friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The more I play, the better I like it.  It will take a few plays to get an understanding of the various card combinations that can be created / used.  There is quite a bit of luck in the card draws, but it is possible to create your own luck by holding onto specific cards at the right time.  Doing this in combination with knowing the possible strategies that can be followed is a key to the game.  A solid game that will likely get better with expansions.

RATING: 9
The best thing about Race for the Galaxy is playing the best you can and then looking back over your tableau and figuring out the story of your empire - a tale of minor conquest to fuel the consumptive demands of swelling populations, or an imperialistic world gradually quelling increasingly unruly and powerful rebels and aliens, or a scientific and commercial society that implemented a variety of developments to excel in all aspects of society.

Additionally, this is the better Puerto Rico, using simultaneous action selection and a deck of cards to get out of PR's practically solved game opening while keeping the role selection vibe strong. I still don't own this personally, but I'm always looking for a good deal on the whole set with expansions. I frequently play against Keldon AI, but I never count online games here!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Revised Review (as of 2015): The systems and design still sparkle, but the base game is just too thin, especially with four players. The expansions add many systems that help mitigate luck and therefore fully flesh out the game and help it achieve the high scores that belie its reputation.


Original Review: A entertaining and tight game with the base set, or a sprawling and brain melting civ-builder with the full set of 1st cycle expansions. Deep game and one that is never not rewarding, especially given how quickly it plays. Brilliant.

RATING: 8.5
A great game, if a bit counter-intuitive. I guess it just needs to be played a couple more times before learning all the different cards (and their interaction), but so far it feels good.

UPDATE: It's a great game that plays in a very short time. It's also great with 2 (I haven't played with more yet). The only downside is it's steep learning curve. It's definitely not a game for casual gamers, and even for gamers it can be a little bit frustrating at times, while learning. That's the only reason why this game is not a perfect 10 for me, and it's very likely to remain a 9 for a long, long time.

UPDATE: I still love it, but finding people to play it with is becoming tougher. There simply is no way to work around those hideous icons. Down to an 8.

UPDATE: A real classic. After all these years, I still want to play it almost all the time. Up a notch, to 8.5.

RATING: 5
My thoughts are the same for Roll for the Galaxy: I struggled with it.

The second was the lack of player interaction, which meant it was difficult to pick up by watching what someone else was doing, because you're all puzzling with your own set of cards, which have no influence on the cards of other players, which in any case you can't read from across the table.

RATING: 10
Players select a phase.  For the chosen phases all players performs action, with the selecting player getting a bonus.  A close cousin of San Juan.  Tactics and strategy.  I look forward to further plays.  Only quibble is the tiny writing on the cards which are also very dark.  Surprisingly (to me!) this has now overtaken Agricola as what I consider the most impressive game of 2007.

Games including TGS & RvI included under RvI title.

RATING: 10
Disclaimer -- I playtested this. One of my favorite games of all time, 100 plays and counting. Its simplistic to call this "Super San Juan in Space" (although I've done it). The changes (simultaneous role selection, almost all unique cards, consumption/shipping, and 'big' buildings with powers as well as variable VP) make a highly replayable game. (And I've played San Juan plenty). The # of decisions per unit time are huge. See my review for more details. 

Rating -- Enthusiastic

RATING: 10
Apparantly, there are expansions that will enable the game to handle 6 players.

Jan-21-2008
I have now played this game 27 times.  20 of those are played only with my wife.  My wife likes the game a lot and so do I.  It was rocky at first as she felt overwhelmed with all the different cards and icons.  It took her 3 games to understand the game.  The biggest hurdle was consume/trade phase.  I like this game because it is so fast for the depth.  That's another reason we played it 20 times already.  We can play it in less than 20 minutes.  Most of the time I am the one slowing her down.  The game is feeling stale because of the limited start worlds.  It is just all in my head though since the start hand really dictates what you'll be doing in the game and that is never the same.  I can't wait for the expansions.  I also wish that someone could come up with a good variant to make any card a start world with the proper price.
Rating: 8

Feb-10-2008
Ok.  I really like this game, especially with our variable starting world variant. This let's you have general plan on what you are going to do since you have more options.  You get to decide what world to play depending on what you have drawn. 

[u]Variable Start World Variant[/u]
--> Draw 7 cards.
--> Settle a world at cost. (Defense = cost)
--> +1 cost for blue windfall
--> +2 cost for brown windfall
--> +3 cost for green windfall
--> +4 cost for yellow windfall
--> +1 cost for Military world of 3+
--> May mulligan but draw 1 less card than prior.  
--> If no production or windfall world, one can mulligan with no penalty.
I can't get enough of this game.
Rating: 8 -> 9

Mar-09-2008
After 80 games and still loving it.  I would play this game over Puerto Rico any day. There is no left/right player binding in this game, which I like a lot.  I don't have this feeling of undeserved wins just because I was to the right or left of the newbie.  This game will remind you of Magic of the Gathering but without the collectable part of it.  You play cards to gain benefits which lends you to do certain strategies but at the same time doesn't feel constricted.  The setup time is virtually zero.  Upgrading to 10!
Rating: 9 -> 10

Aug-01-08
I still love this game.  We reverted back to using the original start worlds, especially that the start worlds for the expansion is out.  We printed them out and using them in our games.
Rating: 10 -> 10

RATING: 7
- revised -
I had a chance to play this a few more times.  My opinion of it is getting better, its possible my negative view is mostly because of the group that I played with.
- revised -

I feel like I need to explain my rank for this game as its so far from the normal.  I was super excited for this game, and even after the first couple of plays I felt like there was a lot of potential.  Then I played it with a new game group recently and realized the ugly truth.  The other players had obviously played the game many MANY times and had thus laid out plans for exactly what they would do.  Each phase blew by like a tornado with everyone slapping down cards and throwing resources around at such speed and solidarity that I realized I could have snuck away from the table and neither the outcome of the game nor the players would have even notice my departure. It is group solitaire.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very good combination of quick play and decision-making. Each hand presents a number of choices as you attempt to fit them into your selected strategy. Roll for the Galaxy is more accessible, but Race feels more strategic. The base game of RftG provides a highly solitaire experience, with one exception. If you smartly select actions to leech off your opponent's actions, you can increase your action efficiency. There's probably an optimal mix of expansions that would make this game better for me, but I doubt I'll find out what it is.

*** Edit, July 2017: The more I play Race, the more I'd rather play Roll. 

*** Edit, Sept 2017: The different dice pool produced in each game of Roll is the key to why I prefer Roll over Race. In Roll, each play feels somewhat different since I collect a different set of dice in addition to the different tableau. In Race, I feel like I'm making the same decisions each game for only a marginally different tableau. The app will get played on planes as a quick time waster, but that's about the only role Race will have moving forward. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Reviewed.  Hits a very sweet spot, where there's a lot of variability that keeps the game fresh, but there are ample rewards for skillful play.  Wonderful.

RATING: 10
San Juan in space! San Juan is a good game but not a favorite, this one I enjoy more purely because of the theme. It feels like a race to pick one strategy and proceed as efficiently as possible, attempting to predict and use to your advantage other player's choices, before the game ends.

Update: Personally I feel this is a better game than San Juan and with slightly less luck involved, as there are more ways of winning here while San Juan you must obtain a 6 cost building or two.

2d Update: Ok, this is much better than SJ! It requires significant skill to play well, and strategic flexibility. If you do not watch what your opponent is doing you will lose.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[i]Posted: 10/23/12, Rated: 8[/i]

[i]Race for the Galaxy[/i] shares the same progenitor in [i][thing=3076][/thing][/i] as [i][thing=8217][/thing][/i].  The two are often discussed in the same breath, which is sometimes accompanied by a mention of [i][thing=19857][/thing][/i].  All of them are great games, and they do feel similar.

[i]RFTG[/i] is the only one with the futuristic theme.  Its art quality and point limitation (a feature from [i][thing=3076][/thing][/i] that is missing from [i][thing=8217][/thing][/i]) set it apart from the other two titles.  It has a rich iconography to describe card abilities, which translates to a learning curve.  If you're not playing this game with any real frequency, then you will have to re-familiarize yourself with these symbols.  This information also serves as a learning barrier to new players; -1 point.

Each turn, players choose the role that they want to play.  [i]RFTG[/i] differentiates itself in this phase as well.  In Puerto Rico, only one player can choose a role placard and utilize its special benefit each round.  In [i]RFTG[/i], players may end up choosing the same role.  This key point means that you are not saddles with a "least worst" decision if the role you really wanted had already been taken.

[i]Race for the Galaxy[/i] thus contains many of the similar mechanics, but ends up feeling like its own game.  I do appreciate the theme, but I believe the streamlined, more approachable nature of [i][thing=8217][/thing][/i] gives that title the edge.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Update: Down to a 9; I burnt out on the base game and wasn't really feeling the expansions.

----------

This is as close to a perfect game as I've experienced:

1) Depth to length ratio is amazing!
2) Scales perfectly from 2-5 players (w/ Storm)
3) Can play 2-3 games of this in the time it takes to play 1 game of most other Euros
4) Several paths to victory, all of them viable
5) Very high replayability 

150+ plays and counting!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Whoooo. Yep, that learning curve thing.  It took me three tries at 3-4 player solo plays to finally get the hang of how to think about this game, and the downloaded player aids helped a lot. I finally managed to get this onto the game table with a 4-player group, and 1 of the other 3 appears to have gotten the basic principles, with a lot of blank stares and lost looks from the other two. But it was worth it - having to walk through a full game really cemented my understanding of what's going on with this game. Now, gotta get this out a few more times so the addiction can take hold. I'm especially trying to use this as a wedge with the Dominion crowd to give them some variety.

RATING: 4
Yet another card game where the luck either falls in your lap or it doesn't. My cards allowed me to settle military cards each round and a special card gave me a generous bonus for rebel bases at game end. I saw no applied skill in my options and after playing like a one trick pony, won by one point.

A soulless experience that just confirms that the majority of players who rave about games such as this really can't differentiate between luck and skill. I can extract no enjoyment from games with card engines that dictate the success of a player beyond their decisions.

I thought I'd dislike this game and I was only proved wrong in terms of the magnitude of how much I hated it.

[thread=766852][/thread]

:chalice:2nd Most Played Game of 2011 (31x)

{BK:HK:tie::20:11:1}
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Peli ei ole vähäisestä pelimäärästä johtuen imaissut mukaansa, ja harvakseltaan pelattuna pelin "perusteetkin" ovat hieman hukassa. Tästä syystä peliä en kovin mielelläni pelaa, joten tästä heikohko arvosana. Pelkästään pelinä se ansaitsee toki selvästi paremman arvosanan, sillä ymmärrän kyllä pelin hienouden, vaikken siitä tällä haavaa innostukaan. (17.3.2009)

Päivitetääns vähä arvosanaa. Painetaan 8 tähän väliin. Tietokoneversiota pelistä tullu ny jonku verran jauhettua, joten kortit ja peruspeli on jo tutumpaa. Ja muutama peli livenäkin, tuli vedettyä. On se kyllä hyvä. Jätetään kuitenkin vielä varaa parantaa. (4.10.2009)

Noni 9 sitte. Toistakymmentä peliä takana, plus varmaan joku 50-100 peliä tiettaria vastaan. On kyllä huippu peli. Jätetään viä vähä parantamisen varaa, eiks joo. (5.11.2009)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
[b]Luck:[/b] While the luck of the draw definitely exists a good player can usually shift their strategy to adapt. Even so a series of bad draws can cost any player the game.

[b]Strategy/Tactics:[/b] Without some kind of strategy you will usually loose the game. As an engine building game strategy and knowing when to shift strategies is crucial to the game. Furthermore to be a good player it is also crucial to learn to read your opponents plays and use their decisions during the game to best benefit you.

[b]Weight:[/b] RftG can be played quickly but has many meaningful decisions which can swing the game either for or against your favour.

[b]Fun:[/b] An engine building game with a lot of flavour and a little bit of chaos. Great fun for anyone who enjoys long term strategy mixed with some luck of the draw.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] So far everyone i have taught this too has loved it. It's a meaty game which can double as a great filler. It also scales well with any number of players. Recommended for anyone who loves card games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The game shares some similarities with Glory to Rome (Using cards for different purposes, sharing a deck from where all the players draw from, role-selection...) the feel is very different. For example, while both games feature role selection, each one does it in its own way. Another example is the buildings in GtR VS the planets & developments in RftG, all three are different and unique.

Once you get past the stage where the symbols make no sense (1-2 plays) they are actually very informative and I like them much better than text.

About what I've read of this game being multiplayer solitary... yes, to an extent. Any game that features action selection where everyone gets to do every action, has an intrinsic amount of interaction in that you must read your opponents in order to use their actions to your advantage. You can play without paying attention to their needs, sure, but your winning chances will diminish greatly.

Haven't really played since I got Seasons and I'm not missing it, so the rating is slowly going down
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Confusing as f*ck all at first, but then settles down. [-]So far enjoying this. But I'm predicting my rating will go down. I'm not pulling Race out as a main course for game night, because that doesn't seem to be its niche for me. Instead, I'm really enjoying the primetime burning of my brain on OTHER new games first, and then pulling out Race for a couple games to cap off the night. This to me seems like the natural place for this game, and its really working for me in this way. RATING: 8
Conditional rating after 8 plays -- I believe it will take at least 30 plays before I know for sure. Happily, those 30 plays will be enjoyable. I am a huge fan of San Juan, and this game is similar enough to warrant a nod. They are *not* the same game, though. SJ is quicker, and probably easier to learn, while Race is a tad longer to play and with it's larger card pool has a much deeper learning curve (both are easy to learn how to play, SJ will likely be somewhat easier to learn how to play well).Components are nice, though for me the VP chips are perfectly extraneous (I always use poker chips for, well, everything). Some have complained that the black card backs become scuffed at the edges, so I'll be sleeving my cards before their first play.Like SJ, Race is elegantly interactive. It's a card game so there's luck, but also like SJ, the skill comes in minimizing the effects of luck over time. The game is short enough to play several times in an evening, and eventual, the skillful players will start winning more.Race is an 8 now. Might go to 9. 10 only if it turns out to be significantly deeper than SJ (which might not be possible)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
1068
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
The first time I played this game I hated it. I thought that the game was a confusing dumpster fire. I had no interest in learning the nuances of it because there didn't appear to be much game there, mainly just memorizing what cards were good and pitching the crappy ones... man, I hate being wrong.

This is actually a pretty simple but fun, tableau building game, filled to the teeth with iconography to confuse you into thinking the game is difficult. It's player aids are the size of place mats as if the game was trying to intimidate you with daunting size alone.

Each turn you choose one(two in a two player game) of seven actions. Based on the actions chosen you then draw/play/trade for that round, then go back and select more action cards. Rinse and repeat until either all the VP pool is gone, or one player has put 12+ cards into their tableau. Most VPs win.

The more you play, the more you realize how the cards work together to score victory points. One time you can develop an entire alien galaxy, scoring points on yellow card after yellow card. The next you delve into military, colonizing your galaxy through military strength and oppression. But the real skill to the game comes in when you have to change gears. Perhaps you were planning on making an galaxy based on trade, when suddenly you grab a card that could possibly turn your galaxy into a vp production machine, cranking out goods to be churned straight to VPs. Do you make the switch, or stay on course? Yes, luck in drawing good cards is involved, but knowing what you are doing can mitigate some of it. (I should note, I removed the card that scores 1VP per development from my game. Every play we had, whoever had that card won 95% of the time. It didn't matter what you were building to, you switched to that and cruised to victory. Since removing it, the games have become quite balanced.)

My first play of this game was with four players and this game simply does not shine with four players. I'll reluctantly play three players, but it just feels kinda average. At two players, this game is juggernaut of awesome. Having two actions really makes you think about what the other person is going to play, and what you can mooch off of them. With only one other tableau to look at, you can figure that out in a quicker amount of time. It's also less players to wait on for decisions to be made and really an all around quicker game. It's quite fun to burn through a night with the base game having each person play each start world once.

Bottom-line: Excellent two player game that pretends to play more players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

However, about the time I had all this in place the game would end! There is a reason it is called *Race* for the Galaxy. Now that I have changed my thinking and view it as more of a light/fast game instead of a 4X game I find I play much better.

I'd be interested to try the expansions at some point.

RATING: 7
Race to the Galaxy is a fast and addicting card game: sadly though it is quite difficult to understand and, even after several plays, most of the symbols on the cards still are a challenge to work out. This way, one doesn’t even mind the beautiful drawings and the themed names on the cards themselves but turns his whole attention just to the gains each card assures, thus overlooking and forgetting its nice science-fiction setting details.
Race for the Galaxy would greatly benefit a new edition with simpler and clearer symbols. (October 2011)

[b]Update[/b] - After including all the expansions in my games I found Race for the Galaxy has grown into an unmanageable behemoth that doesn’t deserve an 8: not only can’t I see any need for expansions, as the original game on its own is more than enough, but I also think the original game plays much better without them, as they add too many useless layers of difficulty that take away all the fun.

This is especially true for The Brink of War, as it’s way too fiddly and makes the game way too complex.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
My rating may look a bit harsh but this is only for the two-player game.  I have yet to try it with more but I want to, and expect it will be better.

I didn't have as much difficulty with the iconography as I expected from reading about it in advance.  The game was taught to me very well and by the end of the first game I didn't have any problems.

There's a tonne of comments about how the game is super-balanced and there are many different equally-viable strategies.  I'm not sure I want a [i]strategic[/i] card game that is so short.  In this game, it means everyone selects an apparently equally-viable strategy at the beginning, then the winner is the player who successfully draws the cards that fit the strategy he already began.

The game can end abruptly, and in a rout. Seems many people here don't mind that ("Just play again!") but that leaves a sour taste in my mouth (whether as winner or loser). I want a more consistently-excellent experience, and San Juan offers this.

This game is neat, but San Juan is a better-developed game in my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
A perfectly balanced, fast, deep game. There are few games this accessible and finely-tuned. Very steep rules/icon learning curve though, but by game 10 you'll be hooked.

RATING: 8
It took me a few online plays then a physical game to really grasp what was going on.  I think I'll really like this game after a few more plays.  The problem is if I were to purchase this, I think I'd have a hard time getting others who haven't played it before up to speed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
For awhile I thought Dominion had ousted this game as my group had somewhat retired RftG.  With Dominion's moon waning, we pulled this out again.  RftG is a clearly superior game (and also obsoletes San Juan if that wasn't already apparent).

I think the main draw is the variability here.  You have a more diverse set of strategies than Dominion, but you are always constrained by what you actually manage to draw.  Managing your hand is far more interesting than the rote draw and play of Dominion.  Picking a role adds a lot more player interaction than you might expect and I hear the expansions ratchet this up even more.  However, both games do suffer a little from a solitary feeling at times.

Now this also means that there is probably a tadmore luck in RftG than Dominion and things wont always pan out for you, but the game is pretty short and it's a small price to pay for a more replayable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This has immediately become a favorite game of my gaming group.  It takes the basic mechanics of San Juan and adds so much more, especially in terms of replayability.  A multitude of strategies are possible, and usually necessary, to get a victory.  Can't wait to get the expansions.

Looks like San Juan can be traded away now...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is rated 10 with all expansions included.  It is one of the most brilliant, engrossing games I have played and raises the limits of what is capable in a card game.  Every time I play, I think up a story to go along with my alien race as they explore the galaxy.  My favorite card is the Imperium Planet Buster.  I will almost always choose an economic production strategy over a military one.  My high score is 87 points.

Notes:
-One of the hardest strategies is uplift.  It is very hard to utilize the uplift cards to score any significant points.  Should switch to military alien is last part of game to advance.
-A peace strategy is difficult, needs heavy production.  It is probably worth looking into this for any exploits with a prestige strategy.
-Military is somewhat overpowered when combined with takeovers.

RATING: 7
Not a good fit at all. one play with my wife and i can see what all the fuss is about but, this will never see the table with my family.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In general I prefer the +1/2hr game length to the -1/2hr length because a game usually needs that much time to have all three of depth, excitement, and replayability. A strategy game lacking in any of those three categories is a bad sign for me. When I first played Race for the Galaxy I saw a ton of both replayability and excitement. I thought meh, decent game but the randomness of the card would get in the way of the depth and strategy. I was wrong. Woops. There is tons of strategy and depth and while the luck of the cards can sometimes get in your way, both the replayability and excitement factors are through the roof making this game top notch stuff. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game of expanding your galactic empire by spending cards to develop and settle. It has an interesting mechanic of cards acting as both something you want to play and as a resource to spend on playing cards. The other interesting mechanic is that you pick an action to perform, but all players get to do that same action, so there's strategy depending on what other players are doing. 

There are a lot of symbols on cards which can make it initially confusing. 

You can also look at Roll for the Galaxy which is a re-implementation with dice. It's simpler to play and easier to learn and teach. Arguably Race for the Galaxy has more strategy. 

Short tutorial video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WeUw0v8Y-gQ

Tutorial video with gameplay: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ziP9liFiKGo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
Low low low player interaction complete with lucky card drawing can automate this game so much that it seems pointless...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Quite a fun game with some interesting ideas. Gets better with a few expansions thrown in. People criticize the lack of player interaction but there's something nice about just doing "your own thing" since it's still a lot of fun during the actual playtime even if you lose. Would recommend purchasing protective sleeves for the cards to protect your investment!

RATING: 8.6

RATING: 9
This is one of the strongest themed games I've ever played. Tom Lehmann has developed a parametric system for describing science fiction, and used his system to describe the canon of science fiction. Every card is a joy to appreciate and play. The game play is solid as well. Games play quickly with very little downtime, typically 15-30 minutes. The rules are simple and easy to understand, explain, and remember. Nearly all of the exceptions and idiosyncrasies are represented in the cards, so you don't need to keep checking the rules. My opinion of this game has increased over time.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My husband wanted to buy this after our first play, while I was ambivalent. It's not a bad game, but very much "San Juan in Space." The main mechanism I don't like about San Juan is repeated here: Cards do multitasking duty (currency, goods, and in-play worlds/technologies), which reduces the importance of what cards to keep/discard and makes it feel less strategic, especially at the beginning. The use of simultaneous action choice is interesting, but means that several people can choose the same action, so there are rounds where everyone explores, or everyone settles (which increases the feeling of multiplayer solitaire, though that's not necessarily a turn-off). After a few more plays, though, it has grown on me. Overall I do like it more than San Juan. I appreciate the "it's not just card-based Puerto Rico" theme more, and the cards and choices definitely feel more varied than San Juan. I won't turn down a play at this point, and I might even suggest it, including as a 2-player game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Played this game a few times now and its San Juan / PR roots are very evident. It's one of those games that is best learnt by playing a few rounds then starting again for real. Our game sped up considerably as we went along. 

Numerous options to attempt to specialise in and numerous ways to gain VP's. First card based game I have played. However, like most card games, if your card draws are bad, you won't win.

I just can't get used to this, somehow it seems too random. You can have a strategy and that's all good, but then when you never see another card to help you along your path, then you're finished. My rating for this game is dropping with each play!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
If I'm going to rate a game an 8, generally it has to have a strong theme. While RftG's theme suits the mechanics well enough, it does bleed off from gameplay pretty quickly into the game. That said, the mechanics are fantastic, so good that I have to rate this game as near perfect. Nothing is out of place and there are several different points of tension on which one is focused at once. The play of the game is, dare I say, elegant. There is strategy and there are tactics. It may be multi-player solitaire, but it also is a "race" and role selection can allow you to attempt to freeze out your opponent, forcing them to take two turns what they could have done in one if you hadn't been clever. I'm having lots of fun exploring this game and all its strategies, so much so that I have chosen not to read any of BGG's strategy articles because the discovery process is so much fun. What a well developed, polished system this is.

Update: I cannot rate this anything less than a 9. It's just so deep. I am starting to see how people can play this 100's of times; the game is about exploring space, but it becomes about exploring the game...as my students say, "So meta." Additionally, I taught my wife to play in under thirty minutes and she beat me by the second game (making her a convert). Granted, she knew Puerto Rico, but it was nowhere near as difficult to teach as I had heard. It is now the deepest, most rewarding game she will play with me, so I have to acknowledge what this game offers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
It takes several plays before the game starts making sense, but even after it makes sense you still feel like you are playing a solitaire game.  Dominion has a solitaire-feel as well, however I actually pay attention to the decks others are building in Dominion and react accordingly.  This, not so much.

I know San Juan is the lighter game, but the role choice in San Juan is more significant in helping or hurting other people directly.  That means San Juan requires you to think more about your opponent's needs. 

Once you get used to the cards there is quite a bit of depth and the more I play the more I want to play.  This game is ultimately better than San Juan and increases in rankings the more I play.
