=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is quite honestly the best single purchase game I have ever played.  The strategy, while subtle at first glance, is quite deep.  This game is full of tough decisions at every corner, and single misplays can derail a winning plan.

It creates tense, interesting games.

Also, it is the game that to me most scratches the "Magic" itch (for those of us familiar with that CCG).  Although the mechanics are entirely different, the decisions still remind me of Magic limited games.  Do I play this small development to keep up on tempo, or do I save for my (potentially) game-winning bomb?  Is it worth it to blow all my resources on this one card, or do I need to slowroll it and hold back?  Is my opponent going to win the long game, and if so, how can I end this the quickest while still not giving too much ground?

These are all fun situations, and really tough decisions.  That's why this is the best game I have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Only played twice. It's not getting the play time it deserves. :) Excellent condition and all components accounted for.

RATING: 9.8

Once you do get it though, it's pretty easy to strategize after a few plays, which is unfortunate. When I play the game, I'm very aware of the cards in the game and what strategy I should take based on the cards I've played. What makes this interesting is of course, deciding which cards to play and how that changes your game. While this is a great game, it's a game where I feel like I will need to get expansions for it fast.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Quasi-collectible (watch for endless expansions) tableau-building card game similar in some ways to San Juan, but as one reviewer put it "on steroids!" Takes some getting used to and will have a moderate learning curve; but, as a filler, (can play out in less than an hour) for gamers still wanting a little meat in their session, this looks like a perfect choice. Pity that it only plays with four (so far)...

The expansion extends this game to five players which is a good thing but one wonders why it wasn't published that way from the start. Wait, what am I saying (just re-read my first sentence)?
++++++
My problem was that I tried to introduce this potential "filler" as a filler after already having played our main game. As a result, brains were already partly fried before we began. Their eyes quickly glazed over and I've had trouble getting this back on the table ever since. They still laugh whenever they see the boxes. It is a brilliant game and I've regretted my gaffe ever since - but I am still going to try to engage my group with this awesome game!

The expansions have been interesting but somewhat uneven - mind you I'm still working on getting acceptance for the base game...

RATING: 10
I like this one so much more than San Juan, it's early days and the shine might come off but the things I like:1. Action cards - this element adds interaction, do you pick the phase you need or try to work out if your opponent will pick it so you can choose another.2. Multiple '6' cards leading to different paths to victory3. Multiple routes to victory (planets, military, trading, etc)4. Fast play (games typically run 20 minutes tops)What I didn't like was the icons, more text would have been better - and white text would have shown up better on the cards. Icons are fine once you are familar with the game, but it adds a bit to the learning curve, and the references sheets are really daunting to new players *** Updated, playing this more and more - really enjoy it, short play time helps. Yes you can play it multiplayer solo, but you miss an element of the game, looking at your opponents layouts can help to predict what they're going to do, and also there's no point in searching (Explore 5 ) for stuff that your opponents already have in play. Can't wait for the expansions! Want a 2nd copy as mine will wear out.

*** Update, not as impressed with the expansions as I'd hoped, but base game is great

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
This game in 10 years will probably be a classic.  It is like San Juan for space.  

The cards are fun to look at and they are of good quality.  I think that there should be tuck boxes provided with any card game where the cards are central to game play.  

You need to play it 2-3 times to finally flow with the cards.  The intricacies of this game make it complex to truly dominate and develop. The game has phases.  The players opt to initiate various phases which then allow the to settle a planet,develop it, and other things.  They continue to grow point values that multiply on the various additions or when your get multiples of a particular type of planet that you are building or settling.

It is popular so you will most likely get to play it often.

RATING: 6.5
Recently downgraded to 6.5 after a few plays with expansion(s).  I appreciate the variety the new cards bring to the game and the way the bonus cards help you focus on some strategy.  But, after several plays, the game feels more and more like a cluttered, mechanical mess.  With so many cards in hand and tableau, I rarely check to see what other players are doing for fear of not optimizing my own cards.  Thus, I feel caught in a solitaire bubble which pops only when the end game conditions are reached.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Oh what could have been.  I love the theme.  I love the art.  The iconography is not a problem.  The underlying game mechanics are not a problem.  Despite all this potential RftG comes up short.  When I first tried it I was engrossed and wanted more.  I thought about it constantly trying to come up with new strategies.  But as the newness wore off, the cards became familiar and the game's shortcomings became obvious.  My opinion of the game soured to the point of resentment.

After 30+ plays I've concluded that RftG is just a filler.  The complete lack of direct player interaction makes the game soulless.  It feels like you're in a solo race vs the deck to make a better "empire" than your opponent before someone hits 12 cards.  There are some interesting poker style elements where you might be able to guess which roles your opponents choose and therefore "piggyback" on their moves.  But in the end a small amount of groupthink is a poor substitution for direct interaction.  You can't trade resources.  You can't collude with the other players to reign in a runaway leader.  You can't manipulate market of political forces to better your position.  Hell even if you build your empire to be a military powerhouse you can't attack the other empires.  Very unsatisfying.

I hear that the expansions might increase the level of player interaction.  I hope so.  I was so let down by RftG.   It could have been great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
 * K,  EKONOMICZNA, STRATEGICZNA
Karcianka

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
Es un juego de cartas de construcción de un imperio galáctico. Me ha recordado mucho al San Juan, pero tiene detalles que le superan, por ejemplo, el hecho de poder ir "recolectando" puntos durante el juego. 

Me ha parecido un juegazo en toda regla. Es de selección de roles. Todos los jugadores escogen rol y lo desvelan al tiempo. Éstos se van ejecutando (por todos) según un orden concreto. El jugador que escogió el rol, además tiene alguna ventaja o bonús.

Además, las cartas que se van "construyendo" van modificando los bonus y el comportamiento de los roles. 

La única pega que le veo es que hay poca interacción con otros jugadores. La interacción es "indirecta"... el jugador tiene que valorar qué roles pueden escoger sus contrincantes.

Un juego muy recomendable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An in depth game that plays well with two players in a relatively short period of time. With more players, this can only get more complex and interesting. Repeated plays increase the understand of the game space created by the card deck, and the subspace created by ones current hand, which leads to a multitude of strategies.

Finally played with 4 players and it was a blast. The deck got shuffled a good 3-4 times, increasing the opportunities to get a shot at a particular card, and also increasing the need withhold cards from the discard which might be beneficial to other players.

Everyone I demo the game to enjoys it, and usually wants a second game immediately after the teaching game in order to test out a strategy or home world.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game seems really complicated at first because it front-loads a lot of information. Personally, I don't really see this as a problem (I train people at work that way sometimes!), and if it is a problem it is offset by the incredibly useful reference cards included with the game.
This is a very deep strategy game focused more on indirect interactions than the direct. If you prefer the kind of game where you "race" for the "galaxy" by blowing up other players, this isn't really the game for you. The idea is to develop your board while trying to figure out your opponent's strategy so you can optimize your own moves by playing off of theirs.
Artwork is pretty good too, and there's a card with a space elephant on it, which makes the game even better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3.5
Owned it and traded away.  Just not for me.  I read the rules numerous time and checked all related threads on BGG, so I felt comfortable with the rules and the icons when I played.  But it felt as if the game was out of my control, to a certain degree.  The cards I drew dictated to me what I should do and, if I had multiple cards that I wanted to use, I usually had to discard at least one of them to get another one in play.  I think that if I had given the game more time, it may have improved, but for me right now, it just wasn't worth the effort - too many other games to play.  I did consider keeping it and buying the expansion to learn the game well by playing solo, but that would ultimately hurt my chances to play the game with others.  If I was the only one in my group who knew the game, I'd have a clear advantage on others as they struggled to figure out the cards and the strategies.  Like I said, just not worth the effort to me at the moment.  That said, I may pick this up again in a few years once my sons are older to see if they want to give it a try.

RATING: 7
Nice theme. Only a slight resemblance to San Juan in that there are actions (roles) chosen by each player, though it plays out differently. Nicely done rules, and there are helpful charts to assist with interpreting the various powers and phases, but it is still confusing for new players to interpret the cards. Artwork not silly like with Battlestations, but quite creative. The necessity of anticipating the selection of each other players' actions will optimize your own play, though it is a fairly solitare type of game. It does look to have a great deal of replayability, though. UPDATE: Raising rating back up again as the game begins to click. UPDATE: One of the most difficult games to introduce to new players, reaching for it less because of that.

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Note: 99% of my plays have been 2-player advanced

Race for the Galaxy is a near perfect game. The decision space is huge because you pay for cards with other cards. The icons are a breeze after the first 5-10 plays and end up being so much better than trying to read text on tons of cards because we can easily knock out a game in 20-30 minutes.

The player interaction is fairly low impact but definitely present. I enjoy trying to read someone's board and guess what they'll play next to set myself up for a super turn.

It is a card game so the luck of the draw can end up giving you an extreme advantage or disadvantage but I would say that 95% of the time you have solid options for dealing with what cards you draw. There have only been a few games where one person completely blows out another person just because of blind luck.

After almost 200 plays I still almost never turn down a game!

So, why is this only a 9? After about 20-25 plays I felt like I needed more and added an expansion. Injecting new cards into the game took it to a whole new level for us.

Expansions (in order of purchase):

Alien Artifacts
We've played AA the most (~140 times) and it created a much more exciting deck to play with. With just AA Race felt like a complete game.

Xeno Invasion
We've only played XI around 5 times and it adds a fun group of cards to the game. The military strategy feels very robust in XI which made it incredibly 'big', but I don't see myself only playing with XI. It will probably be more of a "I'm in the mood to do some crazy military stuff today"

The Gathering Storm
Just acquired it, will report back
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
There is definitely an audience for this type of game.

It decidedly has shades of San Juan (multifunction cards) and Puerto Rico (your selected action is what all the other players do as well except with a small additional bonus for the selecting player).

Be prepared to spend a lot of time learning the meaning of all the icons on the cards.

Is this a decent game? Yes. Is it a Top 10 game? No.

Great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is one of those situations when you can genuinely say that your motto is: "say NO to drugs, alcohol and smoking." Why? Because you have Race for the Galaxy! 

This baby can literally become your addiction as the rush and gaming spirit won't let go until the last chip is earned/ card is placed. 

The only big problem I have with this game is that it's difficult to get more people involved in it. (specially if they are not gamers) It takes some time to learn the rules and it takes even more time to start finding "the patterns" and actually get to the level of Race for the Galaxy players.

I recommend this game to anyone who is into at least one of these things:

a) Galaxy-themed games.
b) Medium or hard core difficulties games.
c) Finding patterns and creating chains in games.

RATING: 9
A perfect game and only ONLY not a 10 because of the heavy reliance on symbols. 

Symbols and language are a tough challenge in game creation. You want people from around the world to be able to play your game. It increases the market and lets people who don't know English/German/Japanese/whichever know what's going on. I get it. But there's a line you cross when you are spending the whole game looking at a pamphlet to tell you what your cards mean. 

After a bunch of plays, though, this game shines. 

Amazing. Just so much fun. Plus, you can draft it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I keep upping my rating the more I play.  With experienced players this game is quick and engrossing.  Where the game suffers, I think, is that your first few plays aren't all that exciting because you do not know the deck of cards or the combinations you need to jump start your VP engine.  Once you've played it a few times you see the different paths to victory and can adapt your strategy based on what others are trying to do.  Like Puerto Rico, an important element to RftG is picking phases that help you more than your opponents.  You want to be "out of phase" with them so that you can develop/settle when they pick it and produce/consume when it is the most benefit to you (for example).  It takes a few plays to get good enough to change your timing to make this happen.  Excellent game.  Much better than San Juan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After one 2-player game, I'm not going to give this a rating yet. Neither of us really knew what we were doing, and I'm sure we messed some things up. Seems like it could be a pretty cool game after the players get to know the cards. This first play was very slow and confusing though.

EDIT: A couple of more plays tells me I'm ready to rate this game a 7 for now. I can see how dedicating oneself to this game could generate a deeper interest in it, but it's just not likely to hit that level for me. I'll give it some more plays in time, but it really hasn't enticed me like it has others.

6/5/10 - I've been playing aganst the AI program available here on BGG, and it really sparked my interest in the game. I'm keeping my rating at 7 for now, but I think I finally "get it" regarding how to play this game.

2/9/16 - I'm dropping this to a 6 since my interested in playing it has been greatly reduced by Roll for the Galaxy, which appears to be a superior game in almost every way. It's easier to teach, more exciting to play, and has much less iconography.

5/5/17 - The official RftG app was just released and it got me enjoying this game again. Bumping the rating up to 8 for now.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An excellent, fun card game with a great theme. Brilliant mechanic (even if it's not original) of using the cards for multiple things. The game is not easy for new people to pick up, but once you get the hang of it, it's a great game that requires both strategy and tactics.  The game has both an economic engine buildup (play becomes bigger and more interesting as the game progresses) and multiple race aspects (players are racing to end the game and pick up points).  The best part is that a game can be completed in under 30 minutes.  A big winner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Choose 1 of 7 role cards, spend some of your cards to play others, build an engine. It can last from 20 to 40 minutes and it's chock full of strategy. Too bad the green and brown colors aren't more distinct. I can't wait for the other expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
UPDATE:  Still hate playing this with people who have played 40+ times, as I lose by mega-double-digits every time, but my wife has started playing, and she usually beats me by less than 10... much more satisfying.  I like building stuff in this game, and care only a little what the other person is doing.  It may not be a strategy for sucess, but it does make the game fun for me.

Finally have played the game enough to learn the iconography, begin to internalize the rules and start paying attention to cards and combos.  I still suck, but I am having a ton of fun while sucking.  

I have only played the game once without "The Gathering Storm," so my rating here reflects the two played together.  Shortly, my rating here will reflect on the base game plus Storm, plus Rebel vs. Imperium.

I really like RftG, and wish I could play it more often.  I feel that there is so much more to explore and, unlike with San Juan, the size of the deck means games play really differently each time.  I like San Juan, but San Juan doesn't.  

I have put together marginally successful civs, but haven't yet made an efficient VP production engine, or a good military civ, nor have I put down even two "6" developments in the same game. And these are just the obvious things I would like to do.  So much still left to explore...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I am loving this game. Very quick to set up, plays in about 30-40 mins with experienced players, scales well for any number of players. A bit of a learning curve for new players due to the icon system on the cards (which is really helpful once you get the hang of it) and learning the different possible combinations of cards. Feels a little bit solitarish, but that's not really a problem. Eagerly awaiting the expansions.

RATING: 10

EDIT - Quickly becoming obsessed...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Now I'm playing it by the right rules, I like it a lot more. Its quick playing time is a HUGE plus -- at times, it feels even faster than San Juan, since your engine can really become a sleek and efficient beast. I still prefer San Juan due to its simplicity and familiarity, but the enormous variety of strategies in RFTG is enticing.

UPDATE: Ok, this game is really fun, but my strategy right now is still very rigid and so highly dependent on luck of the card draw. And I keep losing to Keldon's AI.

UPDATE: 8 -> 9. This game is a treasure. Familiarity and experience with the cards is greatly rewarded. Frankly, luck of the draw plays a HUGE role in the game, but -- and this is a significant "but" -- you can contribute SIGNIFICANTLY to your chances of victory by correctly recognizing the right strategy from your hand of cards. Sometimes that strategy won't pan out, even if you shift it accordingly. But there are enough cards with sufficient flexibility to fit into almost any adequately broad plan.

UPDATE: 9 -> 10. RFTG (and its expansions) has become a "perennial" -- a game I will play at any time, with anyone who knows the game well, for any span of free time. I dearly wish more people I know played it, but the online implementations make it easy to find opponents who will inevitably thrash me.

UPDATE: I would give this game a score of 11 if it existed.

There is some similarity to San Juan but I prefer this - particularly the much bigger variety of cards and consequent interaction.  I also like classic sci-fi so the artwork and theme work well for me (apart from the green spice planet - what gives there? - something that needs sorted as a priority for the second edition) so I do like that I can get Space Marines or an abandoned alien planet instead of a fountain or a wheelbarrow or whatever.  I have a very strict rule not to buy games which one of my group already has but I do break it very occasionally (Puerto Rico and Durch die Wuste are the only (deliberate) examples I can remember) - I need some more plays to be sure but this might just join that list.  [Update: (1) it has.  (2) Another notch up - I do always want to play it. (3) I'm beginning to wonder if this is a 10 for me - real good fun. (4) & (5) the excellent two player game and the surprisingly tough solo game nudge this up another couple of notches - a 10 for me].

[b]TOTAL = 437.5/50 = 8.75[/b]


:thumbsup: [b]POSITIVE POINTS:[/b]

++ Great, medium-heavy weight tableau-builder / engine-builder card game.
++ Good replayability from the different card drawn and the many path to victory.
++ Good card graphic design, that is clean and clear.
++ Relatively fast to set-up and fast to play.
++ There is several expansions available for this game (which is useful to refresh the game when we have overplayed it).


:thumbsdown: [b]NEGATIVE POINTS:[/b]

-- Really hard to teach or learn as there is so many icons on the cards (though there are logical and mostly well thought out) and the so many little rules here and there (less streamlined than San Juan), so the learning curve for this game is steep (I read the rules, played like 10 games on BGA, then re-read the rules to better understand everything, and then I started to win some games).
-- The space theme, the steep learning curve, the iconography and the fact that I already know how to play this game, all this makes it a no-buy for me as I mainly play wife my wife, and all these things will turn her off.


:arrowE: [b]OTHER GAME INFO:[/b]
[b]
Game Weight = 3.0/5
Release Date = 2007
Number of Player = 2-4
Online game length = 5-10 min.
2-player length = Approx. 30-45 min.
Player Count Preference = Best at 2, great at 3, recommended at 4! :thumbsup::thumbsup:
[/b]

RATING: 8
A very interesting hand management game. You can feel echoes of Puerto Rico as Citadels but mechanics are investigated in a deeper way.
This could be considered by the way THE card game: despite point tokens, there is a clever usage of cards that become planets, developements, resources and money.

Sad notes about the possibility to play in 4 players (terribly orchestrated to 5 and 6 players in 2 separated expansions!), and some teaser of future mechanics such Imperium, Uplift and in a certain way Rebel. The final thought is that the game fully satisfy players in the first 10-15 training games, while it is absolutely necessary to buy expansions in order to fix the unbalance between some totally over-powered strategies and the rest.

RATING: 7.5
-The gathering storm
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
UPDATE: Well, it's hard to be too critical of a game for which you have logged 61 plays, all face-to-face. Still, though, I'm a little bit surprised to see the expansion (The Gathering Storm) coming out and that I haven't played the base game in quite some time. It just seems like the play became stereotyped a bit. I think there is a bit too much range with not as many legit strategic paths as you might think, but not quite enough tactical flexibility once you're going down a path. Hopefully the expansions will re-inject some replayability. I love the game, but I'm surprised that I don't have more desire to play it these days.
---
UPDATE: Well, RftG has become (in just a month or so) my most-played game of 2007. My favorite game of the year. I worry a little bit about long-term replayability and the difficulty of learning the game (you need a couple throw-away games to come up to speed), but I can't deny a game that I've played this much in such a short amount of time, and which has shown such a great diversity of play, the 10 rating.

I almost wonder if the sweet spot for RftG, player-wise, might actually be 5. It's added one more avenue to acquire victory points over San Juan, the whole Consume route, and since a non-trivial chunk of the interaction is in riding on other players' action choices, having 5 players in the game might actually make it a little fairer in terms of distribution of roles and not getting stuck out with nobody to back you up.

Regardless, though, I like the game a lot at 2, 3, or 4, and the expansions can't come out soon enough for me :)
---
UPDATE: The most common complaint I hear about the game is that it has "zero player interaction", which is clearly bogus. Your role selection is obviously influenced by other players' play, as is your choice of developments and strategy. It's not direct, beat-on-your-neighbor style interaction, but it's pretty standard for a euro. Well, OK, the other complaint is that it's too complicated, which is a judgment call and for some will be fair.

I think Tom and RGG have done a very good job with the presentation of the game. All the iconography works and really helps make the game playable and reduce what could have been significant complexity. I wish such attention had been paid to Tom's other recent game, Phoenicia, a game where the graphic design makes the game needlessly difficult.
---
Take the amazing, elegant, top-10-type San Juan game, and then add some stuff. Add some more stuff. No, no, keep going. A little more. About now  you get to somewhere around Race for the Galaxy. I liked it quite a bit, but no question it lacks the grace and artistry of San Juan, and there is a non-trivial learning curve (whether or not you enjoy this learning process may be a prime determiner of whether you like the game). I think it will find many, many fans, and I expect I will be one of them, but I doubt that it will knock San Juan from its pedestal.

Chris' teaching tip: I think you want to teach this one backwards. Hand out the standard starting cards. Then have the players put them out in front of themselves as if you were in mid-game and these were their current holdings. Then start with the Produce action and work backwards through the sequence of play. I think this yields the most comprehensible flow. RftG can definitely be rather confusing if you haven't played San Juan (or even if you have, actually).

Last thing: comparisons inevitably spring to mind with another like-titled game, Galaxy: The Dark Ages. Just as G:tDA took a brilliant, straightforward game (Titan: The Arena) and then added lots of complexity, so has Race for the Galaxy (with respect to San Juan). But G:tDA went way over the edge (even though I do like it). RftG seems to be successfully skirting it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
As compared to San Juan, I really like the strategic possibilities in this one as opposed to San Juan.  There seem to be a lot of ways to go about winning this one, and a lot of possible good card combinations.

I really enjoy trying to make a game strategy work based on my start world and opening hand.  Every game you'll find yourself going after something different!

A word of warning, these possibilities come at the price of added game complexity.  All of the special abilities and symbols and are pretty daunting at first, but became more digestible as the game progressed.  If you had a hard time the first time out, don't let it dissuade you!  Overall, a great game once you get over the initial hurdles of understanding everything.

RATING: 7.5
I was lucky enough to play the prototype with the designer.  The game has a lot going for it; it's quick, engaging and if you like building it's quite fun.  In my experience, however, it seemed a bit too much like simultaneous games of solitaire -- the player interaction is there, but is modest compared to the non-interactive elements.  Seems like a great filler, but I'm surprised to see so many 10s.  Who knows, maybe I'm the one missing it and I'll change my mind when it comes out and I play a few more games?  

Edit: three more plays and my opinion hasn't really changed.  Basically I'm in the odd state of believing I'm wrong because I trust the judgment of a lot of people who say there's a lot more to it, so I'm going to keep playing and will see.

Edit: about thirty more plays and it looks like I was right that I was wrong.  Moving my rating up from 6 to 7.5 and I suspect it may rise again.

Further edit: I'm so sure I'm wrong that I bought a copy and will be teaching some friends how to play.  :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The rating on this game keeps decreasing for me, likely because I'm not very good at it.  Once you get past the symbols, this is a simple engine-building game.  The standard deck actually has pretty poor balance, which is only getting fixed now with the expansions (in the original rare element production worlds are dominant, Alien strategies are non-existent).  The play also feels too random to be meaningful.  

Slowly, the game has become divorced from the theme.  It used to be that I would look at my tableau at the end of a winning game and construct a narrative that explained the development of my empire.  Once my gaming group got better at this game, I've had to sacrifice thematic consistency for mechanical success.  I've begun seeing the cards as merely a means to VP, and the game has accordingly lost my favor.

Still enjoyable for a few games here or there, but I'd much rather play a longer board game at this point where I feel I'm building something meaningful.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

However, the cards could have been designed more clearly, though...and the theme...IMHO a civilisation theme would be more apt.

You have a set of cards, you try and decipher the icons, you work out the best way to use those cards. Other players do the same. The hint of interplay provided by the 'action' picks does almost nothing to influence your decision making.

RATING: 6
I really wanted to like this game. I got at least 30 plays under my belt before I finally realized that I don't. I like the theme, I like the art, I like exploring, I like building, I like developing. But what I really didn't like is that winning is determined by production of VP points that feel completely disjoint from the rest of the game. Never mind that you built the most massive infrastructure - if you haven't been pumping out VPs little by little every turn - you will loose before you realize the game is over. I guess the mechanics just doesn't work for me, not because they bad, but because they are thematically disjoint.

RATING: 6
Nice card game that, once you get past the daunting iconography, is actually quite fun and has lots of expansions to keep the game fresh. Each turn players pick 2 out of 5 actions to do, but you must try to get in your opponents' head because you can piggy back off any action chosen by an opponent. Really clever mechanism! Not crazy about the theme and the iconography may scare off some lighter gamers but it is still a good game worth the quick playtime.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Nine times out of ten I feel like I'm just building the best possible produce consume engine I can with the cards that I've stumbled into. The other time out of ten I get the cards that force me to go military with an outside chance at winning.

It's not that I don't like building engines, I do, but I seem to prefer a more strategic engine, like in Dominion, than this one, which is more tactical.

I do enjoy trying to predict my opponent's play and leeching off of their decisions, as well, as the blunting effects of tableau bonuses on the other player's choices, but I find that this takes a back seat to first thing I mentioned.

You also need to play fairly regularly or you'll forget all of the iconography. Also, you can forget about trying to teach this game to someone and hoping for a quick fun first play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Way better than San Juan, its obvious inspiration. The advanced 2 player rules speed the game up just right. Race is fast becoming one of my favorite Euros.

RATING: 6

RATING: 6
The race. Really. You play in solitude and in the end count victory points. Like "stingy knight" you collect sixes because they double and triple your scores.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
San Juan was one of the first Euros I ever played and it really took hold of me - I like role selection and looking for card combinations that fit into a larger victory point-generating "machine".  Then, Race for the Galaxy came along and I discovered the true ideal of tableau-building games.  First of all, the number of potential interactions between the game cards in Race for the Galaxy is mind-boggling, which ultimately allows for more interesting strategies and paths to victory than those provided by San Juan, where the card combinations are very limited.  Secondly, the simultaneous action selection mechanic in Race for the Galaxy is deeper than the role selection in San Juan because it provides flexibility and encourages one to anticipate the selections of one's opponents in order to accomplish more in each round.  From a design perspective, the iconography is fantastic - it summarizes complex information effectively and saves the cards from multiple lines of text, which also means more space for the beautiful art.  I honestly cannot understand all the whining on the forums about the supposed difficulty of the iconography.  Lastly, I love the space theme; at the end of virtually any game, I can look at my cards and immediately come up with a background story that explains their arrangement.  Overall, a deep tableau-building game without complex rules or fiddly components.  Simply awesome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

UPDATE: I played again, and now know how the game works. I still don't love it, but it's ok.

RATING: 9.4
San Juan sucks.  This game rocks.  This game feels finished, and I will gladly get rid of San Juan knowing I have this game in my collection.  Too much of San Juan was getting the "good" buildings and rifling through the deck to find cards that did anything for you.  In this game, every card is good.  You have to figure out how to put things together.  I still have so much to learn about the strategy here that I can't imagine it getting stale any time soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Better than San Juan. Plays quicker, an infinite variety of options and I think there is more interaction (via piggybacking). Very much it's own game as well. San Juan always felt like Puerto Rico lite (but takes just as long to play), where this stands very much on its own. That said, it's impenetrable to all but serious gamers. Aside from the iconography, the rules are just 'gamey'. In Puerto Rico, it was obvious that a shipping strategy (for eg) required a warehouse and a harbor. That makes intuitive sense. Here you need the card with the red haloed circle that has the -1 symbol in the phase 3 section, especially in combination with ... etc etc. The fast, deep play is worth the hassle for gamers though. 

Update: Lowered to a 4. After 7 or 8 plays, I am bored to tears. I don't want to play anymore but I know I will have to many many many more times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
[u]December 2008:[/u]
Ok, my gf LOVES this game and I do too, but right now, after 26 games this month and 16 or so in the last 4 days... I'm a little burnt out... So this game does have a limit... wow I wasn't expecting that... I don't think I'll be burnt out for long though, give me a week and I'll probably be ok to play it again!

Definitely one of the best games there is and the best if you're looking for hand management!

[u]May 2009:[/u] For the firt time since october, RFTG wasn't my most played game of the month. This shows the mong lasting appeal of the game. Moreover, the game was a big hit with all of my friends, newbs, usuals, heavy players, their girlfriends.... I might have presented this one to 15 different people, all liked it.

The game presents tons of different strategies. What I liek about this game is also the great long-term planning there is, which is unusual for a card game and a 30m card game! Of course, you'll be seeing that after maybe 10 plays once you get to know the cards pretty well. Though starting to play this can be hard because of the icons (having played PR helps, and I guess having played San Juan too though I haven't played this one). However, once the 2 or 3 first games are passed (count 45 min each time), you'll get a huge payoff.

Since play 50, I'd say my plays last 15-20 min for 2p. For 3 or 4 it usually lasts 45 min, but we alaways have newbies with us.

Finally, though I prefer the 2p game, the 3, 4 and 5 (with the expansion) versions are great too.

[u]March 2010:[/u] [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/485626/multiple-player-review-race-for-the-galaxy]my review[/url]

RATING: 9
*9* (20+ Plays)
I really like this card game. There's a lot going on in the game and there are endless combo's and strategies. Race has lots of replay value and is a classic for me. There is a steep learning curve, because of the iconography, but once players are aware of gameplay and the icons the game plays well. There's no interaction between players beside the selection of actions, which is kind of a bummer. Still is very competitive with opponents. Players really have to pay attention what others are doing and thinking and adjust. Also a superb 2 player game!

RATING: 7
Now I finally understand the hype.

A very well designed game.  There are times where your strategy depends on what others may decide what to do, and so there is a level of uncertainty in the role that one chooses.  And I can understand why some say this is "multiplayer solitaire", and there is some basis for that.  But there is more to the game than just that.

I consider this a step-up from [gameid=8217], both in theme and complexity.  Both games are still really good games, but I think I like this one a little better.

EDIT:  08/05/16 - I have not played this game in probably three years, as it would have never hit the table and thus I traded it away after the only person I played it with moved away.  And I don't know if I even have the compelling interest to ask someone else to play.  I enjoyed it while it lasted, but like your middle-school girlfriend, it didn't have enough staying power.

I don't miss it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Initial rating of a 6 after one play. But admittedly, this needs about 5+ plays for an honest rating. I like it but... I'd rather play Puerto Rico. This is the first game that strikes me as "multi-player solitaire." Puerto Rico doesn't, because I can scan other players and try too deduce their choices and strategies. But in RftG, the sheer diversity in cards makes it hard to concentrate on the other players, so I found myself just trying to maximize my own little world.

I'll play this again if others suggest, but I'm in no rush to do so. This game actually made me miss the direct conflict in Magic the Gathering. 

I suspect this game needs a group that regularly plays it to delve into its subtleties; I'm just not sure I have a group around me to do that, as we've got plenty of other choices.

Update after 2nd play -- I must be doing something right, as I stayed competitive again, but the sheer overwhelming number of choices makes me feel like I'm gasping for air. I played an entire game without even considering what the others were doing. Weird.

Again, I need to play this 5+ times before I truly figure out whether I like this or not, but play #2 was better than play #1.One thing's for sure--Puerto Rico did not prepare me for this. Not at all.

Update: Eh. Dropped it down to a "5." I've played a number of games recently that excite me more than this. If others encourage me, I might keep playing this to "discover its inner beauty," but right now I'm looking in other directions.

Update after 4 plays: Nah. Make it a "6." I don't think there's going to be a major epiphany, but I like it a little more with each play.

RATING: 7
Finally got a chance to play this and it is a fun game on building your engine as fast as you can and finding synergies in your tableau that allow you to do crazy combos. I can definitely see how it rewards multiple plays by knowing the cards as you'll get a better idea of what chains together. My strategy didn't work out, but I can already see a few things to try differently next time. I also didn't find the iconography that bad, which did surprise me a bit. The only thing that bugs me about this compared to the dice game is the role cards and planet/development cards having to keep switching them in your hand was a little annoying, but otherwise this is a very solid game that I think will be very rewarding in future plays.

RATING: 9
Race for the Galaxy is one of my favorites for a fairly quick game! Collecting plantets or developments of a certain theme or strategy is strangely addicting, and setting up cards that combo well together is fun and fairly challenging. 
The only downside for me is that I have very rarely been able to adequately explain the production and consumption phases to casual gamers. Something about the mechanics of this game, though not overly complex, just seems to completely elude most people.

RATING: 6.8
3 play - 4 players
10  plays - 3 players
10  plays - 2 player
10  plays - solo

This is a good game.  Better with two then with three or four.  There's a fair amount of luck of the draw - but it's a fun way to pass time if you're in the mood for some light empire building / exploration.  

The winner seems to always be the player who draws and places the most/best 6 cost developments.

There is a serious learning curve in regards to the icons, but once you're up to speed, it flows well.  The game seems to capture the feel of "your people" with their own advantages well given its short play time.  Sessions always seem to end before I'd like them to, and usually leave me with a "one more time" feeling.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Need to play this one more, but I think I like it. 3rd play, yup, it's a keeper. Not a pick-up-and-play kind of card game. Not so much stategic as it is tactical. 

What you build in your tableau is going to help create a general path, but you must constantly adapt with each new hand. About mid-game your going to want to follow a certain path to victory, and you can influence the outcomes of each round depending on the actions you choose, but it's just as likely that things are not going to pan out, you'll need to recognize the best decision and continue to adapt until the very end. 

This one never gives your brain a rest. 

9th play introduced: The Gathering Storm Exp.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
San Juan in space, or San Juan redux.  I like the simultaneous selection of roles instead of the fixed selection as in San Juan.  This adds an element of bluffing and guessing to the game which is fun.  Seems like there is lots of game here, and it isn't always obvious what the repercussions of your role choices are.  I enjoy it, and I'm sure it will get a good number of plays.

Update:  After a period of not playing it, and almost trading it, it has enjoyed many plays.  I like it much more than San Juan, and it works really well for 2-4 (haven't played with more than that).  I particularly like the two player game.  There are certainly those lucky and unlucky hands, but trying to work with what you have is very rewarding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Not an easy game to pick up at all (prepare for symbol overload in your first few games), but stick with it and you'll find a great game eventually. Beyond the basic mechanics lies a huge amount of depth, from taking advantage of your opponent's tendencies to coming up with ingenious card synergies. If you can get past the initial learning curve and don't mind non-direct interaction (you're limited to leeching off your opponents and 'blunting' them by not playing phases/roles they're strong in, a la Puerto Rico), this is a must have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Out of all the low player interaction classics, this is one of my favorites.  I think it's better than Puerto Rico simply because it's to your advantage to guess what phases the other players will pick for that round then plan accordingly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Takes a lot of effort to learn all the dang icons, even though they're supposed to be helpful. Also, I often look at my hand and then have no idea what I should be doing to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
:indigo: :( :D :D :) I hated this game at first.

Maybe not "hated," but I rated it a decidedly unenthusiastic 4 or 5 at first. It's worth examining my reasons why, from least to most petty:

1. [b]I didn't feel like there was any tension in the role selection aspect because of its simultaneous nature.[/b] The sequential role selection of San Juan appealed more to me, coming from a Puerto Rico background. I don't know what to say about this, apart from stating that on further reflection I think that there's a surprising amount of tactical planning involved in role selection -- as you gain experience with the game, you stop looking at just your own hand and start to realize that other people's holdings provide you with important clues as to their next move, and compel your moves for defensive/offensive/synergistic reasons.

2. [b]I thought it was multi-player solitaire.[/b] It is, when you're at Level 1. The subtle nature of interaction in this game only starts to dawn on you when you've played it a lot. But it's there. Stop looking at your own hand and tableau and force yourself to think about what your opponents are doing, and the strategic space opens up.

3. [b]I thought it was luck-driven and excessively tactical.[/b] Is there luck? Hells yes. It's a card game, after all. You can draw the perfect engine out of sheer dumb luck. But try rumbling with an experienced opponent and see if it still feels like luck after he wipes the floor with you. The Keldon AI is a helpful, patient, and nasty-tough teacher. Of the super-popular gamer's games that can be played inside an hour, Dominion is a strategic feast that tests your ability to see a plan from the jump, 7 Wonders is a tactics-fest where an initial plan is impossible. Race, by contrast, is Baby Bear's porridge -- not too strategic, not too tactical, just right.

4. [b]I hated the graphic design.[/b] The icons annoyed me to the quick. The cards devote too much space to pictures that don't convey any meaning. Vital clarifications shunted off into the corner in italicized agate type. Grr. It's a learning curve issue -- the icons [i]are[/i] a barrier to entry, and anyone who says differently is selling something. But every card game is improved by knowledge of the deck, and once you get to know it, the icons really do help convey maximal information in minimal space. You just need to be patient. You [i]really[/i] need a patient teacher, which can be  a scarce commodity since one primary appeal of the game to its fans is that you can order Chinese and play a game or two before the delivery guy shows up.

5. [b]I hated the theme.[/b] A bit of Star Wars, a bit of Star Trek, and, hey, why am I falling asleep here? Yes, I'm a cranky bastard, but I'm sick to death of pew-pew lasers in my games. But, well, the game works.

All of this is a long-winded way of saying -- it gets better. It's worth the climb.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Tom Lehmann seems to design amazing games that take 25 hours to learn how to play well. In the case of 2038, I doubt I'll ever invest the time. In the case of Race for the Galaxy, I'm already there for two players and am well on my way with more. Race is an extraordinary game once you get to understand the cards, the phases, and their interactions.

The game is easily a 9 at this point but gets docked at least a full point for being almost unplayable for the first half dozen games, and only tolerable for the next dozen. I would be loath to teach this game, which has all of Puerto Rico's 'drawbacks.' Puerto Rico, though, is exciting from the very first game. Race takes awhile to get there, but it's spectacular once it does.

RATING: 9.85
My best game of 2007:

This game is overwhelming on the first play, with all the vast array of different symbols which are plain confusing, but after that first game, you'll understand it perfectly.

The gameplay is pure economical engine fun, there are a wide array of strategies that pull you in all directions, but don't seem unbalanced, and a huge amount of indirect player interaction which means the game doesn't bog down.  You can play 3 games in 30 minutes (and want to!) and it scales well between 2 to 4 players, playing with a different style for each number.

Update: Pretty much worn through our set already (and we only got it 2 months ago), and I still want to play.  This game is absolutely amazing 2 player.

RATING: 9.5
Fantastic game that plays very quickly but with a lots of depth, you have a lot of decisions to make as you have limited resources (cards) and limited time to play them.  When to switch the engine from drawing and setting up to gaining victory points is critical.  You can see the 'puerto rico' underneath the game but it plays fast and different.  Also, the weak player problem with Puerto Rico is diminished as his bad plays could help any player and there is no turn order.

I really love this game but find one aspect frustrating.  Although play skill is very important a good player with the right cards can run away with the game.  Even if the other players play very well there isn't much you can do.  At first I though player interaction was low and although it's not a trading game or a war game anticipating the other players moves is extremely important.

Although I wish luck were less important in the game it is very fun and very short, you don't have hours invested in a game decided by lady luck (see Risk).  I'm really looking forward to the expansions!

Another update to these comments, March '08.  Well I'm very surprised by the depth of the game, I'm over 50 plays now and still not bored, which is what I expected to be after 50 plays.  There always seems to be something new to explore.  Many cards that I discarded as trash I'm now using to great effect in the right situations.  This game only gets better with more plays!

6/04/08 Up over 100 plays now.  I'm surprised by the depth of the game more then anything else.  I was sure I would be bored to tears by now.  Plays fast and deep.  Highly recommended.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
"Race for the Galaxy's" only flaw may be its steep, steep learning curve. It's unfortunate that this flaw will keep a fair number of people from ever playing it, because once you're over that learning curve mountain, the game you're left with is an absolute brain-burning gem. You don't even need expansion for it to be a blast, and setup and tear-down are a breeze, too.

Who should avoid it? Anyone who detests games that lean heavily on symbology. There really are a headache-inducing number of symbols in the game. If you can handle that, then by all means, give this game a try. You'll be hooked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Once upon a time this review mostly referred to San Juan, as this game was also originally developed as Puerto Rico: the Card Game but was split off into its own thing when it was allegedly deemed a bit more complicated than what Ravensburger wanted. FWIW: this game obsoleted San Juan for me.

In general, if you know what PR is like, then you will have some idea of what to expect here. There are 5 phases that each only happen during a given round when players select them. If you actually select the action you get a more powerful version of it, but much of the game hinges on effectively saving actions by leeching off the ones that other people are choosing. The rub is that unlike PR the action selection is simultaneous and blind, so you have to pay some attention to what is going on around you to pull this off.

Now PR is still one of my favorite games, what is the appeal of Race? Simply put, the game is variable as all get out because of the number of different cards in the deck. The 6 developments function much like PR's big buildings, and offer payoffs for all manner of strategies. In the base set, the dominant strategy seems to be big Produce / Consume (much like Craft / Ship in PR) cycles using the 2X VP version of Consume, but it is also possible to craft a winning Military tableau, or some other, more esoteric combinations, mostly based on having specific 6 developments.

What are the downsides? Mostly they relate to the swingy nature of any game based on drawing cards. You might have a great tableau for a given development card, and be able to dig for it aggressively, but it might be buried, it might have been used as a good, or it might be in someone elses' hand. Contrast this with a cleaner game like PR where the big buildings are sitting out and are subject to a much more public race. I prefer the PR implementation in that particular case.

The other downside is the rules and learning the icons. Man, this game just hums once you are familiar with them, but teaching this is a bear and I have always hated having to do it.

That said, this game is fast with experienced players, it has a very quick setup, and it is absolutely fantastic with 2, which I personally prefer with 1 action each round each player. In all honesty, I like it from 2-4, but it is much more work to keep track of what everyone else is doing in the big game. More than 4 tends to bog it down too much. This was one that I was very tepid on originally, but as time has passed I have played it more, and I really am starting to actively love it, especially since my gf likes it, and it is one of the heavier things in our competitive rotation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of the best fillers I've ever played

RATING: 8
Many comments suggest that the iconography on the cards is a barrier to entry on this game. I disagree. It is not that difficult to understand - especially in the base game. I really enjoy the thoughtfulness and planning required to succeed in this game. It takes several games to understand the necessity for planning, but once you do and you begin to think three, four, seven turns out, it is very rewarding to see a sequence of turns turn out well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Likes: There are so many subtle things going on in this game. It really comes down to how well you can manage the hand of cards you are dealt. There are many strategies to victory, and often you have to anticipate what action other players are going to choose. Also, games are fast-paced as implied by the theme and name.

Dislikes: Very steep learning curve; many players will complain that this game is very luck based. Also, the symbology can be hard to teach/learn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of our favorites...so much depth and replay value.

RATING: 9
Love this game.  The tension of deciding what cards to actually play and what to use as currency is fantastic.  It really rewards specializing and sticking to a plan.  By turn 5 you really need to know your end game.  The explore +5 option is under-utilized for finding a card that will let you know what your strategy is.  I have played 4 games so far and have seen a number of different viable strategies.  Have not played with the "expert" 2 player variant yet.  People say it is a great 2 player game but so far I have had the most fun with >2 players.

The game could be about anything really, which is a shame because I love sci-fi and hoped this would become a favourite. 
Still, in time I could grow to love it and maybe one day I'll understand what other people see in it!

RATING: 1
The cards are way too busy with stupid little symbols that needs a cheat sheet that is like the Rosetta Stone to decipher! I am sure it would become easier to remember them after several plays, but I am not sure I want to invest the time or energy. Once you learn the game I would dread playing it with new players anyway, as I would have to watch them go through the same frustration of learning the damn thing. Also, there is no way in hell I would want to teach this thing to anyone for the same reasons.

I really don't see what all the fuss is over this. There is really nothing new here. San Juan may be not be as "deep", but is fills the niche for the this kind of game perfectly fine. In the end I just think this is just another way over-hyped flavor of the month Euro! BLECH!!!!!

My rating is only from 1 play, but right now I am not all that anxious to try again. I just don't see my score going up with repeated plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pretty good, an interesting take on the path started by San Juan. It has some nice mechanics, and a rich (if perhaps too complicated) iconography. However, it has some serious flaws, too.  The worst one is that the pacing of the game is a bit off - it tends to end just at a point when most players are feeling like they've finally gotten started. Second, it's very luck based, with winning depending more on what cards you happen to draw rather than how you play them (though it's fast enough that this is a bit less of a problem than it might be). Third, it feels like a bit too much has been crammed in - the game probably would benefit from a bit of editing.

Over all, definitely worth playing at least a few times, and it makes a decent warm up game for an evening of play. It really appeals to some people, and if that's you, then enjoy!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Looks awesome!!! Pumps up the gameplay of San Juan with extra Strategy and options.  Love the space theme too. BUT, it's slow and clunky.  2 hands of cards?  Too many icons.  Goodbye!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
(Played a single time, 3P, one player experienced + two n00bs.) It appears to be a streamlined version of San Juan (yesyes, RftG is its own game, but still...) in that cards in this economic game—get a little economy up and running and then cash in—serve multiple functions depending on the orientation. What is different is the role selection, which is independent of other players, and of course the game's subject matter. The learning curve is pretty steep as you must learn the iconography; after that I suspect it's a fun ride puzzling out various strategies. In all likelihood, player interaction is low until you become experienced enough in that you don't really need to think about your own hand any longer. (I was reminded of Mah-Jongg at this point.) This may or may not be a good thing, depending on your point of view. However, a clear problem in this regard is that the iconography does not read well upside-down.

I'm not sure how this game would grow on me. The basic mechanisms are not imaginative, and even feel rather dated at times. It is literally a race in optimisation given a random influx of cards. It does, however, play as quick as greased lightning, which probably explains a lot of its large appeal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Similar in play to San Juan, but deeper and more satisfying.  There is a moderate learning curve.

Production  -> :star::star::star::nostar:
Fun         -> :star::star::star::nostar:
Play Desire -> :star::star::star::nostar:
Theme       -> :star::star::nostar::nostar:
Down Time   -> :star::star::star::nostar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The best board game. Much more fun than [thing=3076]Puerto Rico[/thing] or [thing=8217]San Juan[/thing]. Light, quick and strategic.

Simultaneous turns make for fast gameplay and the apparent solitariness is only superficial - there is deep interaction between players (including some bluffing and double-guessing) and affecting players' choices and strategies. However it takes some time to see, which puts off a lot of players.

I wish more games featured icons instead of text - when you familiarize yourself with them it doesn't take more than a glance to see what is what and who is who...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun 2-player game, definite similarities to Puerto Rico. I agree with general comments about the iconography; it's difficult to decipher at first but after you learn the system the icons are very specific and descriptive. (It takes some familiarization to realize that there are [i]no[/i] non-essential parts of an icon, even the colors and outlines matter...) This is a gamer's game, difficult for the uninitiated to simply pick up and play.

My only significant complaint is that there is a touch too little player interaction for my tastes, but even so this is a solid game.

RATING: N/A
Yves
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game pushes some important buttons. I like games that play quickly but have a long learning curve. Over the first 30 or so games, you'll have many sudden "Oh, that's how it works" moments, and you'll reach a new level of gameplay. The game also has a 2 player mode that pushes the already good game, to become an excellent game. It's a particularly good game for couples as
1) it excels at 2P
2) it's low confrontation
3) it rewards repeated play with the same person, and benefits from being able to get inside each others heads.
4) between players of equal experience luck plays a defining role, which means there's no hard feelings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

B

RATING: 9

That being said, this is a great game if you are into games that require some effort to get over the learning curve. Its not too bad after a few games, but can discourage new players if they aren't willing to make that commitment. 

I only own and have played the base game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pros:
-Very optimization-oriented
-Good replay value/diversity. With expansions, no 2 games will ever be the same.
-Incredible depth (you will get better even after 50+ games)
-Short preparation time (2-5 mins)
-Short play time (15-30mins)
-Fun with (and especially) only 2 players
-Different game depending on number of players
-After a few games, becomes very familiar and easy to play.

Cons:
-Because of the learning curve, someone playing their first game has almost no chance of winning.
-Symbology is hard to get for the first few games.

Interactivity is very light (appealing to the "dislikes direct conflict" crowd) but very relevant (appealing to the "likes strategizing" crowd). The only major downside I've seen is the initial learning curve, but the game wouldn't have the interest it does without all of the required rules-bits.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Components: Thematically evocative artwork on all the cards; quite a joy to look at. The functional information on the borders of the cards is very blah, and is visually distracting. Ideally, a card would not display a phase number on its left side if the card has no possible action during that phase; as is, there is a lot of visual clutter, and once a producing world is covered by a goods card it is difficult to tell what information has been hidden by the good. In general the iconography is effective, though unattractive. The card quality is good, with a nice linen finish that withstands a lot of shuffling. If it weren't for the oversized player's aid, the game could come in a much smaller box.

Experience: The action-selection engine is enjoyable; I especially like being able to perform an action that my opponent has selected; it's like receiving a gift.

Nice, subtle ways in which players interact:
1) Forcing each other to consume prematurely. There's nothing sweeter than turning my own rare good into two cards, while watching my card-starved opponent's alien good converted to a victory point, rather than the handful of cards they were expecting on the following round.
2) Selecting an action which promises to not benefit the opponent (e.g. Develop, when one is sure that the opponent has no development cards). If the opponent ends the round with no cards in their hand, playing Develop and Settle together can exploit their state.
3) Not playing an action card that the opponent is expecting one to play. This enters the uncertain realm of outguessing one's opponent (akin to character selection in Citadels). If I'm card-starved, then of course I'll select Explore, which means my opponent doesn't need to; but if they're counting on me to do it, and I know that, perhaps I can select a different phase, also useful to me, and thus gum up my opponent's plans.
4) Changing one's mind mid-turn to respond to the action cards an opponent has played (e.g. in a recent game I hoped to explore a few development cards that would work well with my current tableau, but when I saw that my opponent had played Settle and Produce, I instead selected a development card with +2 military, which allowed me to conquer a 2 production world during the Settle phase, and that world then immediately produced). 
5) Adapting one's tableau to take advantage of the opponent's strategy (e.g. if the opponent has many production worlds, the opponent will most likely choose Production and Consume, so one's own tableau should have some flexibility to perform during these phases as well).

Our respective production engines quickly differentiate themselves, both from each other, and from previous games, leading to particular strategies. With the variety of cards, and the random limitations of one's starting hand, exploring the same strategy (e.g. emphasizing military power) still leads to different results, and to a tableau with a distinctive character to it. It's fun to discover effective combinations of cards. The more I play, the more I find particular uses for obscure cards that, until that moment, had been only currency to me.

Gets better with every play. There are so many different ways to earn points, and so many effective combinations of cards. This game is amazing.

Currently playing with all cards from first three expansions that don't involve rule changes. Playing with prestige against Keldon's AI (love prestige). Playing with Alien Artifacts without the Orb rules. All awesome.

A very different game with three players from that with two players. More brutal.

After 300 plays, I'm still looking forward to each game. Outstanding every time.

First Played: 2009-01-04
Last Played: 2016-08-27
Plays (366):
2 players: 356
3 players: 10
vs. robot: 1500+ (not included in total)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
One of the best card games ever. Although it's based on Puerto Rico, this game has a much steeper learning curve due to the sheer number of planets, but, once you get the hang of it, it is actually quite elegant. I particularly enjoy the many paths to victory and how the game rewards smart play. I love the theme, but I'm not sure the theme ever actually comes through that strongly. That said, for a card game, the theme is well integrated. The simultaneous, hidden role selection is really what makes the game. The best players try to figure out what roles the other players will select and try to take advantage of those roles while also selecting roles that benefit primarily themselves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Invest in the iconography and you will be well-rewarded.  This game just flows smoothly (err forgetting that whole alieny orby thingy).  People tend to criticize it for being multi-player solitaire but that's a load of bull; the people that win the game are more likely than not those who read what their opponents are about to do and piggyback accordingly.  I love this game.

RATING: 8
Clean and precise mechanics; best when playing with the advanced two player rules. It can seem abstract, but the abilities of the cards are themed beautifully and the artwork, names of the cards, and their powers are almost always perfectly matched. 

After several plays, it seems to me a bit stale strategically. If using only the base game, there are only one or two superior paths to take, which, based on the cards you're dealt, is always narrowed down to one optimal path. This takes a bit of the creativity or individuality out of play, and you rarely have to think too hard about what to do, but still a satisfying and enjoyable experience.

RATING: 8
The good:
This is my favorite care game that requires some knowledge of the cards. Even though I often criticize games like Agricola and Twilight Struggle for requiring card-knowledge, I don't think that applies to RFTG.  Why?  Mainly because the iconography is standardized, which makes comparing card strengths easier.  Also, there is no element of "timing" when certain cards "come out."

The bad:
Explaining the rules is like teaching fractions to a 4-year old.  The cards are also low-quality.

Fun and quick to play.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a deck building game.  Except there is very little player to player interaction via the cards!  

This game truly is a RACE. Build your empire,and gather points in the process.  The only player to player interaction really occurs in watching what everyone else is doing, and realizing that fewer cards are available of each type that they have chosen.

This is similar to Puerto Rico, except that in PR there is much more competition for shipping the goods and trading the goods.  Thus players have more ability to "shark" one another and affect the outcome of the game.  In this game all you can really do is take cards that could benefit someone else.

And unlike most deck building games noobs will suffer in this game.  Deck knowledge/memorization is not as important in Dominion or Thunderstone.  And it absolutely doesn't matter in Puerto Rico.  But in RftG it is extremely important.  Knowing what is left in the deck affects what card you pick next for your tableau.  Noobs have no idea what cards are left, and thus card knowledge can be the difference between winning and losing.

To be good at Dominion or Thunderstone only requires math skill.  To be good at RftG requires thorough knowledge of the entire deck!  Thus the person who owns this game will probably annihilate all of his/her friends (who do not own it) everytime it is brought out.  Not a very good recipe for repeat play!

Worse yet, this game is heavily dependent on "certain" cards being drawn by the players.  So unlike PR or Dominion, players are rabidly hunting through the deck looking for those very important cards.  Failure to pull just the right card, through luck, can mean the difference between winning and losing, which sucks since that means player skill and conscious choices are thrown out the window.

So in short this game is kind of like Puerto Rico *Lite*, with much less player interaction, and it is much more dependent on deck knowledge and on counting cards than most deck building games.  In addition, the game is balanced in such a way that quite a few cards are "must have" or failure is imminent.  So players are forces to scour the deck for that one card that will give them victory.  That in itself is major game flaw.

While a valiant attempt at creating a rival to PR, this game is seriously dead in the water.  Player choices are seriously hampered by the sheer luck that a "perfect card" will be drawn in an enormous deck, thus luck truly runs this game instead of player choices.  Thus your decisions as a gamer are reduced to almost nothing and you are no longer playing a game, but running through a procedure in which someone will win, with little regard to what they actually do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Have thoroughly enjoyed it with many numbers of players. Still some debate about the amount of luck with 2 players. I believe it is now more than I would care to admit, but I still have fun playing it out.
The 25 cards of the expansion significantly helps the balance.

With all expansions up to and including The Brink of War I have upgraded game rating to a 10.  A tour de force, no question about it.

After many many plays have dropped to a 9. It is still amazing, excellent, and I will happily play it, but I won't be pushing for it at game sessions anymore.

RATING: 8
You never know how you're going to play until the first few cards come your way.  Then you take what you've been given and build on it.  One game you may go military heavy, while in the next you produce and consume like there is no tomorrow.  

Having to form a strategy after your initial hand requires a little bit of a shift-on-the-fly mentality (you really can't go into a game with the intent to go, let's say, military heavy, because you don't know what cards you will be dealt), but that's one of the aspects I most enjoy.

RATING: 7

I think the game likely shines with players that have a full understanding of the rules and possible card combinations. RATING: 6.5
(based on playing with Keldon AI)

I didn't feel drawn to this game but decided to try it after finding out it's Touko Tahkokallio's favourite game. At this point I don't understand the praise though.
I won my first game against the Keldon AI without having much of a clue about what I was doing. I'm not used to the lack of player interaction in a game like this. What do I do when my opponent happens to get "galactic trendsetters" up and scoring on his third or fourth turn while I'm still looking for my first production planet? When the cards fall like this, there seems to be literally nothing you can do to catch up. I can appreciate the game design and effective use of icons.

Surely there must be more to this as it is one of the most praised and recommended games in recent history.

UPDATE: After 22 games still hasn't clicked for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my favourite game of all time. Sure, this game has a fairly steep learning curve. First, you need to understand the iconography; however, once you get the iconography, you can easily understand what each card does within one second of looking at it. The second thing one has to learn is the strategy - too often I see newcomers try both the "Military" and the "Production" strategy at the same time and that rarely works. However, once you overcome the learning curve after about 4-5 games of it, you will find a rich and deep strategic card game in here. Once you know what you're doing you can get a game done in 15-20 minutes (even though the box lists a playtime of 45 minutes). Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
If you've played San Juan (a good game), then this is one with similar mechanics, but with more cards, more mechanics, and a more exciting theme. What's not to like?
The first few plays were frustrating, as I was learning the game and all its iconography. It's not as much fun when you feel rushed by those who choose their roles in two seconds every turn. Much more fun when some thought is put into it, and a few minutes are spent at the end reflecting on your galactic civilization. 

I have to give mention to the excellent artwork on every single card in this game. Very impressed!

RATING: 8
I've only played it through the app but it's not hard to imagine what it would be like playing the physical version.

This game is just a pure tableau/engine builder. The learning curve can be steep because of all the iconography but once you understand everything it has very nice depth to it. I've played hundreds of games and I'm still learning things. The mark of a great card game. 

The artwork is hit or miss for me but overall it's pretty clean and very functional if nothing else.

It does feel a little like multi-player solitaire although great players will definitely exploit weaker players by having a better grasp of what their opponents are likely to do allowing them to be more efficient and giving them a nice edge to win.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
I truly wish I had a few more friends that would be willing to give this game a try, because I have only ever played this as a 2 player game.  I love it, and my sister really enjoys this as well.  Inspired by the Puerto Rico role selection concept (actually, this is basically an upgraded re-theme of San Juan), this card game is much easier after about the 4th time played - which is part of the problem.  Steep learning curves tend to turn off most in my gaming group, so they don't give a fair chance to the game.  It is likely that a new player will feel overwhelmed (much symbols/icons to learn), and get crushed by the experienced player - and most likely not play again.  Please, be patient with this game!  It's a great game, but takes a few games to get the hang of.

The cards function very well together. The designer of this game has designed a very excellent game and can rightly be proud of himself!

RATING: 9
