=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Let me preface this with saying that you have to like this sort of card game in order to like this game.  I think people who like that way the cards are used in similar games will like this better than I did.  But the card balance is still bad.  

The biggest problem with this game is that you can't ever work on one clear strategy.  The cards never line up.  You can't say, "this time i'll try production - points."  Nope.  That isn't ever going to happen.  You can never say what strategy you will work on as you can't get any they put into the game to work.  You are alway reacting to what ever is in your hand.  Most people I play with wanted to be able to work on a given strategy but could never get it to work.  It's like playing D&D and starting out as a wizard.  Then a few turns into the game everything points to being a fighter.  Ok, I'll switch to a fighter.  Nope, I need to be a thief.  Nope....it goes on like that forever.  You always feel like you are walking forwards while being pulled backwards. 

The easiest strategy is military.  With each expansion, everything is military.  Now everyone pretty much uses the military strategy.  I always offer this game up first on game night but no one ever wants to play it.  They all say it's a great game ...buuuuut....

I think it's the most overrated game out there.  There are a few things they could have done to fix this but they went the route of most cards just don't work with most other cards and enough of the cards that do work together never end up in your hand.  

As you can tell - this is the major flaw in the game.  it's not like any of the other strategy games that you can go off to bed and think up new things to try next time - because you can't.  it's will always be to react to whatever ends up in your hand.  In strategy games, I like to at least know my pieces.

Now, thanks to the expansions (I have them all), it's simply a military game where you take a few resources.  I thinks it's one of those games where people claim to like it so they look important.

RATING: 8
For me, an 8 after one play.  I like the complex card interactions and think there are a lot more different combinations and ways to play than San Juan.  However, it is very much multiplayer solitaire, in fact you surely could play this as solitaire but then it wouldn't be a race.  Also there is a steep curve as far as the symbols goes, you're constantly looking at the cheat sheet.  If you don't like CCGs and reference sheets or non-interactive games, you won't like it.  Otherwise, it's fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My opinion of Race for the Galaxy is mixed. I like the way phases are selected (which certainly provides some interesting decisions, but also sometimes just comes down to guesswork) and I like the different paths and strategies available.

I'm not as enthused about the surprisingly low level of player interaction... no player cards seem to have any direct effect on any other player (other than perhaps ending the game earlier than expected). Beyond that, timing and choosing sensible actions (and outguessing the other players' actions) and being the first to claim some of the scoring tiles seem to be about the only interaction there is.

While I'm certainly interested in playing more, this game isn't the instant classic I was hoping for.

One last note: much has been made of the icons used in this game. They're not really all that complicated. I was expecting much worse, given the hubbub.

Edit: played again, adding the next expansion. There's a small amount of direct interaction possible (via takeovers). Still feels a lot like multiplayer solitaire... but a good multiplayer solitaire, in any case.

RATING: 6
Good card game, cool theme, and short. Essentially [i]San Juan[/i] with a sci-fi theme, and a notch up in complexity and interaction between the cards. I owned it at one point, but at the time it felt too much like multi-player solitaire and I was getting a little bit into [i]Dominion[/i], so I traded it.

Update: decided to get the Steam app, where I can finish a game against the AI in about 10 minutes. So far I'm having fun with it, but will probably stick to a digital copy only where I mostly just play against the AI. As someone else mentioned, since you can play this game a lot in quick succession it doesn't take long to learn some optimal strategies, which could be very unfun for other players in casual games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Great game. However there are a number of minor things that nibble out a good score for me, which add up.

What I liked:
* Nice depth for primarily a card game.
* Mechanics work well and are simple
* Multiple paths to victory that are fairly well balanced

What I didn't like:
* Too many icons some of which are not straight forward.
* Takes a few games to learn
* An experienced player will always trounce a new player
* Hard to bring to the table
* New players need to play this regularly if they want to become decent.

RATING: 8
With an analog to Puerto Rico's shipping phase and almost one hundred different cards ---- many of which have more than one effect ---- compared to San Juan's 30 cards, this game may never grow stale and certainly will not do so nearly as quickly as San Juan did for me. The best RftG players probably are able to spot synergistic combos of cards, an enterprise that I am neither particularly good at nor especially interested in. However, the game is enjoyable even for those of us who do not normally cotton to games with CCGish elements.

RATING: N/A
I ranked it a "7" but I really don't know how to even rank this game.  I recognize the absolute greatness of the game, and yet all the symbology is majorly confusing.  Its not just me, others are befuddled as well. We constantly have to look up the symbols.  And sometimes the specific one isn't there, you have to infer from other symbols in the rule book.  

It never hits the gaming table any more because of this issue.  I'm not at all opposed to giving it more of a chance, but there are just too many other games out there to bother with it at this point.  Which is too bad.  (somehow Core Worlds makes up for it?)

I'll keep it, hoping that some day (in a fantasy world) I'll break it out with someone who is an expert instructor.

Bought it for 21,95€ at buecher.de.

[2008-10-28]
What can I say? Race for the Galaxy (RtfG) is a great game. If you like San Juan but think that its gameplay gets a little repetitive in the end, then RftG should be right for you. Tons of different cards guarantee a wide range of possible strategies. 
But there is also a fair word of warning: Learning this game and it's strategies means WORK. This is okay for me, but some people I know and play with don't want to put that much effort into a game. First you have to deal with all the icons and even guys that I normally consider great gamers had problems in dealing with them. Even after 15 games they still had to look up some of them in the manual. It wouldn't surprise me, if a lot of people quit playing the game because they can't get their head around the icons. I finally managed to understand them (after ~10 Games) but I'm still not convinced that they're the best way to present the abilities of the cards.
Once you've got the icons down, your next task will be to learn all the different cards and find some nice combos. For me, this part is where the fun of RftG comes from. But I'm quite sure, that this aspect can become a deal breaker for some people new to the game. They won't be able to compete with more experienced players and will soon discover, that some effort is needed to play this game well. Hopefully they are willing to invest it into this great game.

+ Great replayability because of tons of possible card combos.

+ San Juan Advanced: I like the core mechanics of San Juan and RftG really enhances the experience.

o Steep learning curve: While I like it, I'm sure, quite a few people won't be willing to invest that much time in a game.

o Multiplayer Solitaire/Lack of interaction: This game doesn't really have any direct conflict or player interaction except from the role selection. And even calling this "direct conflict" is a long shot. For me, the fun of this games comes from building my own empire and dealing with the cards I've got in my hand the best way I can. But I truly understand people, who aren't satisfied by "just" optimising their cards and resources.

o/- I still don't like the icons.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Received from Secret Santa '07

If I had one word to describe this game, it would be Theme, theme, theme,... 
(OK, that's 3 words, but you get the point)

Really, I do like this game. The card art is stunning, and really enhances the play, at least for me.  I like that it has been designed very open-ended, with features that will only be used in future expansions.  I can't wait for those.

My one real problem with this game is the rules.  They are not clear at all.  In fact, in a lot of cases, they appear to be deliberately ambiguous. That makes it hard to play correctly.  All the different symbols are also difficult to learn.  I know that I've screwed up every time I've played it.  I hope that someday, I'll get a chance to play it correctly, but my game group doesn't care much for it.

Decided not to wait.  Traded if for a whole lot of GeekGold.

I've said it before, and I'll say it again.  If I want a deck-building card game, I'll stick with Magic.  I like it better.  I also like San Juan better than this.  Less complicated.

Loses half a mark for me as it's not a boardgame - I do like a spatial element to my games and also, like most card games, it still suffers from the fact that with reasonably competent players the game will be decided, regardless of the quality of play, by the cards you draw. Even so, the experience you have is still most enjoyable.

I have played 100's of times online using the marvellous Keldon version of the game.

RATING: 7
A lot like San Juan.  However this game differs in that there is very little player interaction.  You are not competing for roles.  Instead you can choose any role at any time and everyone gets to execute the action.  It turns into a little bit of blind bidding.  I don't mind it, but I mention it because I know others do.  One thing I don't like is that actions 1-3 are executed based on the action card.  Actions 4 & 5 are executed based on what cards you have in front of you.  Not very intuitive on the first play.  This is a game you need to play several times before getting a handle on how everything works.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Like this game a lot, it manages to be complex and streamlined at the same time.  Has a bit of a learning curve (managed to get some of the rules wrong even into the third game), but the iconography is really well designed and ultimately it's not as hard to master as it first seems.  A bit random (like any card drawing game) but still has a lot of strategic depth.  Would like to try the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Race For the Galaxy was one of the first games that I played when getting into designer board games, and it stands as the one that has sat in my Top 10 for the longest. This comes from both its exceptional longevity and its exceptional quality. There are few games that I have encountered that combined its sheer replayability and great depth. Even now, with almost 400 plays under my belt, I still encounter new situations and new strategies, things that surprise and delight, and cement this in my mind as the pinnacle of the variable action selection games. 

That is not to say I do not appreciate Glory to Rome, Puerto Rico, and San Juan, I really do, but they lack the sheer variability and strategic expanse that Race For the Galaxy has to offer. Each decision has a tremendous, yet suble, impact on the overall game state, creating constant hurdles that the players must react against, either taking advantage of the opportunities that are offered, or ignoring them and hoping that the tempo loss can be made up for elsewhere. Each card drawn creates a new opportunity for the development of an individual's galactic empire, and deciding which of these will provide the greatest chance for victory and which are false paths that will only lead to ruin only adds to the games replayability. 

Puerto Rico lacks Race For the Galaxy's variety, exchanging that for a lower level of luck. San Juan lacks Race For the Galaxy's variety but also has more luck than Puerto Rico. The only real advantage it has over Race For the Galaxy is its relative simplicity. While a few may find that preferable, I do not. I am no longer interested in "gateway games." Glory to Rome has even more luck than Race For the Galaxy, but lacks much of its variety. It is still an interesting games, but doesn't quite measure up to Race For the Galaxy's elegance and tension.

RATING: 5
good mechanics though slightly complicated to learn at first. Very abstract and relates little to theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Players are developing a trading empire in space.  Players simultaneously reveal an action card which defines the action phases played this turn - take cards, build developments and worlds, earn cash and victory points, produce stuff.  The idea is to build an efficient economic engine that churns out this stuff.  I'm not sure of the history, but this is 70% San Juan, 25% Puerto Rico, all bumped up a bit in complexity.  In reality it isn't complex at all, but there is a lot of stuff buried here in all the cards and associated different icons.  It will take a few games to grasp it all, for those that want to fight the insane iconography.  We didn't - San Juan suits us just fine.  

Positives?  An excellent example of bad production.

RATING: 10
Idea:
Cardgame where cards are played and act as money to pay for the played cards.

Mechanism:
Each player choose action type that they get bonus, and only chosen action types are resolved each round. (explore for new cards / play 'development' / play 'planet' / sell good for cards / sell good for points / produce goods on planets). Try to play cards that combine well with other cards and try to anticipate what actions others choose to get best advantage.

to who:
Winning needs strategy but game itself isnt too heavy, extreamely well playable 1vs1 too. To be useful for more games expansions.

Own views:
One of my wifes favourites thus one of most played 1on1 game here. Would be even better if some cards werent broken compared to their play cost.

RATING: 9.5
I like this game.   The trouble is, two of the regulars I play with don't.  I understand why they don't; in order to do well in this game you need to memorize most of the cards, or at least understand the basic ratio of the cards to know what is and is not likely to appear. I'll hold onto this game because I do like it, but I don't have much hope of getting it to the table very often with this group of fiends.

RATING: 7
Nice one
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I don't generally tend to like complex-card-games, but I've enjoyed my plays of Race quite a bit. The primary differentiation, I think, is the way Race encourages continual movement of cards through hands, which allows players to control the direction of their engine instead of forcing the players down particular narrow paths (or forcing them to dig for answers). More experienced players might feel more constrained, but after 20 plays I still find additional ways to play out hands.

The player interaction is a bit indirect for my tastes, but there's actually quite a bit of room for doublethink and playing off of opponent's phase selections. The number of special powers on each card ensure that phase selection is almost never a no-brainer; players need to take into account their own bonuses, phase selection bonuses, and the probable selections of opponents.

As befitting a complex card game, there's a ton of different cards that could potentially be memorized, but you mainly need to recognize the different classes they fall into. Production, consumption, military, and development-based seem to be the big ones, but it's possible that there's further room to explore.

All in all, I enjoy Race quite a bit, and am happy to play it with anyone capable of understanding the icons. (No mean feat, but the game is worth it.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

RATING: 6
A space race for victory points with dual-use cards.

I like that the cards have a dual use- can either be played in the tableau or discarded as currency. Unfortunately the game is not very well-balanced, and the suggested starting worlds can funnel players into pre-determined strategies, with one start world consistently having the greatest advantage.

RATING: 10
Once you get accustomed to all the symbols, this game has a nice flow. Can be a drag if someone is stalling the game by overanalysing, and some cards and combos seem very overpowered (though they are not and the perception changes with more plays). The game offers some very interesting choices both in long term strategy, and short term tactics. The replay value is massive. There are just so many different strategies to explore. Excellent game that I expect will be played for a very long time. Gets played at least a few times almost every game night.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I initially had mixed feelings about this game.  Seemed over-rated, and the complete lack of interaction (apart from second-guessing your opponent's action card) made it a tough sell.  However, there seems to be a ton of potential here that the expansions might capitalize on. And the CCG-like hunt for card combos makes it always interesting to play.  But there is absolutely nothing you can do to stop someone who gets their efficiency engine up and running early, and midway through the game you can tell if you will lose.   On the plus side, it plays really fast once you get past the iconography learning curve.  The icons are excellent, and art is too, although much of it is far too darkly printed.  I have a sneaky suspicion that part of the reason people are reacting so positively to this game is because light Euros with a cool sci-fi theme are so very rare.  Often one play isn't enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I remember how much I liked my first game of Race, and I still do.  It's a quick, fun game with lots of different cards, many potential building strategies, good scaling with any number of players, and attractive theme/art.  

I have to complain about every game, though, so I may as well begin.  Obviously, it's a card game with a shared deck.  That means that you can get an initial hand (or continuing draws) that does nothing to advance the build you've chosen or lacks any synergy with the start world you were dealt (or any internal synergies).  Yes, you can keep selecting explore to try and draw into some better stuff, but the game isn't that long, and the other players who've drawn better cards will be pulling away.
I'm not sure that all the builds are equally balanced in the base game.  It feels like produce/consume is a bit easier to do than military, and specialized stuff like alien or dev is going to be tough.  This is far from certain, though.  
Oh, and the iconography, while consistent and fairly understandable, is always a pain to try and teach to new players.  Some of them get it, some of 'em don't.

Anyway, this is still getting played, and I expect it will for many years to come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A shorter card version of Puerto Rico in space.  Less fiddly but also much more difficult to process in my opinion until 4-5 plays and enjoy the theme and visuals of PR better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Several times it has felt like the winner is the person who surprises everyone else near the end of the game by playing a high-scoring card that combines with what they've built so far.

Compare this to the way powerful cards are added to a tableau in Glory to Rome: the cards become visible, then they're be completed on a later turn. The more powerful the card, the longer it takes to complete.

In Race for the Galaxy, powerful cards can be added without players having to publicly show progress to add them.

It makes the game feel luckier, less tense, and less interactive.

Also, the game's complexity seems too high for its length.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.8

If this game catches on with my family and it can show that it has re playability it's rating could go much higher. Time will tell. I hope it caches on.

Update: It did catch on, rating went up. Went up again.

RATING: 10
This is a phenomenon when it comes to Sci-Fi titles. Even though it's just a few cards, the genre fits this game perfectly not only because you can fell how your personal galactic empire grows under your directive, but also thanks to some common mechanics characteristic for (let's call them) much heavier brothers like TI which immediately come to mind (even though it's a different title entirely). RFTG is a very quick game once you get a hold of all the possible actions (there aren't all that many), however the amount of possible routes you can take while planning each move would suggest otherwise - yet another phenomenon of RFTG. Love it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pretty much two-player solitaire with just a bit of interaction. And yet, it's two-player solitaire that I love to play. The iconography takes a few plays to get used to the nuances, but after that it actually is very intuitive. Reasonably short play (between 15-30 minutes per game), but when you finish a game, you want to start right up with another. I'm a little concerned about the long-term replayability, but for now, I'm really enjoying it. Not surprisingly, somewhat similar to San Juan and I recommend you play San Juan before you play this, but they still scratch different itches, so it's worth picking up both. Enjoy!

RATING: 9.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.47
Wonderful and justifiably praised space civilization building card game. Player's turns are simultaneous with each player selecting a strategy for that turn Puerto Rico (San Juan, TI3) style giving all other players secondary ability of the chosen strategy. That is one of my favourite mechanics in board games.
Also cards can be installed to players talon as planets or upgrades, or spent face down as resources.

The game is basically race for the win, which gets better with the first expansion, but player interaction is limited only to strategy selection so it feels a lot like a multiplayer solitaire. This changes with adding more expansions.

[b]Edit:[/b] Upgraded to 8.5 with Gathering Storm expansion.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Like in Puerto Rico, role selection which gives everybody the same action but gives an exclusive bonus to the player who selected the role.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
trade note; includes first three expansions, only one box, which has shelf ware, but otherwise in very good condition. Also, i'd sell it all for £40.


I'm fairly late to the party on this. At a mechanical level this is a card engine building game. Play cards that allow you to play more cards, develop combos, earn lots of victory points. It uses the action selection mechanism from Puerto Rico but feels a lot more like Glory to Rome or Fleet in play. I'm not sure whether i prefer it to those other two games though.

having played a dozen or so games i have started to get it. Its a decent enough game but doesn't really rock my world. It is largely a game about knowing the cards and seeing the best combo's/build orders. The expansions mostly just add clutter imo. Though the extra cards are cool.

RATING: 7.5

Something I would play again, but not buy.

I might now consider getting this game in my collection.

RATING: 8
2013-08-19 : Played it a lot on the computer and a couple of times vs humans - after 50 plays it feels a bit played out, but still a solid 9
2015-03-03 : Haven't played it since, which means I'm in no hurry to play it again anytime soon, so the rating drops 
2016-10-07 : Finally hit the table again and I'm once again reminded of how fine a design this is. After so many years my mojo for playing it is back.
2017-05-27 : Installed the game on the pc again and after a rusty start - a dozen losses in a row - finally managed a win again - 35 points in 11 rounds and a win on the cards in hand tiebreaker. This is without a doubt the toughest AI for any game out there.

RATING: 9
UPDATE: I still love RFTG, but I'm afraid to use the second expansion (haven't even gotten the third) because I'm concerned that the game is really getting bloated from its original roots of a shortish card game to one that is way too long and complicated for what it is. (I still feel that RFTG and RvI is one of my top games and am looking forward to the eventual publishing of Alien Artifacts.)

UPDATE: Giving it a 10 now with the first expansion. A great game and not as hard to decipher the cards as the haters will tell you.

The only reason that I haven't rated this one a 10 yet is because I'm late to the Race for the Galaxy party.

This is a fantastic game with a lot of the things I really enjoy -- building an economic machine but not getting hosed by turn order (cough*Puerto Rico*cough) and of course, I like the sci-fi theme instead of Yet Another Rennaisance Trading Game. It's a great collectible card-like game without the massive expense.

The game seems balanced without having the One Clear Path to Victory, and there's the possibility for more expansion packs.

RATING: 10
Have just played for the first time. Initially rather bewildering but we had got the hang of it by the end and will certainly be trying it out again! Rating upgraded after playing a couple more times. It doesn't have the simple elegance of San Juan, but is certainly worth a go. Having played several more times, with various numbers of players, I've upgraded my rating even further - it certainly grows on you, plays quickly enough for several games in succession to be viable and hasn't got boring. Having played quite a few more times I have upgraded my rating to 10 - I'm always happy to play it. It's taken 6 months to get there for me but it's done it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
San Juan is often considered to be a similar game to Puerto Rico that's less complicated and in card form. RFTG is a step up in complexity when compared to San Juan and probably at a similar level to Puerto Rico. The most notable thing about the game is the iconography which tends to drive some people crazy due to being too complex or swoon over how elegant the icons match the effects of a card allowing it to be deduced at a glance. I fall into the second category and look forward to exploring the deep strategies which are in the game and the two expansions that are currently released. This is really good, especially considering how much I enjoyed the San Juan which doesn't have nearly as much diversity. Even if San Juan was as diverse the role selecting mechanism in Race for the Galacxy is definitely more enjoyable. A very good game!! Race for the Galaxy fired Puerto Rico, for me.

Upon further plays of just the base game, I consider at least one of the expansions to be mandatory to get the best enjoyment out of Race. That's the only reason why I rate the base game a 7.

RATING: 9
Even though I often feel that there is not enough player interaction in Race for the Galaxy, I still love it.  I love how there are so many strategies which can evolve based on the cards you're dealt.

I did co-create an Variant which increases the player interaction by adding the concept of Solar Systems.  It's too long to describe in detail here, but essentially the military is localized, there are bonuses for developing non-military worlds of certain types in certain solar systems, and there are takeover rules.  It's a lot of fun 2 player but I haven't tried it with 3+.

RATING: 6
Of the Puerto Rico style games, this sits near the bottom; its a bit better than San Juan, but doesn't wag a finger at Puerto Rico or Roll for the Galaxy. The secret Phase/Role selection is great, and inserts a level of deduction into the game, but more often than not I find myself simply selecting phases based on which privilege is the most beneficial, rather than trying to piggyback off of my opponents, making the gameplay too straightforward for my tastes. It also plays too quickly and prevents players from becoming invested in the world's and developments their are using to build out their tableau.

RATING: 8
Advanced San Juan.  There's a bit of a learning curve with all the specific iconography.  Every player always has every role available to them, and there's many more cards, with less duplication than San Juan.  The deck is also larger, and you'll see less "burn" through the deck as in San Juan.  If you like San Juan, you'll probably like this, particularly if you like science fiction.  The game seems very "tight".

RATING: 8
Rated just based on online plays

Great game. Variety of cards makes it highly replayable and interesting. Very mechanically elegant and wonderfully strategic as well as tactical.

I consider the lack of interaction only a slight downside. The use of cards as the only resource is kind of a feel-bad mechanic because you have to give up some possibilities to make progress. It's especially bad if all of the cards you draw have some level of synergy with each other and you have to choose which ones are worth keeping.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
You wanted San Juan with a little more? Here it is. Not as elegant a system because of VP chits, but also adds another aspect because the game can end when you run them out. No more player position problems because roles are chosen simultaniously. 
Main drawback to this game is that it is hard to look at opponent's cards and tell what they can do. This is necessary for good play.

Is there still a place for San Juan on my shelf? I think so, as it is more accessible to the non-gamer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun card game, about establishing a powerful galatic presence. You start off with a single homeworld, and work towards adding new worlds and new assets to your territory. Each round lets players explore, invest in developments, settle planets, consume and produce resources. Developments, planets, and resources provide a few different ways to get victory points. slightly overwhelming to begin with, the game only takes a few rounds though before it all makes sense, and all of the vast symbols used start to make sense.

RATING: 9
An all-time favorite.  Playable in 20-30 minutes, but contains the best elements of Puerto Rico, streamlined into a CCG-style format.  If I could rate the combination of this plus The Gathering Storm expansion it would be a solid 10 - nearly infinitely replayable with hundreds of strategic routes available, not to mention a fun solitaire variant.  Lowest luck factor of any card game I've played, as a good player can adapt to nearly any draw.  I can't imagine ever getting tired of this.

RATING: 7
(As of [b]6+[/b] plays) A hand-management card game with great depth but also an almost off-puttingly steep learning curve. The complexity that makes this such an intriguing game also makes it feel a bit too fiddly to properly enjoy without committing lots of familiarization time to it. Several unlogged solo plays with [url=http://www.keldon.net/rftg/]Keldon's RftG AI[/url], but not something that hits the actual table very often.

[b]1 year verdict:[/b] Still a good game, even though it doesn't get any face-to-face plays. Keldon's AI has replaced Solitaire for me as my go-to computer time-wasting game.

RATING: 9
I love the concept of racing (no pun intended) to build the most valuable empire through either colonization and treaty or conquest. The role selection and multiple uses of cards are seen in other games but are well established here.

One detractor is the complex language of symbols used to identify card bonuses. This has proved, for me, to be a consistent hindrance to introducing new players to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
(Rating including expansions: [thing=40210]Rebel vs Imperium[/thing], [thing=66121]The Brink of War[/thing])

It may take a while to get into because of the iconography, but it's actually done pretty intuitively and the game comes with thorough player aids.

However, I do agree that the game is much easier to learn if someone teaches the game than straight from the rulebook.

It may feel a bit solitary, because there's no direct player interaction. Nonetheless, you still have to closely watch what other people are doing so you know which phases to pick. It takes a few games to get the hang of it, but once you do it plays fast and offers tons of replayability even without the expansions. What I also love about this game is that there's almost zero setup time and it plays vastly different each time depending on your starting planet and your starting hand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Players' copy of the first edition.  Cards show some wear, but otherwise in very good condition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
Extremely fast game that is entertaining from beginning to end. Every game is different and there is a ton of strategic depth that has yet to be explored. Each game you have to maximize your own tableau while also remembering that this game is a race against your opponents. Do you end the game early so that your opponents do not have time to create a production engine or do you wait it out and starve your opponent of the victory point tokens? High replayability. Do not see this game leaving the collection anytime soon or quite possibly ever.

RATING: 9
Why is a game that is essentially a San Juan makeover so fascinating and fun?  Probably because it brings the basic idea of San Juan to new heights through avenues such as production/consumption matching, military conquest, and development strategies.  The result is a game that is fresh and exciting every time.  Yes, there's a bit of a learning curve, but after a few games (which only run 30 minutes tops) you've got it down.  After that it is a joy to explore the many ways that the cards can work together.

RATING: 10
7 plays - 7/10: it's enjoyable but i don't know where to even begin strategically, which doesn't motivate me to play it again.


10 plays - 8/10: I'd decided to give this a second chance just in case.  I'm definitely enjoying it more as i play it and figure it out more.


15 plays - 9/10: Love it, but the icon system and consume phase are counter-intuitive.  It's also taking me a long time to figure out consume strategies, and i have difficulty playing hands without obvious synergies.


25 plays - 10/10: and there we have it, that says it all.  I now realize the reason it took me a long time to understand and enjoy the game was that my teacher didn't do a great job.  I will be teaching this to many people and they will like it a lot better a lot faster cuz i'll do it right.

67 plays (265 incl. TGS) - 9/10: downgraded this to reflect that despite loving r4tg, TGS is a hell of a lot better.

89 plays (467 incl. TGS/RvI) - 9.9/10: what i should have downgraded it to in the first place, just that i don't really use decimal ratings.

264 plays - 10: remains at this rating. While the base game feels a little simplistic and routine after more than 2,000 plays of various Race formats, it's still the grandaddy/foundation of all variations of by far the best game to date, and therefore an automatic 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Lovely fast, portable game, with depth.  Great with 2 players, or with 3 or 4.  It only really gets rewarding after a few plays, however.  

No need for expansions, the base game plays very well for hundreds of plays, making it great value for money.

There is a significant learning curve - the learners will have to want to learn to play it, or will have to have some patience.  Their first couple of plays may be a little overwhelming - too much to read.  I normally suggest they go for a military victory, as that allows them to pay less attention to the cards' produce and consume bonuses and to focus mostly on the first 3 phases (explore, develop, settle).

RATING: 10
Great game. You'll have trouble talking non-gamers into giving it a chance, and many gamers prefer Roll for the Galaxy due to its ease of entry. But this game really rewards repeat play.  There are so many different strategies that can lead to a win that it continually feels fresh.

I strongly recommend that before playing live, players download the free pc version of the game and practice playing against the AI (which is very well programmed). Knowledge of the cards and the kinds of possible strategies is key. Playing with the AI will immensely help new players overcome the initial barriers to entry.

RATING: 8
My only complaint is that the box is too big.  I know their excuse is so that expansions will fit, and the full-side reference cards are nice, but I would have preferred an FFG-style 8"x4" box instead.

Rating based on my one play so far, taught it to three coworkers.  Spent a lot of time looking at the reference cards, and had to check the rules twice.  Halfway thru the game I felt like I understood all of the icons.  I love games where the cards have multiple uses, and the fact that many cards enter and leave play face down means that you never see the entire deck.  I'm an engineer by trade, and this game's design seems exceptionally elegant and appealing to me.

Okay, played it again 2p today, and was able to pay closer attention to what my opponent was doing.  We didn't play with the advanced extra role cards, and there were several occasions that we managed to pick the same action.

Many people have complained about the relatively low player interaction in this game.  That actually appeals to me -- I like my games to be friendly, and sometimes direct confrontation is contrary to that goal.  As others have pointed out, there is still plenty of interaction; you are always trying to figure out what everybody else is going to do so that you can call the action you *really* need for yourself.

I can't stop thinking about this game.  Last time I obsessed like this was for RRT, and that game has a much greater setup and time commitment, along with the sinking feeling that a bad opening move can ruin your entire game.  RftG on the other hand seems much more fluid, although I can see the complaints that just as you really get things rolling the game ends.  But that just means that you have to plan your tableau carefully to maximize your victory points.

This may be a bit presumptuous, but I think this is going to be my first "ten" after a few more plays.

I've since played this four more times.  I still think pretty highly of it, but it does seem like the game always ends right when things really get rolling, usually a turn or two before you were ready.  It's sometimes frustrating to be unable to really directly affect your opponents, although that's just the nature of this game.  It's also why the game plays so quickly too, so it's a trade off I'm willing to make.

Two more plays, finally, four players.  Got spanked by somebody getting Consumer Markets down in both games.  Wasn't playing my best because I was teaching it again.

Played one more time the next day, 2p, and got Diversified Economy down instead of Consumer Markets.  Pulled 10VP on the last turn of the game for the win.

Came back again to make sure I'd changed my rating on this to a ten.  I already had.  This game is just about perfect.  One of my coworkers is addicted to it so we play almost every day now.  

Coming back several months later, I'm lowering my rating a bit because I haven't played it in a while.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have trouble ranking the base game and the different expansions separately.  I've played extensively with the first two expansions, but very little without.  To me Race for the Galaxy is RftG + RvI +TGS.  My only complaint with the base game is that you need the two expansions to get the full range of strategies. 

I think the tableau building is the part that speaks to me the most.  Individual bonuses, multiple paths to victory, relatively short playtime, incredible depth, multi-player solitaire (yes, as a positive), all make this one of my favorite games.  I can't imagine ever tiring of it.

RATING: 9
I'm a huge fan of this game.  The symbol-heavy vocabulary can be daunting to new players, but this is one of those games that really clicks after a demo round.  

The first expansion is highly recommended; it really should have been part of the base game, as it fleshes out some alternate paths to victory that are otherwise a little anemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've known how to play this game since it came out and never really enjoyed it. I always just found it too complicated. After playing San Juan extensively one summer I wanted something more and picked up three expansions and the base game. I also played a ton against the keldon AI to learn the cards. 

I really don't think there is any game out there that has so much depth that can be playing in under 20 minutes. I find it highly enjoyable now. 

I'd suggest make a friend learning San Juan until you both bored, pick up Race, learn the keldon AI gradually adding the expansions and 2 player advanced, and then duke it out ftf using just the first two expansions with no takeovers. 

For me this game took a lot of work - not because of the symbols - its just a hard game to learn how to play. Totally worth the effort!

RATING: 6.5
I can see why this is attracting so much attention, and there's a lot here for hardened gamers, but there's a basic problem. It's a solitaire game. No inter-action. Yes, it's true that you can look at other people's tableaux and try to decide their action, and that can affect your own choice. But essentially you are playing your hand alone. I also mark it down because it's not a game you can play straight from the box (unless you've a brain the size of a planet). You need a learning game at least, and that's a negative mark in my book. Plus, a lot of the rules conditions are fiddly, tiny little symbols on the card qualify rules, and that causes confusion. RFTG is clearly a very good game, and presses all the buttons for PR/St Petersburg fans. But it's not quite my cup of tea and it's not all that. Nice graphics, nice cards, nice theme, not all that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

While the "lack of interaction" has been cited by many, I think there's plenty of interaction in the simultaneous bidding that needs to be mastered if one wants to win a significant percentage of games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating includes The Gathering Storm. This rating is for two-player advanced. With other player counts, I would probably rate this game somewhere between 7 or 7.5.

The simultaneous action selection of Race for the Galaxy makes the ability to predict and take advantage of other players' actions and strategies very important. It's a subtle form of player interaction, but it's important enough to keep Race for the Galaxy from being simply multiplayer solitaire. Two-player advanced is my favorite way of playing the game, due to being able to choose two actions per turn. This greatly quickens the pace of the game, and the high number of action combinations greatly increases the strategy involved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Similar to 7 Wonders in overarching game play mechanics, but with a much stronger strategy and luck of the draw aspect. With 7 Wonders, I find myself only having to think one or two turns ahead, while I find myself planning three to four turns again with RftG.

The luck component can be a little frustrating at times, severely hindering what you can and can't do, but I suspect much of this can be mitigated by better deck shuffling. Another thing to become accustomed to is the idea of discarding potentially great cards, especially when you're used to games with little or no discard mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Experienced players will beat an inexperienced player 10 out of 10 plays.  Skill is less important than knowing the cards.  Traded!

RATING: 9
This game took me by surprise. While I was initially irriated by the pasted on theme and the complexity of the interactions between the cards, I eventually broke down and gave it a try. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Though generally not a fan of card based games, Race for the Galaxy intrigued me, with its space theme and also its claim to essentially be a less involved Puerto Rico; both of these promises convinced me to put aside my prejudices and pick it up.  As far as I'm concerned, it as more than lived up to both of these promises, and I've enjoyed the dozen and a half or so games I've gotten out of Race for the Galaxy so far.  While initially it seemed the game was unbalanced towards a military victory, after multiple playthroughs (and discarding the preset starting packages in favor of a random starting hand with each of the homeworlds), I've discovered using economic or Six-point card avenues to victory are just, if not more valid, and I feel I've just begun to scratch the surface of options and strategies.  The card tableau each player builds also acts as a decent replacement for a board, which makes the game more visually and practically agreeable for me as well.  One of my few major dislikes, is the underwhelming feeling of what is in the box, however: you only get a bunch of cards and some markers.  It is a great game nonetheless, but I did feel a bit disappointed and ripped off after paying for it and opening the box.

While I'd still rather play Puerto Rico more often than not, Race for the Galaxy has a unique vibe of its own, while also being significantly faster paced and easier to set up, earning its reputation as a great game in its own right.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It was my favorite game until a [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/124742/android-netrunner]certain[/url] cyberpunk LCG took the crown, but it keeps a very close second place. After literally thousands of plays, I still manage to find nuances in this deep game which can be played in five minutes online, or twenty face to face. I am convinced RftG is inexhaustible, even without a single expansion (but [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/34499/race-galaxy-gathering-storm]The Gathering Storm[/url] completes the game). It is difficult to find real life partners for regular play, specially after developing some expertise in the game, so I mostly play [url=http://en.boardgamearena.com/#!gamepanel?game=raceforthegalaxy]online[/url]. Nevertheless, this already is, and probably will always be, the single game I have played most in my life.

RATING: 10
[b]Takes the best of Puerto Rico, broadens out the strategic possibilities, and shrinks gameplay to less than 30 minutes. Incredible game design. I do think this is a better (and quicker) game than Roll for the Galaxy as well.

[b]After 40 plays...[/b] I'm going to go as far as to say that, with one expansion, this is one of the best games ever designed. Right behind Agricola. I feel as though the more I play it, the better and deeper the game reveals itself to be. So many ways to approach getting your victory.

[b]After 10 plays...[/b]I traded it away a long time ago, and realized I'd made a mistake. One of the best euro cardgames of all time. Affordable, expandable, quick to play. Excellent stuff.

It took me about 6 months to convince my wife to try it, and now it is one of her favourite games.

[i]I got this as a birthday present, got bored of it and sold it off. I reacquired it from a friend who wasn't really interested in it. I bought an expansion for it and was smitten by gameplay.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dense, deep game with a short playing time and low downtime (due to simultaneous turns), and varied and emergent strategies.

Interaction is limited to leeching, playing cards that influence opponent phase choices, claiming goals, forcing consumption, and ending the game. There is little resource denial and you can generally pursue your strategy without interference, though you'll benefit from watching, predicting and exploiting opponents' actions.

The game has been extensively playtested and balanced, and it shows in the multitude of synergistic plays that you can adapt on-the-fly. Every turn, you make hard decisions about which strategies you want to pursue and which opportunities you'll give up for others.

The space colonisation theme is very well integrated into the gameplay; note that military conflict is deliberately circumscribed to skirmishes. As you play, you can form mini-narratives of the fortunes of your galactic empires.

Duration: Fast and with simultaneous turns.
Design: Fantastically balanced, with lots of different potential strategies and styles of play. Interaction is indrect and limited, but you'll lose if you ignore it.
Strategy: You need to watch your opponents and guess their moves (but don't have to). You must be flexible with your strategies, and combine smaller pieces into larger ones.
Components: The art is great, coherent, follows the theme and cards sturdy. Icons are logical, but there are lots of them.
Theme: Nicely integrated into the cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
This game was an instant favorite, and is my absolute favorite card game. It is very similar to San Juan, but with a sci-fi theme. I'm not a huge sci-fi game fan, but the theme doesn't deter me. If this game was about grass growing, it would still be fun. There is a great deal of depth of strategy, and a definite learning curve that is fun on the way up. I really like games that involve combining cards in multiple ways (i.e. to score points and to "power up" your civilization). To me, this is San Juan on steroids, since the 6 point developments (think "big buildings" from that game) are useful early in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8



This game is a huge pile of card combos.  I guess I'm a card combo junkie....  At first the icons turned me off (big time) but I realized most of the information you needed was in text on the cards.  But even a haphazard first play made me pick up a copy.  I'm very interested in one deck, transportable card games that are deep and Race for the Galaxy has those elements.  Easy to set up and not as fiddly as San Juan.  This game gets better with plays and may well become a favorite.  Excellent, imaginative artwork and great production values as well.  Try it, it's worth learning!  I'm not a fan of space themes but it works great here-very creative.   Love the quick set up,  portability and the fact that it plays great with two.

Update:  Feels much bigger and solid that Dominion, which is good to me.  I still like Race and hope to play it more despite the crazy amount of icons!  To it's credit, Race feels like more of a board game than quick card game.

RATING: 6.5
It took 30 players for me to realize that I just don't like it. Everyone talks a lot about how much strategy, long term planning and fun is in this game. I just don't get it. I won more times out of luck than planning ahead. So many strategies are subject to a couple of specific cards and you generally have to "waste" all your turns just trying to find those cards only to have them drawn randomly by another player who doesn't need them but holds on to them for a little while because it's pretty obvious that you need it.
Basically you just get cards into your hand, buy the best one using less helpful cards. Repeat. I may sound jaded, but after 30 plays, I didn't see much else.

RATING: 7
[b]Design:- [/b]:star::star::star::star::nostar:  [i]Multifunctional card game with simultaneous role-selection; inevitable comparison to San Juan.[/i]
[b]Execution:- [/b]:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:  [i]Close to multiplayer solitaire; I feel the expansion may be a necessity.[/i] 
[b]Experience:- [/b]:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:  [i]Play seems a touch slow; however moves quite quickly after a few plays.[/i]
[b]Presentation:- [/b]:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:  [i]Appreciate the art, iconography could have been better implemented.[/i]

Comparisons to San Juan do not do this game justice; most importantly because the role-selection does not work in the same (or even a similar) fashion, but also because of the way victory points are attained.

I think this game will improve with the expansion, which I intend to try just as soon as I can.  I expect more interaction out of the game with the expansion; right now there just isn't enough.

RATING: 8
The game clearly borrow a lot of elements from San Juan (and by extension, Puerto Rico). Still, it feels fresh and the various possible strategies all look like they can be played efficiently. One drawback is that cards can be used as "money" or as "buildings", so you are always reading them to decide which ones to keep and which ones to drop. Add to that the huge number of special actions and the somewhat obscure iconography and it makes the game feel heavier than it really is. Another downside is the especially low amount of player interaction, and that coming from someone who considers that both San Juan and Puerto Rico have a lot of interaction.

Rating went up. Somehow this game is growing on me!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
SO MANY ways to get the victory.! SO MANY ways to combine your cards! Make your "hand" work properly is a constant challenge...
More tactical than strategical game, Race for the Galaxy (RftG) challenges you every turn: Every new game round will put you into a "limbo" in wich most choices will lead you thru uncertainty and, probably, to victory... ¡Feel the panic folks!
Most choices are difficult to be taken, because you never know exactly wich is the best option to take. 
One of my favourite aspects of RftG is that it's as deep as Puerto Rico, for example, but it's dynamic and fast paced! In addition, a game of RftG normally takes between 30 to 60 minutes and everybody plays simultaneously... So, you'll never feel boring!
What else can I say... I really love this "space exploration themed" game!

WANT TO PLAY MORE AND MORE!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Classic! Phenomenal with two players - but also scales smoothly with up to five!

RATING: 8
Kicsit nehezen állt össze, de számítottam is rá, mert hallottam már az ikonok nehézkes olvashatóságáról.
Viszont mikor kezdett összeállni, nagyon jó lett. Két játékkal még érezhetően nagyon az út elején járunk, és valószínűleg még csak sejtéseink lehetnek a játékban rejlő kombinációs mélységekről.
Így elsőre nem igazán volt energiánk figyelni a grafikákra, tematikára, de amit láttam az nagyon jópofa, hangulatos volt.
Egyetlen egy dolog nem állt teljesen össze: mintha kicsit hamar véget érne a játék. Pont mikor kezdene beindulni a gőzgép, már vége is. Így a military erősebbnek hatott a termeléseknél. 

Majd meglátjuk még. Mindenképp kell még játszani vele. 

8

Jópár játék után már annyira nem a szívem csücske. Iszonyat nagy benne a szerencsefaktor. Egyetlen dolog, ami elviszi az a hangulat, mivel a kártyák neve és illusztrációja nagyon jó és nagyon tematikus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm growing to like this game, but I still have a lot to learn about it. Really want to sit down and look through all the cards some time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Just got this, finally. My latest gamer pals play this all the time, seriously. I think their feeling is that a game night is not complete if they haven't played it at least once. I'm beginning to feel that way too, although I must admit that I'm not very good at the game. The number of choices available at any one time is pretty bewildering, and I have trouble narrowing down what I should do. I also have a vague suspicion that I make bad choices of which cards to keep and which to use for money. But then it also seems to me that the outcome of the game is highly dependent on who gets the cards they need.

*Update*
Lately, this is my favorite game. I'm really itching for the Rebel vs. Imperium expansion to come out. I love the fact that there are so many different paths to victory. Winning takes a lot of skill, but I do still think you also have to be lucky and get the right cards.

RATING: 9

The iconography is something that will slow new players down quite a bit in the first few plays but even after only one play I didn't feel like it's as big an issue as some people make it to be. An exceptionally fine game, even though it might take a while to grow to that level of appreciation.

RATING: 6
A fun and addictive card game.  Normally I would dislike this kind of game because of the lack of direct player interaction, but it works for me in this game because it is relatively short.  The role selection mechanic works well here.  The learning curve can be steep in the beginning because of the symbol system, but after you learn it it actually makes the game easier to play.  I like the sci-fi theme (even if it is pasted on) and the art is attractive and interesting.  There is plenty of strategy to explore and I fell like I have just scratched the surface, especially with the expansions added in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.05
It's a very neat card game, with a lot of decisions, but I prefer Glory to Rome instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Have now played 100+ games - and 70+ of those were two player. I continue to find myself being sucked into this game. For the first time in a long time, I am studying strategies and cards and combinations. I believe this game allows for the development of more skillful play with additional experience. Few Euros seem to have this quality beyond the first 3-4 games. After that, there seems to be little room for continued skill development. Not so with RftG, apparently. I'm still learning subtleties and the use of the various cards - and can hardly wait for the expansion. In addition, we are developing a following of players in our gaming group. We now need two copies of the game to accommodate everyone, but they are out of print, so we will have to wait a bit.
Af 45 plays we began to see games ending very quickly in 2-player. We generally know by the 2nd or 3rd turn who will win (bad thing). Especially if one player has Tourist World placed and a couple of production worlds. He simply gets too many points per turn. In one of our recent games, I started with Earth's Lost Colony and managed to place Refugee World on the first turn (Novelty "0" cost windfall). But, my opponent played "Consume: Trade" and I traded Refugee World for 1 VP. On my second turn I dropped Tourist World and produced on both Refugee World and ELC. Turn 3 I Consumed X 2 & Produced for 6 VPs. On turn 4 my opponent Settled, allowing me to drop Space Port (Cost 2 Novelty world). I again Consumed X 2 for 6 VPs (now had 13) and Produced on all 3 worlds. On turn 4, I Consumed X 2 on all three using Tourist World for 6 VPs and ELC to consume the good on Space Port for another 2 = 8 VPs. I now had 21 VPs. Turn 5 was a repeat and ended the game. I had 29 VP chips plus 5 VPs on my 4 worlds = 33 points. My opponent didn't have a chance. We both knew by the 2nd turn that I had won, but we continued playing to see if there was anything he could do. He built twice every turn (was very lucky in setting down 2 Military worlds for free each turn and drawing enough cards from "Consume: Trade" to keep getting military worlds he could play! He had most of his points in his Tableau, but still only had 23 or so points. 
We have found the same problem with Global Trendsetters, though to a lesser degree. Since then we have played 2 player games without those two cards and they almost spell certain victory if placed early.

Trade

I like the idea of a short space empire game but the 12 card tableau or 20 odd victory chit endings leave no time to develop strategies.

RATING: 6
I've never played a game where I vacillate so much on my rating. I really do think that having fun while playing RftG is very dependent on who you are playing it with and the long-range strategy that falls in your lap with your first number of draws. RftG is one of those games that is totally mind-numblingly boring when you are waiting for other people to play their turn. There is absolutely nothing to think about when you are waiting. Also unfortunate, some players can take a long time as they puzzle over their hand (when their hand is large) while players with small hands make quick and predictable moves. That kind of unbalance can be upsetting if players are not working at the same pace. Never have I played a game where it could be either exciting or a hell pit of dragging on. I still greatly admire the game for its mechanics and artwork.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favorite games and one I've played probably hundreds of times against human and Keldon AI alike (heavily favoring AI, of course).  Multiple paths to victory.  Nearly perfect balance between the strategies.  The game allows you to strategize, but forces you to adapt as the game progresses.  Agonizing decisions regarding which cards to play and which to use as currency.  There is even a fertile meta-game to explore once you've got a grasp on the card strategies.

The only negatives I can see is that the learning curve for this game is STEEP due to the symbols and sheer number of different cards.  Yet these also become strengths after struggling through the initial plays, so...I guess they're not negatives at all.

RATING: 9
Played Race for the galaxy for the first time today. Played with my girlfriend and we both enjoyed it alot. I watched a couple of introduction videos here on BGG before the game and got a good grip of the rules pretty quick. My gf had some difficulty understanding all the icons but within 1½ hour we had finished our first game. Lots of strategy still to be learned of course but the complains about the steep learningcurve was a bit overrated imo. As I said I've only tried it once so far but my first impression is that Rftg is a fun game with lots of depth yet still playable in 30 min with 2 players. It seems to work perfect for us, being parents to two small children, having trouble ever finding time to finish a game lasting more than an hour. Rating it an 8 after one game. 101226 Edit: Played two more games last night and am now rating it a 9. Maybe that says something? ;-)

RATING: 8
Meh... the theme doesn't interest me. It was as good a game as I expected it to be and have heard it is.

Although it can be fun to choose a strategy and execute it, it's very frustrating to choose a strategy and then never again see a relevant card. It seems that the winner of the game is going to be the guy whose cards best match the strategy that he started with. I've won several games through no real fault of my own, and badly badly lost some where I knew exactly what I was doing. The players are very much at the mercy of the cards.

RATING: 8.5
Initial impression: The more I play this game the less I like it. Super random, you need to have a majority of the cards memorized to know what you're doing ... not fun. 
(Rating 6)

20+ games: After giving this game a chance I can see the appeal.  The randomness is still troublesome but there are some strategy aspects which can be interesting.  You really need to play this game 10+ times to get a feel for it.

100+ games: A fun, fast game.  Huge learning curve & a bit of luck, but definitely enjoyable -if you can slug through a ton of games.

RATING: 8.4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Having not played this in a while, I look back with a much different attitude than I had at first play.  My first play and this was an 8, second through fourth it dropped slightly to a seven.  Race now stands where I believe it truly belongs at a 5.   I don't find that it vastly improves on San Juan, in fact I think all the icons and muted colors slow down and make game play more complex (and not in a good way).  There really is no interaction here, and the game is totally dependent on draw and not good play once a few games have been played and people understand what is going on.  It is a clean, and well designed machine but not worth the hoopla people have been singing.  There is definitely a target audience here, and they will love it, but I find myself much more in the mood to play something more substantial or interactive.  Fun doesn't come to mind when playing this, although it isn't a bad time - just "meh"  

Claims that this game has true depth astound me.  Yes there are multiple paths one can take but this is entirely dependent on initial and early card draws.  The fact that one can design a strategic plan and then never see any other card of relevance can easily mean they are dead from the out set.  The depth in game play here is easily having knowledge of the possible cards one might draw. The tactical elements are also more limited than have been given credit for.   As I stated before once players have a grasp then it is all about card draw, and Race for the Galaxy loses all of it's replay factor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Fairly tough to initially pick up as the icons are quite confusing. Once you start to get them though it becomes a lot of fun. It definitely has a San Juan feel to it and I can see the influence. Players compete to build up technologies and settle worlds. They explore, produce goods, and consume those goods. Different cards give different powers in the different phases. This is where the confusion comes in. there are literally dozens and dozens of icons that you need to decipher to understand what powers you have. 

First to 12 cards or once the VP tokens runs out causes the game to end. players add VP from planets and developments as well as tokens earned with powers. High score wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Also own: all 3 expansions.  All cards are sleeved and boxed in a special storage system.  We pimped this out with cubes and tracking dice to show you military capabilities. We also made extra chits to advertise takeover cards held.  I produced a full-color half-page sized booklet that integrates all the icon references.

Over 100 plays now... which is extraordinary for me for any game.  I can still see myself playing this one again and again.  There is a learning curve, but in our case we were understanding and reading all the symbols quickly by the end of the first game.

The expansions do what expansions should and give the game new life.  

The player aid is fantastic... but only for beginners.  After a few plays you don't need it any more.  A better aid would include info on the distribution of cards in the deck so you can make informed choices: e.g. "I wonder what the odds are of drawing another "Alien" card..."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the game that San Juan should have been.

RATING: 10
This game is so great that I think I may have to go back and lower some of the games that I gave 10's. The first few games were confusing because I had to learn the icons, and I had no idea how to play well. Now that I understand the game I can't stop playing it. 

There are lots of strategies and choices.

At first I was a little nervous that learning all the icons might make the game way too confusing. This is not the case. Once the icons are learned, the game flows very smoothly. If I need to find out what bonuses I get for a specific round, I just scan my eyes across the icons, which is much more efficient than reading a block of text on each card.

This game is very, very well done. It's obvious that a ton of playtesting went into it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
While I'm afraid that the 1-2 game "learning curve" hurdle will eventually lead to some difficulty in introducing new players to the game, I am otherwise enthralled with this gem. It packs more game into 30-45 minutes than many 2-3 hour "classics". 

Take Chris Farrell's advice & don't show newbies the player aids until you've taught them the rules. As well, since the game is short enough, talk new players into agreeing to play twice (because the first game is mainly about learning the system.)

This is NOT, btw, "Sci-Fi San Juan" - I don't like San Juan, and this is quickly becoming a Top Ten game for me!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There was a point where I really doubted this game, but it latched on to my brain like no other card game. The art is mostly great. I'm a sucker for sci-fi games.

It took a few games for the iconography to set in...which makes it difficult to teach instantly to others. The base game is mostly solitaire, but you can force people in to spending their cards before the action they picked comes up. (ie screwage!)

It's amazingly balanced however, and I keep coming back to it. It's my goal to get everyone I know to learn this game to expand my pool of opponents!

Update: I've had to lower my rating a bit on this. While I still like it, it's flopped with multiple groups I've tried it with. I have to admit that it's just not intuitive enough to learn/evoke the theme as many other games that have come out since it was released. San Juan seems much easier to grasp, and even something such as Manhattan Project, which at its core is still an 'engine builder', despite being worker placement. Sorry Race, there are other games that dish out a similar feeling that will get played more regularly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So far my only 10 rated game, even though it has only seen a few plays. I absolutely love the strategy/tactics surrounding this game, and think everyone should own it. A bit hard to explain to some, but oddly enough I understood the game after the first solitaire run-through, and a friend understood the game after his first run through as well. Scales really well from 2-4 players, no downtime at all it seems, and a quick game that packs a lot of interesting decisions into a short timeframe. Until I get to playing this a lot more, I don't see anything I really dislike about it at all. 

Some people compare this to Dominion in terms of likeability (I guess both are short, simple but complex card games for 2-4 players), and I would favor this way over Dominion.

RftG is a good game though, and the icons are not too difficult, but unless you've got someone you can play this over and over with, I would skip it.

RATING: 7
Rating: [b][bgcolor=#C45AEC]5[/bgcolor]->[bgcolor=#893BFF]6[/bgcolor]->[bgcolor=#9AFEFF]7[/bgcolor][/b]

Cardgame where you start off with a homeworld and some starting resources, choose the direction you want to develop your empire, and then build it up into something unique and impressive. 

* Every card in your hand can either be seen as something to buy and put on the table in front of you (in your tableau), or as currency that you use in order to pay for your purchases. Much of the enjoyment in the game can be derived from the angst of throwing away cool cards in order to buy another cool card. 

* Cards that are in your tableu give you special powers that can be used for the rest of the game. There are numerous different powers, but generally they either increase your ability to buy more and better cards, or give you the ability to convert cards into victory points. Acquiring special powers is always nice, and there is much satisfaction to be had in finding synergistic combinations of cards that make your empire powerful in some way.

* The game ends either when someone has bought their twelfth card, or when the pool of victory points (12VP per player) has been depleted. This means that the pacing of the game is in the hands of the players, and you should strive to end the game when you feel that it is beneficial to your empire.

Thematically it is very much in the spirit of 4X scifi strategy games, which are usually long drawn out affairs regardless of if you are thinking about galactic civilization or twilight imperium. In order to fit much of this experience into a 60 minute card game, race for the galaxy employs a fairly short game timer and simultaneous action selection.
Mechanically, it is the card version of puerto rico but with your building options randomly determined by what cards you draw. To offset this randomness there are many more viable strategies than in puerto rico so your hand of cards is rarely completely useless. 
If you use your imagination to fill in the blanks, you can definitely see your empire researching cool technologies, trading with different cultures and invading alien worlds. But the game mechanics, together with the use of abstract icons instead of flavor text on the cards, definitely makes this game more of an optimization puzzle with random elements rather than an epic space empire game.
                                   
Just like in Puerto Rico, the main player interaction comes from correctly predicting what the other players want to do and capitalize on their choices. Because of the simultaneous action selection and some changes in how the resources are handled, there is even less chance of directly interfering with another player compared to Puerto Rico. In other words, avoid if you are concerned about a multiplayer solitaire feel in your games.

The biggest negative for me is that the game has a steep learning curve. It takes a few games before you internalize all the icons and the general flow of the game. Then you need to get really familiar with all the cards in the deck in order to find viable strategies and to be able to play competently. I would say that you need at least five games, preferably in a short span of time, to get a feel for what the game has to offer. Before that, the game will feel opaque and random, and many players will not find this initial experience fun enough to get past the hurdle of learning to play. Once past this hurdle though, there is much enjoyment to be had in exploring different ways to grow your empire and, including solo plays, I've now played it hundreds of times.

I prefer to play the advanced 2 player game. You play as many role cards as with 4 players, so the game flows better than in the 3-player game or the regular 2-player game. It is also less work keeping track of one opponent than three opponents, thereby making it easier to predict how the game will unfold.

Rating is for when playing with the expansions included. I would not recommend using any expansions while learning the game, but they do open up for more flexibility and interesting new strategies, thereby making it a much better game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Race for the Galaxy[/b] [i]Tom Lehman 2007[/i]
My favourite card game up to date is an excellent two to six players game that takes its roots from Puerto Rico/San Juan and offers a lot of tactical choices packed in a short playing time (under the hour for two players, a little bit more with three and four). My only grip are the expansions, sure they give more possibilities like the take overs and prestige, but I dont think the takeover mechanics are well implemented, since they add a lot of housekeeping to the game and I see them as a flawed try to add interaction to this game. Otherwise, this is fantastic game that is way more easy to understand than it seems to be at first glance: just dont be afraid of these symbols, they really make sense after a couple of games.

RATING: 9
We've only played this with two, so I'm curious as to how it plays with more.

The core game mechanic of only resolving phases selected by at least one player (where every player can participate in the selected phases, but gains a bonus during the phase they selected before the turn) means you don't always have a chance to do everything, but are still sometimes helped by the choices of other players. A very interesting game mechanic.

RATING: 7.5
Muy bueno. Tiene todo lo que debe tener un juego de cartas. Las únicas pegas es que al tratar de que no sea tan dependiente del idioma, el sistema de iconos y símbolos se hace un poco complicado de entender para los iniciados o para la primera partida, en la cual estás totalmente perdido. Otra pega es que conocerse el mazo y las posibles combinaciones de cartas da mucha ventaja a los jugadores expertos, que da sentido al uso del "explore +5" para buscarse los combos que un jugador inicial no sabe que existen. Por lo demás, genial. Muy adictivo y con mucha tensión, ya que la presión de los oponentes para cerrar la partida te impide conseguir los combos con la facilidad que te gustaría. 
En una mesa de jugadores expertos, es una pasada de juego.

RATING: 7
As a newbie to this game, this is way too complicated.  There are so many different rules and possibilities that a viable strategy is just not possible until you have played it a lot.  Working out how to get your economy going is a major headache.  It may have some merit, though, since it's overall feel is like a slightly more complicated version of the two-player Starship Catan which does play quite well.  I'll probably have to play this quite a few more times, which I just don't want to do, to get a fuller appreciation for this.  My initial gut feel after playing it half a dozen times is that it's just far too complicated for what is meant to be a short game.  There are plenty of games around which play well by the second or third try.  This is not one of them.  My opinion may change as I gradually get forced to play this more, but I doubt it...
...Okay, weeks later I am finally starting to understand some of the game mechanics here and have upgraded my opinion slightly from a 6 to a 7 rating.  However, a game that takes so much time and number of plays to make sense should sensibly be avoided unless you have a lot of patience.  At the time of writing this comment, I have played this game 22 times.
