=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Simple but deep euro with engine building and some bluffing. The phase system works really well and is one of my favourite mechanics in any game. The cards as currency is a great conceit and makes the whole game feel very smart and streamlined. A lot of people complain about iconography, but I think that's exaggerated.

Adding a comment about differences from Race:
[q="GeorgW"]I'll chime in on the differences between Race and Roll. 

Race plays quicker (perhaps due to my group being more familiar with Race) and has a lot more strategy. While on the surface you make the same kind of choices in both games, such as which planets and developments to go for and which phase to choose, the dice in Roll screw up a lot of the depth in these choices that are still present in Race. 

For example when choosing a planet/development. At any given time in Race you have a hand of around 5 cards. This will of course vary, but in previous turns you've probably also chosen to discard cards that you've deemed to be worse than the cards you kept, so you throughout the game you generally have pretty good control of the cards in your hand. This means that if you play the game well and have reasonable luck, you'll usually be able to find planets and developments that have synergy and will help you win the game. In Roll, maybe you rolled 3 eyes so you looked at 3 tiles and chose 1. Maybe that tile is good for you, maybe not. That's the biggest flaw in Roll to me, because it almost eliminates the engine/tableau building aspect of the game.

A second example is picking which phase you want. In Race, that's a tense choice every turn where you're trying to predict what your opponents will do and balancing choosing something that's better for you or worse for your opponents. It's basically the entirety of Race's player interaction, but it's amazing. In roll, sometimes you roll 5 develops, so you choose develop. The randomness makes the prediction more difficult which in turn ruins the entire point of the mechanic.

With that said, there's still some stuff that Roll does better. It's a much newer game and as such has streamlined the rules a bit and is more colourful. It's also switched the phase sequence in order to make things move a little faster and allow for more explosive turns. 

As a summary, Race is the better game for me, but if you're new to both I'd recommend playing Roll first a few times until you're used to the iconography and flow of the game, then buy Race and never look back.[/q]

RATING: 10
Maybe one of my favorites. Played countless plays now (mostly against Keldon's excellent AI admittedly) and I feel still intrigued by all the strategies that present themselves. 

My only caveat with it is beginner-friendliness or rather, the lack of such a thing. The gameplay is un-recognisable (if you haven't played Puerto Rico, San Juan or other multi-phase selection game) and the symbols can be a bit much for a beginner. If my GF would play it with me I suspect I could rate it a perfect 10.

Edit: And it happened! This is now a PERFECT GAME! My GF was willing to give it a second chance and she weren't disappointed!

RATING: 9
The game is the typical "here are the rules, and most of the cards break the rules", except they don't break it so much as augment your strengths in each rule area. The icons help a great deal, but it STILL takes a while to get use to some of the interplay. 

Puerto Rico / San Juan players need to watch out that they assume too much to be in common. For example, in my first game, I just "consumed" all my production without a care for consuming worlds. In my mind it was a "Captain" phase, and I sent EVERYTHING to the ships. OOOOOPs. 20 VP tooo many!

I am now teaching my 11 year old son, and he's looking forward to playing. He understands the various phases, thanks to PC games like Age of Empires, so now it'll just be shoing him the mechanics and "there's no computer to do your accounting for you!" 

Gerry

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
My opinion of this game will likely move 1-1.5 points from where it is now but the criticisms of multiplayer solitaire are right on the money with this one. The playing time is short (largely because there is almost no interaction whatsoever) and I didn't get that "we played for twenty minutes but it seems like we played an epic game" feel at all.  I can't think of a reason yet anyone would really think that. Not an awful game, but not a great game. This one seems to be far too high on the ratings chart IMO.

Ok dropping a half point with more play. Anyone who tells you this is not multiplayer solitaire is just kidding themselves. The game is completely about optimising the cards in your hand and nothing else. The player that can play their hands the best will always win, regardless of what the other players do. I'm sure I'll have to play this more and the rating will keep dropping. Just a dreadful game that would be so good if there was some REAL interaction not the dreamt up indirect hooey that people try to say exists. For a solo game all you have to do is to randomly pick two cards from another color's hand and give the opponent some progressively increasing number of victory points per turn. Then you can pretend that there is another player there and the results will be the same.

RATING: 10
Epic game. Plays very quickly and is very deep. You have to continually adapt to the cards you get, what your opponents are doing and the strategy you were trying to pursue. 

I adore the idea of having a myriad ways to win, all of them equally viable. I've had my ass handed to me by 10-development tableaus, gotten beat by just a few VPs in mad Produce/Consume dashes and have smirked evilly when putting down a big rebel world, ranking me the points to win the game.

I doubt I'll ever get tired of this game.

RATING: 10
Excellent game. Plays quickly, with very little downtime. The artwork is fantastic. I love the sci-fi theme. And the game itself is highly addictive.

I also find that the iconography, despite the problems it causes for many people, is very helpful in allowing one to easily scan the cards for information.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Race for the Galaxy is the sort of game I can sit down and play over and over for as long as time allows. It's light enough that there's no fatigue factor, heavy enough that it stays challenging for play upon play upon play, random enough that each game has a very different contour, skillful enough that there's always more to learn.

If you didn't like San Juan, don't assume that you won't like Race for the Galaxy.  Yes, the two games both began as attempts to design the card game version of Puerto Rico.  San Juan holds no interest for me, but Race for the Galaxy is so far superior that it stretches the comparison to the breaking point.

RATING: 8.5
One of the best games I have ever played. I have ordered the first expansion to play also as a solitary game. The first game was hard, because the symbols are a bit difficult to apprehend, but the second game went ok. You are building a galaxy empire with a bunch of cards and it works so well..it is amazing. We preferred it to Roll for the galaxy. What's more we had some doubts about the replayability of Roll for the galaxy on long term.

RATING: 6
At first I was a bit daunted by the complexity of this game, but once you get it, it is quite simple to grasp. I like the look of this game with the nice space theme and some really cool pictures. People have complained about the iconography, but I don’t see the icons themselves to be the problem, but the complexness of the game itself.

I prefer to play with the advanced game with two players, but I will play with any amount of players (although I prefer it with 2-4 players). It’s definitely a game that gets better with repeated plays. I play this extensively on Keldon's computer version.

RATING: 4.9
I just don't like games like this. I dislike card games with a ton of iconography on them, but even when you learn what the icons do, abilities on other cards modify/intensify the original ability so you have to keep track of everything going on in front of you as well as everything your opponents are doing. That's too much accounting for me. I'll play it if asked because I don't dislike the game, but I won't seek out a play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The learning curve is steep but once you really learn the game, and evolve past struggling with how things work and what all the little symbols mean, this emerges as an uncommonly deep game with a surprising degree of theme. The problem is that it will take several dozen plays to arrive at this level of comfort (hint: play against the computer AI). Has evolved over time into one of my favorite games, it is a rare thing for me that a game has gotten so much stronger over time. I think the game is just about perfect for what it is ... about the only drawbacks are that games too often turn on the 6-factor developments that come into your hand, and military takeovers are underdeveloped.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
You have to get used to those pictograms. While you get into the simples ones soon, some 6-costs developments are hard to understand. Is this the game itself? 
I felt that the game ends just when it gets going (12 cards played finishes the game) Maybe 15 would be a good alternative, but then also overview and bookkeeping will become more demanding. As for interaction with other players, the action selection should do so, but most of the time you can't figure out what others want to do because you can't read their cards so you mostly play what's good for you. Still a Multiplayer-Solitaire with lots of chaos. Nice with its space theme but I am not that happy with the game myself. Newbies wil always take the "Explore" card with which they can keep one more card, pros will use the other "Explore" card with which the can look at five additional cards, so the can pick the one that suits their strategy they set up at the beginning of the game. So, during the game you just execute the strategy. There are no gamey options to make it interesting. Experienced gamers will just look for the combo they know/like. Just browsing through a pile of cards until you get what you want is a poor game. No interest in playing ever again. When playing with role cards then I prefer San Juan or Glory to Rome anytime.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Excellent game and I like the sci-fi theme, although I think I am a bit Raced out after spending the greater part of the year playing Keldon's AI.  Lots of interesting decisions to make, especially in trying to predict what phases your opponent(s) will choose and whether you will piggyback on the other chosen phases.  In-hand cards as currency is a very clever way of forcing you to make critical decisions on what to trash and what to keep.  It's very tempting to want to do it all, but almost every time I do this, I end up losing.

A bit heavy as far as rules and strategy/tactics, so unfortunately my in-laws (my usual gaming group, plus my wife) did not take to this game very well and has only had one play with them.

RATING: 3
S=3
Single play rating of a 7. This was based upon the potential of the game and admittedly a little hype.

I have now played 5 games and the rating just keeps slipping, even though I have won 3 of the 5 I played.

For a game with "lots of cards" "tons of choices" "multiple paths to victory" "uber amounts of depth".....blah blah blah....it sure seems that I really only have one "good" option every single turn and that the person that can recognize this good option more often will win.

Sure, this can be applied to lots of games...even to some I probably like, however, not when the game is touted for its "depth of play" and "meaningful decision making".

I will say that the game seems to be very well balanced and playtested....just not fun.

RATING: 5
I hated this when Dominion was the only game I played. It seemed like you had to memorize the deck to get anywhere, and the produce/trade thing just felt clunky.

And so I spent years hating this and seeing no reason to go back to it. But as I write this comment, I just played several quick games on BGA out of curiosity and... kind of liked it? Cautiously optimistic. The produce/trade business still actively bores me every time I try to think about it. 

I guess I've finally realized that some themes are a negative for me, not just a neutral thing to ignore.

Well. Let's see how this goes. I got heavily into Innovation with a similar arc (hated early games, avoided it for years, dabbled when I saw I could play online, now I like it a whole lot). There's still something janky about both games. They're not so much acquired tastes as... it's like eating mussels. There's work to enjoy it, and the work isn't fun on its own or a joyous rite of passage. It's just this stupid thing that's nevertheless worth doing if you like mussels.

I think. I mean, I don't like mussels.

Matt's

Interesting play throughout the game, forces you to be adaptable and constantly critical of the path you're taking, not a game you could play on autopilot. I still hate trying to teach it, and a number of my friends just don't want to bother still. That being said the game is deep, card based, and well-timed; these traits combined make for a game I like quite a lot.

7 --> 8 Yeah I really made a mistake rushing the rating.
4 --> 7 For now

[-]I've made a mistake, played this 1v1 finally and started to "get" it. I've got a ways to go yet but I intend to play much more of this. (Only 1v1 though, god forbid I have to try and teach it to someone else)[/-]

[-]No desire to try this anymore, feels very boring. Kinda meh overall, nothing that seems interesting/exciting enough to warrant another shot. Should probably give it another try though, game has too many good reviews to be as bad as it feels[/-]

RATING: N/A
Heard a lot of good things about this game and bought the whole set.  Sleeved them all too.  I've played the basic game with gathering storm thrown in, but I can't find anyone else to play it with and I haven't been that impressed with it the couple of times I have gotten to play it.  I don't mind the complex iconography, but I wish the game had more direct interaction between the players.  I like games with direct conflict, or at least a good strong mechanism for indirect interactions.  This game seems best suited to players who don't liked to be messed with.  The name is a very apt description.  It really does feel like a race to be the one to finish first.  I won't get many opportunities to play it again either since several of the people I play with are color blind and the game is impossible to play for a color blind person.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a good game. You build your galactic empire by playing cards from your hand to the table. Each round you select one of 5 actions to perform, which either let you play cards or draw new ones. It's a race for victory points with nice gameplay: no downtime, minimal shuffling, and plays in just over 30 minutes. It's not a deckbuilding game, it's more like San Juan than anything else. This might be too complicated for kids, but it should appeal to anyone over about 12 years old.

I admit I would rate it lower if it had a more mundane theme and/or poor artwork, and I would probably have given up after the first play.

RATING: 5
Not enough player interaction to hold my interest.  Fan boys who claim that there *is* player interaction are deluding themselves.  Reading someone's tableau and counting the number of cards they have in their hand is *not* player interaction.  If you don't mind no player interaction that's fine, but please call a spade a spade.

And even if you do pay close attention to your opponent, strategies are constrained by luck of the draw, so you can't react strategically to your opponent's tableau.  I imagine playing the card-drafting variant could improve this aspect of the game.

A boring, lonely chore.  Works better as a computer game, and I'll play against the Keldon AI occasionally.

RATING: 10

Play count doesn't include Keldon's AI.

RATING: 9.5
I think my play numbers for this and the first expansion speak more than I can, but let's try... Most of my friends keep saying that you just do your own thing and the game plays itself. That's exactly why they lose to me 9 times out of 10. :) Icons will baffle everyone the first game, but they should make perfect sense soon. Being a UI designer, I really appreciate how consistent the iconography actually is. Once learned, you will instantly understand even new stuff from the expansions, or at least guess close enough. This is also one of those games, where you think that you know all worth knowing about it, just to suddenly receive a revelation and step up a level to find out how much you've missed before. But it's still really enjoyable to play even before "leveling up", which is essential for getting the game to the table at all.

RATING: 8
I love san juan but expected not to like this.  Heavier san juan with tons of bad iconography?  No thank you!  I successfully avoided it for almost five years after its release.

Well that was a mistake.  The iconography is actually very logical and I had no trouble picking up on it at all.  It is a little bit solitaire like a lot of the puerto-rico-style games but the role selection timing gives just enough interaction to be interesting.

Plus the fun of the game is in building a victory point engine through your tableau and trying to extend the game or end the game depending on your table position.  

After playing a few recent games that people compared to this (eminent domain) I have to say that Race for the Galaxy is the best of the bunch.  Nice fast game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Obviously, this game shares a lot of the same mechanics as San Juan.  However, there are many important differences:

- A player can develop a technology and settle a world in the same turn, which means that they can add 2 cards to their tableau each turn, which makes for a shorter game (since the game ends when there are 12 cards in a player's tableau, much like the 12 buildings limit in San Juan).  With players who know what they're doing, this game takes 10-20 minutes.
- Each player turn can consist of less actions than there are players, if two players choose the same role.

- If you happen to draw a killer combination of cards early in the game, you could walk to an easy victory.

- There are not 4 copies of every card in the deck -- there are a large number of different unique cards, so the chances that you'll draw the card that you want (or a killer combo with what you have already) is lower.  My point is that random good luck often cannot be overcome by strategy in this game.  The only strategy to overcome bad luck is to lose quickly and play the game again!  (Well, you could also spend time choosing the Explore +5 action, which allows you to draw 7 and keep 1, and hope that other players will pick actions that work with your cards.)  This is very different from San Juan, where no great starting hand will give the game outright to a particular player.  Basically, I feel satisfied after playing San Juan, because my good play can keep the game close with a player who has a good starting hand.

After many plays, I kinda like this game, but it took quite a while for me to learn enough of the cards to understand what strategies were even possible, and even now, I lose very often.

Even more than in San Juan, where you really want to build a second production building as soon as possible so you can trade (especially silver, coffee, or even tobacco), in this game you need to get a production world up and running so you can get a bunch of cards from "consume with trade".  The mistake that I keep making is holding on to big (4- or 5-point) cards and planning to build them 3 turns later, which is way too slow.  I should ditch them early in favour of settling small 2-point worlds (especially green worlds) that can give me something to trade away for cards.  The odds are good that someone will try to set up a produce-consume feedback loop, and you should try to take advantage of that.

I try to keep track of other players' developments and planets (which is very important to do in this game), but it's still hard for me to manage even after much practice.  I actually think that it is critical to understand your opponents' motivations -- you should guess what they will choose as actions, and develop/settle cards that will give you actions for free without having to take the action yourself.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7

This is a game I actually don't get to play anywhere near enough. I've played against the Keldon AI quite a bit, and against the solo robot. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I think the game is very good. But I have two problems with it. They are not earth shattering, throw the game out the window problems, but they are keeping the rating of this game from going up.

The first problem I see is the lack of player interaction. It really feels like your playing solitaire in group. There is not a lot of interactions and whatever the other players are doing rarely if ever affects what your doing. In my opinion, a space building game where you're trying to develop a whole civilization almost require player interaction.

The second problem is the randomness of the card draw makes it difficult to develop a sound strategy. You can get lucky and draw all the right cards making it an easy walk to victory or you might get screwed bad and not be able to accomplish anything because the deck just isn't turning your way.

Those two criticism aside, I still enjoy playing it immensely. Hence the 8 rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Frustrating at times this game still manages to be very fun. Need to play more and maybe buy an expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
RftG has a wonderful theme with all the SF gimmicks, but the game sports a difficult to grasp iconography, less streamlined than San Juan and more dependant on luck.
I like the way there are so many "thematic" strategies (although if you remove the theme veneer there are always quite the same), I like the way so many cards and combo feel carefully balanced, but I've played too many games where I felt luck decided the outcome; once you know how to play decently, that's all there is.
Sure a player with a few plays under his belts will trash a newbie, but when all players have made the effort to think about and know the cards, there is no other real skill to build; moreover, whereas in a game of Puerto Rico the seating order has an impact, here any player's stupid move might drag you down as well... not an improvement, and still good card draw will level clever play everytime.
I am not sure it is a bad thing at all; games can be really quick and when the cards come in your way and with a little geeky sf imagination, a win can be very satisfactory, so I feel happy to own this game which can feel fun and rewarding at times, but it is definitely not a top tier strategy game.

edit: these days I only keep the cardboard version and its extensions because the author made something so fun to play on the computer.  Face to face, there are better choices.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Has a CCG feel in that cards can/should be used in combos.  There is little player interaction, other than the fact that you all draw from the same deck, and that the action you select (out of 7 or 8 choices) also allows the other players to do it (minus the bonus, a-la Puerto Rico).  Cost to "build/activate" a card is done a-la San Juan, where you need to discard a card.

An interesting combination of mechanics, and a relatively fast playing game (under an hour).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The iconography can be a bit difficult when you first start, but once you get it, most any other game iconography will come easily.

RATING: 10
Race for the Galaxy is a great example of not judging a game based on one or two plays.  I don’t think anyone in my family picked up on this one very quickly (for example, none of us used the “Consume – Trade” power during our first couple of plays, because we did not see the point -- *at the time*), and because of our slower understanding of how to *really* play the game, it seemed rather disappointing.  A few games later, however, and wow – did our opinion ever change!

This is probably my son’s favorite game (along with Dominion and its expansions), and one of my wife’s favorite as well.  And, as you can tell from the “10” rating I gave it, it is one of my all-time favorites, as well (at the time of this review, Agricola and Race for the Galaxy are probably my two favorite games).

Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[Initial Impression: 8]
I immediately liked the complexity and potential interactions between strategies, which puts it over the top compared to San Juan. The game clearly rewards knowledge of the cards and the ability to adapt to the card draws - allowing yourself to get too stuck in your initial strategy when the cards don't support it is a sure route to defeat. 

I like this game a lot, but after relatively few plays (10+), it was already feeling a bit samey. I think this is because there are only a few start worlds, and whoever is best able to capitalize on a strategy compatible with their start world generally comes out ahead.

We've started playing the variant where each player is dealt 7 cards, then must build one world and pay its cost (you may build a military world as if it were a non-military world during this setup stage) - that is your start world. The leftovers are your starting hand. This increases the variability dramatically, and forces you to decide whether to build a cheap start world and have a large starting hand, or build a more useful but expensive start world and be crippled with a small (or non-existent) starting hand.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
I played it first at boardgamearena.com but i wanted to try it out in person. After 15 online games i was not sure how the game works, but with the belp of the boardgame club everything got clear. I don't like this game as much as i do with Glory to Rome, altough the game has huge replayability and it is fun to play. After 2800 online games im still learning how to play one specific card in a specific situation. I love that you have multiple choices which path you take. I have to admit that it is a big pain to teach, firstly you must teach all the simbols and the role selections can be a bit confusing too. But after they learned it, it seems to be a big hit and everyone just asks for a game.

Pros / Cons:
-I like it because every card can be played in different situations and the game is never ever the same.
-It is great to think over the situations and what role should i ask to get out in the best possible position while not helping to the opponent(s) more.
-I like it because it is fast and can be played more than once, the playtime is around 30-45 minutes, and i recommend it with any number.
-One of the best price / value game so far.

-I dislike it because of the very low interaction between the players.

RATING: 9
2 - 4 players

A 2007 Christmas present.  This is another card-game version of Puerto Rico, similar to San Juan.  The learning curve is somewhat steep due to all the symbols on the cards.  For most people, you'll need to play the game once before it all sinks in.  Only takes about 30 to 45 mins to play once everyone knows how to play.  The more I play this game, the more I like it.  I am looking forward to the expansions that will add more players and more cards.

RATING: 4
5-9-10
I haven't updated these comments in almost a year.  I'm glad that this trend died down with our group very quickly as I found this game to be very boring and with far too many stupid little icons.  Even after multiple games I'd be struggling to figure out quite exactly how things work.

It's like chess - perhaps fun with people near your skill level but with people who are really into the game and know all the cards, don't bother.  It's just not deep or fun enough.  No long term planning as cards are absolutely random and choosing a role brings in an unwanted level of player interaction.  People will harp on you if you pick suboptimal choices and it's just not fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Race for the Galaxy (RftG) base is about my top overall game. [OFW: Obligatory Fanboy Warning]

The game itself is a hand management game, which took the base ideas formed into San Juan (about the same time), and greatly improved them.

Multi-use cards pose questions on use or application, and in some cases do not come into the game as an active card but as a passive good.

Multiple phases are laid out with very intelligently designed icons that tell players at a glance almost everything one needs to know about a card.

Good Sci-Fi artwork decorates the cards and adds to the thematic setting of the space exploration, exploitation card game.

The expansions are well thought-out, and are generally as good as the original, running to 3 different thematic arcs as of now.

Based on rating, #plays, portability, and well, just everything, this is the top dog, and will likely stay there.

Some History: (ancient?)

5/31/09 - First full play against the Robot from Gathering Storm, and won, albeit on NU-B level. 7.5 for starters, with possible upside.

6/11/09 - So far only a few solo plays, but I like the changing feel of this game a lot, and would realy like to play some FTF - raised to an 8.

7/12/09 - Up to 30 plays, almost all solo. Beating robot much more often, 1st win against Difficult level 7/11. This is a fascinating, fairly quick to set up & play, game with a lot of replay value. Hope to teach some friends to play and build some FTF plays, as that will definitely change the strategy and play - raised to an 8.5

8/08/09 - I've played a couple more FTF games, and like these better than the solo robot games; up to 45 now, and while this might not be the 1st choice if I have a whole day to play games, it is SO time effective that for shorter time slots it's almost always my 1st choice - raised to a full 9.0. (Also placed Rebel vs. Imperium on preorder).

02/09/10 - 100th play - Unfortunately, I lost- damn robot!

02/06/16 - Nearly 250 plays of the physical game later, including all 3 arcs (but not including any AI plays), I still love this game.

RATING: 10
And here we have a real winner! What a great game. I've played dozens of games on my PC against AI. Actually that's what convinced me to buy this. So kudos to who ever made that thing.

Fast, deep and varied. What's there not to like!? Yes, it can be harsh for a new player. You have to play a few games to get it. Icons? What about them? Difficult!? Now don't be silly. If I've teached this succesfully to new people, anyone can do it.

I really like the fact that every game is different. The game "forces" you to play differently each time, because of different starting world and cards. In some games it can come to the point where you always play the same way, but in Galaxy you have be able to change your playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finally got a chance to play it to see what the buzz was about. It helps to have some background playing San Juan and/or Puerto Rico, so this was easy to pick up. Another newbie who was new to games in general got lost fairly quickly. The icons and symbols are somewhat confusing, but that's the nature of the beast. It plays like San Juan, with the exception of everyone secretly playing one of seven roles, which is a very neat mechanic, and the turns are deceptively fast for all the iconography involved. Race feels like it has more theme, with impressive and immersive artwork, than San Juan, which I can't help but think but it's simply Puerto Rico-lite with cards, and I don't have that feel of being governor of a plantation.

Update (4/11/09): Taught 2 San Juan veterans and 1 San Juan novice. Complex iconography had some confused until half-way, including me. There are many, many icons and these require referring the rulebook, and even then, it is somewhat confusing. Still, the veterans liked it, and enjoyed the SF theme (even though one of them doesn't like SF-themed games). I've upped the game play weight up to medium, since it does require substantial thinking to piece it all together.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[center][size=6][COLOR=#878787]LIFETIME GAME [microbadge=28495]:star:[microbadge=28496] "PLAY FOREVER"[/COLOR][/size][/center]

After one play, this is a slick little game.  We're all fans of [i]San Juan[/i], and science fiction, so this one's a natural for my group.  I was lucky enough to know ahead of time that this was multiplayer solitaire with minimal "screwpportunity" and was, like it says in the title, a race game.  Bring your economic engine online, get it humming & working parasitically off of others' actions, rake in the VPs and end the game on your terms.  At least, that's the idea.  For me it was more like "guess wrong and waste several turns" and fall behind all red-shifted and small in the rearview scanners.

The integration of theme and design is very good—every card contains a nascent story.

STRATEGY NOTE:  Doing nothing but feeding heavy metals to Planet Disco will not get you the win.  No matter how cool it seems at the time.

Rating could rise (or decay!) with future plays.  We'll see...

UPDATE:  More plays, more of the game reveals itself.  Wonderfully subtle, and requiring a deft touch—at this point I feel like I'm doing brain surgery with Mickey Mouse hands and usually the patient... [i]dies[/i].  Most games that feel like this push you away and keep you from wanting to do the work to figure it out; this one is so captivating, so tip of the tongue, so [i]almost[/i]-that-time I find I can't wait to play again.  I feel there's a couple of metric tons of game in there, game that won't fully come to light until everyone is comfortable with the cards—much like [i]San Juan[/i] (in which, I must admit, I only recently figured out when to pick Prospector—but when I got that it became a whole new game).

And, as Dave says, "Pursuing the military strategy is just [i]fun[/i]."

So there's always that.

[b]After 70 plays:[/b]

[q="HiveGod"][i]Race for the Galaxy[/i] is a game that only opens up with experience—it begins as multiplayer solitaire; morphs into an actual race where the goal is to build an engine, pull into the lead and then end the game as quickly as possible; and finally becomes a game about knowing, intimately, what everyone else is up to in their tableaux so you can simultaneously draft off of their efforts while minimizing the amount of "help" you provide with your choice of action for the round.

That last bit is often never reached or grokked by the casual player, but it's truly where the game is—a player who doesn't pay attention to everyone else and chooses actions based on what they need most right now will always lose to the player who does pay attention and uses everyone else's play parasitically.

It can be obvious or subtle, and with good (experienced) players it becomes a very cagey game of quintuplethink, but to my mind it's well worth the work to get there.  There are few games that reward the effort as thoroughly as [i]Race.[/i][/q]
[microbadge=15220]

[b][thread=791360][/thread][/b]

[microbadge=12164]

#Edit: I have had to re-rate this game from 7.5 to 6.5, simply because I really don't know what I'm doing as I'm playing it. I don't know the cards, I don't see the strategies, I spend half my time dumbly looking at the cards without knowing what exactly to do next, let alone think of a optimum play. I either buy this game and start playing it exclusively to learn it or I just give up. Maybe I'll just go half way and keep trying...

07/09/2008: Played a 3-player game yesterday and was able to mount a feeble "militaristic" strategy that led me to an amazing last place. Again.
Nevertheless I'm slowly starting to pick up on the basic intricacies of the game and how it should be played. I wish games went a bit further than the 12th building. I've decided I want to buy this game and I'll probably play it to death until I know  the cards and various strategies well.

RATING: 10
A word of caution about RFTG.  Make sure the person teaching you this game is a good explainer, or make the commitment to read and re-read the rules and the BGG boards to learn it correctly.  This is a great game, but it is very difficult to learn with all of the symbols.  Unfortunately, I was taught by someone who is not very good at explaining games.  So, I was pretty lost during much of my first game or two, and then got a sour taste in my mouth about this game and gave up.  Now, a couple of years later, I sat down with the game and was determined to learn it correctly.  Mission accomplished.  This is a great game with lots of depth.  Think of it as San Juan on steroids, with a space theme.  I love it and can't wait to play again and again.  Oh, and we need more expansions - many more - right away!

RATING: 10
This is a good game, it very casual and easy to learn, the game was designed very well and the symbols on each card makes the game very intuitive, by showing which phase the card has an effect for a what effect you get. As the name suggests, its a race, a race to the largest galaxy; but the problem with that is it reduces the amount of player interaction, its almost like playing solitaire. Players affect which action will be performed, but there is no way to stop someone, i feel that the action card should have had flaws for other players if they played during that phase. They also need cards that have global effect, that hinder or disrupt another players. You should also be able to conquer (through military) other players settlements (planets).

Overall its still a good game, as it is easy to teach, learn, and play. The game play could be more aggressive though.

RATING: 10
This thing is the real deal.  I couldn't believe how sweet it was and I really only barely "got it". UPDATE: After about 12 plays (6 solo using Lucas Hedgren's system), this game keeps surprising me.  It does many things right: 1) plays quickly and doesn't overstay its welcome  2) provides a changing, robust decision tree that makes every turn a "nailbiter", with push-your-luck mechanisms  3) gives quite a bit of indirect interaction, predicting what phases you can get away with NOT placing on each turn.  Just a great package.
UPDATE: Yeah, it's a "10"
UPDATE: Well, maybe a "9", with a "9.5" including expansion and solo option

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Well, it took me a couple of games to understand the icons and about a dozen to understand the strategy, but this has gradually become one of my all time favourites. A heavy, build your position game with some luck, certainly, but that's forgiveable in view of the brevity of the play. Like all 'blind action' games you have to gamble that your opponents will choose something that benefits you, and as a compound interest game you want to draw the cards that build on what you've got already. Complaints of minimal interaction certainly have some validity (you'll have to design your own cards using the blanks in expansion one to overcome this, but the system's extensible pretty much indefinitely) and the Consume-Produce loop is VERY powerful once you've seen it, making the base set something of a single strategy affair. For me this is 'Puerto Rico - the Card Game', but I can understand the feelings of those who say it's a much more modest achievement.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Tremendous game, always want to play this. Like San Juan in space, although it is much deeper, and with more different viable strategies. Keeps getting better with every game.

Always play with the expansions - absolute must have's.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fast-paced, San Juan-esque card game. At the moment my rating for this is fluctuating.  I like the range of strategies understand why this is addictive. I've found myself playing it much more than expected, and I don't even own it. On the other hand, this game is frustrating when what you have  a hand full of things that don't work together or when you can't draw what you want, as the combos are extremely important. This problem is compounded by the shortness of the game--you are sure to draw something worthwhile EVENTUALLY, but it may all be over by then.  It is also undeniable that taking away the role selection decreases player interaction. 

It can stay a seven for now, since I will usually play it and think it's, yknow, pretty good, but it is in some danger of falling to a six next time I have a game where it seems murky.

EDIT: This seems to be one of those games you just keep playing... not necessarily because it is your favorite, but because it is a card game, it's fast and nobody complains about it too much.

EDIT: Seriously, I've played this game way more than I want to.

RATING: 9
This game has a bit of a hurdle to get over if you're not familier with these sorts of card games and not good at remembering symbols. Once you jump over that, it works very well, as you can play the game almost mindlessly yet can use a nearly endless variety of strategies to win, all at the same time. It's amazing how a game so quick and easy can be so deep. Plus it scratches the same itch as customizable/trading card games (Magic: The Gathering and so forth), with an endless stream of getting new cards to add to your personal deck, and a constant need to figure out how they all work together in the most efficient way. It's all about synergy, and I love that sort of thing in my games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.85
Un juego que toma los elementos principales de Puerto Rico (gestión de recursos, elección de roles) y crea un sistema muy sólido y profundo que se juega en un relativo corto tiempo. Mecánicas principales: elección de rol simultánea (altera mucho la forma de jugar respecto a su primo Puerto Rico). Información oculta que alienta el rollo Vizzinni (averiguar lo que va a hacer el otro para contrarrestarlo y viceversa). Combos de cartas. PROS. Sin aperturas estándard como en Puerto Rico. Mejora lo de ayudar sin querer al de tu izquierda. Interacción sutil y tensa (forzando a consumir prematuramente, jugando acciones que no beneficien al contrario, no jugar una acción que el otro espera ansiosamente, adaptar tu despliegue al juego del contrario). Espléndida relación entre duración y profundidad. CONS. Necesita expansión para ser interactivo de verdad. Imprescindible la piedra de Rosetta (ayuda de jugador) para descifrar los iconos de las cartas. Curva de aprendizaje elevada.Se podría jugar en piloto automático. No existe línea clara entre tus cartas y qué hacer para lograr los PV's. Azar (a veces el ganador es sencillamente el que mejores cartas le han tocado)

Baja de 9 a 8.8 porque entraron juegos mejores en mi colección y por no jugarlo tanto OCT 2013
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Get past this learning curve and you will discover one of the best games out there.  Game mechanics are elegant, it plays very fast, and has a large amount of strategy.  Also, I think it scales very well to 2-players.  Excellent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First played 12/11/07. Taught in ~10min, play in 45min w/4. Game contains good luck/strategy mix. Similar mechanics to San Juan. Players build cards (planets) in their play area, starting off with a free home base. On each turn, players secretly decide which action they will choose: Explore (gain more cards; choose from/keep more), Develop (build development; -$1 to build), Settle (build world; get extra card), Consume (VPs; VPs or $), or Produce (good(s); 1 free windfall production). $=cards in hand. All players take each action chosen that round starting with Explore, however special action is only taken by player(s) who chose that card. Windfalls are planets which need assistance to produce; however start with production. Settlements are non-military (stated cost) or military. Military require a specific military size achieved in play area (cards may state military size in red on line III). Hand limit is 10 after each round. Game ends when a player reaches 12 built in play area. Count VPs stated on cards and VP chips. Most VPs wins. A little challenging to piece everything together. Once you get through the first 1-2 games, it will go smoother and faster. I'd strongly recommend trying it out especially if you know someone with it. Give purchase & regular basis play consideration.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I like the artwork on the cards and the science fiction theme.  This game is not extremely complicated, but it requires several plays to really grasp everything that is happening in the game. One of the more interesting aspects of Race for the Galaxy is how each card can potentially be played to provide victory points as well as provide persistent benefits, but the cards are also used as cash to pay for other cards.  When you play a card and add it to your tableau, you are forced to choose which cards in your hand to discard to pay for the card being played.  Players are constantly making stimulating decisions in their efforts to maximize their score.  All players get to perform each of the chosen actions, but they benefit from a bonus when performing the action they chose.  A significant consideration should be dedicated towards trying to benefit more from the phase your opponent chooses than your opponent benefits from the phase you chose. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Advanced San Juan . . . in space.  [Although I like it a lot more than San Juan.]

Great theme, great design.  Just something about this genre of game (San Juan, Glory to Rome) that just doesn't click for me as quickly as I think it should.  Probably a function of my not being a big-time CCG player.

It took 3 plays for the hieroglyphics on the cards to actually mean anything to me . . . and finally by my 7th game, I felt like I could piece together a strategy using my cards in hand.  By games 15 - 20, I began to realize what other players were working on and how poorly I used to play.

If you're willing to put in some "investment" plays, this will be a fun, quick game in the collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Well, after a long wait, I finally got to play this game.  And in many ways, it lives up to it's potential:

Pros:  Amazing selection of cards lend themselves to a diversified selection of strategies.  After even a single game, all of the iconography makes sense and you don't really need even reference sheets.  Simultaneous selection of almost all choices speeds up the game play.

Cons: There is less interaction than San Juan.  There is player interaction, but it's still pretty scarce.  Maybe after a few more games I'll be able to better pay attention to what everyone is doing.  In the mean time, with everything happening simultaneously, I just concentrated on myself.


In the end, it's not the greatest thing since sliced bread, but it's a darn good economic card game (Much better than St. Petersburg IMHO).

Apr08: The speed man.  It's the speed.  I'm looking to this game more and more for just how much in can pack into under an hour.

Aug08: Okay, it's going all the way to 10.  It's not perfect, but it's darn close and I still play it regularly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ideal Players: 2-4

Description: Explore the universe, discover technology, colonize new worlds, and build an economy in this galactic civilization building game.

Pro: Role selection requires anticipating other players. Cards provide multiple paths to victory. Easy yet complex dynamic. Cards used as currency simplifies record keeping. Fantastic card graphics and consistent iconography.

Con: Extremely complex game, requiring at least one play to understand. Graphics, text, and iconography make the cards extremely noisy. Almost too complex for a card game. Random card draws make it difficult to intentionally choose a strategy. No direct player interaction.

RATING: 8.7
With all of the cards in this game, I expected some balance problems and some annoying redundancy covered by art. Man was I ever pleased that the masterful work of the creators somehow beat the odds and produced one of the all time best noncollectable card games. I enjoy this game as both a 2 player and with multiple opponents. The end result really does have a "Race" like feeling as players dash to get a working strategy out of the deck and into play before somebody triggers the end of the game. Great game.

RATING: 8.3
What bad thing could be said of a game that takes seconds to set-up, less than 30 minutes to play, doesn't bog you down with the table layout, and doesn't require you to memorize every single cards ability, but rather only a series of symbols. 
Living in Japan, it's so important for me to find a game that reduces all of it's complexity down to a series of symbols than any nationality could understand. And this game does it flawlessly. 
The parasitic nature of the turn order, simultaneous actions and the satisfaction from chaining resource production makes this game a must for any strategy and/or resource management fan. (^_^)

RATING: 10
OWNED SINCE 2012
I recently got this game, based on the many positive reviews here on BGG. This is a great game and it is everything everyone said it was. I am glad I choose this over San Juan and Puerto Rico. I also bought the first expansion, Gathering Storm, which is a nice but not as much of a value. For me, it only adds a few new cards, 1 more player, and that is it. It also comes with Goals, which are VP that can be collected for being the first to accomplish something, but my wife does not like them. The expansion also comes with blank cards (that I will never use) and pieces to play the game 1 player. The 1 player is cool, but I will never use it. I am glad that I got the expansion, but others might have provided more contents that I would use.  
UPDATE: I think one of that things that impresses me the most about this game is there are so many different paths to victory. I recently played my wife and at the end I looked at her table and thought she had won by a lot, but after counting points it was a tie @ 41 VP each. We just had very different tables and ways of earning our VP that you could not tell the winner by just looking at the board. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games, after 10 years I'll still play. I like how quick it is, and the optimization puzzles, betting/planning, and reading players are fun challenges. Since there's a good amount of randomness and hidden info there's not too much AP - looking ahead only really helps for maybe a turn.

I like both 2p with double actions, and the more traditional board-game feel of 3p+.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
One of the best games i've played.Immensely deep and immersive and crazy addictive.I've been playing on boardgamearena.com for a few days and each game is a joy to participate in.At the beggining the learning curve seems as steep as Everest,but as you play you realise that the game is more of a "get the hang of it" rather than actually having to learn something.I must point out that the difficult thing for begginers is definitely the iconography.It's all strange icons and symbols and hands and hexe's and numbers in the beggining and some things will seem ridiculous to look at.My advice is just keep playing and at some point you will realise that you are actually slowly getting used to the icons and paying more attention to what's going on.Take it easy and you'll see.The art is incredible,the cards are well balanced and i love how you pre-plan your game based on the starting planet and how easily your plans can be altered (if the circumstances are such that measures must be taken),or how smooth your strategy can play out if you decide to go with it.One of my favorite games.

RATING: 5
I am beginning to think Tom's designs aren't for me.  I thought the effects in this game were less interesting than San Juan.  I am also not sure that I like the blind action selection, as it adds a mind reading element that does not seem to add much.  Finally, the art, while attractive does not convey any meaningful information, and sort of distracts from what you need to look at.  By that I mean, you can look at a card in San Juan, see it is the well, and know its the well.  When I look at a card in Race for the Galaxy, I see a bit of sci fi brick a brack, but it is not clear what it does or why.  I can imagine my impression improving with time.  My impression of San Juan certainly has.  But the first impression was not a strong one.

RATING: 4
:thumbsup: simultaneous coattail-riding action selection 

:thumbsdown: tactical race
:thumbsdown: unintuitive graphic design.

As is, the optimal strategy is to randomly draw more synergistic cards than your opponents. I could be convinced to play it like a customizeable card game where each player had their own deck that they would cull a certain percentage of the cards from before playing to promote actual strategies and counter-strategies, but I'd rather play [url=https://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/108687/puerto-rico-limited-anniversary-edition]Puerto Rico[/url]

RATING: 8
Very solid card game.  Reminds Puerto Rico and San Juan a bit (a few ideas from Thomas Lehmann were borrowed and incorporated into San Juan, but Lehmann ended up with this game).

The problem for the beginners might be a ton of different cards to familiarize with.  But you learn them quickly and the gameplay is smooth very soon .
 
I really like the game alhough there's some luck factor (expansions only magnify the problem) and some solitaire play in it.  But the game is short and you can always repeat the play.  And - above all - it is fun :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So truth be told, we've played this game well over 100 times now
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
Well Tom has finally done it, in fact I think some of his other games were just primers for this one, like Phonecia for example which just wasn't polished enough. Tom really likes these Civ building engine style games and now it looks like he has near-perfected one albeit a lot is borrowed from PR ans SJ. 

The problem with some of his other games is they come out very dry and strategy can be quite subtle, this game has the subtlety but finally got rid of the dryness. The theme does come out in the game nicely, I don't really feel like I am building in space or anything but some things do make sense thematically. 

Yes more or less multiplayer solitaire but when you can crank out a game in about 25 minutes I don't care, also the expansion is possibly going to add some screwage if you want it. It also is not true solitaire, you do have to watch the other players carefully and try to leech off their actions as much as possible, similiar to other games of this nature. This leeching actually adds a guessing element and a push your luck element as well as you might take some chances other people are going to do something to max out your efficiency. There really are not enough 20 to 30 minute MEATY games and this will be in my collection because it is and it supports 2 players. 

The game has a significant learning curve, 1 or 2 games just for the icons and a lot more to learn the cards, combos and strategies. The symbols are quite helpful after a few games but I still have to look them up, as the game is so fast this looking and wondering is really lengthening my overall learning curve which is already steep. There are a lot of cards and learning how they intereact and pair up is really going to take a lot of games.  As lots of people have noticed, this is good and bad, bad for people just trying to jump in and play and not wanting to have the patience to really 'learn' the game, good for those who will take the time as it will really add to the replay and overall depth of the game.

[u]UPDATE[/u]: Well San Juan does seem a little more streamlined and here luck might play an even bigger factor. When and which big scoring cards you get is of course subject to the card draw and if you are building towards one of them and don't get it your doomed because someone else did get their 'big building'. You can also try to grab them early and hold onto them while building towards them, this is a more sure-fire method but holding cards will cost you. There certainly is a lot more to explore here than SJ although it still feels like a race, at least this game isn't pretending not to be a race!

[u]UPDATE[/u]: 6 => 7 After 5 plays Race definitely has that addictive quality where you want to play again and try to improve on your last playing. There is also a ton of variety and enough depth to certainly keep you interested as well. I'm pretty sure my rating is going to keep trending upward but the luck factor will most likely keep it from top tier for me. 

[u]UPDATE[/u]: 7 => 7.5 Yep, it's starting to come together after 7 plays, the payoff certainly will be bigger than the pain in learning

[u]UPDATE[/u]: 7.5 => 8 Well the wife didn't like this at first BUT now she is requesting it. It's a fun 30 minute game and makes an excellent 2 player game (best imo for lower luck) as well as scaling up to 4 perfectly. I think there must be at least 5 or 6 strong strategies to go for which allows for good flexibility and also helps mitigate card draw luck. Getting the big 6's early and building towards them is the only way to go to also mitigate luck however between 2 fairly equal players luck is going to be a big factor in who wins, in a 30 minute game I'm okay with that. We are seeing a bit of a ceiling now after 12 games but we still have a ways to go and we still enjoy it and want to play as it's so short and interesting. San Juan would bore me to tears I think now, this put the shipping element back into the game which is another viable strategy. Here's how I see the progression in RFTG:

1 - 4 games to really get the symbols down where you don't look them up (2 to 3 average). 

5 - 10 games to really start knowing the cards and [i]start[/i] seeing the different strategies available and subtle interactions. 

10 - 20+ games to really know all the cards, how they combine and knowing which strategy to go for and when.  

Current high score is around 78

[u]UPDATE:[/u] 8 => 8.5 Have played 30 times and we always come back this and always will. TGS expansion while most of it isn't useful, the 3 big 6's give another 3 paths, just for those you pretty much need the expansion. Excellent 30 minute game for 2 players, would play with 3 or 4 too but the luck is higher at those numbers. One of the best card games for 2 players along with Netrunner and Haggis.

[u]UPDATE:[/u] 8.5 => 9.5 I don't know what is wrong with me, but I should of had this rated a little higher long ago. Probably played 50 times by now (this feat alone means its worthy of this rating, could be the only game I've played that many times as most [i]really good[/i] games peter out at ~25 for me), and out of the 750 different games I've played to date it is one of our favourites for sure. Multiple strategies to explore/ paths to victory IS the biggest strength imo here, and its wonderful. Luck is mostly in check IF playing only 2 players and don't use cards for goods (see my Tidbit below). Theme comes through fairly well and art is lovely on the cards. The Goals from expansions add another "path" almost, they are nice point grabs you really have to watch out/shoot for, the more we played with them the more we liked them and they add some tension as well as its yet another thing you are [i]racing[/i] for. 

I guess what holds it from 10 for me is some luck of the draw (This is what held my rating a little down originally but have decided its mostly in check esp for the game time. Note you can't just shoot for a strat and see it through from the beginning, it might work or might not just due to luck. So normally you see what fate hands you first [6's], and try a strat based on that, and usually will work out well that way but you seldom still might need/want a card and just don't get it, when you do though, shazamm!) and we do play with a couple of [i]small[/i] tweaks for preference/overall balance with expansions added, like ending at 14 cards and a slight increased amount of VP's, but this is pretty much a perfect game at least for us when you can play something with this depth in 30 - 60 mins, a true classic that will always remain on our shelf.  

[b]Tidbit[/b] - to reduce luck DO NOT use cards for goods, this was a bad design decision IMHO as you randomly take out much needed cards by the players, why? (reduced bits in box, and not enough thought to negative effect that's why imo) They should have included cardboard chits for goods, use cubes from another game and enjoy the reduced luck
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The learning curve of this game is overstated, there are a lot of symbols, but you should be comfortable with it after a couple games. The reason I'm not so wild about this game is that as far as which cards to play when that always seems pretty straightforward, the only real decisions come from having to predict which actions your opponents will want so you can get as many double actions as possible while denying your opponents the same, and this is a perfectly valid way to have a game but it's not really for me (though I'm happy to play it every once in a while.) It also seems like luck of the draw becomes a big factor between people of roughly equal skill, though it's quick enough that this isn't a huge problem.

RATING: 9

The biggest learning curve is learning what all the symbols mean.  Many paths to victory.  Games are always over too quickly, just as you're getting going.  It's fun to put together powerful combos.  There is a definite element of chance as to what cards you draw though.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
San Juan fell out of the rotation because I got bored with it - there was only one real way to play it until you found your six point card, and then you would formulate a plan for the last 2-3 turns from there (and even then, the 6 pointers were pretty unbalanced.)  

This is San Juan on steroids, better in every facet.  Several productive early game strategies, six pointers are more balanced, there's almost always a way to work with the garbage you've been given and stay competitive until help arrives.  And it plays in half an hour.  Can't say enough good things about this.

RATING: 10
A beautiful two player gaming experience.  Yes, it's a race and some may argue solitaire-like.  On some levels, this is true.  However, frequent game play, understanding key card combinations, spotting trends in your opponent's build patterns leads to a deep intuitive gaming experience.  Classic.  Belongs in every collection.

Brian went military tonight. Tough to beat when he's pulling the right cards. I fell behind on the Settlement/development phases and lost traction. Beaten bad. 

2017, finally started on the expansions. Loved Gathering Storm, found the attack mechanic in Rebels too clumsy for a 2p, and the game lost some of its charm, but the addition of Brink of War brought everything back into balance.  Still not playing attack mode, don't use the solitaire feature but the first arc with 2p or 3p is a great game.

RATING: 10
The moment my copy arrived, I sleeved all of the cards.  These are identical in size to Magic cards, so there are plenty of sleeve choices.  I went with the fairly expensive "Japanese" brand metallic sleeves for the main deck, and some heavy UltraPro for the role cards.  This doubled the cost of my set, but in the long run it's going to pay off.  I expect to play this game a lot.

I'm a huge fan of San Juan, and enjoy but rarely play PR.  I'm also a long-time lover of Magic.  Combining these becomes a no-brainer for me.  Race is a ton of fun.

The multiplayer solitaire complaints are nonsense.  Have those people play face up against experienced players and see if they still feel isolated and free to do whatever they want.

RATING: 8
The rule book is rather well written, at least in comparison to other games. Note that the Consume phase of the game can be confusing, but the forums here provide a lot of help.

It is a bit of a two-player solitaire game, but I like that about it. We don't just sit there in silence playing -- we talk to each other, we encourage each other, we swear at each other. It's a fun interactive game that doesn't actually require interaction.

It is a player vs. player game, but it is not too competitive, and it is completely non-confrontational. There's no blocking or stealing. I repeat, I like that. The process of playing and building is the fun part. Who wins or loses is secondary.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a very well-designed game, and despite the random chance of what cards you draw, there is always a strategy to be found and developed as you play.

Bonus points when you play with people who know the game and can play much faster; the frantic pace makes it more exciting. Can be a burden for more casual gamers.

I tend to get burned out on this game after a few play-throughs, and it takes a while before I'd want to play again.

RATING: 8
RftG is a very good Puerto Rico-like cardgame. In some aspects very similar to San Juan, of course, but more complex and much more interesting than that game. In some ways it feels almost like a mix of San Juan/Puerto Rico and a CCG like Magic: The Gathering, borrowing the complex and interesting card interaction and potentials for strong combos from Magic.

I have been positively surprised by RftG: I dislike San Juan and my expectations for RftG weren't high before trying it. However, the game has exceeded any expectations I could have had and I have thoroughly enjoyed all my games so far. It is a solid game that feels a lot less one-dimensional than San Juan. So far, it seems the hype is warranted ín this case.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Perfect balance of depth and speed.  Improved by each expansion.  Very elegant gameplay, iconography is spot on for repeated play (And probably not good if you go 8 months between plays).  One of my favorites, and I like it more and more over time.

Each layer of strategy slowly shows itself to you over time, with more plays.  At first, as you're learning the mechanisms of the game and how they interact, you need to get a feel for how to expand your holdings; when you should dump cards that may be useful, and when you should hold back for something better.

Next, you learn and become comfortable with the potential range of helpful cards you're likely to get, in roughly what quantity, and how they interact.  You're apt to find powerful combinations and focus too much on building towards them, slowing yourself down quite a bit - note that a game played at a very slow pace with this sort of groupthink can produce stunning point totals.

When you're starting to get comfortable with the fact that when you're ahead, it's almost always best to push the game forward, is also the time you start realizing how important it is to look at what your opponents are doing, and take risks based on what they're likely to do.

When this happens, you become an OK Race player.

The game is still random enough that repeated play will result in a significantly more experienced player losing, but the odds are tilted in the better player's favor as much as any single draw deck card game can get.

Suffice to say, I feel I've merely scratched the surface of this game (Probably ~30 plays in person and many multiples of that on the computer).  While I don't particularly desire to play it 5 times in a row like some people do, rarely do I go more than a few gaming sessions without playing a game of Race.  It's the defacto filler+ for us.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of the best purchases i've made, this game is extremely challenging and just doesnt get old, the options make each game unique and I like the starter world concepts. Must have game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
2011-08-22

Initial Rating: 8.0 (June 2010)

I love RFTG, it’s my most played game of all time (except for MtG) and its on my top ten favorite games. I bought the game accidently and it was a happy one for a change :D.

RFTG has a surprising depth and I think the luck factor is rather low as the best player almost always wins, it has a short play time, plays nicely with 2,3,4,5 or 6 players (with the expansions) as the plays are simultaneous, it has a great theme (I love space games) and the art is terrific. On the bad side this game has a steep learning curve, EXPERIENCE MATTERS, so I have a hard time finding opponents to play with. One complaint from my gaming partners is that the iconography is very confusing, I have never understood this objection, for me, the iconography (almost all of it) is pretty clear and fairly intuitive.

I totally recommend it, if you find it difficult to learn, I encourage you to play through the pain, You won’t regret it.

Current Rating: 9.5
[hr]
2013-07-11

My girlfriend finally is requesting this game, she says she likes it more and more with each play. I’m so happy :D. For so long, no one in my game group wanted to play this with me :D.

I’m downgrading its rating to a 9.0 so my feelings for the game match the BGG recommended rating system. RFTG is an excellent game for me, one I always want to play. It is still in my top ten of favorite games. 

Current Rating: 9.0
[hr]
2015-05-01

It’s been almost 5 years since my first RFTG play and I still want to come back for more. It is no longer my most played game (Dominion is), but I still love the game and I´m always ready to play it. I’m thrilled that it is my SO favorite game :D, so now I can always play it if I want to. Also my game group has increased a lot during this 5 years, so many friends really like the game. 

I no longer consider a negative the steep learning curve, I have found that many of my favorite games share this trait. The real negative for me is having to teach the game. I have done so many times in the past and I’m getting better, but it is always a time consuming task and many times is for naught as some players won’t touch the game again. A RFTG game between two experienced players is pure bliss.

I have played the game many times, but sadly, I haven’t explored the expansions as much as I wanted to. The only one I have really played is The Gathering Storm. The reason for this is that most of the time we had newish players so we left off those cards. Another small issue is that if I play with the expansion and later want to pay with only the base game, separating the cards is time consuming. I’m thinking about buying another base game to avoid this.

Bottom line, RFTG is a GREAT game. I don’t think I will ever get tired of it. Now, I vastly prefer to play it as a two player game.

Current Rating: 9.0

2016-12-24

One of 2007´s favorites.

RATING: 10
For lovers of complexity like me, this is strictly better than San Juan.  There are numerous different strategies, and the cards combo together well enough for even a former Magic: The Gathering player.  I discovered new combinations constantly throughout my first 25-30 plays.  No, there's not much direct player interaction -- but if I want that there are other games I can play.

Iconography can make this game difficult to teach.  Even after more than 100 plays, though, I'm still willing to play this any time.  As much as my wife loves RftG, I think this game may have obsoleted all of the other two-player, sub-60 minute games in my collection.

RATING: N/A
No rating yet as I have played "Race for the Galaxy" a grand total of once. We had a stellar game that was a one point separation between all totals. Very close game.

I did not feel a ton of player interaction in it and I did miss it for one reason alone: I couldn't see how to stop--or even impinge--a running victory point engine across the table, but I did realize the game is exactly as advertised: a race. 

I had a lot of fun and I want to play more to get familiar with cards and tricks. I also greatly enjoyed the theme and did not find any issues with the iconography. I was able to pick it up fairly quick and managed to put in a very good showing vs. experienced players.

It was a Hell of a tight race. Not bad considering they could always choose the card they wanted from their hand.

I played "Glory to Rome" a number of weeks after "Race to the Galaxy". I may like that one a bit better, but both systems need more play. 

In contrast, "Glory to Rome" had a lot of player interaction and I could hamper another's play and still siphon off their moves as needed. I had a lot of room to maneuver. 

I should note that I did not feel stymied in either system and both allowed me paths of play each turn. I did not feel locked into one option in either game and could be flexible when needed.

"Race for the Galaxy" is a great looking game that flows well and I did have fun. Will I buy it? Maybe. I need to play it more and see what the expansions do to it. They could make it an absolute must. I do think the game is very worth owning.

RATING: 10
I like this game a lot. The cost is a little high for what works out to be two decks of cards - using card sleeves is necessary for long-term play. Addicting - it's like that viral behavior of Settlers - you play it a bit, then you start wanting your own copy to share with other friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
- A great game. I love the combos. It's really satisfying when you're able to massively pull off a particular strategy. 
- There is a fair amount of luck though in terms of the cards you draw and when you draw them.
- Really should be played 2 player. 3-4 players is okay, but the game really shines in a head-to-head setting as there's less luck/reliance on correctly predicting which actions players will pick. You're also able to achieve more on your turn with two actions. I feel this helps balance the Military vs. Produce+Consume strategies.
- With two players I find myself focusing more on the other player to anticipate their actions. You also might want to play cards that don't really fit into your strategy but take advantage of what your opponent is doing. With 3+ players, this feeling is diminished as players turn inwards, selecting the one action they need to happen.
- Massive learning curve due to all the iconography, especially if you include the expansions.
- Adding/removing expansions from the deck is a pain. My preferred combination of expansions is probably #1+#2 without takeovers, however #3 does flesh out some of the alternative strategies and helps minimise luck of the draw. It does however add complexity and slows the game slightly.
- I like playing this game fast and gung-ho. Better to play 3-4 games in quick succession than 1-2 slowly, carefully choosing every card to spend/discard. As a result, I avoid teaching this game or playing with newbies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like this card game. It has a sharp learning curve but pays off well. I can see a lot of depth in this one. Looking forward to getting expansions.

RATING: 4
Could a card game get any more confusing than this one?  Exceptions to actions, confusing card symbols, unclear rules,.. just a few of the problems we had while muddling through  our first few games.  After my second attempt, by rating has gone down.

I figured that after playing the game once, the symbols on the cards would get easier to understand... nope.  MAYBE ONCE YOU'VE PLAYED THE GAME 100 TIMES.

Another game that takes a simple system (like San Juan) and turns it into a monster.  I'm sure that there is lots of strategy here (if you ever figure out the cards) but, if you are a casual gamer, it's probably best to try (and I do mean 'try') to play a couple of games and then leave this on the shelf... the learning curve is that steep.

If you tend to play the same game 50 or more times, this might be a great addition to your collection but if you are like me, who might get to play the same game maybe twice in a year, RftG is a good one-shot and nothing more.

I think that I'll stick with San Juan.

RATING: 9
Race for the Galaxy is very close to being a ten in my books. A truly excellent game in terms of sheer replayability and variety (when combined with the cards from its original three expansions; I never play without them, so I'm basically reviewing the expanded game rather than the base game to which this rating is attached). RftG has easily the best time-to-reward ratio of any game I've played.

It's the inevitable shortcomings of the luck-of-the-draw tableau building format that make it remain a 9/10. Even at its best, with tight two-player games, the fundamental mechanics simply can't carry it to the pinnacle of enjoyment that a 10/10 would require. There's just not enough game there to let it, even though all of it that IS there is nearly flawless.

Still, a must-buy for any hobbyist.

RATING: N/A
[b][url=https://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/BoardGameGeek_Golden_Geek#toc8]2008 Golden Geek Winner[/url][/b]

In the card game Race for the Galaxy, players build galactic civilizations by playing game cards in front of them that represent worlds or technical and social developments. Some worlds allow players to produce goods, which can be consumed later to gain either card draws or victory points when the appropriate technologies are available to them. These are mainly provided by the developments and worlds that are not able to produce, but the fancier production worlds also give these bonuses.

Players:   2, 3, 4
Time:      30 min
Mechanics:  [property=2040][/property], [property=2020][/property], [property=2079][/property], [property=2015][/property]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It does have low interaction between players (solitaire), but as with Puerto Rico, you have to take a look at your opponents' game and analize it if you want to be competitive and win.

The artwork is beautyful. I highly recommend this game.
