RATING: 10
I feel strange rating Race for the Galaxy.  On the one hand, it's a great game, with loads of replay value.  I find it fun and interesting.  HOWEVER, it is also wildly over-priced for what you get.  You spend $35, and basically get a deck of cards and some cardboard scoring chits.  I understand that there are a lot of up-front costs...artwork, cards, etc., but that doesn't change the fact that RftG is a bit too pricey.

UPDATE:  I'm moving RftG up to a 9.  I want to play it pretty much all the time.  I've taught it to a bunch of people, and it has been a big hit.  YES, I still think it's over-priced for the stuff you get, but I've enjoyed it more than pricier games, so I can't complain as loudly as before.  We'll see, but if Race holds up, it might end up as one of my few 10s.

UPDATE:  It's a 10.  My girlfriend and I play this almost every day, and always more than once.  We both can't get enough of Race, and that makes it a 10 in our book!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
Deck building with a twist: you get the bonus but all players get to do the action you chose (speeding up play), planets can produce more cards or victory points, and the true victory is in card combinations. However, what planet you start or what major bonus card you draw determines you goal and playing style. More over, once you know your opponents, you know how each round is going to play out and it's all about the shuffle. Still, a reasonable game with good replay value.

BIG PLUS: strategy affects other players, relatively simple to learn
BIG MINUS: predictable opponents, strategies are limited
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My rating began at 8, went up to 8.5 and now up to 9.  This is an awesome game!  I can see this hitting 10 at some point.  There's a lot of gaming goodness in here!

If you use the initial starting hands (which I [i]highly[/i] recommend for your first few games) you have a choice of some pretty clear strategies.  Since playing without the starting hands, the strategy choices seem to be expanding, which is contrary to what I initially thought would happen.  The way the cards interact with one another and with your strategy is very subtle, something I feel San Juan lacks (there's like 2.5 strategies in San Juan).  The fact that the 6-point development cards give you in-game bonuses is sheer genius, and completely changes the nature of the game.  They drive your strategy (or they have the capability to do so).

Tactically this game is very rich, too.  Choosing which cards to discard can be a deliciously hard decision, much like in San Juan (but given the very wide variety of cards in Race for the Galaxy, it's that much more "fun").  Making the best with what you've got or adapting your strategy to what you're holding is part of the tactical decision-making needed each turn.

Finally, the multi-player solitaire feeling is not as prevalent in this as in San Juan, at least using the "advanced" 2-player version.  There's real angst in trying to figure out what your opponent(s) will choose for their action(s) as you try to decide on your own: do you go for the sure thing, try to compliment your guess at their choice, or will the bonus drive your decision?  Lovely stuff!

(P.S. after writing up this little review, I've changed my rating to a 9.5 -- it's that good!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent game and I can really see the similarities to Puerto Rico when I play it. However, the way the game plays with the simultaneous role selection and the ordered phases of the roles is fantastic. There is a learning curve to the game but come on most of the games on this site require you to learn the intricacies of the game.

Is the game multi-player solitaire? No more so than Puerto Rico to me. Much like Puerto Rico you can look over the table to see what you opponents have going for them in their tableau and also see the number of cards in their hand. Based on that you can make a hunch as to what role they are selecting. Do you want to develop/settle? Is there anyone else at the table holding a lot of cards? If so it likely that player is going to call one of those actions and if you have no preference as which then choose a different type of action that you'd also like to get done this round. 

Can people help out their opponents? Sure they can. However, unlike Puerto Rico where they tend to help out the player to their left, in RftG they could help any other player at the table. For instance if someone isn't paying attention to cards in play someone could play out a development/settle action that would allow another player to get to his twelfth card and end the game. 

Okay, so I've compared it to PR because of the similarities how about the differences. In PR I feel that there are a few standard opening moves and several buildings that are far superior buys than others. In RftG I have not seen a standard opening move. You have to initially deal with what you're opening hand is and then modify your agenda as you receive more cards. In PR coins are currency while in RftG the cards in your hand are the currency so you must decide what you're planning on playing onto the table vs use as currency. And since you can only get 12 cards to the table you have to decide how important each card is to your objective. There are times where a card that looks cool just doesn't really fit in with your plans so walk away.

A deep, rich, rewarding game with plenty of decisions to make that plays in  30 minutes and leaves you with the desire to play just one more hand...amazing.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A good game that doesn't live up to its hype.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game gets better and better. Played both multiplayer (best), against the robot (great) and with Keldon's AI (I just prefer playing with the physical cards, or else i might as well play a "real" computer game i think. Keldon's is great if you want to try out strategies). Such a great game in a small package. There is tons of tension and decisions have a great impact on how well you do. There is random elements with the cards, but luck plays a smaller factor that what appears after your first couple of games. Brilliant cardgame. I play with just the base game and Gathering Storm. tGS ads balance to the different roads to victory as well as adding the brilliant goals without adding anything fiddly (i'm looking at you expansion 2 and 3!!!) Looking forward to the Alien Expansion, it will hopefully get people to pay this game again :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The complex symbology used to show the interactions between developments, worlds and actions is daunting on a first play. Once you get accustomed to it, though, the gameplay is quite enjoyable. Lots of different cards, lots of options.

EDIT: After futher play, I've marked it down a notch. I'm starting to feel that the game plays TOO quickly, which puts you somewhat at the mercy of the cards. Yes, experience will better inform you which cards to keep, but the game feels a little bit too much like a crapshoot at times. The end point is entirely arbitrary and there is no sense of developing towards something. Honestly, if I'm going to play a game of complex card interactions, Netrunner is more interesting, has a clear goal besides netting a bunch of points, and is way more immersive!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bajo la apariencia de un juego de cartas futurista se esconde un buen juego con cierto gusto a juego de Civilizaciones, aunque es un juego de Gestión de recursos (bueno, en realidad no sé dónde ponerlo).

Mediante cartas se trata de ir desarrollando una especie de imperio, con el que tratas ganar puntos. Para ello cada jugador tiene cinco cartas que no forman parte de este imperio, sino que son las fases del juego. Cada uno decide en secreto al principio de la ronda qué fase va a jugar, lo cual le reportará unos beneficios. Es una mecánica muy parecida a la del Puerto Rico.

Un juego bastante interesante al que creo que le falta un poco de interacción más directa (poder atacar a tus rivales, por ejemplo), pero que seguramente es algo que se dejó para incluir en las ampliaciones.
[color=green]

Other than that - perfect card game for multiple players or even two (w/advanced rules).

RATING: 6

Also, the "cards-as-money" mechanic means that you have to play in a zen-like state where you're open to multiple implementations of an overall strategy and completely unsure whether you'll ever get any specific card. I like to be a little more calculating about combinations in a game such as this. I initially thought this would be a blast because of the CCG roots, but there's only a sliver of attraction left in this for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a fun game, but the first play through is tough because of all the symbols that need to be recognized. The symbols are well designed, but you have a lot of cards in your hand that need to be scanned quickly. It is an economic game in which you play a card for one of five actions that you want to do: get cards, develop technology or settle a planet, both which involve playing a card face up in front of you, produce goods, and consume goods. So initially you build up the economy to produce goods which gives you more cards and then as the game goes along start producing or playing cards to give victory points. There are many different types of cards and the space sci-fi art on the cards is nicely done.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I disliked this game at first. Yet another card game. Limited interaction. An exercise in multi solo card optimisation.

I was unconvinced at other players reports of it being the best game. I listed why it couldn't possibly be the best game.

Then someone said - it's just a card game. But for the time it takes to play, you have a lot of replayability, a lot of depth and many ways to go about things.

Which is true. Taking it like that - a really short but dense game, it is very good indeed.

After sticking it with for many plays I actually enjoy this quite a bit now, and like trying to optimise for a better score whilst attempting to take advantage of the subtle interplay between players of selecting actions.

Cool stuff. Took a very long time for me to appreciate it though.

---------------------------
This is pretty much the best game ever.  I can't recall being so eager to play a game.  It has loads of strategy, interesting decisions, hand management, and balanced diversity. This last point is probably where the game really shines, there are at least 4 distinct strategies and each plays very differently and has an equal chance of success. The balance in the game is mind boggling.

The only real criticism is the lack of interactivity between players, it feels a lot like multi-player solitaire much of the time. However there is heavy interaction in choosing actions, since all players have an option to perform the chosen action, especially in the production phase.  I'm assuming future expansions will address this issue, but to be frank it doesn't bother me very much, it is a very enjoyable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
So much like Korean "Go Stop", in that there are so many different ways to score points, with some cards able to score in different ways and thresholds for scoring, bonuses for sets, and on and on. The biggest difference being that in Go Stop, you can continue the game if you score the minimum needed first, to rack up more points, so it has a push-your-luck element as well, which is the 'go' part of the name. I actually think learning how to play the game is half the fun, although many people complain about the steep learning curve. A game with so many light bulb moments that you'll feel smarter just by playing!

RATING: 9
A swift and solid (as a rock) card game.  The hieroglyphic icons take a little bit of getting used to, but a few hands should be enough to see you into understanding.  Really, this is a revised, lightly tweaked and very tight remake of Puerto Rico set in space; and that isn't a criticism!  Where RfTG really comes into its own is through the careful creation of synergy: "I play card X so card Y will score and enable a return on card Z etc."

If I owned one card game, it'd probably be this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent card game which--like DOMINION--has great CCG-like mechanics but isn't a CCG.  The theme is perfect for the mechanics as well--science fiction--& players determine, with cards, which phases of the game within a turn will be played.  The initial start for newbies is a little daunting (especially if you've never played a CCG) with all the symbols on the cards showing what the card can do (rather than having text explaining it), so one will find themselves looking at the players reference card a lot.  It is for this reason I gave it a "9" instead of a "10" due to a late "AH-HA!" experience.  But once you have that experience, it's full-tilt-boogie-card-flopping-fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Race for the Galaxy is my most played strategic card game. The theme and artwork are really cool, and I like the idea that Tom Lehmann has tried to create a universe to paste on this abstract game. This game offers endless replayability, especially after adding the expansions. The Gathering Storm increased the possibilities of the rules in the core set, and freshened it up without adding game-changing mechanics. Rebel vs Imperium changed a lot, and not for the better; it added a lot of agression, which doesn't work for me in this game. The Brink of War added an enterely new way of scoring points, which makes the game a lot harder, but definately rewards flexible play. This game plays quickly, it is very deep, and makes games such as Puerto Rico and San Juan redundant for me, because the role selection is the most exciting bit of these games. I mostly play this game as a 2P game, using the double role selection variant. I have yet to try out the drafting variant. I am also very curious to see how the new Alien Artifacts expansion will work out; hopefully it will provide some fresh air in a game that has been played to death by my friend and me. UPDATE: I used to rate this game a 9, but it's starting to decrease to a 7: still a great game, but because it is so low on player interaction, I'm enjoying it less than I used to. Also, I'm getting more convinced that this is a better game when only played with The Gathering Storm expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Maybe its a result of playing with people who are more experienced at the game, or maybe it's that I don't understand the iconography near as well as I think I do - but this game just feels a mess to me.

The themes and ideas behind the game sound so interesting though, that I feel I need to give this another go with a group that is as inexperienced as I am.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favourite card games. The phase selection is brilliantly well done, and the gameplay and balance is so tight that it's almost unbelievable, especially when you look at the sheer amount of cards and options involved. Cards as currency is great and works perfectly. so many things that this game gets right. Unfortunately symbology is not one of them, which can be a turn-off for newbies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I used to hate this game. The rules are needlessly confusing and the iconography is horrible (Can I get a crib sheet for the crib sheet?). This is not a game you should try to teach yourself how to play. Having someone who knows how to play the game makes learning it much easier. The game feels like it is trying too hard. San Juan, a very similar game in mechanics, works great: easy to teach, quick to play, and intuitive. However, what I like about RftG is that it has more options than San Juan. Once you get past the horribly written rules and the poor card design, you see that this game has lots of different strategies and different paths to victory. In the end, you have a well-thought out system that was poorly implemented. And I still enjoy playing it immensely. I have played 200+ games of RftG and still love it! However, both expansions are poorly done and not worth the money.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

By far one of my favorite games.  I have hundreds of unlogged plays against the AI.  A different game every time, many paths to victory, and it scales very well.  Great fun!

RATING: 8
One of the few games we got just on a whim.  I knew a lot of people liked it here, but that it lost the Dominion vs. Race for the Galaxy battle here.  It turns out to be a great game.  Once I learned that it was first designed as a card version Puerto Rico I could see the similarities.  It is very interface intensive.  Meaning there are A LOT of icons that you have to learn before the game will just play smoothly.  Once you've learned the icon system it is a quick, fun game. 

It is another game that has little to no conflict with the other players, which makes for a great game with my wife.  If you want conflict you can get an expansion, which we have not done.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The game is fun, but only if you like luck-based games.  Once you know the cards and understand how they go together, it becomes who gets lucky with cards.  Ever had all those production worlds, but just couldn't draw a SINGLE 6-pointer while the other guy places EVERY rebel world in the deck?  Yeah, that's luck.

4 stars overall.
8 stars if you like luck-oriented games.
1 star if you like skill-based games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
Number of players: 2-4

Components: (10)
The cards are wonderful quality and the VP tokens are thematic and functional.
  
Rules: (10)
The rules are written in a very accessible and pragmatic manner. 

Setup: (9)
It's a slight thing to have to keep the starting planets sorted, and a lesser thing to have to keep the action cards sorted. It's not horrible, though.

Area required to play: (9)
You'll need enough room for everyone to have about 12 cards in front of them, with enough room around those cards to have cards on top of them, but not covering all the information.
 
Fun: (10)
This is one of the best games that I have ever played.

Theme Integration / Mechanics: (9)
The theme is wonderful and works. I didn't notice, until the third time that I played, that I was playing a Euro. It is a little weird to have your hand of cards and also a hand of action cards. It's something that you soon grow used to (also, once you're familiar with the action cards, you don't have to hold them so much as you have to know which one you're ready to select).

Replay Value: (10)
I've yet to play with any expansions and I already feel like I could never grow bored with this game. I can only imagine what will happen when I add more variety into the mix.

Storage: (10)
Get a deck box and you're set.

Accessibility: (5)
This game really isn't crazy complex, but those symbols really turn a lot of people off. I love them and think that it's perfectly functional and becomes second nature after the first game.

Over-All/Bonuses/Biases: (+10)
This is one of my absolute favorites and I don't foresee this ever changing.

RATING: 8
I'm not a fan of the science fiction theme, and I don't really even like San Juan all that much.  But this game intrigues me.  I like how quickly it plays and there seems to be many different paths to victory.  The multiplayer solitaire criticism doesn't really bother me all that much since the game is so fast - I can understand why people say this, but the guessing game of who picked what role is interaction enough for me.  One minor problem is that it is difficult to make sure that your opponents aren't cheating or playing wrong, but that's more of a group problem than a game problem - it shouldn't be a factor for me.  I hope to find some people with whom to play regularly, as I can see how this game will open up with repeated play.

RATING: N/A
A very clever card game with interesting mechanics: the five phases complement each other amazingly well. I like how you select the phase simultaneously and everyone has to do that phase. This certainly gives a twist to the game in that you do not only decide for yourself but for the other players as well. 
One has to prepare for a steep learning curb when learning the game, but it seems, if you persevere it will be rewarding. It took me a while to figure out how the different phases work together, let alone the symbols. 
Playing the game on the computer and watching one or two tutorials can help a lot.
Rating will depend on future plays with my family.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It took me a few plays of this game to wrap my brain around this game (even though I have played San Juan before).  The first play tends to be quite overwhelming, but after a couple of plays, everything makes sense and then you start to appreciate all the different cards and different possible combinations.  I suggest that you give yourself 2-3 games before deciding if you don't like it because it takes a couple of plays to get over the initial bewildering possibilities.

In the first few games, it seems like people tend to build a lot of small cards and end the game without much consumption or 6-developments.  At this point, the military strategy seems to be king.  Then someone will start produce-consume 2x and then the consume strategy for VP seems to be king.  Unlike San Juan, the 6 developments are quite powerful and should be built early in the game since they garner you with nice bonuses.

It looks like with experience, the game will last around 30 minutes.  There is quite a lot of depth for such a quick playing time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
For a long time I wasn't fascinated about the idea of playing this because it was so widely compared to San Juan. When finally playing I liked it as so many others have also liked. Good scifi art and lots of puzzling symbols give the game a CCG feel, but as a process it actually reminded me most of Catan Card Game. Winning doesn't feel too important here, it's rather about your own top scores. That unfortunately also turns the game towards the direction of solitaire. I also suggest using a maximum of one expansion when playing. My main problem with RftG is that games often tend to end when the engines are running and it starts to get interesting.

RATING: 8.5
Mostly play the game with 2 players, but it's a very different beast with more. The shared actions mean that a 3-5 player game has some push your luck as to which actions will be available, and trying not to benefit your opponents with your selection: it's a much more interesting game IMO. With 2, the game is very tactical, and results are more luck-based as you take away much of the strategy behind action selection.

RATING: 7
This was easy to pick up and I think the iconography is very straight forward.  I could explain this to anyone without difficulty.  I really wouldn't predict that I like this game.  It really doesn't have a ton of strategy (your roll you choose mostly depends on the # and type of cards in your hand), everyone benefits from your action (something that bothered me in Eminent Domain), and it is quite multi-player solitaire.  You can't attack your neighbor and nothing I did affected him at all.  And yet I really enjoyed it.  The theme is so immersive for me.  I think the artwork is partially responsible for this; it is quite possibly my favorite artwork in a card game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Pretty underwhelmed after 2 plays.  There are some neat ideas in the game, and despite the built-in randomness associated with the card drawing, it does appear possible to cobble together combos of various worlds and developments in a way that is interesting and satisfying.  But the game is over much too quickly -- just as you feel like you're getting some traction and starting to get your "engine" up and running, poof!, it's one or two turns away from the game end.  The name is quite apt, but hurried nature of the gameplay jars with the theme of explore/develop/produce.  The game seems to have a moderate learning curve with respect to playability -- you are looking at so many cards with so many different effects and trying to figure out which cards to keep and which to discard.  Presumably this gets easier with repeat plays but the range of effects makes this daunting initially.  It's frustrating when figuring out what your options are is more difficult and time consuming than deciding which option is your best.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Tableau builder with the same design starting point as San Juan. I found it much more accessible, and the flavour is well done. That still doesn't make me a fan of tableau builders, I'm afraid. Gameplay is solitaire-ish; you can pay some attention to what everyone else is doing but this slows the game down, and in essence you're racing an unpredictable clock. Pursuing a military strategy is a crapshoot since your progression can be completely shut down for several turns. Production should be more reliable, though there are still obvious push-your-luck aspects. I can recommend everyone to try mrkeldon's computer version (with borgemik's patch), but [-]it wouldn't be my first choice[/-] I would never request it with other people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
San Juan on 'roids.  Tough decisions and lots of them.  It lacks the simple elegance of San Juan but makes up for it with complex play.

RATING: 9
Rated after one two player play with my 13 year old brother in which we got a few rules wrong, but nothing major.

This game seems really fun. Definitely overwhelming at first with the number of icons, but everything fits together very cleverly and the variety of strategies to achieve victory seems very wide. I am looking forward to figuring out this game!

That said, I suspect after 50 plays or so one might find the strategy becomes clear and knowledge of the cards makes replayability less interesting. A little more interactivity would be nice: perhaps the expansions provide this.

I think this will play 45 minutes easily as we get better.

Big, huge advantage to those who know the cards well, etc.

RATING: 10
(Spanish)
Uno de los mejores juegos de desarrollo que he jugado. Las reglas parecen complicadas en un principio, pero una vez que aprendes la mecanica resulta rapido y sencillo de jugar. Eso si, con muchisimas posibilidades estrategicas y muchas formas de conseguir la victoria.
La caja incial presenta una reglas muy interesantes y bien balanceadas. Creo que el factor suerte es poco, casi todo el peso cae sobre la estrategia elegida y sobre la eleccion de las acciones que juegas en cada turno. Segun elijas que fase jugar en cada momento , daras un paso hacia la victoria o hacia el desastre. 
Esto lo hace un juego complicado de dominar, pero muy interesante. Cada partida es diferente, sobre todo si utilizas las expansiones que abren muchisimas nuevas estrategias y posibilidades.
Un gran juego de con un balance perfecto entre las cartas que permiten a cualquiera ganar la partida siguiendo la estrategia que elija.

RATING: 8
[10/1/09: Thought about giving this a 9, but I dinged this back down by a point because there are times when you just can't get the cards you need, especially when you're playing with one of the groups that're shoehorned into a particular strategy. Alpha Centauri and New Earth can be absolutely obnoxious to play as sometimes, if you just don't draw the Rare cards. It's still a great game, and the AI available is fantastic for practice.]

WAY better than Dominion due to its interestingly variable paths to victory - if the right cards came up early on, I'd imagine even the New Spartans I played as my first time might be shoehorned into a produce-and-trade veep strategy. 

I won the only game I've played, most likely due to luck. It's fun, but I have to ding it a few steps for its total lack of interaction. I was told that an expansion's in the works that'll allow for offensives, and while I can imagine that without constraints, this will just turn into a hammer-the-leader mechanism or something that hands the victory to the New Spartans, I'm sure there'll be some balancing in there. Anyway, I'd love to play this more; it's not too long, and you can get creative with your strategy.

RftG does intensify my regret at having blown $30 on Dominion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is brilliant.  In a matter of 12 cards, you try to build a point-grabbing engine; but of all the games similar to Race, none of them do it with this much subtlety and nuance.

However, that also means there's a high barrier to entry.  Figuring out how to play Race can be like learning a new language, and getting burned by constant losses.  It's difficult to introduce this game to people, and that makes it imperfect for me.

But once you're in, the game rewards you with seemingly limitless variations of its puzzle, and it's so quick and dynamic that I can't help but keep trying to solve it again and again.  For the initiated, this game is a true modern classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
It's such a struggle to get the hang of at first, but once you have it down, Race is such a fun game.  I love the impossible decisions that come when you need to sacrifice a card.  The "phases" mechanic makes it unique and not just a deck-builder of sorts; planning which phase card to play is a delicate dance every time.

Race has been accused of being a multiplayer solitaire game, which isn't totally unfair.  Your opponent's choices won't affect your plans much at all.  Personally, I don't mind that in a game.  The fun for me comes from analyzing my position and deciding what to pursue, not from "gotcha" moves against others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In space, micro-management, developement and synergies are beautiful.

RATING: 9
I once had an unfavorable out look on this (claiming I wouldn't want to play it again).  However, it stuck in my head long enough that it just itched, so I bought it.  Happily, buying it and playing frequently hasn't alleviated the itch much.

I haven't played it a lot compared to others, but I have played it a lot compared to other games in my collection (at least 20 times over the course of the first month of owning it).

I look forward to playing it, and each game opens up new strategies and results.  Between two equal players there is a good amount of luck involved (what cards are you going to draw) but it does allow to adapt based on what you do draw.  Like many great games, this one sticks in my head and after every game begs to be played again.

RATING: 8
Rating based on solitaire play to learn rules.

A huge upgrade to San Juan.  Similar game play with a much better theme and many more strategies.  I love how the different "6" cards can impact the development path you can choose to take.  This rating could go way up with FTF play.

I also don't understand the  many criticisms of the symbols on the cards.  It isn't that difficult to learn what the symbols and colors mean, and the player aid card is a great help.

RATING: 10
I've never liked a game as much as Race. Variety while retaining balance is one of my top criteria for liking a game, and this delivers. The years spent playtesting really show through.
Don't believe those who'll tell you 2-player is the best way to play: it'll do if you're lacking players and don't have anything better to play, but a lot of the interesting tempo manipulation and mindgames are lost.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent follow-on game to San Juan. Up to four players gather resources and take control of planets. The first player to get twelve cards (planets, technology, etc) on the table (as in San Juan) or when the bank empties, ends the game. Then total up the VPs and declare a winner. Although the mechanics are similar to San Juan, there is a lot more here. The cards contain tons of symbols that must be decoded. They are in the manual, but you have to do a lot of hunting to find them.I can't wait for the expansions! Rumor has it that two expansions were delivered to Rio Grande along with the final version of the game. I fully expect the base game to sell out pretty quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Played only once (edit: twice now).  I'm sorry, but I was extremely irritated by it.  It is gratuitously overcomplicated; there is no "elegance" to its design.  It's hard to imagine the designer actually having rejected any of his clever ideas for strangely complex cards he could add to the game.  There are a great many similarities to San Juan, but in that game, the number of distinct cards is reined in and their functions are more natural/fundamental, which means you can spend your time thinking on the next level -- about how various combinations of these cards will help your particular situation.  But here with RFTG you have a gigantic mess of specialized functions that feel very contrived.

I think this game appeals mainly to the type of gamer that wants to spend hours studying a game and memorizing all the cards and what they do, so that they can then use their superior knowledge to win games they play against the uninitiated.  I'll pass...

Update: I actually wanted to play it again. And I tried really hard to like it this time. But it still sucked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Did not like this the first (or even second) time played, but it has definitely grown on me. Looking forward to trying the expansions in the future.

RATING: 6
Quick playing time: check.

Fun: hmm, where did I put the fun?

I haven't enjoyed playing this one yet. I am trying. I think I can pretty much follow the iconography at this point. But I haven't been able to find a way to have a good time playing.

It doesn't help that I play badly and can't, for example, figure out how to get a trade-consume engine going.

It also doesn't help that the early draws usually seem to push you into a strategy, and if later draws don't support that strategy, you lose. The game isn't long enough to change focus partway through.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Includes the Expansions:
Race for the Galaxy: Alien Artifacts (English first edition) (2013)
Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm (English first edition) (2008)

Rating after one play with the Alien Artifacts expansion. The production value is great, for such a simple card game. The artwork on the cards is truly evocative of their different names and abilities. Like Fleet, you are building a point-scoring engine by adding cards to your tableau. However, unlike Fleet, you have no way to interfere with the plans of your opponents. Instead of an auction mechanic, RftG employs role selection. This is just enough to keep you paying attention to what everyone is doing, but not enough to really give you an impact on what they do. I would say that it's even one step removed from card drafting as an interactive element. That said, RftG plays quickly, and once you get the hang of the five actions you can get in a truly strategic game in around 30-45 minutes. The box suggests it for ages 12 and up, and I'd say that's about right. My 12 year-old could play it, but was frustrated at times and needed some help. Would be rated higher, but it is only really great as a two-player game.

Replaced by Roll for the Galaxy.

RATING: 10
Incredible game, I've played 100+ games of this and I can't wait to play some more! Finally a game that uses randomness as a way to change how it is played each time and not simply destroy any kind of strategy. Lots of different strategies, I'm still amazed to find some different ways to win, even after all the games I've played. Each turn, you have critical choices to make and they will deeply affect the outcome.

It's a game that takes time to master, I would say that only after 10-15 games you start to feel some of the strategy involved. The symbol system can annoy new players but it isn't that bad really. Without a doubt the game with the best bang for the money I have in my collection.

RATING: 9
Pierwsza. Podobno trudna bo wiele ikonek iwogóle ;) Bardzo, bardzo dobra gra. Niestety wymaga trochę wysiłku w poznaniu jej. Jednak po zrozumieniu ikonografii i zasad to mechanika gry wydaje się prosta jak budowa cepa - choć instrukcja temu przeczy. Wzorzec dla zwrotu "easy to learn, hand to master" trochę jak w przypadku szachów nie tak trudno się nauczyć ruchów a bardzo trudno zostać mistrzem. Mnogość różnych strategii i dróg zwycięstwa. Dla dobrze znających grę bardzo krótkie partie. Wymaga kombinowania i promuje znających karty. Masa ludzi uwielbia tę grę, wielu gra na komputerze w wersję ze sztuczną inteligencją lub z innymi online, wyszła na androida wersja beta (ang). GFP a obecnie GF przebąkiwała że chce ją wydać po polsku ale ostatnio przycichło.
Do podstawowej części są jeszcze trzy dodatki i razem tak naprawdę tworzą jedną już dosyć skomplikowaną grę (Arc 1)(pewnie dlatego została podzielona na cztery by gracze ją strawili). Oprócz tego jest jeszcze Arc 2 i Arc 3 obie są jakby innymi grami ale obie korzystają z tej samej podstawki dodając inny zestaw kart i nieco innych zasad. Arc 2 - Alien Artifakt - dodatkowo tworzy się modułową planszę w której wyszukuje się artefaktów obcych, Arc 3 - Xeno Invasion - oprócz gry przeciwko drugiemu graczowi jest  jeszcze chyba jakaś semikooperacja czy coś, by walczyć z kosmitami. Kart z różnych Arc nie można mieszać.

2-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
"Race for the Galaxy"

2-4 (1-5 с дополнением)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Race for the Galaxy is a great example of how to craft a solid game based on snowball economies and optimization: add extensive doses of deduction.

Each turn players simultaneously and secretly choose an action. All players have access to the same pool of actions, and the one who picks each of them perform it with a bonus, but the rest of the players will be able to perform it too. Actions which aren't picked by any player are skipped for that round. This forces players to create efficient engines which not only run on their own, but also can benefit from the other player's actions, while simultaneously benefiting their opponents as little as possible. Players not only work with their own engine in their heads: they must keep everyone else's engine in mind.

This makes most interactions incredibly subtle and indirect, as there is no way of directly affecting your opponents. Yet it's not a "multiplayer solitaire", as truly efficient play requires extensive deduction.

The game's biggest flaw is its learning curve, which is stupidly high: you need to be very familiar with the deck. Multiple plays are required, as it's impossible to play without having a general idea of what you can draw. And while it's easy for a newbie to see an efficient combination once in action, the game mechanisms obscure what other players do. This is due to the fact cards can be either built or used as currency, and all discards are made face down. This means newbies can't truly analyse what veterans are doing, as they simply see the results.

Newbies are exposed to a tremendous overload of information. Thankfully, once all players are familiar with the game, it flows super fast. A game with newbies can easily last an hour or longer but, once all players are familiar with it, games can be consistently finished in twenty minutes or less.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:2,4

[i]For more information on how I rate games, [geekurl=/user/Kodeir]go to my profile[/geekurl][/i]

Love the possibilities for different strategies and the feeling of some sort of space opera - if you can get into the theme, you will have fun describing how your empire is growing to your fellows. Only thing that doesn't make me rate this 10 anymore: The new military rules of the second expansion feel to complicate and artificial for this elegant game. They don't give the feeling of a real interaction but are more annoying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Even though it's tableau building, doesn't feel too much like multiplayer solitaire (though it does a little), as you rely on others to take actions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My thoughts on this peculiar bird:
*Expensive for the pack of cards and a few counters you get.
*Player interaction is quite limited.
*Enjoyable for players who do not like direct confrontation.
*Play mechanics and resource management are smooth and well-designed.

This thing has a steep learning curve, and rewards knowing the deck by heart (yes, even with the three expansions you better know what cards are in there...)

Race for the Galaxy is a geek's game, requiring quite a bit of thought and time investment to learn. Basically, it's most suited for mathematically minded adults; my 15-year old brother calls it 'Rape for the Galaxy' and will go nowhere near it.

It is a no-no for new gamers and grandma.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Perfect game.
9 only because of steep learning curve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Might trade - have to replay
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The iconography is initially very confusing however the game mechanics are simple and fun to play. A 4 player game takes around 60mins and player interaction is better than expected. The game isn't too head wrecking either so you don't feel mentally drained afterwards. I'd rate it higher if the icons were easier to follow.

Don't attempt the drafting method, it would take as long to draft as to play as every card would entail AP.

Rule clarifications:
1) Stacking powers. Any '+' or '-' ability stacks, so you could have an explore of +10 cards to pick up for instance. This also applies to a single Trade. For Consume however, there isn't a plus/minus symbol so the powers don't stack.
2) If multiple players chose the same card, the action happens once.
3) If any player chooses Trade/Consume, ALL players MUST Consume using ALL of their Consume abilities if possible, The players determine the order of Consumption as benefits them most.
4) 2xConsume only applies to VPs, specified in the manual.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really enjoy this one -- I think it takes all of the good elements of Puerto Rico, adds a much cooler theme and artwork (who doesn't get a thrill at picking up references such as "Spice World" or the nods to David Brin's "Uplift" series?), and does a much better job of getting across the feeling to every player of building up a galactic empire.

UPDATE: Having now played with goals, it's REALLY hard to go back.  I first played with goals on the Genie server, and had to go buy Gathering Storm once I realized how much it adds to the game -- higher interactivity (direct competition for the same goals) and your galactic empire has a purpose.

RATING: 9
Very good card game space themed .In RftG you have to develope your space civilizatin by conquering planets,produce on them, develope improvement,and commerce.
It's fast but funny and very replayable ,similar to Puerto Rico and his card verion San Juan but a little more complex than the last one.The only thing is that tere isn't direct interaction,the only interaction is that roles played by you will be played without the benefit even by other players so you have to try to predict what other players could play in order to play a perfect turn.

A lot of strategies are possible and expansions add more and more.

RATING: 6
The comments on vandemonium's [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/31418]Games I lost this weekend[/url] list make me curious about this.

[b]Update 2008-06-28:[/b] after trying it (a 3-player game with two experienced players--klellingson & his son), I thought it was "OK," but not my kind of thing.  We played fast, with only a little inspection of what the other guys were doing (at least on my part), so it really was like the multi-player solitaire which people complain about.  Not bad, but not the kind of thing I would ever play with anyone I know.

[b]Update 2010-07-08[/b] (2 years later): I was wrong.  Dan got me this for my birthday a couple months ago, and we--and by "we" I mean "almost everyone I know"--have been playing the heck out of this.  I don't understand why we like it, but we do.  (Ray won't like it.)

[b]Update 2011-02-24:[/b] I may as well make this a 10.  Liking the same thing everyone else likes just rubs me the wrong way, but almost everyone loves this game, from Hellhammer (age 7) on up.  I think it's heavily luck-based, but we'll have nights where the same person will win five games in a row.  The difference between how much I thought we would like this, and how much we actually like this, proves I'm not that good at predicting what games we'll like.

:star: :star: :star: :star: :star: [b]Update 2017-03-22:[/b] after [i]literally thousands[/i] of plays with every combination of expansions, I'm [i]finally[/i] kind of burned out on this, so dropping it to a 6 ("well... OK, I'll play this").  No matter how you measure it, though, this game has been [b]my best dollars-per-hour-of-fun[/b] of [i]all time.[/i]  It's a goddamn luckfest, but it gives the all-important [i]illusion[/i] of meaningful choice.  If you haven't played this, play it.  If you've played this once or twice & didn't like it, play it again.  It's a great game, and if you don't like it, [i]you[/i] are the problem.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This game seemed like a more complex (and prettier) San Juan, so I will compare it to San Juan.

The more complicated rules allow for more tactical decisions, and the space exploration theme is always a good one.

However, this game suffers the exact same flaws as San Juan: the randomness of the cards that wind up in your hand can ultimately make or break your chances of victory, and there is almost exactly NO player interaction--it's very much like a multi-player solitaire (military ratings are only used for conquering planets that can't be colonized normally, NOT for battling other players!). I'm told that at least one expansion makes the game more interactive between players, so that will really be a good thing.

RATING: 9
Great game that plays well for 2 but scales up well to 4 as well.  The cheat sheets can be intimidating but it's because they show all of the various combinations of symbols.  It all makes sense & the cheat sheets don't have to be explained in detail when teaching the game.

Familiarity with the cards makes the game more enjoyable.  Subsequent plays make the game even more fun.  It's kind of like playing a board game made out of cards.

The base set doesn't have much player interaction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The game is reasonably easy to pick up, depending on the way it's taught.  However, the particulars of the cards available in the game can significantly influence how well a player scores, in a way that new players may not be aware except through luck of the draw (e.g., drawing a card that happens to work well with other cards drawn, as opposed to planning for one of the cards known to work well with what you have).

As player skill improves across the game, so does the opportunity for strategy.  I really enjoy the advanced two-player game for the added control.  The expansion cards further balance the game, and the homeworld-choosing option helps as well.  I think some of the goals throw more randomness back in though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

Nice cards, though, but I even have problems with the artwork: in San Juan you can clearly see who has which type of buildings and other cards - in RftG it's a lot harder.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[2008.Mar.29] For gamers who enjoy Puerto Rico and San Juan, this card game is a must have. Based on the widely acclaimed Puerto Rico, Race for the Galaxy is its own game (albeit with quite a unique and colorful history) and is the smarter-and-sleeker card game that San Juan should have been (not to take anything away from San Juan, which is a good game itself). The similarity between it and its progenitor (Puerto Rico) should be quite obvious to almost everyone. Where this game takes a quantum leap forward is through the thorough usage of symbology on the cards. These symbols that appear on the cards--although daunting and seemingly incomprehensible at first--are an excellent summary of each card's ability, and is a breakthrough in design and presentation. It is very important to note that this game is best when played more than once. Familiarity with the different cards (and their abilities) is critically important for improved play. Give the game a try, but please play it more than once before rating it here on BGG--you'll be glad that you did. See you amongst the stars!

:star::star::star::star::star:

RATING: 9
This is a perfect storm for me: I learn abstractions like the icons easily, so I find the gameplay fluid and joyous. The core game mechanic is also about creating order out of chaos on a round-by-round but evolving axis, which is probably one of my favorite game activities--one that I am also pretty proficient at.

Luck can play a pretty strong role once all the expansions are merged in, which is a bit of a bummer.

RATING: 3
I did not like it much. First it's really confusing, there is a lot of components reusing and it's hard to catch the flow of the game. I don't like that you chose one role cards and that the other cards are just useless in your hands for the rest of the round. I don't like the fact that the only interaction with othr players is to try to guess which card they are going to play. Analysing your board is hard enough, analysing other people's board to expect that they intend to do is almost impossible since there is too much information to analyse and remember. In puerto rico, you an easily see what is going to happen by glancing at another player's board, here you can't because there is too much rules and abilities involved.

I would have prefered a game where all phase occur each turn and playing your role card only gives you the bonus. Being able to play more than 1 role card each turn but only recover 1 card randomly each turn could also be interesting. I would also loved more player interaction like attacking your opponent. Or if you play the same role card that somebody else, you need to bid another card (bottom right value) and the loser does not play this phase.

RATING: 10
I find RftG very enjoyable and did not find figuring out the iconography difficult at all.  The first play or two might be a little slow figuring everything out, but it is fairly intuitive.  Of course, experienced players are at a huge advantage since they will know the card combinations that exist.  Much better than San Juan in every aspect!  I appreciate that each game is different - sometimes its a slower paced game more focused on developing engines to churn out victory points via production, other times it ends up being a straight up race to get 12 cards laid.  There are times where you will need 50+ points to win, and other times where even 20 points might win you the game!

NOTE:  I only give this a 10 with 2-3 players and preferably with the expansion.  I prefer not to play this game with 4 or 5 as it is harder to find the cards you desire when pursuing strategies.

RATING: 2
Did SAN JUAN need to be buried under the rubble of complexity and arcane iconography?  In brief, No.  Making the role selection a simultaneous action has the effect of introducing a dull guessing game, or maybe an un-interesting game of chicken.  In the end, yet another solo optimization race. This is worse than Princes of Florence for me. RATING: 3
It is a game that seldom popular among wargamers too.  Colorful card art, thematic imagination about the sky, card multiplayer play...all add up to a success formula.  However, it doesn't work on me unfortunately.  The lack of a cooperative mode, neither nor competitive, renders this game colorless, instead of colorful.  No interactivity of any sort. The strategy seems to be for everyone going it alone, with what you have at hand and on the table. Or you just follow like hitchhiker in UNO.  Yes, the title is aptly named: it is a race.  The player who gets to the objective: either  deploying 20 cards onto the table or the victory points pool is all consumed.  Limited time and resources for you to do all sorts of things: explore, develop, produce or consume.  By the time you think you are just beginning to reap with your "perfect" plan, someone might have already won the game and ended it.  Oh, God, I should have discarded all those useless cards!  But how do you know?  It is that kind of uncertain chaos that ruin a player's experience in the end.  It is too random for my taste...like playing poker cards.  Where is my heart?  Or that King?  It might be fun for a family in an afternoon with a cup of tea.  To wargamers, definitely it is a hype and best to stay away.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Rich management game with indirect but real interaction between players.  The following is partly based on what I heard my fellow players say, and on my own perception of the game.

* It takes one play of intense thinking to grasp the mechanics; you then feel like playing Race for the Galaxy again, after investing so much thoughts in the game.  You understand that you could have scored double the number of points you did.

You feel much more at ease during the second play, and you start to become immersed in the game mechanics.  You can really see how your cards can be combined and produce victory points.  In our game, the player who had played once had twice as many points as the two trailing players.

In later plays, you start paying attention to what the other players are doing, and try to profit from the actions they will probably choose, or use actions that do not benefit them.

* I like the fact that powers are expressed with symbols: even though they take one or two games to grasp, they allow you to quickly gauge the power of your cards.  Plus, the possible combinations between cards become graphically obvious.  I prefer this graphical system to the text found in San Juan.

* This game feels like San Juan to me, with an added tension coming from the simultaneous choice of role: you do not feel like your role was imposed on you (as can happen in San Juan), and you can concentrate on your plans.  Of course, the others are doing the same, and you can feel the "race" between players.

* After 150 games (with the 4 first expansions), the richness of the game still amazes me: I still regularly encounter new combos that were never used before. This includes Takeovers in 2-player games: they are very rarely used, but promise to be quite memorable when they do.

* I like how the complexity of the game can be tuned through adding more or fewer expansions. The feeling of deeply learning the smaller game is nice. The intricate variety of possibilities offered by the first arc expansions is incredibly rich.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Con expansión "The Gathering Storm" y "Rebel Vs Imperium"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is one of the most confusing games to learn.

Each card give you a benefit.  If the cards had the benefit written out in text, I think the game would be much more fun to play.  Instead they have designed a huge set of graphics, all about 1 inch wide x 1/2 inch tall, trying to communicate what the benefit is.  This is extremely confusing.  We spend half our game trying to decipher the graphics often having to resort to the internet to get help. To me, this graphic representation of card benefits is a handicap to game play.

Also planets produce and consumer goods.  The way the game tracks these good is to take a face down card off the draw deck and place it on the planet.  It doesn't matter what the card does.  It is just a place holder for a good. Not only that but a color is associated with it.  This is also very confusing.  I would like it better if they just had some cards to represent the good or color cubes or something.  I think having actual cards for the goods on planets would eliminate a lot of confusion.

All that said, the game mechanics are fairly fun.  Once I figured out what most of the graphics meant, I starting thinking of stategies for future games.

I think it would be a good game but I have a lot of design issue with the cards.  I'd love to try to redesign them to be more intuitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I love this game. I don't even care if the theme is "pasted-on" and there is no direct player interaction. It's a blindingly fast and involved economic engine builder with simultaneous action/phase selection (read: an element of opponent prediction) and randomisation that keeps it fresh but will rarely determine the winner. Too bad about the steep learning curve, but there was no way around it.

RATING: 6
Most of what you've heard about it is true. Yes, Race for the Galaxy is a good game. Yes, it feels like it lacks direct interaction. Yes, knowing the deck helps massively. Yes, the game is easy to play once you're into it but with rules hard to grok and a confusing icon system, the barrier to entry is very high. But if you like games and have the opportunity to be introduced to RftG by someone who knows it well, you should definitely give it a try (and then another try because you're first play might very well be horrible).

RATING: 10
My first plays of RftG left me wondering, concerned, and confused. The game was complex and damn near impossible to teach, but I kept coming back to it to learn more about it. Eventually it became my most played game of 2008, then my most played game ever!

I like it because:
-- Card games are fun especially when playing a clever card combo. 
-- The space theme is nice change from historical themes.
-- The icongraphy is some of the best I've ever seen.
-- It plays quickly thanks to simultaneous actions and consistent icons. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Loads of fun and depth once you grasp the iconography.  Recommend trying the computer version first to learn the game.  Cards are gorgeous, and expansions keep the game fresh.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Since we really liked [GAMEID=8217], [GAMEID=28143] seemed like it should have been a sure shot.  However, we held off on getting it for quite a while.  I was worried about the theme and the iconography not being appealing.  However, we finally got this in a trade and once we tried it out, we were hooked!  It's now one of our favorite games, and probably the second heaviest game that we have.

I shouldn't have worried.  This game was an amped up [GAMEID=8217]---it took the same basic gameplay, but added so much more.  It retained the feeling of building special cards, but in this case separated out Worlds and technology-oriented Developments.  However, added to these card combos were so many more paths to victory---you could go military, you could go exploring valuable worlds, you could set up a production/consumption engine.  All of this kept the game very fresh, although we're looking forward to trying the expansions.

The theme:  I was initially afraid that she wouldn't like the theme, although in retrospect I wouldn't have thought that Spanish colonialism would have been an attractive theme anyway.  She does put up with it, and she had a lot of fun with the art (especially cards like the Galactic Trendsetters or the Resort).  On the other hand, I really like the theme as I was a big fan of the Davin Brin Uplift novels.  Although abstracted, I do get the feeling of building a space empire.  I think that the more routes here compared to [GAMEID=8217] makes the game a little more real---e.g., there's a gameplay and thematic difference to military or production strategies.

The icons:  We had no problem with them.  By the second or third game, it wasn't even an issue anymore.  I was a little surprised by that, and thought that we would miss the text, but the icons producd a very clean result and lets you easily see what your opponent is building.

Interactivity:  Although it's been called multiplayer solitaire, we find the game has quite a bit of interactivity.  We're always looking at what each other is doing and we're constantly trying to guess and bluff what phase the other player will call that turn.  It's an additional layer of optimization that you have to do to play well.

Complexity:  I was worried about the complexity of the game, but it turned out to not be a problem.  She quickly grasped the rules and by the fourth or fifth game she was already scoring up to 54 points.  However, if we had not played [GAMEID=8217] before, it probably would have been [i]very[/i] difficult to pick up.  If you haven't played either, I would suggest picking [GAMEID=8217] up first.  On the other hand, the added complexity adds a lot to the game.  Having played [GAMEID=28143], I'm not sure if we'll ever go back...

So far, we've only played it with two, and mostly with the experienced two player rules.  It works very well.  This is another case where the two player game is different from the multiplayer game---you now call two phases each turn.  This gives you more control and ease in executing card combos, making the game more strategic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of those nigh-infinite-variations card games. Victory point collection based on both cards played in your tableau and actions taken during the game. There's a small but multifaceted variety of strategies available, and the randomness is relatively controlled via cards instead of dice, which really helps.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like space themed games. RftG is fast and many strategies can be pursued. 

I think the players who have played often enough can tailor their play to what they see coming out from others. Not a problem but expansion may fix that.

The only "downside" is that there is no direct interaction with other players other than you perform what somewhat else chooses.

I've heard rumors that Tom is considering a more interactive game expansion subsequent to the long delayed 1st expansion.

RATING: N/A
Players: 2-4
Best: 2, 4
Time: 30-60 Min
Type: Strategy  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Race for the Galaxy may be as good as this type of game (something along the lines of "strategic resource management card game") can get. Certainly, it is good enough that many of its strengths and weaknesses point to qualities that may be inherent in the genre, and its strengths should only be rejected by designers that work in this category after careful consideration.

Aside from the card powers and a couple of minor points, the rules are actually quite clean and easy to grasp. Experience with Puerto Rico and San Juan are helpful, of course, but it shouldn't be too hard to figure out how to play the game from the rulebook.

Figuring out how to play the game [i]well[/i] is another story. RftG achieves an impressive array of strategic possibilities by taking a modular approach. A particular strategy is made up of one of the various card-generation modules that are available (say, an Alien Technology windfall world for trade, or one of the cards that gives its owner a card every time he produces a good of the specified type), plus 2-3 point generation modules (say, quick military settling plus New Galactic Order & Galactic Survey: SETI, or Galactic Trendsetters plus Galactic Renaissance) and voila, you have a strategy. Of course, some combinations have better synergy than others, so judgment and experience come into play here.

The problem is, with so many strategic "modules" in the deck, Lady Luck will walk up and bitch slap you sometimes. I'm not entirely sure how rare it is, even. You can start on a strategy in good faith, get smacked with an incompatible batch of cards from your first trade, switch plans, then get another batch of cards that fits your original, invalidated, plan again, or perhaps neither of your first two directions. While the first reverse is almost to be expected, the second, or even third, is not, necessarily, and a paucity of useful cards during the middlegame can be even worse. Adapting to this is impossible sometimes, at least at my level of skill. Fewer "modules" would ease this problem, but the price would be a cut in the delicious strategic diversity.

The range of strategies creates a steep, but interesting, learning curve for the game. A less palatable part of the learning curve for some, though, is the iconography of the cards. While I find the icons intuitive, and picked up on them quickly, my regular opponents are finding it a harder slog.

Worse, the size of the icons, mandated by Rio Grande to allow for larger art on the cards, compromises the game's usability. It is essentially impossible to read what a card can do from across the table, and there is simply no need for it. The icons could have been doubled in size, maybe more, and a change to a different, less cluttered and muddy, style of illustration would have made card identification a snap. They even fouled up the card name area, using an overly bold, overly compressed font, and setting it as dark grey on medium grey. You really have to strain to make out what an opponent can do. Boo, I say.

The dark side of the variety, and this is compounded by the poor usability decisions, is that RftG will bog down the analysis paralysis-prone pretty badly. Race wants to be a 20-30 minute game, packing a lot of punch in that timeframe. One or two slow players drag it out to 45-60 minutes, where it feels more "typical."

Oh, if you require the ability to reach out and directly affect an opponent's position, stay far far away. Personally, I'm down with indirect player interaction, but there is a large segment of the gaming community that howl at this type of game as though it kicked their puppy.

In spite of its problems, though, Race does have that certain "something" that keeps you wanting to come back for more. The variety of strategies keeps the game fresh, and you often feel there is something worth seeing just over the horizon, or a new insight to put into use. This is what gives it a similar feel to Magic:the Gathering, even without the cardboard crack business model. This quality makes it a textbook "9" on the BGG scale. I am (essentially) always interested in playing RftG, but, unlike a true 10, I can envision a situation where this may no longer be the case. We'll have to wait and see how I feel after I have explored most of its nooks and crannies.

UPDATE: Finally tried a couple of 2p games, which was interesting. The extra control makes having a solid strategy that much more important - you can't just ride the wave of chaos the other players produce, leeching as opportunities arise just won't work. Also, one of the "big three" - settle, develop and produce/consume - just won't come up much in any given game, which also makes it different in an interesting way.

I don't get a chance to play 2p games a lot, but RftG is definitely part of my 2p rotation now.

UPDATE: This game has single-handedly made 2p gaming my dominant mode nowadays. Trips to Tim Horton's for coffee and 2-5 (or even more once in a blue moon) games of RftG happens 2 or more times a week. I've played over 125 games at this point thanks to this factor. 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The iconography on this game makes it very difficult to teach to beginners, but if they get over that hump this is an extremely addicting quick game. While production seem overpowered without the expansion and getting good cards the first few rounds can seal a victory, the cards also means you have to adjust your strategy each game based on what you get. Yes this game is often multiplayer solitaire, but you also need to adopt your tactics based on what actions are available each round, allowing for at least a player vs. environment feel.

This game should be introduced to more "experienced" boardgames and is better if they have played games like puerto rico/San Juan.  I do think the setup is a bit troublesome as you  have to search for the 4 world cards in deck

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ok this is a multi-player solitaire. So what? A LOT of Euro are solitaire fest. But RFTG is one of the best of its kind! 

Components: lots of card. Artwork is quite good. It's a bit expansive for the material you get but the gameplay   replay value makes for that.

Gameplay: everyone has talked about it. This is San Juan on steroid. But it is so much better: more cards, more variety in powers, more strategy, veryone can take the role they want, lots of different strategies.

Theme: I found the theme to be REALLY good. The different powers of the world VS the developement fits the theme very well. There some nice reference to David Brin Uplift Saga and some other Sci-fi literature (World producing spice anyone?).

What is most outstanding is that since it is a card game, replay value is really high. No 2 games feel the same and the setup cannot be too scripted (even if it can be influenced by starting world). The are really a lot of path to victory and for clever play. 

Update:
Since this game is a multi-player solitaire :), playing using the solitaire variant is still fun! It aso helps to get a feel of the game and of the different card combinations.

Update rating to a 10. This is a truly great game. I introduced 4 new people to it and they loved it. This is less complicated to explain/grok than I thought. As soon as player understand that at each phase they have to check each of their cards for specific effect related to that phase everything clicks in!

Update: best game of 2007 hands down. I cannot think of another game that can pack as much punch, thinking, fun and theme in such a short playing time. Once everyone knows how to play the strategy layer opens up to a totally different game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
[microbadge=5][microbadge=5389]

Comparisons to San Juan aside, Race for the Galaxy provides an interesting take to the card game.  It's systems are far more complicated than expected (though not negatively so), and represent far more of what might be expected from a board-board game instead of the card-board game that it is.  The player interaction makes this something a bit more difficult than just optimizing and flying through card draws.

RATING: 9
A fun game, with a lot of interesting card combos and the like. It feels like your fate is largely in the draw of the right cards, but there is certainly skill involved as well - I'm just not sure what degree of skill vs. luck there is.

This game is highly addictive, once you get past the rough first couple of games (where you are learning the iconography and how the game plays) - still a lot of fun after many plays (probably getting close to triple digits, and the games been out less than 6 months as I write this).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wonderful engine-building game, but a pain to teach. It's easier than it looks, but it is so hard to get new players over that hump. It is also difficult to be good at it right away, which can turn players off. (Roll for the Galaxy has more appealing components, and I found it to be the more worthwhile purchase over time.)

At it's best it is really fast, has a lot of interesting decisions, and a *ton* of variety. Your tableau is different every game, and it is soooo satisfying when you start to get good turns because you correctly guessed what the other players were going to choose, and you start to understand what to pick. Then the game really starts to sing and become a "race".

In terms of atmosphere, it is a dream come true if you like Master of Orion, or space empire building games. Your civilization kind of becomes a little story, and the art is fantastic.

RATING: 8
A simultaneous/secret action selection tableau/engine-building game.  Outstanding design; fascinating artwork.  There is some "luck" involved in quickly obtaining the best combination of 6-cost developments and synergistic cards, but there is much to be said for making the most out of a weird hand.  Along with Tichu, one of my hands-down most-played games.  TTFN

It's funny, I don't think that the theme and the mechanics are particularly well-integrated, but the game benefits immeasurably from the theme, the quality of the artwork, etc.  It is a bit of a challenge to assemble a thematic narrative out of a game of it, which I feel like should bug me more than it does.  Mostly, I just admire its flexibility and scale, which hits a Dominion-like sweet spot for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Tableau building card game set in space.  It includes a role selection mechanic that allows other players to take the same action.  You can get more cards, build developments, settle planets, produce goods, set goods for victory points, or trade goods for more cards.  Cards are used as currency as well as can be played.  The symbols on the card make this game difficult to learn.  But if you learn the symbols the game plays very fast.  

An excellent game once you come up on the learning curve.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.99
Best Cardgame ever

i like playing race for galaxy  but my wife dont enjoy playing it because of all the cards and different strategy to win (in my mind these are pros (^__^) )

so my rating for this game is : 8.5
my wife rating : 6.9
average : 7.7

RATING: 8
Wow, this game hit the spot from the start.  Sure, it's lacking in direct confrontation (something I enjoy in a game), but it's not missed.  The graphic design (heavy dependence on cryptic icons) and theme prevent easy play with non-gamers, but otherwise a great design.  I prefer Glory to Rome if time is available.  The expansions are not a must, but do add interesting combinations and additional goals.  They add some interaction, too, but I'm not sure it's worth it.

RATING: 6
This is a pretty good game.  I found this game after Google searching "if you like 7 wonders then you will like . . ."  The game has simultaneous play similar to 7 Wonders which is great and makes for fast play.  The major limitations of this game are that you can only play with 4 players and the biggest of all, that there is virtually no player interaction.  There is virtually nothing you can do to impede or interact with the other players in the base game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Another role-selection game. I enjoy Race for the fact that it only uses cards. I think this was the first "card only" game that I actually took a liking to. I usually prefer a board with pieces that move around (even if its finicky). And most times I'm disappointed with cards. But the way Race uses cards as EVERYTHING you do in the game, is genius. You use them as your hand, to build up your tableau, to pay the cost for your cards, as resources for your plants. Its something I had never experienced until this game.

The biggest (and most obvious) downside are the symbols for the game. It is hard to teach new players this game since its like learning a new language.

RATING: 8
This is a fun, tableau building game ala San Juan, but with more depth and more fun.  This is primarily due to the fact that you have more options you can build to make production a viable strategy.

There are many very cool options to put together some sort of "machine" in your strategy, and both building and/or collecting VP chips are equally good paths for getting points.

With a great variety of cards and fairly quick play time, I think this will get alot of plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
play on BGA also
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Straightforward "buy cards and get victory points" game. In principle not difficult to explain or play, but there's a fairly steep learning curve for new players due to a complex system of symbols to indicate what a card can do, and how and when it does it. There's some kind of logic to the design of the symbols, but the symbols don't quite contain enough information to be easily decipherable for new players, so any game with a new player will tend to get bogged down in "wait while I'm checking the rules to figure out what the cards in my hand does".

RATING: 8
7/2008 It certainly has some similarities with San Juan but has a lot more variety.  There's many strategy possibilites and some planning is possible despite being a card drawing game.  Card knowledge is vital if you wish to win.  This game might even be a 9'er if it stays clear of becoming a CCG.

5/2010 With the added expansions the game realy comes together.  There's time pressure, difficult decisions and lots of subtle interaction; almost making this a brain burner.  The (complete) game (with all expansions) is a 9er.  (Tom, it feels rude to initially have released an "incomplete" game just to get the extra cash through expansions.)

1/2011 It's tooooo much.  With only occational play as times goes by the game is just too complex with all expansions.  Actually, prestiege and take-overs could have been left out.  Rating back to 8.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Everyone should download Keldon's AI and play this 100 times.  If you still don't like it, there's something wrong with you.

I've had the most fun ever just learning the ways of this game, and I've a lot more to learn yet.

The huge variety the many different cards bring to a highly strategic game is just amazing.  Every so often I still have moments where I find a great use for a previously unloved card, or find a new twist on a previous strategy. 

The balance of strategy with flexibility, variety with consistency and randomness with control have not been better achieved in any other game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[Played 11 times]

Nice game, but it has no place for me. If I want a game full of different cards with endless interactions, I've Magic. If I want a similar idea, but with simpler execution (thus more accessible to newbies), I've San Juan. "Race for the Galaxy" is a sort of middle ground I simply do not need.

Extremely light interaction and quite long learning curve due to the many cards and the abstruse myriads of symbols (that also failed to make it language independent, since there's text here and there too!).

The sci-fi theme and the bland artwork do nothing for me as well.
Pricey.

UPDATE: tried again (two year later) and it felt a needlessly overcomplicated San Juan.
