=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Game for gamers. Better than [b]San Juan[/b]. There are many similarities for sure, but everything that is different, is better (even the theme ;)). First few games were a bit long and confusing and all I could do was stare at my own cards (and choose my actions only thinking of myself). Learning curve is much steeper than in [b]San Juan[/b]. The cards have symbols indicating their function instead of text. It takes time to learn the symbols, but the player aids are excellent. The player interactions come into play after few games (of course it exists in the first games, but players may not be aware of it). Can be played in less than 30 minutes.

RATING: 10
My favourite game by far. To me the icons are fairly easy to understand after a two or three plays, and the variety of different strategies and options makes for a different game each time, so it doesn't get old. I enjoy the subtle interaction of "leeching" off other's choices, and trying to guess what action they'll take. The relatively short playtime means you can quite happily play 3 or more games in a row, and allows you to test new strategies without feeling you'll waste 2 hours if it goes horribly wrong at the start. An excellent game, can't wait for the expansions.

RATING: 8
Played this so many times my deck has started to fade - If id known how much i was going to like this id have sleeved the cards. card game where you build a tableau of planets / developments which will aid you during the game and score points for you at the end. pay for these cards by discarding other cards in your hand. synergy and variety make this a great card game and easy to learn. Only negative i have is that there are a few far too powerful cards (improved logistics)and the player with the most 6 point development cards usually always wins

RATING: 8
Traded for [thing=3125][/thing] collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of the best card games, ever.  Basically a space/scifi card game version of a worker placement game like Puerto Rico. Not sure that comparison is fair, but to me it's similar (actually a better comparison is San Juan, which is the card game variant to PR) since it's a similar game mechanic of pick a role (which everyone uses, but you picking it gives you a benefit), then you do things early game to gain more cards with an end game goal of getting the most Victory Points.  Again, similar to San Juan but RftG is more complex with more strategy, which to me means it's better!
Only slight flaw of this game is it's been criticized for being a multiplayer solo game; meaning you win based on your own game and the interaction with your opponents doesn't really matter. It's a good/fair criticism; if the game could find a way to force players to interact and create some kind of offensive/defensive element it would be even better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I now officially hate this game, except for solitaire.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game! It is very fast to play, with quite a lot of indirect interaction after acquiring enough skill. No direct "take that" mechanics may be a plus for some players.

It has quite a learning curve. The first hurdle is at the very beginning - learning the symbol system. Once you get that, you can play, but you will get beaten by more experienced players.

The second hurdle is learning the basics of strategy. You have to get the idea of the four possible routes to getting VPs (getting lots of expensive developments, military conquest of high-scoring worlds, producing and consuming goods for VPs and trading, that is selling valueable goods to get lots of cards to buy anything needed).

The third hurdle is starting to observe the other players and trying to figure out what action will they take. In the meantime you'll get to know the cards available and plan accordingly.

When you get over the third hurdle, the game suddenly becomes highly interactive (even tho you dont speak with other players). Before that, it may seem like a multiplayer solitaire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game implements an incredibly slick and elegant card system....once you get it. However trying to play the game straight out of the box following the rule book is very difficult. You really need to watch it played on youtube to get it then its relatively straight forward.

The game plays in 5 phases I) Explore pick up new cards ii) Develop-play advantageous cards which aid later phases iii) Settle-play planets which generally produce or consume goods iv) Produce-Produce goods  v) Consume goods for points or extra cards 

The currency is simply number of cards which are played to develop or settle various cards. The sacrifice of various cards is where some skill comes into it and can be very rewarding or upsetting depending on how things play out.

In a turn round each player (2-4 in base game) chooses  a phase to play and all the chosen phases are played by all players. If you pick the phase you have advantages e.g. pick up more cards, use less cards etc. This though is the only real player interaction. This adds to the game as you can predict the actions of your opponents to aid your game. 

The race element of the game also mean you have to track what your opponent/s is doing as an end game is generated when players reach a certain number of settlemnets/developments played or uses all assigned victory points for the game.


Winning is simply the player with the most net point value of cards and victory points earned throughout the game as well as any development bonuses

There are many strategies to win making it very replayable i.e. miliatary occupation, producing or playing key devlopment cards. 

Only slight downside is the rules provided but once you get it the reference cards are very useful and it makes sense.

Thoroughly recommend for 2 or more players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
8.5 - Mar 2014 - 3 Plays:  I'm starting to feel like I'm getting the hang of this game and I REALLY like it.  It's quick, but still tense.  I'm looking forward to getting some more plays in, and trying the 2 player advanced version.

10.0 - Oct 2015 - 27 Plays:  This is still going strong as my favorite game.

RATING: 7
Excellent Game. I agree that this is the game the San Juan failed to be!

I have changed my opinion: Race for the Galaxy is for Hardcore gamers, while San Juan is more suited for casual players.

Race for the Galaxy has
+ Complexity
- Space theme
- Nice, but unsupportive art
+ A lot of diversity, giving a huge replay value

San Juan has:
+ Simplicity and elegance
+ Puerto Rico Theme
+ Clear supportive art
- less replay value

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've played this a few times against actual players and about 6 or 7 times against the Keldon AI.

To put it briefly: This is one of the more interesting and deep engine builders I have ever played.  You are given a slew of interesting and choices to make from start to finish.

That's also the reason why I prefer Roll for the Galaxy over Race.

Understanding and able to play at a competent level requires players to drown themselves into a sea of strange iconography and insanity.  It demands a new player's patience and several hours to finally "grasp" the game.  The AP potential is huge considering that you need to spend cards in your hand to build your tableau, which is another level of thinking for the players to ponder.  Great idea in terms of depth, but with certain players it could be the killing blow due to a player or two spending the table's time over a simple decision.

As someone who has been into tabletop games for a good portion of my life living on this planet, I can handle that.  I'm not the norm though and the vast majority of players would probably give up after their first game due to the complexity and not having the faintest idea on what is considered a "good play"

Hence I will always be up for a game of Race for the Galaxy, even though I will likely lose badly in it, but I will never own it when Roll for the Galaxy is available.  Roll might be a more "casual" trimmed down experience, but it can be understood and enjoyed after the first few rounds, not half a dozen games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Oddly enough, I didn't like Puerto Rico but I enjoy playing this one.  Maybe it's just my taste in games has evolved or maybe it really is just a good game.

RATING: 8
I came into my first game of Race not expecting to like it. Low player interaction isn't a dealbreaker for me, but it's a red flag. And that first game was rough; I don't think it was taught to me the way my brain would have preferred. My second was much smoother, and by the third I could see how much was on offer.

I love the role selection, the guessing game (also fun in Puerto Rico and San Juan), and needing to have a strategy and adapt your tactics to the cards you draw and the pace the table sets. There's a lot here, especially for a game that can take less than 30 minutes.

The card art rocks, and the theme is expressed well through it and through the little "snapshot" of your empire you get as the game progresses.

---

I've had a lot more fun with Race two-player than with 3+.

More expansions haven't added many more plays.  The game is on hiatus for us.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ready your exploring boots and pull out that space suit. Fire up the terraforming robots and get ready to race the stars! You are explorers and opportunists taking advantage of the vastness of space and the secrets it holds to succeed. Here the fate of the galaxy is truly "in your hands". With a handful of cards and a deck to explore in, players work with what they have in order to pursue the best strategy in order to explore, colonize, develop, produce and trade their way to winning.

Resourcefulness, cunning and a bit of luck play centrally in Race for the Galaxy. Like in many card-driven games, players try to maximize a limited amount of resources and actions in a turn to put together a viable enough way to win. Victory points are awarded with every successful development, settlement and trade done. And once enough of the galaxy has been developed and colonized, the game ends and the one who has affected it the most, whether by peaceful diplomacy, by military conquest or by profitable trade, wins.

The mechanism for limited actions taken in a round requires players to maximize what they do in a turn. So what does a good opportunist do? He not only takes advantage of what lays before him, but also of those going after what he wants. Though this is a competitive race with only one winner, it is important for you to realize that relying on your competitors can actually be the best strategy. Race for the Galaxy brings out this sneaky paradigm pretty well.

Light, fast and simple. There is no direct confrontation here, RftG is a flat out race to the finish line. But if you focus to much on your lead, you can easily forget how your opponents are gaining from every action you take and netting them more benefits than you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Update: What the hell was I talking about below? This is a veritable modern classic, as accomplished as they come. One of my favorite games, and I suck at it.

----
(2007) Very decent game; complex, fast moving, low fuss. Contrary to the general sentiment, playing this has raised my appreciation level for San Juan considerably, which tries to do much less in a more pronounced way than RftG, putting you in a very tight straitjacket from the get-go.

The flexibility that you perceive in RftG might be a bit deceiving, though. When you start playing better opponents, perfect execution of the one chosen path could be equally important, which seems to hurt the game a bit.

RATING: 8
Broadly speaking, this is the kind of game where you build up a resource engine, then switch to earning victory points and hope the game doesn't end before you want it to. There is a decent (but not astronomical) number of scoring paths to follow, but during a game only a few of them seem worth considering. The scoring often seems slightly crude, since most of the special powers boil down to a number and only a few effects change the mechanics in other ways.

The game works best, in my opinion, with two players, two actions per player and turn, larger starting hands and no homeworlds.

RATING: 5
Simple game play, yet interesting strategies. Similar to MTG in terms of trying to figure out synergies between your cards, but I think that's about as far as that goes. Really forces you to adapt to your draw evolve what direction you are going.

I certainly enjoy it as it has a good deepness to the strategy but is playable quickly and easily. Really well designed and it's clear that it has been throughly playtested. But it also doesn't blow my mind and I think there are other games out there that scratch a similar itch that I generally prefer. I'll still happily play this regularly, but I'm not in agreement with the zealous love that some seem to have for it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Race for the Galaxy is unique in that it is a game you can clearly get better at playing over time.  There are many different strategies to choose from, which helps with the replay factor too.

As I've played, I've grown more excited for each time this hits the table, rather than slowly eroding my desire to play.  If you're looking to learn a game to play with a specific group as a reoccurring event, then this is a game you should seriously consider.

Let me contrast this to Seven Wonders.  RftG plays faster, with more variation between games, and you actually control your own destiny.  When I lose in RftG I usually know what I did wrong, and when I win I know exactly what I did right. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
3 / 5 - Good.

After one play, I can see that this is a game which would require multiple plays to properly evaluate. To my surprise, I actually found the game quite thematically compelling: the effects on the cards all seem to make sense (space marines give you a military bonus etc) and I did get the sense of building up a little space empire. But the game itself seemed absurdly confusing, not just in terms of rules and icons, both of which were amazingly obtuse, but in terms of options. There's so many different effects and ways to get things done that I find it hard to fathom how anyone could form a coherent strategy, especially with the luck-of-draw. And yes, it's very low interaction.

RATING: 10
Fun game, don't let the discussions about the rules and icons scare you off. The rules aren't as complex as they seem at first but the paths to victory are numerous and not obvious. 

Race has been described by others as having a sharp learning spike. Keldon AI is an effective but an emotionless and unforgiving trainer. Good way to reinforce the rules if you don't have someone to teach you instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Pros:
+ Multiple legitimate paths to victory
+ Deep Gameplay - constantly discovering new card interactions
+ Quick play
+ Outside of the luck of card draw, no kingmaking or aiming effects, so the game is less frustrating than it could have been
+ The simultaneous phase selection mechanic is one of the best and most interesting mechanic in any game I've ever played

Cons:
- That "multiple paths to victory" does not correlate to you getting to make a lot of decisions - way too often the game more or less plays itself with one obviously correct decision each turn
- Way too often one player will get a series of good draws early and will totally steamroll everyone else
- Overwhelming and frustrating for casual or new players
- The artwork is beautiful (and this is a minority opinion) but I find the color palette of the game drab
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2-6 players (with the expansions)
hand management
simultaneous action selection
variable phase order

This was one of two games mocked up to be the card game version of Puerto Rico. One game became San Juan, the other became this. You can feel the similarities. Very light on player interaction, but you will spend more time thinking about what other players are doing than in Dominion.

Rules are printed on cards in a symbolic language described on a variety of cheat sheets. Most people know the game after a single play through, and it plays quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The second euro game I bought.  I've played this one primarily 2-4 players, with my favorite being the 2-player advanced version.  I use the cards from The Gathering Storm, but not the goals.

What I like:
- It's fast. Most games take 20-40 minutes.
- You can specialize in different areas to get VP.
- Simultaneous role selection reduces downtime.
- 2-player advanced lets you plan your strategy a little better, and makes the game go faster.
- No direct conflict, but you need to watch your opponents to be efficient, and perhaps deny them high scoring cards.
- Sometimes you have to make hard decisions to keep or discard cards.

What I don't like:
- Some strategies, like going the production/consumption route, will make your action selection pretty repetitive once you've built your engine.
- Occasionally you can get behind due to a series of bad card draws.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An exceptional game, finely balanced.  Involving playing a combination of cards representing one's space empire, collecting more cards and scoring points for having the most impressive civilization.

 Great art, and games play quickly.  The title really matches the game play - often the race is down to the last few cards to decide who wins.

However, if you are looking for a game to introduce to new gamers, then this is not the game you are looking for.  There is some initial rule complexity to explain, and some iconography which takes a little while to get used to.  The first game is necessary just to get over the initial complexity (and is unlikely to be enjoyable).  But once everything 'clicks' then this game is absolutely marvellous.  Best to let an experienced player teach this game and play open handed to talk the new players through the different strategies.

Have only recorded a few plays in person, but have over 40 via the Keldon.net app.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This was the first game that really blew my mind. Still one of my favorites. The iconography is annoying, but intuitive after thoroughly learned. Setup and tear down are lightning fast. There is hand and tableau management, simultaneous action selection and engine building in the game. The mechanisms are very elegant. My biggest issue with it is teaching the iconography. The player aid is almost as big as the box, for crying out loud! But nonetheless, for me, it's all worth it. Really amazing game.

RATING: 7.5
An interesting, and fun, game. Love the variety of cards, actions, strategies. Hate the variety of cards, actions, strategies! It’s too much really because no 2 games are the same and you have to be an expert in every aspect to have a chance at winning. You need to play a few times just to get the hang of it, and then another few times to try and memorize all the cards. 

But once you do this, it’s a fun game. There’s no bash the leader and you can tell where you stand at all times. The rulebook is good and the card art is fine. It plays quickly as everyone plays same time and that’s wonderful. 

The expansions add some fun (and yet more variety of cards, actions, strategies) as well. 

I’d rate it higher, but the wide expertise you need to have to have a chance (and there is some randomness/luck that can sometimes overwhelm or benefit you) really detracts.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I think this game is overrated, but I see why Geeks like it. Many Geeks hail Magic: the Gathering as the Godfather of all games, and RftG plays very similarly. Almost all the cards are unique, which grants players flexibility in adapting their strategy. Although I enjoy this game, I actually see the diverse cards as a weakness. Because the 100+ cards are practically all unique, there is no way to predict what you will draw and therefore it is difficult to adapt a strategy. Yes, this randomness creates a "race-like" feel of I-need-to-capitolize-on-EVERY-move-better-and-quicker-than-my-opponent, but it also reduces player interaction to zero. Nothing you can do can influence your player beyond making them consume goods (which, if they are awake during the game will identify this threat and either be fine with it as they cash in their goods for VPs or they will be pre-emptive and trade their goods for cards anyway). Also, because of the iconography used for identifying each card's unique attributes for a given phase, it gets very confusing and impossible to keep track of what other players are doing (not that it matters much except it lets you see what cards you will never have in your own hand). In addition, I don't think I can introduce this game to non-gamers because of the 100+ unique cards with 100+ unique phase icons, which are NOT intuitive. I enjoy San Juan a lot and do not think RftG is superior, as many Geeks do. I'll play either, but I'm gonna give RftG more table time to see if my opinion of it changes.
***UPDATE: I have tried to find fault in this game and realized that for as much as I try to find why I feel this game is overrated, I find myself wanting to play it CONSTANTLY! This one is one of my wifes favorites and I finally admit that this game is really great! Once you've figured out the gameplay (I used San Juan as reference when teaching my wife) and the icons this game plays fast. My wife and I play games nightly and our new routine has changed from "what game do you want to play?" to "what game do you want to play AFTER Race for the Galaxy?". The diversity of cards offers EXTREME replayability and a sense of anticipation as you use that explore +5 phase card to go searching for that crucial card to complement your current tableau and strategy, or that VP x2 phase card to turn your goods into points before your opponent gets around to using the crucial card they were using the explore +5 phase card to find! 
BOTTOM LINE: This game is a fast, competitive and FUN game with nail-biting suspense and tough decisions with a little luck thrown in to fray your nerves a bit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Played 2 times

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A little too abstract to be instantly compelling for casual players.  Complex and challenging.  Great mechanics.  The design is clever, but not as intuitive as games like Puerto Rico or Stone Age that make more sense right away (due to the great visuals + text combination)  Race for the Galaxy has the text, but the visual components need to be learned and memorized, as they aren't as obvious right away.  (For example, a circle and diamond to differentiate worlds and developments, and different glows or colours on the circles to show a world type.  Also actions like Consume are very themed, and not instantly recognizable.  It's a little easier to teach someone Puerto Rico, and even easier to teach Agricola or Stone Age, that have rich Visuals that just make sense with the game mechanics.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This game blew me away, after reading many users mention the steep learning curve due to the iconography I took the chance regardless and instead found a very intuitive, easy to play, flexible, and incredibly fun game with plenty of strategy that has become one of my favorite games with how much it offers in such a short playtime (20-45 minutes) with minimal setup and breakdown time as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Preliminary rating. I like the game at first (theme is nice, nice artwork, great components). The amount of symbols is overwhelming and a bit harder to learn. Even my friend, who played it already more often, had to look up certain symbols. I can imagine that this is an obstacle everybody talks about.

The gameplay itself is really nice. You need to think more about what card to play then, say, in 7 Wonders or Dominion. Then there is also the choice of action: not only to play your card, but also a bit reading of the opponent (and working against him/her).

My rating may go up with more plays.

Edit: played it once more. The game starts growing on me, but still I think learning all the symbols makes this a harder game and should be played more just to get over the 'learning the symbols' phase. Due to this the game tends to be slow when I take a turn. :)

Edit2: I thought about this game. Downgraded my rating because of the chaos. I like the combination of drafting and paying for it with cards, together with choosing a role, but the huge amount of possibilities makes it a bit chaos for me.

RATING: 5
Roll for the galaxy is just so much more streamlined, without the cumbersome useless, convoluted rules Race has.  I feel like if they re-did Race with some of what I find convoluted reduced it would be better.  The military purchase is unique but it's hard to pull off due to luck- I went through back to back 8 card draws and only the 16th card finally had a military point to spend.  There was just NO other method to get there and it seems like you have very little control compared to Roll.  In fact a strategy seems to be to force people to consume goods they'd otherwise sell for cards or double their victory points on.  I also don't like not being about to do what you need (consume a brown good for cards) unless you happen to drawn and are able to build that as a part of your engine- after which it can be used against you whenever a good is present.  The whole produce coming after consume is weird too, having learned roll it seems to make more sense to produce then consume which allows you to pull it something off in one round with a bit of luck in your opponent's phase pics, but it's based on getting lucky enough to draw something and be able to build it just to be able to do it on a subsequent turn from producing.  So a solid 5.  Would be 8 or 9 with a re-think.

RATING: 6
I used to really like Race, but I'm over 30 plays in and it never stopped feeling like multiplayer solitaire.  It just doesn't have enough direct interaction for my tastes.  Gave it away, but still happy to play it now and then.

And for actual solitaire, I prefer the VPG States of Siege games.

I've played this mostly with programmer types and we've all found the iconography to be very easy to grasp.  (The former art teacher had a different experience.)  I wish Infernal Contraption had a similar system.

The rules are great for reference, but they're lousy for teaching you how to play the game.  A few sample rounds played solitaire will make things crystal clear, however.

RATING: 7
It is less complicated than it looks. However my attention was totally occupied by my own cards (reading the symbols and catching up different rules) that I was unable to care what other players were doing for the WHOLE game. Such experience is rare to me. I even didn't take a look to which card other player has played. Of course I believe advanced players need to read the situation of other players in order to play well. However, reading cards played by other players is not convenience because of the interface design of the game (everyone play cards in front of him/her). 
The "war"/occupying phase is not as exciting as its name suggests. C'on, there should be at least some casualties after war.
These reasons made me think that RftG is decent but not great, though apparently it is as addictive as CCG. 
I gave it a low rating using BGG's scale since  this kind of game isn't interesting unless playing it many times to understand the system. I'd rather steer away from it.
(*Card game, Sci-Fi, Optimization, Bluff)
===============
Because of the addictive AI, I am fairly familiar with most cards now. I still think it is not easy to read the cards played by other players in case I play it face-to-face with them.

Even the people that have played much more than me have to constantly consult the rule book to decipher the multitude of icons, and how they relate to one another. RATING: 8
I am a player of almost any kind of games.  I love abstracts, I love fun games, familial games, tactical ones, etc.  But Race for the Galaxy got me hooked.  It took 2 games but I was like a northern pike who was presented with a baby trout.  I can't resist...and frankly I don't want to resist.  This is the first game that makes that funny feeling in my stomach in a long, long time.  The games are always different.  There is a ton of strategy involve.  It's a subtle game of reading the mind of the opponent and it catters the gamer in me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Wow, I really suck at this game. After 10 plays, I still don't get how to combo up, nor do I understand how to plan ahead. I have won one game by employing an extremely linear and obvious military strategy and being lucky enough to develop lots of might right off the bat, then drawing military world after military world, and gazumping people off military worlds they owned. It was a very low scoring game, too - I won with 35 points. That strategy didn't work again as no-one holds on to military worlds now when I play (!). 

I don't know if it's just that this isn't how my brain works or what, but none of the iconography clicks in for me. Everyone else seems to have left me standing.

After almost 40 plays now, I've won twice. My second success was another low scoring affair - I won with 31 points this time, so feel it was probably down to poor card draws for the others.

I think this is a much more interesting game than, for example, Dominion, where the variation seems to come from using different combinations of card stacks, whereas the combos possible in RftG have much greater flexibility and possiblity - if only I could exploit this during play...

[Update:] This is now by far my most-played game with over 70 plays. That's not to say it's my favourite - I have others I prefer - but it's quicker than my top games and is easy to carry around. I am now managing a win for every 10 games(ish), which is poor, but an improvement.

[22/11/16] Nothing quite like a new RftG expansion to bring you down with a bump. Having played 7 games with Alien Artifacts, I'm surprised how different the sameness is. What's interesting is that I thought I had a handle on the mechanisms, where I understood the fundamental interactions; but it turns out I just understood the interactions of the previous cards through experience. There's nothing intrinsically different about AA, but I've lost my edge. This is a good thing from the point of view of interest and replayability, but somewhat disappointing from that of perceived expertise. Oh well... onwards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Being a fast and dangerously addictive game this is probably my most played one, and after two years we still find new combos and strategies. 
Two of it's most addressed flaws are the complicated iconography and the multiplayer solitaire aspect. It surely does require some effort to pick up the game's logic, but after that it's pretty straightforward and intuitive. Any new cards can be deciphered at a glance, as it contains every information you need in a consistent way, so there's no need for further elaboration. [i](unless it introduces some new core mechanism, of course)[/i].
Regarding the lack of interaction, you certainly can play it looking just your cards- if you aren't in it for the win. However you should look your opponents' cards for two reasons. For effective play you have to guess what phase the others will select and then select yours accordingly, and you have to recognize certain patterns to counter them in time, changing your strategy if needed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I'm not a huge fan of card only games. This is a fine game that can be difficult to teach.

RATING: 9.5
Such a dense game in a tiny package.  The (seeming) difficulty and number of plays it takes to get comfortable with the flow of play and contents of the deck are well worth the number of rewarding plays once you arrive at the place of playing on a very competitive level.  2 player duels are amazingly tight, and can provide a great white knuckle experience as you try to blend available gambits to build point trees, cut off your opponent, and push the game towards its end in your time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 6
Phase-driven deck drawing card game where players choose phases hidden from each other and everyone performs only and all the phases selected. The theme integrates well with the mechanics and there are a few alternate routes to victory. Has a race game hiding at its core, but one with some strategic depth and a controllable amount of luck. While the game itself is mid-complexity, some rules and some card effects are mind-twisting and confusing and takes time to grasp and cope with. Virtually no direct player interaction but fast play times and reasonably interesting build options makes for a reasonably decent game.

RATING: 9
Upgraded to a 9 after several more plays. This game hits the sweet spot.  It is fast, playing out in under an hour, yet complex with loads of interesting decisions in a science fiction setting which I love. Almost no take that game play which makes it very spouse friendly, yet there is interaction because you get to play off your opponent's orders.  Your spouse will like it because she can build her little empire without you trying to wreck it. And you'll like it because the game is designed in such a way you can always make something work no mater what cards you're getting.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game definitely feels exactly like what San Juan should've been.  In San Juan, I always feel like there isn't enough time to actually play the cards I want and I end up simply being at the mercy of the cards in my hand, but with Race, I've generally been able to plan out strategies, execute them well enough, and have a decent chance of winning the game.  I like that there's a distinction between military planets, non-military planets, and developments, which allow you a variety of methods for building, and I especially like that the military buildings don't require discarding cards from your hand.  There's a large diversity of cards and abilities that can be found in the deck, which numerous choices about which strategy to pursue.  However, I've become tired with it as the additional expansions have greatly increased the "race" aspect of the game and limited the engine-building aspect.  My rating has been dropping as I'm just no longer excited to play this game. I guess this type of game just doesn't really appeal to me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
The first few times I played this I really didn't like it and traded it away.  I saw the similarities to San Juan but already loved that game and this one just seemed too convoluted by comparison.  I came back to it a year or two later and quickly came to appreciate it.  It feels like a good mix between San Juan and Eminent Domain, but they're all different enough to stand on their own.  I like that other players can't directly interfere with my plans, but it's still interactive in trying anticipate other players' actions.  I haven't explored the expansions, but even just the base game is very satisfying once you get past the 1-2 game learning curve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

Downside to the game is the high barrier for entry, which means there aren't too many people that I know that I can play it with. (Pretty much me meg and nate... probably orlando and eliany... and that's about it.  Maybe Meghan and Matt if we continue to convert them into gamers)

RATING: 7
Fantastic Card game! Love the theme and the game play is very interesting. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
First, the iconography is not that hard nor is the gameplay difficult. Pick a phase, do all selected phases in order - get a bonus if you picked it and that's it. The card layout is about as good as it gets for helping you along. With the Consume phase, where you gain points and cards by using up goods, it can get a bit fiddly since suddenly the order in which you do the actions matter a bit. Either way, not that hard to learn and really quite enjoyable - this is a real engine-building game but due to the player controlled end conditions (grabbing all the available points or reaching a 12 size tableau) you can't build it without considering the tempo as dictated by all the players in the game, you need to adapt so that you won't be stuck with nothing as the game ends, or fizzle out too early allowing the other players do massive final turns.

It's a 7 for now, but I can see it trending up if I play it more. I like it - it feels more mathy and calculable, but also more granular and consistent than Mottainai which is my closest comparison, so while similar one is wacky and chaotic the other is more subdued and calculating, I like both. Good game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

For solo only, fun but I struggle to figure out the strategy. I like it!

RATING: 10

I think I need to play more 4-player games.Update: I'm fickle, I'm back on the bandwagon. Just when I think I've exhausted a strategy, something new pops up. Good game, superior to San Juan. I've never played Puerto Rico but this piques my interest. Update: Bumped up to a 9 after 50 recorded plays (accurate count is probably in the 70s).

Update: maybe shelf this one till the expansion comes out. It did last 100+ plays.

RATING: 9
i love it no one else done its got like 5 icons and variations on that! bad press for no reason! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: Select a role each round and play the actions within what roles were chosen by the group. Settle planets, produce goods, and trade or sell your wealth to come out as the player with the most impressive collection of planets.

Played as: 2,3 player

Pros: Well done roles and mechanics make a nicely balanced game given so many options. Game plays fast but with enough different cards, there's variety pretty much every time. Refreshing theme amongst so much same, same. Scales well from 2-4, or at least it appears that way to this point. 

Cons: Totally frustrating to learn. The privileges awarded by planets and technologies are far from intuitive leaving it utterly painful to encourage play after the first struggles through the game. Playing a game shouldn't feel like taking a test.

Other: Got this and played it before I lucked into getting San Juan. This is by far the more complex game if by interface alone. For a 'family' game San Juan is the way to go. This is more of a quick gamers version. I liked the game less before I started to like it more. My learning curve ended up being 4-5 games, though I'm still learning some details here and there.

Best Use: I'll put it in the small group, 30 minute filler / time killer category.

Will play again...definitely.

11/29/12: Played again, finally. Three players this time. We needed to re-learn the game since it had been so long. RATING: N/A
Horrible, horrible graphics. What idiot puts 8pt(?) black type on a grey background, on a black card? And don't any of those planets rotate to a light side?
The game is OK, with a huge random factor, but it's not a pleasant visual experience for a game where you must refer to cards all the time. With 50yr old eyes it seems I must forget about seeing my opponents options, even at less than a metre away. I cannot believe they pitched these graphics outside an experienced playtest team. There are 'pretty' pictures looming in the darkness. But I want mid size print and a small picture, because the PICTURES DON'T MATTER,INFORMATION DOES! End of rant, what a disappointment. 2nd edition cards please.
Only played twice. Nasty rating coming if patience doesn't pay off.

RATING: 5
I bought this at BGG.CON after getting schooled in it by sshawmd.

I didn't expect to like this as much, especially when I realized I was in over my head during that first game. But I "got" it enough to at least form a strategy, however weak, toward the end. I think the mechanics are excellent, and it appears to be deep with lots of viable strategies. I'm looking forward to not sucking at this any more.

Oddly, I was even more overwhelmed during a second play of this. I was rusty enough that I felt like I was completely re-learning it. Also, my group played [i]really, annoyingly[/i] fast, so I didn't have a chance to think and absorb the way I wanted to. And when I drew a bunch of high cost cards that I couldn't play early, then draw nearly an entire hand of high cost alien worlds that I couldn't settle using my colony drop ships...aaaaargh!!!!

I managed to win my third game, by luck I think.

This seems to be a supremely frustrating game, but I clearly need to play more to just get to the point where I feel competent. I'm not sure that I'll ever play this often enough that I feel like I have a good handle on the strategies. But I'm [i]willing to [/i]play it more often than the opportunity comes up.

I ended up trading all my RftG stuff away. When I go that long trying unsuccessfully to convince myself to like something, there's obviously a disconnect. So I said bye bye, and I haven't missed it.

RATING: 7.9
A very fun "tableau-building game".  I guess that is what you would call it?  Because there are two end game scenarios (get all victory points from pool or somebody builds a 12-card tableau), it really does feel like a race.  You are trying desperately to see a strategy come to fruition while at the same time constantly re-evaluating your situation due to the time factor and other players' strategies.  Really solid game that would be a solid 8+ if it weren't for the entirely too confusing symbols (iconography).

RATING: 10
I've been "seriously" gaming for 10+ years, played nearly 1000 different titles and for the first time, without equivocation, I can answer the "What's your favorite game?" question.   An [b]outstanding[/b] game in the style of San Juan (actually it's the other way around).  The art is exceptional.  The game is fast, but full of compelling tactical options, interesting combinations, engaging thematic elements and numerous strategies to pursue.  In the less than a year since it's been out, it's become my 3rd most played game ever and I have no doubt it will be the most played before long. 

EDIT/UPDATE: >5 years after I wrote this comment and all of the above remains true, and it's become my most played game.  I mostly only play with the first two expansions, without takeover rules, but enjoy all of the expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Amazing game.  Space-themed.  Uses selection of turns played (explore, develop, settle, consume, produce).  The goal, of course, is to collect the most victory points.  However, does not use any tokens for payment, you use the cards in your hand themselves to pay for different worlds and development cards.  In other words, this game is light since it's only cards and VP chips.  Good even for two people if you choose two phases at a time.

RATING: 8
[microbadge=1714]

[i]I will list any multi player Play comments under the Base game...which will most likely be zero.[/i]

02/06/2013: I have not played this with other humans yet.  And probably won't...at least for the foreseeable future.  However, this is a very deep, strategic card game.  There are many paths to follow in terms of gaining VP.  The sci-fi theme, I think, really shows with the artwork and as you build up your tableau of cards in your play area.

The iconography and sheer number of cards / options can be a steep learning curve, but it's well worth the effort.

RATING: 9
iOS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A little overwhelming upon first glance but once you start playing you realize that it's a tightly designed game where each of the many mechanisms fit in elegantly.  I lost my first couple of games because I tried to build a strong, efficient engine.  In this game you need to burn some of your good cards, that would improve your long-term productivity, in order to gain victory points.  I feel that it's the "race" aspect of the game that really helps make it unique.  Otherwise it would just be another euro/engine-builder.  The problem with my engine strategy is once it was built the game was over before I had a chance to churn it for VPs.  Some players will notice that the game provides minimal direct interaction.  Perhaps the expansions will "fix" this.

UPDATE: Great game but I'm less excited about playing each time it's brought up (which is often).  Bumped down a point.

UPDATE: Bumped back up a point after playing the 2-player version a number of times.  In a 2-player game, despite the quick play time, as you have more actions and control you get to pump your engine a few times and your decisions re: which actions help you more than your opponent are much more transparent.

RATING: 10

Recently played a 4-player drafting variant and it was great fun. Breaks a little the random exploration part but allows for really powerful decks. Basically you draft from packs of n+3 cards where n is number of players. All cards drafted together form your own draw deck. Then play normally. RATING: 2
Playthroughs: 6, with experienced players and newer ones. Some plays were with the first expansion.

Pros: Cool pictures and large variety of cards leading to varied gameplay.

Cons: Low player interaction- primary mechanic gives you little way to interact with the other players. You can frequently hose yourself but rarely hose the other players, even if you figure out their strategy. Its basically advanced solitaire. Expansion adds small competition for victory chits, which reduce but certainly don't alleviate problem.
High confusion level- I say confusion level instead of complexity because the rules are not very complex. However, the game is presented in a very poor manner that leaves you constantly looking through your hand and board trying to figure out what you can do. There are many symbols that can mean different things depending on where they are on the card. The game 

Overall, everyone leaves the game dissatisfied, feeling as if they have wasted time, even the winner. Do not buy this game. I earnestly wonder why it is highly rated.

RATING: 9
Excellent game - moves fairly quickly due to the role selection mechanic, which I love. Fairly complex strategy; though luck plays a role (it is a card game), it usually isn't too noticeable - you always have something you can do.

The game has a steep initial learning curve due to the iconography, which - though it eventually makes sense - is not immediately intuitive. Experienced players also have a huge advantage over new players due to card knowledge.

These drawbacks only apply to the first few games - the only long term knock against it is the lack of confrontation. This is somewhat mitigated by the expansions, and that won't even be a drawback.

It also scales down to two players quite well, which is rare.

All three expansions
Base game plus RvI
Base game plus first two expansions
Just the base game  

I play with goals about half the time, and almost never use the combat system.  Fans of combat would certainly have different opinions than me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
A card game with a science fiction theme, where the theme really doesn't have anything to do with the game.  But the pictures on the cards a well done, and got universal approval from the players present.  Rated after 3 games.  RftG is a played with an initial set up of cards, with each player picking an action card for each turn.  Players get bonuses for their action cards, but may still play on other players actions, but without the bonus.  Players attempt to score the victory points in varies manners to win the game.  First game can be VERY confusing, but with further play the confusion diminishes and some elements of strategy can be tried.  Strategy is limited somewhat by the luck of the draw, but hey thats cards right? Yet as with any card game, players can minimize the luck with some insight into what the values of the cards and their interaction represent.  RftG game play is quick, and overall game time short.  I found the game surprisingly enjoyable, and RftG will be one of my choices for a filler in an evening of gaming!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I played this because Ryan's played it a few thousand times already, and he recommended it to me.  This game uses the same mechanics as San Juan, but is incredibly different from (and much more complicated than) it.  This is not a beginner's game: virtually none of the 100  cards are duplicates of each other, each card can typically do multiple things (in one of five phases), and there is a strong component of experience in the game (due to needing to know what cards are available, though there's also luck, evidenced by my winning the first game I played).  I love it; there are enough different cards to make multiple strategies effective, you have to tactically respond to the cards you get, and while it doesn't have a lot of player interaction, the role selection mechanic requires considering what other people will select. 

Edited to add: I've now played this twelve times (including the expansion), and I still love it. My group has gotten very experienced at this game, and thus we can play through it very quickly, making it very enjoyable even though it's clear that luck plays a decently large role.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Haven't completely wrapped my head around this one yet, but so far it's a deep yet short building and production game. I love that, because it enables you to learn from the previous game and immediately apply what you've learned. Knowing all cards by heart does seem like a prerequisite to be any good though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pick actions to improve your galactic civilization for most points.

Plays: More than 100, most against Keldon’s AI.
Type: VP engine = a game where you build an engine to collect victory points most efficiently.
Complexity: Medium.
# of players: 2-4.
Playing time: 30 mins.
Player interaction: Competition for unlimited resources – actions. Opportunity prevention.
Randomness: Medium – card draw.

Replayability: High against AI. This is one of the few efficiency engine games that I actually enjoy, probably because decisions involve dealing with uncertainties, which makes it not just an equation. Face to face replayability is not so high, as there's too much to keep track of with action cards, cards in hand, goals, card powers in play and victory chits. Having the computer to keep track of everything makes the experience more about decisions and less about "maintenance".
Fun: The fun lies in the decision making of hand and board management. Packs complex decisions into a quick game, which is nice.
Memorability: Low, it’s an efficiency engine that doesn’t create stories.

Thematic integration: Weak.
Components: Decent. 
Expansions: The Gathering Storm is a welcome addition to meaningful decision making. Others I’m not sure.

Who will like this: Strategy gamers, especially to play solitaire against AI.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow, this game saw constant play the year it came out. It never seemed to exhaust itself- game after game after game, it maintained its pull for me and mine. It's been on the shelf for awhile now, but not because it somehow played itself out or exposed itself as a lesser design; new games just arrived and we all thought Race would make a triumphant return sooner or later. Now, though, I wonder why we haven't returned to it. Hmm.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Adjusting my rating from October 2013 of 9.1 down to 8.5 - this game is complicated enough to teach, and gets crazy with all the expansions added.  I still love the game, I just never get the chance to bring it to table because of the above.

This game is a doozy at first, because the creators went hogwild with the iconography.  There is a symbol for everything, not all of which is especially intuitive, and sometimes there are symbols which don't make any sense at all in the context of what you're doing.  Then you have some words delineated with colored text... some of which work in the base set (eg "Alien") whereas some don't do anything until you start adding expansions (eg "Imperial").

All of that said and meant: this game is a delightful space empire builder that encourages multiple different paths to victory, and one which can see your strategy shift from the beginning of the game, to game's end, based on what you draw.

Even still: check out Eminent Domain for a more approachable game in the same genre.

(Written 5/4/16)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Wow.  Having played twice, really, REALLY difficult to imagine never wanting to play this.  Obviously, San Juan on ultra steroids, and all the good things that people have already said. . .but the theme and the storylines that get baked into the game are just brilliant - from asymetrical starting worlds, to different tech "paths" based on early decisions (that sometimes reduce your military or other powers), each player ends up with a vastly different experience and potential victory.  Highly recommended for a gaming crew that has played some gateway games and are looking for MORE.

*updated*

Still an awesome game two more plays later.  Don't know if I need to address naysayers on this column about the "solitaire" - uh, no, "solitaire" is to complete or clear a board - there is a "race" here - which means you might have to make "blunt" or sub-optimal moves to stay "in" the race - and the "ESP" involved is to figure out what others might play so that you can get the extra mileage on your turn. . .not to mention, if you take a similar "route" of expansion, you are then competing with that player(s) for cards, when taking a different route might be better. . . .
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game feels like it was tailored exactly to my tastes and pulls the best that card games like this have to offer.  It seems extremely balanced and the replay value is way off the charts.  The only major downside is the learning curve, which prevents me from teaching it to a lot of people.  I have not found the form of player interaction to be a problem and prefer it to direct clashes between players.

Initial thoughts: 9
Added .5 points: Every time I play this game I want to play more and more.

RATING: 10
My rating has gone up every time I played.  I'll be picking up a second copy at some point, since the first one is going to wear out eventually.

My one criticism: the icon system is a barrier for entry, and very intimidating for the first game.  However, after a couple of games, it all makes sense.  I do wish there was more text on the cards and less artwork, though.  Lots of tough decisions, and the game seems to play out differently each time.

Note: the game is very, very similar to San Juan in many aspects, but Tom Lehmann was involved in making SJ, and has permission for this version - I reckon they should have put the design story in the manual, though, because it looks like blatanyt plagiarism without the context.

Anyone outside of my group who wants to play has played a thousand games and squashes me. *sigh* It seems like you need someone who is willing to learn the game and grow along with you. Disparity in experience level makes a huge difference in this game.

The game has clicked for my wife and I. We are playing the balls off of this game. In the space of about a month, Race has become our most played game.

RATING: 7
Race for the Galaxy seemed like godsent when it appeared - an improvement over San Juan, with a nice scifi theme to boot.

Also, Race for the Galaxy is simply a pain to play with newbies, which is a big minus.

I've rated it 10, but the rating has since come down a bit. At its best it's still a ten, but those moments are rare enough. I do like the Keldon's AI version, it's a nice little solitaire game to play (and when I say solitaire, I mean it, as I never look at what the computer players do).

Suggest.

Bumped rating up after two-player game against my son. He was ambivalent about it and said he wanted to play it again before he decided. I, on the other hand, really had the game open up for me somehow this time, and I felt like my head was going to explode. Even though it IS essentially complex solitaire, it is also HIGHLY immersing. So I guess if I can't have conflict based player interaction, I'll take depth.
---------
Another .5 ratings bump after first four-player game. Experience was rich, and far more complex and challenging that the solo and two-player games. 

Still, in spite of the fact that ALL new players were familiar with San Juan, there was a lot of frustration over the complex iconography, and what was perceived to be needlessly complex mechanics in some places. One player's comment was, "they should have spent less time on the art, and more time just writing card text that clearly explained what each card could do. I shouldn't have to play a game like this three or four times to feel comfortable with how it all works."

---------

Nonetheless, I am starting to think this game is superior to Dominion, but I suspect the above noted complexity complaints mean it will see the table far FAR less.

---------

Ok. 35+ plays in. Got the first expansion. Have slowly coaxed the wife into playing it now, and she begrudgingly admits she likes it too. It's in the top 5 now.

---------

Things have kind of fizzled out with this game. The wife now refuses to play it because she feels like she has to relearn the rules every time we sit down to give it a try. None of my guy friends but Josh care for it at all, and he never comes down for gaming at lunch anymore, so I am left with it sitting on my shelf gathering dust. I do really like this, and there is tons of replayability, but its complexity for many of the more casual gamers I tend to game with means it is severely flawed in at least one respect.

----------------

Ratings downgrade after getting Eminent Domain to the table. A superior design revealed the flaws in this one. I strongly dislike having to discard my whole hand to do anything meaningful, and I still believe that this game can be played in a non-interactive bubble, basically ignoring my opponents entirely, and still achieve victory (assuming I get the right cards in hand.) I still like this game, and it gets played, on occasion, at lunch with the kids. But once I get a copy of Eminent Domain, I suspect it might get traded away.

------------------------------------------------

Played more ED - that one may as well be called Erectile Dysfunction. And this one - took it out and played some solo games of it and realized that it otherwise hasn't seen the table in three years. No one else likes it, and the iconography is too much a barrier to entry for new players. Ratings downgraded again. Up for trade.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Took me several two-player playthroughs to learn to like. The first barrier -- and it is a serious barrier -- is the game's ill-designed iconography. Even the iconography of a computer game as sophisticated and icon-dependent as Civilization IV is less complicated to teach and learn. I would love to see this game reissued in five years completely reformatted by professional designers.

The second barrier is the difficulty of figuring out what the game's strategies are. Because your ability to act is based on the cards that you draw, and because a two-player game is unlikely to go through the deck even once, you are generally reacting to the cards that you manage to pull into your hand. While I enjoy a making-the-best-of-what-you've-got game as much as the next person, I'm uncomfortable with the idea of so strategically smart a game as Race for the Galaxy seeming to be so luck-dependent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great game in the Porto Rico/San Juan vein, except it's got the combination/flexibility of its progenitors without the weight/time cost associated with it. One of the best Euro game in the last few years.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A complex, deep card game. I find it very fun to have to try and work out a strategy with the hand you're dealt, although some players dislike the game for that very reason.

Difficult to introduce to new players, but I find that more often than not, once they get the rules down, they love it and want to play over and over again.
The supplied cheat-sheets are very useful for beginning players to use to learn the symbols!

Card-sleevers beware: the deck can quickly become enormously tall. This problem can only be made worse by the addition of expansion cards.

The box, standard Rio Grande Games size, is massively too big. Probably the worst (lack of) use of box space I've ever seen.

RATING: 9
This is my favorite Eurogame.  It's often compared to San Juan, but RFTG is much more complex (and consequently has a much longer learning curve), and also much more fun.  There are a wide variety of strategies, which helps keep the game fresh (as well as three expansion sets which increase the complexity dramatically).  There is also a great free computer AI that you can practice on, although the AI is so good you'll probably find it very frustrating at first.  If you like San Juan, you have to try RFTG.  You'll probably never want to play San Juan again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I really wanted to love this game, but I just can't. I do see the potential for strategy here, but the strategy nonetheless feels like a chore to me. Pick a strategy, then hope for the right cards to come up. If the cards you wanted don't come up, or if your opponent is threatening to end the game before you have time to execute your strategy, change your strategy quick and try to keep up. No matter how adept you become at anticipating and adapting to the events in the game, you are forever just hoping to draw the right cards at the right time. Seemingly, the only difference between a subpar move and a brilliant move is whether or not you subsequently drew the cards you needed.

Update 11/19/2015: I still have the same issues with the strategy-on-rails, but it can be interesting to explore the many different successful strategies you can cobble together from the cards you draw. I still feel like the game is playing me rather than me playing it, but at least (for now) there's some interesting scenery to distract me from the fact that I'm on a train ride.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I can see why this could be overwhelming for some. Lots of moving pieces in this galaxy-exploration/conquest game. I suspect one will be rewarded for multiple plays.

RATING: 8.9
A great game that is enhanced by its theming.  Role selection has less of a 'denying your opponent' element than Puerto Rico or Citadels.  The fact that cards are also resources keeps players from hoarding, and creates uncertainty in pursuing specific strategies.  This for me changes the game enough with each play to keep it engaging and interesting.

A bolygók nyersanyagokat termelnek - egy lapot teszünk képpel lefelé a bolygóra -, majd ezeket fel is dolgozhatod - eldobod róla a lapot. RATING: 8
Really fluid empire building game with cards. If you like games where you create the engine that pumps your hand full of cards (resources), this is the game for you. The game icons take a while to get used to but in the end they make sense and are easy to read.

The game is daunting to teach for new players especially if they are not used to this kind of games. Some players may also be annoyed by the fact that this game has very little player interaction.

UPDATE 5/13/2016:
After playing Roll for the Galaxy I had to lower the grade of this game a bit. The new version does so many things right and updates so many things it just feels this game is not as attractive anymore.

RATING: 9
I love the base game, and the first 2 expansions; the 3rd one (from the first "Arc") IMO destroys the best aspects of the game, as the prestige-point system rewards winning players (especially militarily powerful ones) and so you have a runaway winner problem, and the game becomes a headachy struggle to rein the leader in.

Roll for the Galaxy is good too, but hasn't clicked with me in the same way as yet.

UPDATE: Still playing this and finally making the jump from mediocre to decent player. There's just so much pleasure to be had from this quick but thinky game. I've found the key piece of advice was: don't worry overmuch about hanging onto exciting cards at the start, just get cards down that are of some utility, get your card-flow happening ASAP, and build from there. (I've learned to love New Military Tactics and Colony Ship for their ability to jump start your tableau by grabbing powerful planets quickly.)

RATING: 8
Not nearly as hard to learn as everyone makes it out to be. Good heavens, people... they're just icons. 

This is a great game. Basically, it's what Puerto Rico, San Juan, the Settlers Card Game, Jambo, and others all wanted to be but weren't... a nice, streamlined, balanced, "economic engine" game with multiple layers of complexity and multiple ways to victory.

As Stone Age is to Pillars Of The Earth and Agricola, so this is to San Juan / SoC / Jambo and Puerto Rico.

RATING: 8
Like San Juan but much more interesting. I'd give RftG 10 but -1 because its learning curve is made steeper by the confusing iconography. The problem is that the icons are so abstract that they don't evoke what they intend, making the learning curve worse. Once players become a bit more familiar with the system then there's plenty of depth and replayability to be had in a game that plays in the same time as San Juan. The real fun is making tough choices in making your cards generate VP faster than anyone else. I give RftG an additional -1 because skill is rewarded but winning somestimes just comes down to dumb luck of the draw.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.6
Why make a game unnecessarily difficult to learn? The small font and non-intuitive icons are a lesson in how not to design a game. However, for those who persevere with the learning curve underneath it is a reasonable game which plays quickly.

RATING: 9
Great game that captures the 'feel' of building a galactic empire. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
+3 exp
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For me this is still the pinnacle of the modern card game designs. 

There are just so play styles and strategic plays to be made. The cards can combo in so many different ways and the action selection...whilst not totally original here...allows for beautiful interplay as the players try to leech off one another and minimise their opponents ability to do so.

The icons and rules as written don't make it an easy beast to love at first (by that I mean the first 30 odd plays) but once a playgroup has come to terms with the basics, there is a universe of good times just waiting to be explored. 

The game definitely gets better with the expansions...at the expense of more complexity at first.

RATING: 9
My rating has gone up from a 7 to an 8 since I'm finally comfortable with being able to decipher the icons.  Playing San Juan a half dozen times or so has probably also helped.

I could see this going up to a 9 in the future.  The game definitely has a steep learning curve (understanding the icons).  But once you get that figured out it's pretty fun.  

Problem is that unless you have a group dedicated to playing this several times in a row and get over the "icon hump" you will never get a chance to see it shine.  And hence, why I decided against purchasing it.

The new Android App now available as of 7/17 is actually Very Good!  Best way to learn and probably play, since all icons on cards are explained with text! Bumping rating up to 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great card game with absurd levels of depth.  The learning curve is murderous, but the flexibility allowed within the game only becomes apparent a number of plays in.  A less forgiving version of Glory To Rome and San Juan and fully deserving of a place in any serious collection, whether you think you like card games or not.

Expanded in 2014 to include Alien Artifacts, whose cards broaden the experience significantly and add to its depth while not ramping up the complexity too much beyond the base game.  Currently playing this with the (interesting and preferred) advanced 2P version, but yet to throw in The Orb.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Weight: 2.97 / 5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've probably played this a dozen times now, all with 2 players.  After the first couple of games, we switched to the advanced rules, which substantially improved gameplay.

I like trying to plan your actions based on what you predict your opponent will do, and the simultaneous nature of play.  The theme is fun- stacking up a bunch of alien worlds or building a genetics empire is a blast.  The turns are fast, and the tableau card number limit almost always ends our games quickly- it does feel like a race.

I seem to have trouble with certain strategies, and success with others.  I've never gotten a development-based strategy to work, and consumption strategies haven't been dominant even when they have won.  I see military as the easiest path to take.

I find the limited number of starting worlds frustrating.  I don't like starting the game and not necessarily knowing what strategy to pursue, as is often the case with some starting hands and planets.  It's not the uncertainty or the decision I dislike, but rather the feeling of aimlessness even once a decision is made.  Double exploring for the first couple turns often seems best.  I look forward to using the Gathering Storm expansion in the game to increase the number of starting worlds and add new strategies.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

With 1St Arc extensions.

RATING: 7
It's a good game but I have to point out that it's NOT colorblind-friendly. The cards have really small symbols separated only by color. This means that if you are colorblind like me, you have to mark the sleeves to be able to play it.

It has a neat mechanic where taking an action gives other players the opportunity to do the same action. This means you have to try and exploit those chances to do "free" actions to win the game.

RATING: 10
If you are able to surpass the initial learning curve required to actually play this game, can be one of the most satisfying card gaming experiences you will ever have. 

It has a fast paced gameplay (especially 2 player), no waitimes, and a good balance, perfect complexity. Besides, cards have a good quality and they look nice. This game excels at everything.

The only downside would be that it is not easy to get into the game at first (I would advise, keep playing it for at least 5-6 games before letting it go). 
Also, the player interaction is quite low, which I don't mind at all. It just feels right to play these kinda games sometimes, where it's all about fun.

Finally, there are many good expansions that keep this game alive for so many plays.

RATING: 10
Race for the Galaxy is a fantastic game.  Perhaps the biggest compliment I can give it is that I've already played it over 50 times.  It provides a huge amount of depth in a very short game, and it plays really well across its player range.  It is perhaps the pinnacle of what a card game can be; everything that is good and bad about it can be traced to the fact that it is a card game, and the issues that comes along with that.

This is a really fantastic game, and I would recommend it to anyone.  Check it out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
By game three, when my novelty goods producing space empire with strong links to trade associations began raking in the VPs, I realized what the fuss was all about. My, what a thrilling, intriguing game! While not terribly original, it is at least a collection of very good parts. The system borrows heavily from San Juan (which I like quite a bit), and the gameplay reminds me of Agricola (which I absolutely adore). So yes, it's another economy engine game, but the parts that make the engine seem to mesh together better than in many similar games I've played. The card powers can be used to complement one another in different ways, allowing various strategies to emerge. Player interaction may not be very overt or obvious, but you'll have to keep an eye on what the other players are doing and adapt your play accordingly. As the name says, it's a race - and letting that race end too soon (or drag on for too long, for that matter) can cost you a lot of points.

RATING: 10
Recently upped this puppy from a 9 to a 10.  I have played it over 20 times and still love every game.  I was initially demoed this at BGG con and had to get a copy right away.  I am not a fan of PR but I love SJ, but this to me is a better version of SJ.  Admittedly the first play of the game is rough, but give it a few more and I think you will realize that there IS player interaction...maybe not directly but there is a certain aspect of trying to anticipate your opponents next play.

A lot of people call it "multiplayer solitaire" but not looking at an opponents strategy/cards is the fastest way to a loss...

This game plays great with all players from 2p(advanced rules), 3p and 4p

RATING: 9
Race is fast and fun. Its only disadvantage is that it's hard to feel like you're playing it to its full potential until you know the contents of the deck really well, and that doesn't happen until many games into it.

* * *

Now that there are three expansions out, and I've played Race enough to know the contents of its deck, I really dig it. Like Dominion, you have to build a working engine out of randomly selected components. Race is more ornate because there are more components, and different in that you have specialized access to whatever you draw. Then the phase selection mechanism is fairly unique and adds a lot to the games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the best 2-player games out there. Quick to play (especially online) but still offers TONS of strategy options. The better player will win pretty much every time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In this space card game, one attempts to settle, develop or conquer planets. Cards are played out of your hand to satisfy the building cost of planets. Each player has a deck of actions to choose from (draw more cards, settle, develop, trade, etc). If other players have chosen different actions, you also get to execute the action, but without the discount associated with choosing the action.

I feel this is the best game of 2007! It's an addictive little card game and I always want to keep playing. The first few games were a bit bewildering to me, but once you understand all the symbols, you start to see all the nuances of each of the cards. We have also played this with 5 players, and it works just as well. I am looking forward to the expansions. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Downside is the feel that you are playiong your own game sometimes.  New expansions should change that...

I'm well satisfied with my decision.

RATING: 6
Didn't know this was an alternative development of San Juan until I got the chance to play it. Overall I think I prefer the original San Juan because 1) although I can see how the combo-building can appeal to some, the original was just more elegant which is a plus for me and 2) the simultaeneous action selection felt inferior to the original mechanism because we tend to just select what we want to do. I know you can benefit from correctly guessing what other players want to do, but this decision was much more explit and well-informed in the original mechanism. In the end, if you want to play safe, you just do your own thing, which lowers the level of interaction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Multiple strategies, complex combos, eurogame-style interaction (try to benefit from the other player's decisions more than they benefit from yours), and a wide variety of cards makes for a fun game that's different every time.

Some say the game is mostly luck, but in my experience, that's just wrong. While luck is a factor, mitigating it is the true strategy.

This is a terrible game to use for introducing non-gamers to gaming. The complexity is too high and the strategies too obtuse. I've seen multiple would-be gamers turned off from gaming because of this game (they don't understand what's going on, everything feels random, and they lose horribly while not having fun). Please, please don't use this game to introduce non-gamers to gaming.

I most enjoy this game with 2 players, and find it less fun with 3. 4 players is better than 3, but 5 is too many.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With so many icons and so many ways the cards interact, you need to give this game some time before it all sinks in. Once it does, you'll be able to appreciate it.

RATING: 8
La dinámica del juego es interesante, muy parecida a la de San Juan aunque más compleja. 
Cada jugador dispone de un set de cartas en el que tiene 5 posibles roles y cada turno debe seleccionar secretamente uno. Todos los jugadores juegan la acción básica de todos los roles seleccionados y adicionalmente, los jugadores que seleccionaron cada rol, realizan una acción adicional por haberlo seleccionado.
Se utiliza una única baraja de la que todos roban y el objetivo es el de construir, con las cartas robadas, que representan mundos y avances tecnológicos, un imperio galáctico próspero. 
Cuesta un poco acostumbrarse a la nomenclatura que utilizan las cartas, ya que no se utilizan textos para describir lo que hacen sino símbolos, pero una vez aprendidos, agilizan creo yo, el juego.
La estrategia es muy importante ya que hay que determinar de qué manera se construirá el imperio (a partir de mundos militares o no militares o de avances tecnológicos) en base a lo que uno va robando.
Muy recomendable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably one of my favorite card games right now!  Took about 2 sessions before I understood the mechanics, but now I'm hoooked!

Rejected.

RATING: 8
