=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a near perfect 2 player game that can be played in 30 minutes.

After you get over the initial iconography learning curve you start to quickly see all different kinds of combinations you can form in your tableau. There is never an obvious winning strategy since you are at the mercy of the card draw and often have to make the best of what you have. But that's really what the game is about.

Having to decide what cards to discard in order to build the one you really want is a difficult but rewarding experience.

Knowing what phase your opponent is going to use and playing off of that is really where the interaction comes in this game. Staying inside the head of your opponent helps RFTG avoid the multiplayer solitaire that can happen in similar games.

I can't think of many other games that pack this much of a punch in such a short amount of time. 

My only negative points for this game are for how hard it is to teach a new player and for the artwork which is not really my style.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I can see why this is rated so high as there is a LOT of diversity but it is not a deck builder but a get up and go card game.  Very well put together.

RATING: 7
Two years ago: "So yeah, Puerto Rico in space with a TCG element.  If PR didn't beat RftG by a good number of years (and if TI3 didn't do it better, even IF clunkier) I'd probably be a little more forgiving.  But this game is pretty deadly.  Its saving grace is its speed: It's over almost before it begins.  I truly don't see the hype here."

Now: I'm more forgiving.  I see the hype here.  It's speed Puerto Rico.  It's as cock-blocky and passive-aggressive (or, including certain expansions, active-aggressive) as you decide to play it out.  The learning curve is still a little vicious, and it CAN be multi-player solitaire until you pass it, but once you cross over to the point where you see how your actions can affect others, it starts getting... interesting. 

It's still no BSG, but at 20-30 minutes it's not trying to be.

The base set is fine for the casual player.  Really.  And card sleeves are probably a good idea.  And Keldon's AI is a must-have: Play several games solo to get a feel for how the cards interact, and you'll have 50x the fun when you play face-to-face.  Hell, I'll give Keldon's program an 8.5 for solo play; it will kick your ass five ways to Sunday until you get better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
150+ games on PC, my record on desk 68 points (without expansion)-mainly blue planet and technologies
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favorite thing about Race for the Galaxy is the enormous variety. On this count and among the games I've played, it's surpassed only by Dominion. With expansions, Race for the Galaxy includes several hundred cards, and in any given game you add just a dozen or so to your tableau. The space for exploration of strategies is huge.

And the possible strategies truly are different. You might settle many cheap worlds and crank out points via a produce-consume cycle; create a towering military and explore heavily to score a few select powerhouse worlds; or build a self-sustaining infrastructure of developments that reward further developing. Better still, while most cards are carefully designed to support certain strategies – blue worlds support production and consumption, while military worlds do not – a few cards break these rules, making room for crazy hybrid strategies. One starting world lets you settle most military worlds as if they were civilian worlds, for example, an ability which twists the usual space of possibilities.

The game's drag-free engine building also makes for a spectacular arc of development. You begin with a lone world and a few cards. You end with a dozen worlds with looping powers; a purring engine, a perpetual motion machine that spits out points. 

Despite this generosity, the decisions are points of high tension. For cards are the primary currency of the game, so to add a card to your tableau you may need to discard 5 others.

All the while, you must pay close attention to your opponent. Though you cannot directly hamper her plans, you must choose your role based on its relative value lest you benefit your opponent more than yourself.

Somehow, this entire experience is distilled into 20 minutes. (It must have something to do with the brilliant mechanisms for simultaneous play.) 

I know of no other game that packs so much variety and complex decision-making into so short a time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Sleeved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is an enjoyable role selection game that plays very quickly and is easy to learn. 

Many people have said Roll for the Galaxy is easier to learn than this, but I find Race much easier and cleaner. Roll has far clunkier rules in my opinion.

For the cost, the speed of gameplay, and tightness/strategic depth, I think Race is definitely superior to Roll for 2P (I have not played either with more than 2P). The only thing I like better about Roll is the custom dice are pretty sweet.

RATING: 9
Smooth - very smooth CCG game.  It feels really tight - as if every possible combo has been analyzed and tested.

The icons did not phase me that much - they seem to make sense, but I specialize somewhat in pattern recognition.

Another tactical game - I have been unable to establish any long-term strategies - just go with the flow.

I really look forward to trying this with a real opponent.

After introducing this to a friend:
It was painfully apparent that experience with the game makes a difference.  I was able to easily defeat a novice even though I was not trying, unlike San Juan, where I lost the introduction game I played.  I prefer games that reward intelligent play a wee bit more than luck.  So far, it appears this will be the case with RftG.

After playing with real opponents for several games, it confirms what I have already written.  Outstanding middle weight card game.

Why this is not a 10:
-> Being a middle weight game reduces my prospects for playing.
-> I would like some variety in my gaming.

RATING: 10
Incredibly deep combo-building engine game. This game has the highest depth-to-playtime ratio of any game I know of (barring timed abstracts), and is infinitely replayable with a plethora of strategies.

It strikes a perfect balance between strategy and tactics; one cannot predetermine a strategy beforehand, but must adapt to the cards dealt. On the other hand, while changing strategies mid-stream is possible, it is seldom worthwhile. There are a multitude of strategies to use and they are generally very balanced.

I personally have never had any trouble with the icons.

RATING: 8
After subsequent plays, this game is losing interest to me. It has much of the feel of playing Magic. If you pull a good combo of cards, you have a great chance of winning, but a poor hand of cards can set you back. Once you learn what the cards are and what combinations work best, it's just a matter of playing them in the right order. That doesn't mean you're going to win, just that eventually it will just come down to card draws.

After more plays, I think I'm getting into the Explore +5 action more. Once you know what card(s) you're looking for, there is some strategy to pulling more. It's really about playing what you have and playing your cards into each other.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Race for the Galaxy shares lots of mechanism with San Juan. It actually seems to have even less interaction with players than it. You do have to be aware what others are most likely to do so you can benefit from it but beyond that you have very little interaction. There is a good layout and symbols on the cards. So you can see easily (once you learn the symbols) what you can do in each phase of the game. Once you have more games under your belt you'll probably start to remember better what bonuses you get in each phase but I had sometimes hard time to remember those.

It is definitely a very good game but it takes the first game to learn the mechanics and it helps when you have idea what type of cards there are in the deck. I won't think it will be a too big hit with non-gamers as it has a quite steep learning curve. RftG is simply a great game with a lot of replayability and as a bonus game is over in a short time with experienced players.

Update: It's a bit different with two players advanced rules as you can do double-developing or -settling and you're able to play consume/produce-cycle all by yourself. Not sure if this breaks anything in the game but it plays a bit differently being still an excellent game. Two-player game works well with the basic rules too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Whoa. This game is incredible. And deep. But still really quick.

The theme has been built very carefully, and the mechanics fit the theme perfectly. The components aren't bad either: The cards are very sturdy, and the artwork is nice, and serious thought has been given to usability issues. Thanks to the graphic design, layout and the icon system, gameplay is really smooth and it is very easy to keep track of your special powers.

Lots of possibilies for ultimate killer combos, and for me the game feels more like a hand management game than a snowball engine optimization scheme. There is also quite the right amount of outguessing, which usually ends in me choosing the wrong phase anyway ;P

Success depends mostly on how good you are, but since the game only lasts about half an hour, and (unlike in most snowball engine games) gameplay and artwork don't suck astronomically at first sight, it is reasonably easy and fast to reach a comfortable skill level. 

Raised the rating from 9 to 10 after 10 playings. 

And just when you think you know the game, they'll give you the expansions...

RATING: 8
The iconography makes it; it's very simple to quickly judge the value and functionality of all the cards in play and in your hand, and the phase selection system is extremely well integrated both visually and mechanically. 

It'd be dry and boring if it was a long eurogame, but a functionally instant setup time, slick layout, and viscerally satisfying card drawing and hand management really give it teeth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Space themed card game with asymmetrical factions and some tidy mechanisms. There are lots of symbols to learn and card combinations that make it good for repeated play in a static group, but terrible if you're introducing new players. This is a great game for a group, who are going to play the hell of it and become competitive enough to enjoy the intricacies. As a casual player I had some fun, but felt that without any meaningful way to affect the other players it became a dull efficiency game with set plays and luck of the draw dependency, which is a shame as this would be a great alternative to the glitzy CCGs, but without the expense. (6)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I enjoy playing this game.  It's fast enough after a few plays that the luck factor doesn't bother me much.  It does seem like the game rewards players who manage to draw all the parts of their "combo", however, and player interaction gets less important later in the game when everyone has their plans in place.  UPDATE: Downgraded from 9 to 8.  The card combos are just too strong, and there are those occasional games I won (or lost) where I never had to pay much attention to what my opponents were doing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Trying to delevop a card game with the richness of Puerto Rico and adding something of its own is definitely no mean task. Race for the Galaxy was meant to be a more complex game than San Juan, attempting to keep the principle of the different phases of a game with a little advantage to the player who chose to play them. At the same time, it does not restrict the choice of a phase to one single player, and the huge amount of action cards that can be deployed within these phases means that  a vast range of possibilities lie open for each match. Last but not least, the game offers a clever, Bob Abbott-like payment system: to play out one card a player needs to pay an amount of other cards in his hand.

Unfortunately, Race for the Galaxy isn't as brilliant as Puerto Rico by a long stretch. There are several reasons for this: the icons system is economic but difficult to get used to, there's absolutely no interaction nor anything like a common pool for the players to choose from (actions, cards... whatever), there's quite some luck as well since a draw does not always include cards that support whatever a player has already on use, and even after many, maaaaany plays (until players learn how to optimize their hands) neither good cards nor good tactics can win a game on their own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.4
Decisamente poco immediato e, anche se fondamentalmente semplice, risulta ostico specie nelle prime partite. Molti simboli sulle carte, non sempre immediati, e una volta compresi bisogna  imparare a sfruttarli a proprio favore e infine conoscere le combo (molte) più produttive. Un gioco da provare diverse volte prima di poter padroneggiare. La meccanica è simile a quella di Puerto Rico con scelta dell'azione, con piccolo vantaggio, alla quale però tutti possono partecipare. Simpatico anche in 2, rende però al meglio in 4.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I never got bowled over by Race for the Galaxy. There was some appeal to the game, but I never rated it to the ridiculously high levels of the community as a whole, and I can't see myself playing the 50-odd games a year that devotees seem to clock up. C'mon - it's a simple card-laying game propped up by a geeky theme and some top-notch card art, but nothing more. Among other problems, the card turnover can be too swift and the VP awards don't seem to balance terribly well.

[i]Lotteried in November 2009 G4GG[/i]

[2010/02/08]

I just played my first game... scored 2nd place with 51 pts... i dont think that matters.. just felt like writing it...


6 of us played last night [the game only supports 5], each person had a hand, and i shared a hand with another person who never played before.... this is the first time where i've ever shared a player spot with someone, and I enjoyed it WAY more that i would have imagined...  the other guy on my "team" had never played either... so it wasn't like we were just watching the other play...


did i like this game?.... yes


was i good at it?... i'm good at everything... i mean yes


was it entertaining? kind of... i had fun building my hand.. and i did see the benefit of predicting other players moves... but there was such a lack of player interaction, that i felt that was the biggest miss of this game... FORTUNATELY... i was paired up with someone.... sure, it made it a bit like a co-op (which i typical dislike).... but if anything, it added to the enjoyment of this first "learning game".... now if i play again... i want my own hand... and to be completely isolated from the rest of the world... 


Recomended.. to gaming introverts (who like hand mangement card games)


I'll play again... but i'm not seeking it out

RATING: 7.5
Steep learning curve, but once you learn the rules it is a very fast and fun game with lots of complexity and strategy.  

Expansions add more depth and balance (as well as a few more strategies), but at the cost of the speed and ease of play that first pulled me in.

After further thought, the base game is really compromised by the limited viable winning strategies.  While I still like it, the expansions are necessary to add balance but detract from some of the aspects I like about the base game (easy setup, quick play).

RATING: 5
Bear in mind I've only played this once and it could well get better after more plays.

For a newbie, the amount of different symbols used on the cards can be mind boggling.  I spent half the game not really having a clue what I was doing.

A lot of games get accused of being multi-player solitaire, most of the time unfairly in my opinion.  This game, however, really did feel like multi-player solitaire.  I didn't really have any idea what the other players were doing and it didn't really seem to matter.

By and large I'm not a big fan of card games anyway.  This one could well get better after you get used to all the symbols and become familiar with the cards, but to be honest I'm in no hurry to get to know the game better.

RATING: 10
[b]Race For the Galaxy[/b]

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]- Role selection and trying to leech off your opponents role(s)
- Cards have multiple uses during the game
- Excellent 2p with the advanced rules
- 20 minute play time packed with strategy
- Seemingly endless replay value

This is my favorite 2p game to play with my son. We will be playing this for years to come, what an amazing game. We have since added RFtG: Alien Artifacts, RFtG: The Gathering Storm and RFtG: Rebel vs Imperium expansions to our collection.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (9):[/COLOR]

[i]I bought this game after quite a few BGG'ers recommended it to me in various threads. I was looking for a good 2p game to play with my son. After our first 3 or 4 plays I was not impressed, I actually regretted my decision to buy the game. However; since I have a limited gaming budget I was stuck with it. So my son and I continued to play, we instituted the advanced 2p rules and we started to get familiar with the cards. These 2 factors ended up completely changing my view on this game. 

My son and I had very little trouble figuring out the icons, I find that whole argument to be a little overblown. It may hold water if you are teaching this to a non gamer, but this isn't a game I would pull out in that circumstance.[/i]

36 -> Base RftG
78 -> Arc 1, The Gathering Storm + Rebel Imperium
92 -> Arc 2, Alien Artifacts (7 included the orb)
43 -> Arc 3, Xeno Invasion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love this game! :) Not too long, plenty of decisions and variety.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I suck at this game, but I still appreciate it. I can tell that despite the luck-factor, there is an underlying strategy to it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Race for the Galaxy[/b] is a card game using the multiple role selection mechanic.  It is [i]very[/i] similar to the [b]San Juan[/b] card game, except now every player can choose the same role and receive the same bonus for choosing that role.  A game usually takes about 30 minutes to play, but can vary, especially with new players.

The cards are well designed and you can tell that they put a lot of thought into the layout.  There is very little text on the cards, and instead the game uses iconography to depict the function of the cards.  Icons are used almost to excess, and you will find that you have to frequently refer to the player's aids, with all the definitions of the many different icons used, for several games at first.

I think the game is good and well designed, but I feel that somehow the game isn't done, and that there should be a little more of everything.  It really seems that the game was designed as incomplete, and I suspect that one must purchase the expansions to complete the game.

I haven't played any of the expansions and I'm not sure if I will ever buy them.  It is a good game, but I don't like to [i]have[/i] to purchase the expansions just to get a complete game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Slightly complicated but very fun once you get the hang of it

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Includes:

[thing=34499][/thing]
[thing=40210][/thing]
[thing=66121][/thing]
[thing=92932][/thing]

This is definately one of my favorite games.  It has excellent mechanics, artwork, and a alot of decision making.  The role selection provides for some really nice player interaction, and you definately will benefit from guessing what phases your opponents will play.  But overall this is a game where you can't target your opponents in the same way as a game like Glory to Rome or Citadels.  There is some luck in that there is card draw, but it is a game where I have noticed that generally the better players win.  A potential negative is that the game has a relatively high learning curve, and it often takes players a few games to really "get it."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I put off reading the rules for R4tG because I was intimidated by all the reviews that described the game's steep learning curve.  Imagine my relief when I discovered this was not true!  I'm not particularly quick to learn new games, but this one was a relative cinch based on my experience with 7 Wonders.  Granted, there are a great many cards in play during the game, so multiple plays will lead to an increased appreciation of one's options, but I found my very first game to be fun and challenging, leaving me eager to play again soon.  The quality of the cards and the artwork on them adds to the experience, and I feel the many complaints I've read about the cards' iconography to be unfounded.  Yes, it's complex, but there's no way this could be avoided, given the complexity of the game.  Familiarity comes with play, and the icons rapidly begin to make sense. This game may not appeal to those who want the ability to directly sabotage their opponents, but I personally appreciate having no one to blame but myself (and the luck of the draw) if I fail to maximize my opportunities.  Exciting and intense with very little down time, R4tG is a fun and intellectually nutritious game that requires constant planning, the revision of plans, and the weighing of options.    (5+5)

RATING: 10
2010/02/04:
Okay this game is as good as GTR in my mind now.

I've played with Keldon's AI and friends (mostly with AI) for more than 100 times, and still feel there are much room for me to improve my skill or to get a better understanding of the game. To name a few things that I'm still observing:
1. Each card's pro & con.
2. Each card's pro & con in different combination
3. Each card's usefulness in different playing style. (Rush, $ minded, produce consume, development, military)
It's hard to believe how deep this game is...

On a side-note, the game feels perfectly balanced after throwing in "The Gather Storm" expansion. However when "Rebel vs Imperium" expansion is also thrown in, it completely PIMPED the game into a wacky ride! Less strategic, more chaotic, more luck, but also more FUN!

2009/11/30:
I'm bumping this game up to a 10. 
Well deserved.

----------
Thanks to the released RFTG AI, I finally got a chance to play repetitively to see if I'd like this game. After playing several times, I immediately went out a buy a copy. (Smart marketing strategy RIO.)

I liked it better than I thought I'd be! RFTG is a elegant and sophisticated piece of work. Not nearly as fun, interactive and creative as Glory to Rome. However RFTG feels more like a intellectually competitive game; certainly a good, if not extremely good alternative to GTR. (I think Glory To Rome will be my all time favorite, period.)

I like RFTG for its short play time, planning & calculating oriented nature, multiple paths to winning, and believe it or not, its SUBTLE Interaction. However there's a tendency to win more with Produce/Consume strategy and a mild Run-away leader problem. Once the Consume engine is built-up, it's hard to stop it. 

Well... my strategy idea may change in the future as I sink more plays into it.

NOTE: Because of this game, I'm dropping Puerto Rico's rating lower. I just can't imagine myself going back to play Puerto Rico anymore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I didn't enjoy my first ten games of Race because it has a steep learning curve, and only grudgingly played it when others wanted to. I stuck at it because I knew it was a good game based on its high rank, now it's one of my favourite short games. 

The icon system is annoying and makes learning the game difficult - I don't care about being able to see art work - I'd much rather a card was covered in a paragraph of text that described exactly how it works, whilst also retaining the icons for experienced players.

In terms of gameplay, it's closest to Puerto Rico (buts shorter and with more luck), like a more complex version of San Juan and only some vague similarities with Glory to Rome. I think PR is the better game because it doesn't have the flukey good/bad draws. 

The main differences from PR are the simultaneous action selection, hand management, the military mechanic, 2 types of buildings (Devs and Worlds), and both Trader and Captain are integrated into the Consume phase. 

Play against the AI here:
http://www.keldon.net/rftg/

It's really good for learning the game because it enforces the rules for you. I think the best way to learn is 2 player advanced, as you have more control and can thus see the effects of what you are doing. Games take me about 4 minutes each.
This helps you learn the icons and deck composition and gain experience. The AI is strong.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

Good game, overall. So far it feels like scores are very heavily linked to cards drawn, although I could see how more plays might allow to get better scores with worse cards as well. But still, luck of the draw naturally has very heavy influence here.

Bought used in great condition.

RATING: 10
I love this game.  Great theme change and adaptation of puerto rico.  I have yet to play with anyone who grasped the strategy well enough to make good decisions.  As a result I know I have not seen the complete depth of the game.  Getting pounded by a few expert players would give me a better gauge of the game, and I am sure it will push this game up .5 to 1.5 points.

Edit: This game is just way too good.  I am moving up to a 9 for now, but this game has no ceiling.

Edit: Has to be a ten.  I have played this hundreds of times, and I will never turn it down.  If I ever rearrange my top ten, this has serious consideration for the 1 spot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I think this is the only 10 in my collection.

Yes yes, it's a steep learning curve. Yes yes, there are a *million* little icons. Give me icons over lengthy card texts any time, please. 

I must have played more than 1000 hands of this in the past four years, half in person and half via Keldon's AI (and the other online play environments before that). It never gets old, ever. Play time is perfect, the depth of decisionmaking is perfect...it's perfect in every way for me. 

However, it requires some time to master. This to me is a positive, not a negative. It means it'll give you something to chew on for months and years. It's not "solveable." Mastery means experimenting with every strategy, memorizing the deck (much easier w/o expansions), really investing in getting your head wrapped around the game.

I'm not persuaded that adding the expansions made the core game any better, although playing it with ALL the options turned on (goals, takeovers, prestige) is one hell of a tough game. 

Cannot say enough good things about this game.

RATING: 6
"I don't mind the icons, but the whole game just feels like a slightly-bloated San Juan. I prefer role drafting of SJ over the simultaneous reveal of Race. The base game of Race feels a bit incomplete (while also feeling needlessly complicated)."

What I like:
- Pay cards to play cards is cool
- Theme is nice
- Pretty quick, with experienced players
- Military option for settling

What I don't like:
- Simultaneous role selection
- Trade/Consume split
- Complicated special abilities of cards
- Base game feels like it is missing some cards

My Rating started as a 7, but the more I played, the lower my rating went, down to a 4. After not playing for a couple years, it's back up to a 6, which is where it is likely to stay. 

The BGG-voted weight of 3.0 seems about right.

RATING: 7
Dreaded learning this game. Sat on my shelf for 3 months before I got the courage to plow through the minefield of icons. Took 2 hours to get through first game, but surprise: we both liked it. I'm glad I held off on my initial reaction of 'trade this asap!' after I first saw the rulebook and the 299 icons on each card. I look forward to game 2 when we can cut it down to an hour. And bonus for my wife: she won the first game, so you know that's going to make her happy to play again.

Update: This game is solitaire, and does not work unless you play with someone at exactly the same level. For this mechanic, I much prefer 'glory to rome' and have not gone back to Race after the initial 2 plays. Highly overrated.  

Update: game is superb when played on keldon. Game is much better on pc than playing the card version. Also, easy to get games in, which is very hard to do in real life, as this game appeals only to a very small subset of hardcore gamers. You learn quickly from your mistakes on keldon, but it still takes many games to get familiar with all icons, amd many more games to actually win. Playing against live opponents requires all players be equal in play skill, which seldom happens. Game is much too complicated to teach to casual gamers.  For sale.

RATING: 8.5
I find that games of RftG are a very rewarding experience, full of strategy, interesting decision making and tension. Not only do you need to pick a strategy based upon your home world and the cards available to you, but you need to watch what the other players are doing in order to try and counter their plans.

Given that it is a card game, there is an element of luck to it, but the games are quick so you can play many games in one sitting, which evens out the luck factor somewhat. Moreover, the luck of the draw can be minimised a little by selecting appropriate actions, but it is certainly somewhat responsible for providing some of the aforementioned tension that is present in the game.

RATING: 6
I loved this game at the start. It took a long while to get used to, but after 150 games (including online and Vs Bot) I still can't figure out a strategy that works, and whether I win or not bears very little relation to what I do! Perhaps I need to get back to playing Vs humans again, but I think that the strategies are so varied, you can't wait on the card you want and getting the best from your hand is a mammoth task.

So I started playing against humans again and have downgraded my score. I am getting frustrated. I have tried all the different techniques I can think of and still can't guarantee a win. Ultimately the variety in the cards and the complexity of the game does little to aid play and it is starting to feel like an extremely well debugged 'bad idea'. Sometimes when we meet I can tell by the second round that my hand is too lousy and I'm never going to win and I just have to play on with that knowledge. I like that luck is a part, but you should be able to start with any hand and have a shot at winning.

I love the flavour and the theme but apart from all that this game just sucks.

RATING: N/A
2.97 ($30)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favourite games. The iconography is a marvel of modern gaming design, with only a handful of different icons Mr Lehman has managed to fit a lot of information on each card, but keep them easy to read when they sit in your hand or in your tableau.

It is a very tactical game that forces you to change strategy depending on the cards you draw and I really like this aspect of the game; you can’t just choose a strategy and run with it unless you are really lucky with the cards you draw.

I bought the first expansion after playing the base game around 10 times and I see no reason to not play with it. Picking it up with the base game would be my major recommendation if you’re going to buy this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I don't understand all the complaining about the iconography.  After about three games, the symbols make perfect sense and make the game play much smoother than loads of text would have.  I do, however, understand the complaints about multi-player solitaire.  In a 2 player game, it is far too common for a player to quickly build an efficient engine and just crank it for the rest of the game.  Even the most ardent Race fans have to admit that picking Consume X2 and produce four rounds in a row is not a thrilling, epic adventure.  When you are able to set that up, you barely care that there is another human at the table.  In the three player game, there is more subtle interaction because you must attempt to predict what actions your opponents are going to pick so that you can leach off their choices and hopefully pick a phase that will not help them much.  Even with all that said, there is little to no interaction among the players' tableaus.  There are a couple of cards that allow you to draw a card or two if you produce more _____ goods than your opponents, but that is about the extent of card interactions.  That said, if you never learn to anticipate what others will do, your skill level will be capped fairly quickly.  There is definitely skill in choosing phases that will push your agenda without aiding, and perhaps even slowing, others.  And even though I have made some negative comments, Race is still a game I will play anytime and even suggest.


Note:  Some of my complaints are fixed when an expansion is added.  It seems that more options are added to slow down/interfere with players going on autopilot consume X2/produce.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Rahdo Top 10 Civilization
Paste - Compared to Dominion

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I am not sure why this game doesn't work for me, but whatever the reason, this isn't a game I ask to play.  Some things that I don't like: using cards from my hand to "pay" for playing other cards; cards that count as "goods" and stay face down until you turn them in for points or other cards; the highly confusing Consume action which has two parts (this has never been clear to me).  I do like the flexibility to play this with two players or with more.  I like the option of a basic starting hand or a random draw.  The rules are pretty simple.

RATING: 7

Man this still pales next to Roll for the Galaxy for me. I hear that it really starts to shine at 10+ plays, so I am going to do my darndest to get there. Race appeals to me because it is so short yet so meaty with quick setup and takedown. Roll isn't bad with length and setup, but it is worse in that regard enough that it inhibits it from coming out every night.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Despite having a very similar style of gameplay to San Juan (cards used both as money and buldings, some cards produce goods, others give you bonuses or points) I've found this game a lot more enjoyable and replayable. Part of that is the theme, but I think the main factor is the way different sets of cards work together to give an array of viable strategies. Each time we thought one approach was game-breakably good, someone went and found another one that could beat it. Plays fairly quickly, too, which is a bonus.
Main drawback is a lack of direct interaction between players...maybe this comes in in some of the expansions?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As hard to learn as everyone says. Once grasped, a thing of genius to behold. Early in your career, it will take 90% of your cognitive capacity just to execute each of your turns. Learning to play competitively, as in reading other players' tableaux and considering what they are likely to do in an effort to "win the Race," only requires the other 90% of your cognitive capacity.
Strikes me as a game that will appeal to folks who like games requiring heavy concentration, which is to say that the space theme doesn't seem terribly important. Sometimes you decide to build something other than what you need most just because "we come such a long way," which is another way of saying the games ends very quickly. And the artwork is wonderful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Solo 2 player friendly. Heavier Rules. We are loving this game and the tableau!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Hands down, the best card game I've ever played. It's absolutely brilliant and I seriously would never turn down a game. Fast playing, incredibly deep and the combos you can pull off are great. Even after 100+ plays, I still am not that great at the game. The icons for this game are brilliant. Now to new players, it's a bit rough, but after a game or two, they are well onto their way.

I just have 2 issues with this game and it's not really the games fault. My first issue is that the game is short...a bit too short. It falls into this weird category of not quite filler and not quite long enough to be the main meal of the night. I could play it over and over, but people are usually done with it after 1 or 2 plays. The second issue I have with it is that it's rather difficult to get a new player into it and experienced players can crush a new player.

My Race Gauntlet:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ga3g2oy2TBLHDWEDqFpXSdnKqFP9OybNHFbjchbeyI0

RATING: 5
UPDATE: Traded at Alphaspel. Nah, I might be a fine game with more plays. But as all games have this premise, I feel no need to struggle with this. Better to play games that feels more "right" from the start.

*** 

It's like San Juan but a lot more complex. Fine, I have always lacked some depth in SJ. It's got nicer artwork than SJ and the paths to victory are several.

Great, so I bought it.

When reading the booklet I discovered the rules were very detailed. Hm, not overly complex maybe I thought, but there was a lot to learn. Well, yes, the rules where actually kind of hard to digest I discovered by the second reading. Am I stupid, it has a weight under 3 on the geek? Is it just the amount of all small details? These icons and small symbols?

Fine... But surley this was a good buy after all?

Well, not really. At least not for me. Initially the game where sadly not that fun to play, although I saw some potential. The sum of RftG is less than the parts and San Juan is to my surprise a much better game. 

I will try give it some more plays so the ratings will hopefully rise. I think that this is a game that needs to be played a lot before it really shines.

RATING: 8
Very similar mechanic to San Juan, with greater complexity and maybe more depth.  My sons are more enthused about this game than me,perhaps because I rarely beat them!  Although I am happy to play when prompted, I do find that once someone has obtained the cards to facilitate a particular winning strategy (and there doesn't appear to be many variants despite the apparent complexity), the game quickly becomes a series of mechanical plays until one of the end states has been achieved.  Maybe I will find greater depth in time if I can be motivated to look hard enough.

UPDATE: after more plays I have grown fonder, increasing score from original 7 to an enthusiastic 8.  Definitely a game that grows on you.

RATING: 10
My favorite game of all time.

It got its inspiration from Puerto Rico, but it turned it completely around and is, in my opinion, a much better game. And I like Puerto Rico a lot. 

It's Puerto Rico the card game with simultaneous role selection. It's super San Juan on steroids with a space theme. It's infinitely replayable. It's complex and challenging. It's deep. It's interactive. It's quick. It's flawless. 

It's perfect!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For some reason I can't get enough of this game. Been playing the Ai a lot lately. I love the amount of depth packed into 30-60 minutes of play (half that time vs the ai). The expansions help flesh this game out nicely so I'd recommend getting them with the game.

I'm hoping to get my wife into it now that she is familiar with a similar game, 7 wonders. The downside to this game is that it can be hard to understand at first due to all the iconography.

edit: My wife caught on just fine to Race for the Galaxy. She is finding the more she plays the more she likes it. This is currently my favorite fast game since it plays in 30min or less but has good decision making and depth.

edit: this game just doesn't get old. A real classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Trying to add depth with more symbols and more special actions on each card generally does not suit my gaming style. I feel 7 Wonders employs the same technique, and I don't like that game either.

There may be a theme to this game, but I spent so much time trying to read the symbols and decipher what everything meant to pay any attention to what the theme on the cards actually said or meant.

A great game can take a small set of things going on and provide a rich complexity based on how everything meshes together. There seems to be a trend in games to add depth by adding more stuff going on. This is a mistake in my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

More options then in San Juan, but the ultimate plus comes from simultaneous role-selection, that one is quite an improvement!

Edit: And the game just goes better and better. 8->9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After a lot of plays, this has lost some of its luster, but is still fun with experienced players. Teaching this game is not fun, though. Unless the players are already interested in the game and understand that there's an unusually steep learning curve, it can be an exercise in frustration for all involved. Unlike in traditional board economic games, RftG has a much less transparent engine, so beginners will not see what steps they need to take to make progress unless it's spelled out explicitly. 

Update: has found its way back into the rotation - still a lot of fun. Have been exploring a few new approaches and am looking forward to the expansion. *** now that the expansion is in my hands and I've got a new regular 2P opponent, this is going back to a 9.

9 -> 10: I always enjoy playing this game. My first 10.

Note - all plays are recorded under the most recent expansion's entry.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It seems like [i](even though they've been published by different designers and publishers)[/i] this game together with [b]San Juan[/b] and [b]Dominion[/b] form a trilogy in a way. It has been said that this brilliant but [i]moderately heavy[/i] [b]cardgame[/b] has been inspired by San Juan and there are lots of similarities between them. If I would [i]have[/i] to pick one of the two I'ld pick San Juan but just because it's a little lighter and quicker. The [i](seemingly)[/i] "thousands" of symbols in this game are a little confusing the first couple of plays but are fairly obvious after that. An awesome heavier cardgame.

Borrowed the game, played it the same evening. Should therefore play a lot quicker next time, and it did. We played it twice more with the standard rules, then went on to the 2 player rules, which I like even better (I won, so that also helps :) ). 
Bought the game by now and explained to new players for the first time (or rather my bf did). They were a bit overwhelmed by the symbols at first, but caught on quick enough...

RATING: 9
I love the mechanic of using cards for multiple purposes.  Add that to engine building and space theme and I'm sold. It plays a little like multi-player solitaire, depending on the strategies that each player is taking.  In some games there is a very cool synergy where you can deduce what role your opponent is going to take and then decide whether you should take that role or not. In others, your strategies and the timing of those strategies don't line up at all and you are essentially playing on your own. If you could always play off each other's role selection it might be a perfect 10.

I also think the iconography is pretty intuitive. I can never remember what the different buildings do in Castles of Burgundy, but I have an easy time with these icons. It may just depend on how your brain works.

App plays not logged.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I would rate this a 10 if the multiplayer solitaire aspect wasn't so strong. It's still a great game.

Also, still waiting for Alien Artifacts to be released in "spring 2012" if I recall correctly.

RATING: 7
The rules and the many, many symbols on the cards made our group think this would be complicated to play, until we got through the first round.  It's actually very simple, and to my mind, it felt quite a lot like Gin, because it's a mostly non-strategic card game where you start with a random hand, look for weak synergies in your few cards, plan to implement those synergies fairly algorithmically, but defect from them opportunistically if other players offer you a better opportunity or you get a good random draw.  Interaction with other players is almost non-existent.  You occasionally guess whether another player is committed to a certain action, which gives you a partial action for free, and trying not to give them actions matters a little, but for the most part, it's a 4-player solitaire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the best engine building games there is. Short and fast with experienced players. This is a go to super filler for any game night.

RATING: 9
Very good game, the learning curve makes this a no go for casual play though. The expansions are necessary, but a rip-off for what you get. Solo rules? Even a mediocre PC game gives more fun than playing this rather cumbersome solo variant. The take-over rules really go against the fast-paced soul of the game with all that whacky book-keeping, and the Prestige thing seems to have too much impact and gives birth to cards with graphical and iconical overkill. The graphics on the cards seem to have been of greater important than the information because the font is barely readable, written what seems dark grey on light gray on a shaded background picture instead black on white in a window - abysmal design errors. And I have some expansions in english and some in german because the company couldn't keep that in sync for the german version. 

Now you might ask why does he still care for the game and give it a 9?

Because it is an EXCELLENT game! So excellent that you play it even despite all those stunning shortcomings mentioned above. BTW, I do not (never ever) play it with take-overs or prestige, but use all the other cards and, to some point, the tokens for additional ways to get VPs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Take Puerto Rico's mechanics (role-taking and VP-enhancing buildings), remove all the clumsiness that burdens PR (ships that only carry on type of goods, settlers, trade house limits...) and you'll have Race for the Galaxy. A fine, elegant card game, that plays quickly but has tremendous depth and a reasonably well integrated theme.  

Update: this is fast becoming one of my favourites. You really come to enjoy it when you understand the whole point of the game is to constantly adapt your strategy to the cards you are dealt with, instead of just looking for one or two specific cards.

--

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game has moved up among my favorite games of all time. 

Many levels of strategy to enjoy, with more becoming evident with every play. The learning curve is steep, particularly without someone to guide you. But once it clicks it's a beautiful clockwork of finely meshing gears that is a pleasure to play. Any strategy will likely need audibles on the line of scrimmage as you make decisions on which cards to keep, which to lay into the tableau with the hope they will work together to produce points. When it works, it delivers a genuine feeling of accomplishment and a job well done. When it doesn't, well, you just want to play 1 more time to give it another shot. A true sign of an excellent game.

The icon system, while daunting at first, is brilliant once absorbed, allowing information to be conveyed while maintaining the integrity of the great artwork, which in turn keeps the mood of the theme present at all times. It's a glorious combination of form and function, and I'm so glad I finally jumped in and learned how to play.

This is one hell of a game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It is a beefed up San Juan.  Also, I think itis a little to similar to Glory to Rome. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Very good "addition" to the San Juan family.  Of course, if I had played this first I might think that San Juan is a streamlined "spin-off" of Race for the Galaxy.  The variety of cards creates a greater range of possible strategies, which are fairly well explained through the use of unique symbols on each card.  The icon-style "hieroglyphics" seem to work better than a primarily text-driven system, as it enables the creation of a more varied deck of cards without using too much text to explain a slightly different mechanism.  This game really is a "race", as setting the tempo for getting something done (be it trading, consuming, military, etc...) has to be kept at a fast pace or your opponents may leave you in the dust.  There's a learning curve here that seems to be steeper than in San Juan, I am sure expansions will bring this to the forefront.  A very fun card game with some very exciting choices (leeching others' role selections is a great feature).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Has much in common with San Juan, but with various subtle improvements and a whole lot more depth & choice of strategies. Plays much quicker too, which is great as it allows multiple plays to try out different approaches. It is a little harder to learn/teach than San Juan, but well worth the effort.

VP chips are a great inclusion, both as an alternate end condition, and as a scoring aid to help avoid the need for paper & pencil (though double the quantity would have been appreciated for when playing with more players). The chips are a bit small & dark however.

The theme appeals to me much more than that of San Juan, and the potential with the 2 expansions is pretty big.

The cards & use of icons throughout are great - except perhaps the titles are a little dark & hard to read under lower lighting conditions, although the titles are not at all important to gameplay.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Race for the Galaxy is one of the bravest design I've seen. Tom Lehmann gives us only a deck of cards (I don't count points tokens since they can be replaced by anything) and promises a worthy game every time. And, oh god, it is delivered.

Of course there is chance, luck of the draw and so on, but with such an elegant design it really doesn't matter - even if you lose, you still have fun, you still accomplish things, use your imagination, make really hard choices. It's amazing.

As for interaction - for people who think that race (in sports, video games, boardgames) has lack of interaction and only disciplines like box, where people fight, or chess, where you can knock opponents pieces, involve any meaningful interaction, Race will fall flat indeed. But interaction here is much more subtle. To win you don't have to get as much points as you can, you just need to have more than your opponent. You can benefit from phases that your opponent chooses, you can speed up end of the game by building or grabbing all points. There's plenty of very gentle and brilliant interaction in Race.

And expansions coming in arcs that offer you different play styles? Even better! I never understood why a lot of people didn't like Alien Artifacts. It gives you opportunity to make Race game a longer one, you don't have to use it, it's a choice me and my girlfriend always wanted. Maybe someday we will see a coop expansions arc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great game, but it lacks interaction for it to be among my top games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I liked this game after my first few plays. It was all about building a thematic space empire and seeing who got the right cards to win. Then I played a few dozen games against the AI, and something clicked. It really is a race: to get cards in your hand, cards on the table, and a large chunk of vp chits. There's no time to sculpt the perfect combo, R4tG is a manic and tense efficiency race to get more out of every action than your opponents. Beautiful!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have a stronger preference for icons in designs rather than text as reading slows play and makes it difficult to assess what opponents have in their tableau e.g Puerto Rico.

But boy does RftG suffer from icon overload. This unique language is a major hurdle in translating into a smooth first gaming experience and as such I was put off. But the title, imagery and icon for "drop ships" was a magnetic hint of what is one of the most strongly thematic card games playable in an hour.

Some time later I downloaded the AI version and armed with the rules I slowly learnt the language of the iconography and phase bonuses. Since then I've been addicted not only to the running scores that the program handles, but intrigued by the themes.Gamers are often attracted to play a game again to explore tactics and strategies. RftG is a rare instance of me wanting to explore the mythology, much like Tales of the Arabian Nights.

However, I won't be doing so in face to face situations as the racing tension and play speed is lessened as you determine the current scores of the tableaux. I don't mind in 2 player situations, but evaluating the varying worth of the 6 cost developments is too much.

RATING: 6
I did not enjoy my first game (4 players,) and after a couple more playes I'm still not interested in it.  My initial impression was that take San Juan, a clean, streamlined game and forcibly add a whole bunch of fiddleyness and complexities to all aspect of the game, bloating it to the point of disintegration, and you get this game. I don't feel that bad about it now, but nevertheless I avoid this game.

In my first game I felt the gameplay was more like hard labor than fun, but it is certainly not as bad as it's going to feel the first time. But the game does have a large aspect of a multi-player solitaire, everyone deeply absorbed in their own setup, largely oblivious to what everyone else is doing. Overall, this is an elborate game system of mostly short term optimization. It is not a complex as it might initially appear and gets easier  as you get more comfortable with it and get to experiment with different card combinations and strategies.

RATING: 8
Fun game with reasonable play time. Fairly luck weighted, with player choices are based largely on being familiar with all the cards in the deck. It's not complex exactly but actually has a fairly steep learning curve in the form of speilized iconography to remember, and needing to have a good encyclopedia knowledge of all the cards in the deck so you can make informed choices. But you are mostly choosing what to gamble on for your draw luck. Are the other players racing it or do you have time to work for a longer term strategy? It's a game where each player is doing their own thing as best they can, but have little influence on other player's games. An appropriately named game, it's not demolition derby for the galaxy.

RATING: 5.9
Race for the Galaxy (RFTG): Hi San Juan, hope you didn't mind me copying you.

San Juan (SJ): That's OK, you stole just enough that nobody could accuse you of printing the same game under a different name and theme.  I would have been pissed off but you took my game and changed it so that there was absolutely no player interaction, you don't feel the theme and you made the cards and rules far more complicated and fidgety than needed.

RFTG:  Do you really think so, I mean I really look up to you.  I am who I am because of you.

SJ: Look kid I really should be thanking you.  I was hot when I came out, got lots of plays but then fizzled out.  After playing you, folks will love to break me out again.

RFTG: But I will have expansions and new looks.

SJ: Come on kid, you can put a T-Shirt on a piece of crap but it's still a piece of crap!

RFTG: Come on, I'm not that bad, am I?

SJ: No your not that bad, but your not that good either!

RATING: 8
This game is quite overwhelming at first.  The iconography on the cards is quite baffling.  My first 10 plays I still was just hanging on and trying to figure out how the game worked.  It's so quick that you don't have time to look at what other people are doing or really evaluate how every card will affect your play area.  I have been enjoying the game more of late, but I think it's because I finally know the cards well enough to be able to quickly determine which cards I want and which I can throw away.

RATING: 8.5
Easily one of my favorite games.  Keeps getting more enjoyable the more I play.

RATING: 6.5
Not crazy about this, which surprised me.  I figured the space theme would hold my interest, but there are very limited decisions to make, and the iconography on the cards requires substantial memorization to play effectively.  I'd put it in the same category as 51st State, in that, although I like games with some meat on them, I don't want to have to learn a new language to play them.  
Might've just been my mood, though, so I'll give it another try some day.

RATING: 8
A role selection game derived from Puerto Rico with a more appealing theme, shorter play time, and faster setup/tear-down.  There are numerous expansions which add various improvements but also make the game more difficult to teach, especially the last in the first series of expansions.  I note this because I don't get to play this as often as I would like due to the steep learning curve.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have played this with actual live humans, and also on the excellent boardgamearena implementation.  This game is fantastic, and is far and away my most played game.  The card synergies are everywhere, but are often subtle, revealing themselves after many plays.  Initially this game felt to me a bit like multiplayer solitaire, as others have indicated.  After some extended time, though, seeing where your opponent seems to be going and hoping to draft off his/her actions becomes a fun sub game that really helps out your strategy.  The art is great and the theme is to me quite evocative.  Almost my entire experience with the game is the base game.  I think a military strategy is perhaps underpowered, but that's a minor quibble.  This is an exceptional game!

RATING: N/A
Shamefully, I haven't brought this to the table yet. Woof.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game took me a while to really get into.  I played this game for a little while and was really disappointed with it.  The game seemed too random and fickle and very luck based.  On top of that, everyone said I just had to "play more" to which I say that if a game can't show how good it is from the beginning it doesn't deserve the extra plays.

Then I played San Juan, and it was everything I was looking for that Race wasn't.  It was easier to understand, had more copies of the same cards so you had a better chance of getting the important cards for your strategy.  I thought it was the answer.

But eventually I got tired of San Juan.  It became predictable, and a little bit easy.  Then I went back to Race, and I couldn't put it down.  The game had suddenly turned into everything I wanted.  It was more interesting and had lots of avenues to winning.  On top of that, I liked the theme better and the cards were more interesting and complicated.

I had to play San Juan before I could learn to truly appreciate Race.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Rating more likely to drop to a 7 than remain at an 8.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
A game that greatly disappointed me. I liked San Juan and expected to like this as well.

The devaluing of the role selection mechanic with the timing of those roles, destroys the interest i had in San Juan. In it the timing and the ability to deny access to roles is the game. The only interaction RftG is predicting the other players roles so you can ride on their coattails. 
The use of a space theme doesn't outweigh the degraded version of game play.
Considering:
the need to memorize many cards with the benefit they provide. 
the obtuse iconography, 
the gameplay which removed the primary aspect I enjoyed, 
it sounds like I should stick to San Juan, and avoid this turkey in the future.
To those who say you need to play it 5 or 10 times before it clicks, and you see the beauty of the game. I say rubbish. The first few plays have to show something of interest to justify the time, otherwise it is not worth it.

RATING: 8
A good card game with lots of possibility. It look intimidating at the beginning with all the icons. But once you start playing, every thing falls into place. The rules are simple yet they could have hadded a couple of turn sequences in the rulebook for more understanding. The cards are of high quality and the graphics are superb. But on the down side, the icons are realy small and so is the text witch make it hard to read. Will come out of the closet often.

Très bon jeu de carte avec beaucoup de possibilités. Semble intimidant à première vue avec tous ces icônes. Mais lorsque vous commencez à jouer tout rentre dans l'ordre. Les règles sont claires et en même temps, l'éditeur aurait pu ajouter quelques exemples de tours de jeu pour faciliter la compréhension. Les cartes sont de très bonne qualité et les graphiques superbes. Par contre, les icônes et le texte sont vraiment petits ce qui rend les cartes dures à lire. Devrait sortir souvent de placard.

RATING: 9
A masterful development of the game mechanisms that first saw light of day in Puerto Rico and San Juan. Cards are used both for their primary purpose and for paying for other cards. There may not be much in the way of direct interaction, but the winner will usually be the player who has been the most mindful of the decisions of other players. Ignore your opponents at your peril.

RATING: 5
I think this game has cool mechanics, but I just don't find it very elegant. There are just so many rules for a relatively short game that I find to be highly dependent on the luck of the draw to really be worth it unless you're willing to really dive in and play a lot of games. It does offer some fun and interesting decisions, but I prefer games that are a bit more elegant with their rules. 
As for the actual gameplay, it is very hard to engage in any strategy due to the very random nature of the draw. Sometimes your cards just jive together perfectly, sometimes you just want blue planets and can't draw them. Played this a lot on BGA.

RATING: 10
This is one of my favorite under-one-hour games. It took me a few plays to get the hang of it and quite a few more to truly see the nuances of the strategy.

I greatly prefer this game with two players as you can fine tune your offense and defense strategies both by having only one player to focus on and because you can play two phase cards per round. Multi-player feels a bit more chaotic.

I have been playing this game several times a week since I learned it nine months ago.

RATING: 4.5
The prospect of yet another "deck"-builder game had me grinding my teeth. I hate Dominion with a passion and the similarities seemed rather obvious, but here I am, admitting that I did enjoy RFTG after all. Of course, like Dominion, it lacks the player interaction of so many games which came out recently (Dominion, Dungeon Lords) and is more or less a mulit-solitaire game. In a 2-player game, it is quite fun to see what your opponent is up to, but am really doubtful whether I will be able and willing to follow the respective progresses of four players at all. The artwork is great so is the flexibility of the deck.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of my current favorites. This game is the perfect balance between complexity and quickness. Its easy (once you've learned it) but there are still a lot of ways to win. I also appreciate that it has a quick setup time. 

This game is pretty hard to learn -- the iconography is definitely a hard sell for someone who isn't a gamer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I love card games.  I especially like card games full of all kinds of special power cards.  So I was predestined to like Race for the Galaxy though at first it really fell flat.

Each player has a hand full of role cards.  Players secretly choose one and all players reveal what they have chosen simultaneously.

The chosen roles are all performed in a specific order.  Explore, if chosen, is always first and Produce is always last.  They allow all players to perform the action that goes with that role, though the player who chose the role card gets a bonus.

There are two ways to get points.  Place cards into your tableau via Development and Settle actions or consume goods via Consume actions.  Of course every card you get into your tableau will likely give you some special power and the goal is to get the cards in your tableau to synergize so you can get the most points and then end the game.

The game immediately inspires a feeling of multi-player solitaire in that at first it feels like you can do just as well by ignoring what your opponents are doing as following their every move.  Repeated plays reveal this not to be entirely the case.  But you are still not going to get the crazy interactions that exist in games like Glory to Rome.  In some ways it feels like Race for the Galaxy has had all its rough edges smoothed over.  

The game is appropriately named.  It is very much a race.  Players rush for the endgame while socking away points.  Players draft, in the racing sense, off each others role card selections trying to get other players to do as much of their work as possible.  In fact lots of times it feels like the game goes by too fast and I wish I could linger a bit in the intergalactic empire I've created.  But thinking about the game as a race combined with the fun of finding card combos to make my economic engine run more smoothly than my opponents' has made the game a joy to play.  But more than that I love the theme.  Yes, I love the theme.

My first game of Race for the Galaxy was pretty boring.  But that night I literally dreamed about the cards I played and the worlds I had built.  I needed to play again.  While I had initially missed the game play elements that make this game a blast, the theme was calling to me.

Another anecdote for those who would malign Race for thematic reasons.  My brother-in-law was visiting.  He's a sports enthusiast and we had the basketball game on TV.  We were going to play some Race for the Galaxy and I didn't even invite him because I figured he'd want to watch the game.  Once he saw what we were doing he invited himself over.  As I was explaining the rules he suddenly stated that it seemed to him that the purpose of the game was to create your own identity.

And that's exactly what Race for the Galaxy does.  It allows the players to reinvent themselves and the galaxy with every game.

By the way, the expansions improve the game in my opinion.

(Maybe you're wondering why I haven't mentioned any issues with the icons.  That's because there were none for me.  An excellent reference card is included with the game.  After half a game of looking up the icons the system became transparent to me.  Whenever inexperienced players have a question about a card we just let them show it to the rest of us so we can explain it.  That way all the experienced players have the same information and a novice player is going to be playing more of a solitaire game anyway as they try and figure out the strategies.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
= 2014-03-03

Played one 2 player starter game at the end of a long game day. It was my first play and my opponent's 20th or so. I went in expecting to be slaughtered, but I didn't go in expecting to make soooooooo many mistakes. I just couldn't get it! It seemed so clear when it was being explained and I complemented the designer on the seemingly clean way he indicated the phases of the card powers, but clean or not, it wouldn't stick.

I must have mixed up the VP and Cost icons a half dozen times and those are two of the most basic icons in the game! I couldn't remember what the windfall planet symbol was to save me and I never really grasped what a "Consume" action was. This was a starter game with the first expansion and my starting cards were war oriented so I decided to work for that, but when I played my 6-cost "get a bunch of points for each planet with a red ring around it" card, it was pointed out that it was actually a "get a bunch of points for each RED planet card". Ugh. Every other turn I was being allowed to take back my move because I'd screwed something up.

Maybe it was getting late or my brain was exhausted after 10 hours of games. Or maybe the rumors about the inscrutable icons are true.

I generally dislike games with lots of unique card powers and subtle interactions between those cards. I was hoping to be pleasantly surprised after having this game recommended to me multiple times by many people, but I don't think it's right for me.

I have, however, committed to giving it one more shot before I declare it a mismatch.

As a game design, this one probably deserves high marks. On a more personal rating scale, I'd give it a 3.

RATING: 8.999
Aqui sim, um jogo (cardgame) que diferencia os homens dos guris. Alto teor de brain-burn, decisões difíceis, mas ao mesmo tempo simples.

Cada jogador gerencia o desenvolvimento de tecnologias e a colonização de planetas no universo por meio de ações como Exploração, Desenvolvimento, Assentamento, Consumo e Produção.

Não é dos jogos mais fáceis de se aprender, mas depois que se pega o jeito, é difícil recusar a uma partida, que pode ser diferente todas as vezes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Race for the Galaxy has executed the latest strangle hold on our gaming group.  Much like the introduction of Dominion, this game encompassed the entirety of our game nights for about a month.  Mechanically, it borrows from Puerto Rico in that each person's action selection allows every player to take that action (with a bonus to the chooser), but has the 'all you need is cards' feel of Dominion.  This element really can't be overstated, as the cards themselves serve all purposes from developments and settlements to be played to resources to pay costs and goods to be traded and consumed.  Really a stroke of genius in the elegance department.  Add in the fast play time and the fact that there is no real down time between players since everyone plays simultaneously, and this game is an ideal recipe for our game group.  I really can't recommend it highly enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Quick game to play, but pain in the butt to learn. Lots of rules and lots of icons to remember. Playing it face to face is annoying with the number of cards you have to track. Playing it online is much much simpler.

This game starts out as a good bit of a skill. Once you learn how to play and are playing against people who know how to play, it becomes a game of luck. Each player hoping to pull the better cards or the cards that fit the strategy they're using.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
San Juan is not the be-all, end-all of games, so why everyone is going gaga over a complete re-make of it (Race for the Galaxy) is kind of baffling. Since San Juan's strength IMO is its simplified & quick play, RFtG's increased complexity is not a plus. Add on the fact that just like in San Juan, there are highly unbalanced/overpowered cards that you can end up getting in combination with the support for them, and that will likely determine the winner against equal opponents. No clue how even one person could rate this a 10.

Every time I play this, it's the same difficulties in wrapping my head around the mechanics, card effects, and game flow. It is WORK, every time and everyone I've played with has agreed (noone is highly experienced in the game). I'm starting to question the balance in design, since it's too dependant on drawing synergistic cards to win - I'm thinking the military is too strong, and therefore New Sparta is an unbalanced starting world.
[b]edit - confirmed unbalanced starting card.[/b] 3 times I've started with New Sparta, each time I've won going away.  edit x2 - after many more plays, this is still true : New Sparta inordinately increases the win % chance.

I'm beginning to get sick of these games that have a metric buttload of text on the cards that require you to bring the game to a grinding halt just to read and understand what 5 cards you just drew do.

More plays later, this game is absurdly complicated, with sub-phases and card extensions to the standard (difficult) turn phase options. It feels like an accountant designed it, and requires a flowchart and legend to refer during play, and that's still not enough for most people to know how to play their cards - they require an expert to consult to know how to plan their hand.
[b]Not[/b] a good trait in a game.

I'll quote Richard Garfield on game design : 
"Gratuitous complexity is a rampant problem with trading card games. When I look at a card, I don't want to see a lot of attributes that matter only one game in 1000, or conditional effects that are minor and seldom come up."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3.9
Very disappointing.  I am generally considered fairly smart, but the rules of Race for the Galaxy are bewildering, and I consider the game extremely unfriendly to new players.  After three plays of RftG, I still felt like I was stumbling blindfolded through a maze, banging my nose on places I couldn't go, with no idea where the goal was, let alone how to get there. And I'm not talking about depth of play, or experienced players overwhelming inexperienced ones, like in chess; at least in chess you can play the game [i]correctly[/i] (even if badly) with 10 to 20 minutes of explanation, instead of being told yet another bloody exception every time you try to do something for the first hour of play. I might grow to like this game as much as I love San Juan (one of my favorite games, similar to this one in principle) after more plays, but I sure don't [i]yet[/i]. (After reading other players' comments...) Agreed completely, there's no reason to ever look at anything the other players have played, unless you don't trust them to play fair (or correctly), or to see whether they need 1 or 2 more cards to end the game. "Multiplayer solitaire" is pretty close to the mark, except for the bewildering and unjustifiable fact that someone else's action can force you to sell your production for a victory point right when you needed more cards, or something like that (still not sure what happened or why).

RATING: 8
I like this game as much as Roll for the Galaxy at this point, but for different reasons. Race just feels like you are putting together more combos for your engine. In Roll there seems to be more emphasis on manipulating the dice. I like both, but Race makes me feel smarter as I put together cards to build an amazing engine. The one detractor from Race compared to Roll is that the simultaneous action selection is a bit more choppy as you look at your hand and then at the phases, followed by the card flip over. This is a minor hit, but I find the in action selection to be more fun in Roll, while more rewarding in Race. Overall, they both get 8's and I love them both for their length and level of strategy. This is a great combo if you have an hour. You can play a game of Race and then a game of Roll getting your fix for both systems. I recommend both, unless you hate dice for Roll, or you are not looking for a challenging learning curve for Race. **Wife:8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game requires some time (a play or two or a thorough reading of the rulebook) in order to familiarize oneself with the system of icons used on the cards and with the mix of cards in the deck. The main system of interaction with the other players is through the role selection phase in which players simultaneously select one of seven roles to play that turn. Since each player has an opportunity to perform all roles selected by all players on a given turn, anticipating what roles will be selected by the other players will help one maximize efficiency. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game does have a steep learning curve, but it is the best card-driven game I've played.

If you have a group of heavy gamers that are willing to play this half a dozen times just to get the hang of it (plus half a dozen to start to figure out the strategies involved), by all means try this one. Everyone that I've played with loved it.

RATING: 8.5
