=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
At first sight, there is no interaction between players. After a couple of games you realise that you should always see what the others players are going to do. You define two extreme strategies: militaristic one and the economic one. The first one is fast, the second one gives more points. The first one works if you have 12 military planets. The second one takes more time to be implemented. 
Then you can imagine all strategies possible in between these two strategies. Most of the time you will do one intermediate strategy because the others players are influencing the game in one or the other and you must adapt to their strategy.

A great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game wins the award for most visually intimidating. However, once you know the basics of how to play, the cards are fantastic, because they contain so much information. On first glance it looks like you have to learn a new hieroglyphic language in order to play.

Do not be intimated this is a fantastically rich, space empire building game, that takes no more time than most filler games to play. There is no direct conflict in this game, but you will feel like there is, when your opponent triggers the end of the game just before you complete your carefully ordered plan for galactic supremacy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I read that the icons were confusing. And they were. But slowly, I've learned from the rulebook and the forums. And now I see the masterpiece that is this game.

The game only has cards and victory chips. That's it. So for that it's great because there's not too many things to fidget around with.

Secondly, everything is in card form which makes the game replay value sky rocket.

Third, the game plays in a way where downtime is minimal and is fast.

Finally, player screwage doesn't really happen. An action benefits all players, just some benefit more than others.

You get a great-looking, highly strategic, highly replayable game. I undoubtedly recommend it. It only took two plays for me to get the game and now I can't wait to play it again.

*I've been playing it a lot and every game is different. This might be my #1 right now.*
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I think RftG could be a great game, but it has a really difficult learning curve. I have played 4 or 5 games of it now and I still find myself getting confused about what everything does. It makes it very difficult to form a strategy. It's a game with a huge number of options at every turn, quickly leading to analysis paralysis. I think I will enjoy it much more as I become more familiar with it, but I still feel lost playing it.

Part of the problem is the iconography. Although it is well considered, the idioms are not intuitive and many of the icons are similar enough that remembering the differences becomes difficult. It also greatly increases the learning curve because you not only have to learn the mechanics and the strategy but also the meanings of all the icons. Instead of acting as a memory aid, they become a foreign language that must be learned before the game proper can be learned. I find myself wishing the cards had more explanatory text or else a reference book that detailed each card for when the iconography becomes ambiguous.

I also find I have trouble establishing a strategy. This may be because I'm still learning it, but it may also be because there are so many choices, or it could be because the starting hand and planet have a considerable effect, or because so much depends on what cards you draw. I can't tell exactly which factor makes it difficult, but it's currently quite frustrating.

I can't give this a solid review just yet, other than to say that this probably won't go over well for new board and card game players. Consider this a game for experienced and patient players only.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I only started playing this game about a month ago, but I can tell that it is going to have interesting strategic depth for a long time.  The great thing about RftG is that each planet and development adds a new strategy and something eles different to think about.  Each phase does something drastically different for each player, and a player must consider their own strategy as well as the strategy of their opponent.  I am really good at having a strategy and putting it into play, but I am less effective and examining my opponent's strategy and conceiving a strategy that will make his plans more difficult. This game has so many layers of how a player can and should act, which provides a remarkable amount of depth to a game that is basically a bunch of cards in a box.  This game is worth purchasing because it can be played for a long time.
*********
Now I've been playing Race for a while and it is still freaking awesome.  The expansions add a lot, my favorite thing they add is the extra start worlds.  The only aspect of the base game I started to find boring after 100 plays were that I was still using the same old start worlds.

The depth and complexity of building each tableau which turns out so different from the one before it, is mind boggling.  I am so glad that I learned Race for the Galaxy!

RATING: 8
I've really liked this game a lot, but so far have found most people I've played it with struggling to see what I see.  I think that the iconography is brilliant and elegantly implemented, allowing to easily understand what everything does, but again, other people I've introduced it do have had big problems understanding how all the cards work together.

All that being said, I really enjoy the process of trying to create a machine that works for you and figuring out a path to victory that makes sense based on what you start with, etc.  I'm a huge fan of the victory point generating combos, and often find myself leaning towards them, but have had an occasional military strategy net success as well.

The more I play this game, the more I see differences between those that have played it a lot and those who are just getting comfortable with it.  I think the people that are just getting started with the game get distracted with trying to do too much, or going from whatever interesting card they have to the next, rather then focusing on one particular method of getting victory points.  For example, having great military, but still putting effort into trading, etc rather then conquering to end the game.

RATING: 6
This is only based on one play,so it definitely has room to move once I get a grip on the icon system and how everything fits together. It definitely is a San Juan-game with more going on, the question is whether that makes it a better game or not.  On my first play, I had enough trouble figuring out what I was doing, let alone trying to anticipate my opponent's play.  If the game is manageable to the point where watching over other's play becomes viable, then it will probably have moved up some in my rankings by that point.

I've played a couple more times and I'm not sure my rating will change after all.  My problem is that this is a game that is fun if you play it regularly enough so that the icon curve is non-existent.  Unfortunately, I don't get to play games right now enough for that to be true.  With more frequent sessions - I could see wanting to play this more and hence a higher rating.  Definitely play it though if you have the chance.

(When rating games I focus on the "how likely I am to play this game again" part of the BGG description rating, as opposed to the "quality" part of the rating.)

RATING: 6
TRftG is very similar to San Juan, but it is quite a bit more complex (actually has the distinction of selling goods for money or for victory points as in Puerto Rico) and has asymmetrical starting conditions. After a few games vs. AI on the PC, it seems to be very dependent on your card draws, and it is about what the best is to make of your draw.

This game is really multiplayer solitaire. If you have quite some experience and play it with only two or three players, you might guess what actions your opponents take and benefit from these. Compared to other games (even others marked as "multiplayer solitaire") this is still on the very low side of interaction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have now played a second game. Although it is somewhat interesting, the game does not reach the higher levels some geeks are giving it. I found that much (too much?) depends on your starting strategy, which in turn depends entirely on... luck. If you get the right cards from the start to build a winning strategy - and one which you'll be able to advance, then you,re set. If you get a fuzzy mish mash of unrelated cards, your level of strategy and skills will count for shit.I have lowered my rating from 7 to 6.

RATING: 6
Clever and engaging efficiency game. The theme is captured better than I expected. Lots of tough choices. Doesn't overstay its welcome and plays briskly once you have a couple games under your belt. Has a "let's play again" quality. 

On the other hand, it's not especially interractive. Luck of the draw is pretty strong for such an analytical design. And ultimately, each game is forgettable. RftG doesn't immerse or generate a memorable narrative.

Have someone tutor you through a couples games face to face. Then install the AI version and play it a few more times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Quite easily one of the most luck driven pieces of tripe ever made.  You can win 10 games in a row and lose 10 games in a row due to nothing but complete luck of the draw.  Lehmann is a hack, POS designer with no intelligence of what makes a game playable.  Yahtzee has more skill than this utter shitstain of a game.  This septic dump of a game is easily the worst I've ever played. Honestly if I could give this a zero or lower I would.  This game is essentially all luck once you know the cards and combos.  With evenly skilled players the game plays itself by the exceedingly random draw it gives.  Adding more and more expansions only makes that worse.

update: The more I play this game the more I know it needs a mulligan rule.  I've had games where you starting hand is so bad you have lost before you can fix that with random draws.  I've started with multiple 6 cost developments in my hand or all military worlds with no military to play them or no production or windfall worlds for several turns.

The only good thing about this game is that it can be quick but if a player takes time to count out each card it turns into a miserable waiting game with little to no fun to be had.  What could be a great game boils down to card draw luck factor and whomever draws better wins.  Eliminating any level of skill a player may have.

All in all it's inherently flawed as is and needs many fixes as there is no way to mitigate bad card draw.  San Juan isn't much better but at least it limits the exceedingly crazy draw by the costs and same starting cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
A fairly simple card game with a very limited level of player interaction (the only interaction is the rather subtle phase selection mechanic at the beginning). Players build up a series of worlds and developments which score them victory points, the highest victory points winning.

The mechanics, game play, and feel of the game are those of San Juan and Puerto Rico. I think I prefer this to Puerto Rico but am undecided when compared to San Juan (which I also see as superior to Puetro Rico). All three games are so close that only one of them is really needed but I've not invested enough time or thought to know which offers the greatest depth. This is slightly tormenting me as I know one of these games should be in my games cupboard but that all three of them are pointless repetition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.04
Took me a while to understand both the rules and strategies of the this game, which if i had rated it then, it would have been a mistake.
Having over 100 matches on boardgamearena i have to say its grown on me.  There is lots of replayability, its easy to setup and quick to play. Considering the expansions now....

The main downside to this game, is the time it takes to teach it to others due to the iconography.

Would suggest that gathering storm is the only expansion worth getting if you want solo play.

RATING: 9
fun game with lots of variety.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is one of our most played games ever, with great long-term survival.  It's years old and still hits the table regularly.

It's short. There's almost no player downtime.  There isn't a lot of player interaction, but enough to keep it interesting.  You have fun even when you're losing, because you can still do things.  There's no elimination.

We play usually with expansion cards but no expansion special rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Most of my experience with RftG has been as a 2-player game (the "advanced" version where both players select 2 phases each turn) - but even in just this form it is one of the deepest and most replayable card games in existence. And, while it gets better with expansions, the above comment applies to just the base game on its own. (Compare with Dominion, the only pure card game I rate higher than RftG - both are improved with expansions, but Dominion needs several to reach the true heights of greatness, while RftG is there already with just the base.)

The fact that it plays in just 20-30 minutes is also great, as you can roll off 3 or 4 games in a row. I'm terrible at this game (my winning record in 2-player games with my wife is probably less than 10%), but I still love playing it - there's so much to explore; you learn more every time you play as you get more familiar with the cards, but it plays totally differently each time based on the order the cards come out in. An absolute classic, RftG fully deserves its place in the BGG top 20 (it has fallen out since I first wrote this, as was inevitable, but it still deserves to be there), and indeed I would even say it's generally underrated around here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Traded for El Capitan
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
For me, race has the just the right mix of luck and strategy and incorporates all of the best aspects of Puerto Rico - role selection, economic development, etc. The setup time is drastically shorter than PR...it's less fiddly since it's a card game, primarily. The icons on the cards are at first gibberish, but after a couple of games, they become one the games greatest assets. You don't have to memorize all of the card's abilities, nor do you have to read small text on each card, each turn in order to determine what the card does. A quick scan and you know whether or not you get a bonus in a particular phase of the game...genius design. The only knock against it is the learning curve. While similar to the learning curve for PR, I find race slightly easier to teach since you don't have funny rules about the trading house and shipping....instead you have other funny rules. But, for some reason, people seem to grasp this one easier. Quicker setup and cleanup and easier to teach nudge this to 9. Superb game!

UPDATE: I've downgraded this to an 8, but only due to comparison against other games in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is perfection.   Plays fast,  tons of interesting decisions every turn,  and just FUN.  And. ...it is one of the few games my wife will ask to play several times in a row!   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
(7/2/08) - Received this today as part of a trade for my 3 Power Grid expansions. I was just too impatient to wait for the reprint I guess!

(7/30/08) - Played this for the first time today. While I'd love to give it a knee-jerk 8-9, which is how I would rate it at this point, I know that RftG is the kind of game that needs multiple plays before its true colors show. In this case I think more plays will mean an even higher rating.

(12/04/2008) - I meant to rate this back in October when I got a bunch of plays with it. Several games has shown that this is an excellent game. I have only played 2-player matches so far, but have enjoyed each one immensely. Once you learn the basics of the game, go right to the Advanced 2-Player Game, it's great! I look forward to playing with 3 or 4 players and seeing how much things change.

RATING: 9
Played far too many times on BGA.  

It's difficult to put my finger just yet on how I manage to be bulldozed by the good players and manage to do the same to inexperienced players myself.  The game is all about tempo, when to draw the game to an end and also knowing what your opponent is trying to achieve so you can piggyback on their actions.

I see no issue with the iconography; certainly when it comes to the base game.  It's elegantly designed and should come easy to players within the first couple of games or so.

A truly great game - am sure that will be able to convince the wife to give it a try.  Just not sure if she'll be willing to put in the initial hard graft to learn it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
Race for the Galaxy finds it's niche and fits there perfectly. The card game CCG players will love and not have to spend a fortune on. It does have a bit of a learning curve, and isn't entirely intuitive. The icons can be confusing for new players, but function well with familiarity. The game has good pacing with virtually zero downtime; though there is virtually zero player interaction as well. It's entirely about efficiency and how well you manage the cards that are dealt to you. While this game encourages strategy, if you don't draw cards with synergy, you will likely lose to someone who does- regardless of strategy. The game plays so quickly, though, it's easy to play a series where that luck can be mitigated.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

Part of the problem may have been that I was playing with experienced players who played quicker than I was comfortable with, along with a rather quick rules explanation.  Suffice it to say I felt rushed.

The iconography sometimes works, sometimes feels overdone, and a lot of the time more use of text would have been better.

The games I played felt rather random and were mostly multi-player solitaire.

I purchased the game before I played it, and thus it ranks at the top of my list of purchases I regret.  My own copy has been punched but not actually played.  I do plan on trying it again, but not sure I will given that there are other games I would rather play/try.

RATING: 6
Multiplayer solo game. Yes, there are other players, but you dont need to mind about them. As some people has pointed out, you can get some advantage from predicting other people actions and act in consequence (ala Puerto Rico), but other than that, there is no interaction.

Too random for the first plays, until you get knowledge of the cards, options and strategies.

I will look for the expansions that adds more interaction (which lack of is my only niggling complaint), as overall I think the game is elegant and well designed, with a nice theme and a short duration that helps to get it played.

RATING: 8
bgg.con '07
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
----------

I learned RftG after I played Glory to Rome.  I honestly expected to like GtR better, but I actually prefer RftG because of the production/consumption mechanic.  Trying to build a lean, mean P/C machine while finding synergies to multiply your VPs is incredibly addictive.  The military strategy, on the other hand, isn't nearly as much fun to me because I feel like I'm just mining the deck for the +military and military-focused 6 devs.  

love all of the variety in this game.  I think it's deeper than Glory to Rome, but it definitely has more of a solitaire feel -- which I don't mind.  

I think GtR has more variety out of the box, but RtfG's 3 expansions more than compensate.  However, I do feel that adding all three expansions into the game increases the luck of the draw in the game; adding the super-search role (Brink of War) is a nice idea, but the issue still exists.

I feel like Base + Gathering Storm + RvI is the sweet spot.

This is my #5 game.

----------
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So far so good. Really enjoyed my plays of this. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
All of my plays, with one exception, have been solitaire using the Robot A.I. from The Gathering Storm. These comments are specifically in regard to the solitaire game.

[b]What I Like[/b]
:d10-1: The game plays fast. I can think my way through a game and still get done in under a half hour.
:d10-2: It's a challenge to beat the Robot. I've only played on easy difficulty. After improving my game play I am now able to beat the Robot approximately 50% of the time. I'll soon start increasing the difficulty.
:d10-3: Each start world has different abilities. For the player, this means cards in your hand will vary in value depending on the game and will affect your strategy. 
:d10-4: The Robot has a different play style for each start world. These unique play styles will affect the player's strategies as you will want to avoid selecting actions that complement the Robot's strengths while seeking actions that minimize its abilities while positively affecting your own.
:d10-5: The huge number of different cards will ensure that the options presented to the player are different each game. 
:d10-6: Maybe not a big deal for some, but I like the theme. While others find it too generic, I feel it is suitable.
:d10-7: Once learned, the game play is logical and actually fairly simple.
:d10-8: I think the iconography used is a great way to clearly communicate card abilities without cluttering up the cards with text that could be misinterpreted. 
:d10-9: Small boxes don't take up much space and are easy to transport.

[b]What some people may not like[/b]
:d6-1: This will vary from player to player, but the learning curve will be steep or hard to understand for some. The different phases of game play, bonuses for selecting actions, the subtleties of correctly following the game play sequence, and the wide variety of planet/improvement abilities may combine to make this a tough not to crack for some players.
:d6-2: The iconography may increase the learning curve for those who prefer text.
:d6-3: The theme may appear too generic or pasted on for some people.

[b]Summary[/b]
I think this is a great solitaire game. It plays quick, doesn't take a lot of space when playing or when on the shelf. Each game plays out as a unique experience due to the variables in card draw. The A.I. Robot can be tough to beat, even on the easiest difficulty, which is as a solitaire game should be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
 This isn't really a game you can bring out for casual gaming friends, and the learning curve is pretty steep.

Hardcore gamers will love this. Lots of strategy, easy setup and cleanup, etc.

Another minor qualm I have is that there are a million different symbols on cards, and they take a while to learn. In a couple instances, the same symbol means something different in different phases, which is a personal pet peeve (and only adds to the learning curve).

I realized a few minutes into looking through it that it was too much. Six months later, with a good amount of gaming experience in the interim, I opened the box again...and by then I was ready. I would strongly recommend anyone interested in giving this a try--but put off by the perceived complexity of it--to give San Juan a try. Learn that one, and then Race will seem like just another step forward.

This approach seems to have worked.

RATING: 7
After all the hype not convinced yet about this. The rating is only after two-player game but there are definitely a few problems with this game. I guess the game is supposed to be compared to San Juan so let's do it so:
 
What I love about San Juan is that even though it is quite deep and strategic game where it's essential to know the cards to do well - it's relatively easy to pick it up and start playing by new players. Not so with RftG. Even for a seasoned gamers and people who have played a lot of SJ it takes time to understand all the different symbols and their meaning on the cards. The symbols are well designed and when understood work quite well but somehow it seems there are too many variables going on. The game could have easily been simplified. 
 
The game plays quickly even with the complexities but with different resources, different types of planets (rebels, aliens, etc) and different action types there seems to be too many parallel things going on. There seems to be many different strategies involved but it might prove too difficult to pursue any of them if the cards don't come up as wanted. It also seems that the game will become even ore complex since some things were left to the upcoming expansion.
 
It's certainly a game for gamers and SJ veterans who want more of the same but it certainly seems to be lacking on the design side.

RATING: 9
Very enjoyable innovation on resource gathering/production type-games.  No setup time required and simple idea--yet somehow it ssems that the end result is greater than the sum total if its individual parts.  Those elements that may seem borrowed or inspired by other games are here because they provide good strategy foundations.  Few points for artwork, and it seems that the card designs are both spartan and somehow busy at the same time (this will no doubt improve in future editions, which I have to believe will arrive one day), but that does not make it any less fun to play.  Score has increeased with future replays--I think the rules were technically well-written, but were so precise that we missed several key points (also due in part, no doubt, to the fact that my friends all have ADD and will not read directions and that I, also, am mostly mentally challenged!).  For example, we did not understand that it was unnecessary to collect VP chips for constructed development/planet cards--somewhat major part of the game. The cards seem to be wearing out quickly due to the black-colored card  backs--particularly with the role cards which are handled constantly, and some are used more frequently meaning that they may reveal themselves before they are turned over.  Minor semantic quibbles, though, for an inventive, fun, quick, and addictive game.  This one is a classic.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Chris (?) posted a terrific tutorial which amounts to:
* Give each player a premade starting hand.
* Tell the players you're playing as if you're in the middle of the game.
* Have all the players place their starting hand on the table and have a hand of NO cards.
* Discuss the anatomy of each card EXCEPT for icons during the phases.
* Have each player select the LAST phase and play each phase from last to first.
* Explain the icons ONLY for those cards which do something during the phase.
* When you finish the tutorial, you can continue the game, or start over with the premade hands.

Why:
* Understanding Race's icon grammar is difficult, especially when most games actually don't have icon grammar. This tutorial gradually introduces icons. Also, players aren't overwhelmed by the icons in their hands because they have no cards in their hands until halfway through the tutorial.
* The first phases taught in this tutorial (production, consumption, trade) have the least decision making within the phase.
* The tutorial uses the same premade hands you can play a standard game with. By the end of the tutorial, the players will at least be familiar with their premade hand.

***

Race can be easily played as a "two-player game played by one player". It's one of the few games where the base game does a *very* good job standalone.

I haven't played TI, but I'd say Race is a hand management game. The toughest decisions are deciding what cards to keep, and which to throw away (you discard cards to "pay" to put other cards into play). The game is also a classic opportunity cost game -- you must play your turns more efficiently than your opponent. 

***

The first time I played Race, I was astounded that the Military didn't have any effect on the other players. Then, I assumed, the Military was more like the Klingons. :laugh:

Anyway, it's "interaction" by BGG standards. It's not Ameritrash interaction -- nothing blows up, and all that. 

It *is* interaction in that you have to analyze not only everyone's face-up tableau, but how many cards they hold in their hands. Race isn't solitaire, in that I've yet to play a solitaire game in which I deduce my opponent's move and plan accordingly. If you play the game MSP, you will lose.

Here's a tip: If you own the game and are looking for a solitaire game, play both sides of a two-player! The game's easy to setup, and doesn't take much space. I play during the load screens of my computer game on my crappy Compaq laptop.

As a former CCG'er, I enjoy Race. I like the synergy, and min/max'ing when you play off other player's actions. But if I want to blow something up... Well, Nuclear War is still in the closet!

***

Coming late to the thread, but this is one great review. I play the game almost several times a day "solitaire" (by playing both sides of a two-player game) and enjoy it very much. Race, by far, goes on my "The Game I Most Regret Listening the BGG Comments on Before I Played It" because, as a former CCG'er, I picked up on the mechanics of the game in only one game. Compared to Magic's banding mechanic, this stuff's a cakewalk. I'll add that the icons on this game make the game *easier* to play than with text. Fans of Race use the "leeching" strategy to deduce the plays their opponents will make, and it's easier to read icons on an upside down (or sideways!) card than text.

*****

Here ya go: 

General strategy: Draw as many cards as you can. Not only will this allow you to pay for your cards, but will open options. You may get to the point where you have two very viable options and can't decide. Flip a coin.

Blue: Consumer engine. Play as many cheap blue planets as you can. Play the developments which convert blue goods to victory points. Select the Consume 2x phase. 

Brown: Mining engine. Look for the brown developments which combo with the brown planets. You won't have the runaway consumer engine like blue has, but, IIRC, you will be able to draw cards faster than your opponent. 

Military: Draw cards. You want the military goal cards. You will also want to keep a military planet to play onto your tableau when your opponent calls Settle. While military is easiest to understand, it's not easy to win.

Goals: Well.. yeah. :laugh:

c) Study your opponents tableaus and hand sizes, and deduce which phases they'll select. If possible, manage your hand so you can put into a play a card during another player's phase.

This is *not* your typical Euro strategy game. It's a tactical hand management game, with (and don't tell anyone on BGG this) a good dose of CCG strategy (draw more cards than your opponents, and memorize which cards are in the set). Despite this game being derived from a Eurogame, its plethora of cards and icons make me think of it as Ameritrash as any CCG.

***

Haven't playe SJ, but have played CCG's:

* Theme: It's not the tired old fantasy game, but it's not the boring trading/farming/sheep stuff, either.

* Combos: aka. Engines, synergy is a big attraction for this CCG'er. Despite the variety of cards, you only have to remember how each color's engine works (and it's typically Consumer Blue vs. Miner Brown). 

* Deduction: Guess which phase your opponent(s) will play. Again, something that isn't in most CCG's. Amusingly, if your opponent(s) have *no* idea how to play this game, they'll easily thwart your attempts to out-think them.

* Tactics: None of this non-intuitive long-term planning bonus points crapola. 

*****

You make your own luck.

One of the basic strategies that appears in card games is to draw as many cards as possible. This is obvious in Dominion and Magic, but not as much for Race and Cosmic Encounter. Yes, you don't know what card you're going to draw. But the more cards you draw, not only will you increase the chances of getting a card you can use, but you will have other cards to pay the cost.

Notice that I used the words "cards you can use", which does NOT mean "cards you want". If your strategy depends on getting a certain card, or a narrow range of cards, you will lose the game. A basic Race strategy is to have a *flexible* hand and tableau that works well with a wider range of possible cards drawn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

+ Balances adaptability with tough, strategic decision-making.

+ Fast and compelling, making it likely to be played multiple times in a row.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A very satisfying game with enormous strategic variability. There are tons of interesting ways to combine card abilities and mechanisms, each of which can lead to surprisingly successful strategies. I appreciate the simultaneous/shared execution of the actions - it creates a sense of balance and agency, since no one player gains any huge advantage by taking an action alone. I also like the precision with which players build their tableau MUCH more that this mechanism's cousin (antithesis? Evil twin?) - deck-building. This is essentially deck-building in reverse - rather than selecting specific cards and casting them into an entropic pile, players draw from a random pile and use the cards they have to create something very specific and fine-tuned. Sure, card drawing is random, but there are enough draw-adding mechanisms to greatly mitigate this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Fantastic. Wonderful.

The theme really permeates this game, but doesn't detract from the strategy and essential nature. The luck-elements are enough to make each game different, but can be mitigated enough to mean that skill and thinking are vital. The artwork and symbols lead to a very attractive game, and the play is quick and easy. Indeed, my play-count is undoubtedly well off because we play this so often, both between games and in several-game runs, it almost always is just taken as read.

The similarities to Puerto Rico are there, but the game plays differently. I can't wait for the next expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Visual Appeal: (5)
Some of the card art is just good, but most of it is great! I happen to think the symbol system of organizing information is a very good one. With a little invested time, they become second nature and they don't clutter the cards. The discard and draw piles can get a bit messy with many expansions added, but the game generally looks nice and compact on the table with no board and minimal chips.

Components: (4)
The cards are a very durable linen finish that feels good enough that I chanced not sleeving them. Since I usually play with all the expansions I was afraid of making the decks even more of a mess to shuffle every game. The VP chips are a decent card stock and a reasonable size. I like the personalized player phase cards. They make it easy to see what phases are happening and you can just turn them face-down when the phase is over to eliminate distractions.

Theme: (4)
This game has a theme of space exploration, research, and military struggle. I feel like all of the themes are represented well by the mechanics. Although it is highly thematic, I don't like the takeover rules from Rebel vs. Imperium. I feel like it slows the game down and diminishes the reason why it's a "RACE for the Galaxy." The variety of card synergies in the game populate the RftG universe with diverse worlds to explore.

Learning: (2)
I label this a 2 for the benefit of those to whom I've taught the game. To be fair, it took me a while to become comfortable with the symbols and the cards too, but most players just find this overall a difficult game to learn. There are player aids to help new players but the synergies take experience to spot. The number 2 complaint that I hear is that they try to follow a certain strategy but the blasted cards won't come up! It is hard to teach players how to just go with the flow when they want to think of a more long term strategy right out of the gate.
Gameplay: (3) 
I like the challenge of predicting your opponent's phase so that you can benefit from it each turn as well as your own phase. There is little direct player interaction without the take-over mechanism in place. I remove it by choice because I don't like it, but if you choose to use it, you can actually steal an opponent's hard earned planets! 

Overall Fun: (5)
I have fun with this game and I don't care what anyone else thinks. It is a fun medium-heavy card game with a good implementation of phase selection and hand management. Lately I've been playing most of my games on the Keldon AI servers. I enjoy that the program has ongoing support and that I can play against a very competent AI opponent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I guess I'd put this game in the category of games I'm willing to play but will never purchase myself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Plusieurs choses frappent lors des premières parties de Race for the Galaxy : le thème SF, malheureusement sous-exploité par la plupart des éditeurs ludiques, la qualité des illustrations, le nombre d'icônes.

Les premiers points permettent largement d'aller au devant de la première difficultés du jeu, découlant du dernier point : les premières parties sont pour le moins laborieuses et confuses. Il ne faut surtout pas hésiter à aller au delà : les parties sont rapides et dès la troisième ou quatrième, vous pourrez ranger les aides de jeu au fond de la boite.

En ce qui concerne le jeu lui même, on retrouve tout le feeling et la richesse d'un JCC. Le système de pioche et de défausse de cartes s'apparente au tirage de boosters et à la construction de son Deck tout au long de la partie. Du coup, on se retrouve avec les meilleurs éléments du JCC (la construction du deck), sans les défauts (le côté automatique de la phase de jeu, l'aspect collectionnite et mercantile). C'est, il me semble, le tout premier jeu à réussir ce tour de force, et ça donne un jeu nerveux, riche, original et addictif.

Il n'y a pas (encore ?) d'interaction directe dans RftG. Cela semble rédhibitoire pour certains, qui semblent associer automatiquement la SF au grands combats spatiaux ou aux conquêtes pour le contrôle de la planète voisine. Pour moi, ce genre de raccourcis dessert la SF plus qu'autre chose, et c'est un excellent point que de voir développer des thèmes plus subtils dans ces mondes futuristes. De plus, on n'est finalement pas trompé sur la marchandise : comme son nom l'indique, RftG est un jeu de course, et l'objectif est bien de faire plus de points, plus vite que les autres. L'interaction se trouve donc finalement plus dans les phénomènes « d'aspiration » (on profite des actions des adversaires pour avancer plus vite) que de blocage. Et c'est peut être aussi ce qui fait tout le sel et l'équilibre de cet excellent jeu.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
In Race for the Galaxy players are racing to achieve the preeminent civilization by settling planets and gaining technological developments.  The winner is decided when one player has at least 12 developments and planets in play or a set number of victory point chips have been exhausted; the player with the most victory points wins.  Each turn players secretly select which action they are going to perform, then simultaneously reveal their selection.  Each action selected will grant an action for all players during that phase, with an additional bonus to the player who chose the action, so players must carefully consider not only which bonus they want on their turn but what actions the other players will choose.  The actions vary from drawing cards, developing a technology, settle a planet, trade goods, consume goods, and produce goods.  Actions are activated in the same order each turn (drawing first on through production) regardless of who played what; in this fashion there is no "first player".  The cards in Race for the Galaxy function as either a planet or development, a good produced on a planet, or currency; this will force players to consider their options each turn based on the cards in hand, deciding which will be used to pay for the others, and this is not always an easy choice.

Each planet and development are worth victory points at the end of the game, but some planets allow you to consume goods for victory points.  Other planets allow you to consume goods for more cards.  Some planets can only be conquered with military might, others can simply be settled by paying its cost in cards.  Some worlds produce goods, some produce goods and cards, others just produce cards.  Both worlds and developments have special powers that activate only during certain actions, so players must carefully choose how to use their planets and developments in order to obtain more victory points than the other players.

With the variety of planet and development powers and the dynamics of the action choices made each turn, Race for the Galaxy tests a player's ability to build a strategy on-the-fly, and then adapt and refine that strategy as the game progresses.  Players must always be aware of how their action choice will impact their opponents and work to maximize their own gain.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really enjoy this game -- I like trying to plan my moves based on what I think other people might be doing.  It's like simultaneous PR -- but instead of trying to figure out 4 moves ahead, all I need is one move ahead -- but with so much randomness based on what people have in their hand, I'm less likely to guess right.

Which I like.

Fun, quick game.

One caveat -- this is the anti-gateway game.  Do not try teaching this to newbies -- they will be lost forever.

RATING: 10

And we're STILL noticing little details on the card art. Best game of 21st Century. If learning the icons is a struggle for you, it may be worth weighing that against the likelihood of getting hundreds of plays out of the game.

RATING: 5
A more advanced version of San Juan with a populist space theme. There doesn't seem to be as much player interaction with the multiple character role cards available to each player. After a few games I'm not really interested in exploring this any further. There's multiple paths to victory - as long as they involve either trading or picking up the right military worlds. At the end of the day though (if you strip out the "wow cool, space theme"), all you've got is an abstract card game with non-confrontational player interaction. How... "nice". Look, I'm glad so many people are enjoying this - I recognise it's a decent game - I'm just not very interested in it myself. I must say that I do find it somewhat relaxing because it just completely sucks the competitive urge out of me. I can sit back and just not give a damn - I'm just not that into it. Now, if I don't care - is that the best way to spend my precious gaming time? Not the best challenge for the other gamers at the table either. Plus, this game will ruin your eyesight.

RATING: 7

Players try to dominate the galaxy picking different actions, such as explore, develop, settle, consume and produce.  All players will perform the action you select, so you will need to choose the one that is comparative better for you, or worse for your rivals, thinking in what they would pick.  There are several ways to win, and every game is different, depending of your initial setup and hand.

RATING: 9.5
Plays track games against human opponents and do not include games against Keldon's AI. 

Fast, strategic, and fun. Has a fairly steep learning curve. The iconography isn't that bad, but knowing what you should be doing strategically takes a while to figure out. 

There is a fair amount of randomness, and a large part of the game is doing the best you can with what's available. It's important to set up a card economy, and find ways to leach off of the phases other players choose. 

For a game that takes me 5-15 minutes to play, this game offers a great deal of strategy and variability. Race for the Galaxy packs more decisions into a 10 minute game than most games that last an hour. 

The first expansion arc is fun, but has two main problems.

1: It makes the deck too streaky, and adds a cludge factor to help deal with the problem that disrupts the smooth flow of play.

2: There is significant power creep, and some cards from the base game are overshadowed by better cards.

The second expansion arc does a better job of preserving the value of the base game cards and manages to improve strategic diversity without adding so many cards that the deck becomes too streaky. The main issue with it is that the Orb is not a good addition, since it drastically slows down the game and interupts the smooth flow of play. Fortunately, you can just ignore the orb and add the cards in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
San Juan and Race for the Galaxy are very similar games, mechanically. Each round, each player selects one role (producer, trader, etc.) and then all players perform the actions associated with that role; the player who chose the role receives an extra benefit. In Race for the Galaxy, the role selection is done simultaneously while in San Juan it is done in turn order. In both games, cards have multiple uses: they are played to a tableau to build plantations or settlements or developments; they are used to pay for the buildings being built; they are used to produce goods on plantations/settlements which are later traded in to get still more cards back into your hand. The object of both games is to build out 12 cards in your tableau and have the highest combined score resulting from those 12 cards. Both games involve hand management, choosing which cards to hold onto for building later and which cards to spend for building now. Essentially, they are the same game with different themes. San Juan, however, is much easier - it has a lower barrier to entry (the cards have explanatory text in English, whereas Race has a system of icons/hieroglyphics), but less variety, less depth/fewer strategies. San Juan is not a gateway game, it's got too many rules to be that, but it is a good gateway into Race. Race is the "step up" from San Juan. But, if you're not likely to play often, or with the same people, I would advise going for San Juan over Race - the barrier to entry for the latter can be enough that you may never get to play.

I actually find I connect more with San Juan, Race can be a bit overwhelming. I find, right or wrong, that I tend to enjoy a game a bit more if I have a good enough understanding to compete well and win frequently. I can do that in San Juan - I've never won a game of Race. The trouble with San Juan is that the strategies, once learned, become rote. It's still enjoyable to manage your hand and make the decisions on which cards to keep and which to spend, but at a certain level, these really aren't "decisions" any more - if you're playing a certain strategy then certain "decisions" become dictated/automatic. There's more going on in Race, more ways to win, so this sense of putting the game into "cruise control" doesn't happen as it does in San Juan. But, then, I've played San Juan over 100 times, using the AI, and I've only played Race a few times. Perhaps, once I've crossed the century mark with Race, I'll have the same feeling of "cruising" through the game....

Right now, I have both games rated 8.5 but their ratings are headed in different directions - Race has the potential to go up as I come to grips with the system while San Juan is likely to go down as it becomes "cruised" out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
I'm posting an initial rating after my first two games -- a crazy, confusing storm of coaching from other experienced players, with me just trying to keep up and make a few unsound decisions of my own. I was surprised by how short the game can be. There's not much time to plan, build, and use what one has built. The game could end long before such plans can come to fruition. I'd increase my rating if there was more time to get involved in each game, to really investigate the consequences of creation.

Whenever the opportunity arises I'll play again, but I doubt I could teach this game to any casual gamers I know. Hence, I don't expect to get much better at this game, but it's possible to appreciate it somewhat from afar.


Update: I finally bought it, and I'm learning how to play better each time. It still feels like it ends too quickly most of the time -- not in terms of minutes elapsed, but in terms of decisions made.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not a big fan.

Good: conveys feel of Puerto Rico very well; satisfying for 2 players (not blatantly zero-sum, and simultaneous role-selection works for 2 players, in my opinion), infinite replay value

Bad: very, very steep barrier to entry; not fun with more players (too many cards to keep track of, don't like simultaneous role-selection in multiplayer games, becomes near-solitaire as you try to cope with the overwhelming information set), player interaction is often governed by luck (you picking Settle when your opponent just happens to have no cheap worlds, hidden information in cards); rewards experience too heavily, due to remembering what every card does and knowing general strategies (related to steep barrier to entry); and most importantly, very quiet game where talking to your opponents only interrupts their thinking.

I don't mind playing this game with 2 or 3 experienced players (2 especially, since it's fun despite not being zero-sum), as it offers quite a bit of interesting mental gymnastics in short playing time. The doublethink and what you think your opponents will do gets too overwhelming with more tableaus, and the game becomes more solitaire than intelligent piggybacking/leeching, which is the best part of the game (more than finding cute combos). Would not bother introducing this to new players. Totally silent gameplay, you could hear a pin drop when people play this.

4+3

RATING: 8
I've played my fair shart of Race over the past few months.  I'm still completely sure how I feel about it.  Let me start by saying that I enjoy the game and have enjoyed it since my very first game.  Still, there seems to be something not quite right.

For one, I'm still really not all that good.  I do occasionally win.  However, when I do win, it does not feel like I have done a whole lot to actually manage to succeed.  It feels like it is mostly luck.  But, hey, it's a card game, so there is going to be some luck.  

I guess I sometimes feel there is too much luck.  That is what keeps this from being a nine and may doom it to a seven before it is all said and done.  The biggest problem is that I seem to frequently have games where I cannot get anything to go my way.  Every now and then, once per session, or something like that, it is easy to deal with.  However, it seems like I always manage to string 2-3 of these painful games together at a time, and it just kills the enjoyment for me. 

Still, it's a lot of fun and a lot of bang for the buck.  I'm happy to have it.  [04/07/2009]

RATING: 9
This is a fun, quick moving game that is still strategically complex. The learning curve is a bit of an obstacle, mostly (I think) because the mechanics are rather abstract, with cards being used as game pieces, as currency, and as goods, and card powers being presented in the form of icons. It's a bit like learning a new language. Once you get the hang of it, though, it is very fun and challenging. The random element of drawing from a deck keeps the game interesting; you can't rely on simply pursuing the strategy that worked for you last time, you have to be able to work with what comes your way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Just played our first game of RftG.  Understanding all the symbols was confusing, but the rules were well laid out.  Even our group of four first time players picked up on the interactions between the players, and tried (with mixed success) to predict the actions of the other players. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Well I wanted a 2 player game which would be complex enough to keep my brain occupied. Lots of data, lots of options, some risk evaluation, but you can overcome all sorts of stuff if you adapt. So far, I like it a lot. Be warned though, learning curve IS steep and may cause frustration is some players, as it takes some time not only to understand the pictograms but to remember all the details of the rules. As far as player interaction goes, yes it's not directly confrontational and the interaction might be very low, but it exists on 2 levels. One is predicting which phase the other players will choose and if you got your psychology right you can potentially profit a lot. Second thing: it's a race. Oh, and the third thing: the card you're looking for, might be hidden as a good, or it might have been discarded by another player. So you're making decisions on relatively low information. 

For me it's the first card game since MtG that has the high level of complexity, plus manages that on a very lower card count (Blue Moon just doesn't work for me) and with different kind of gameplay. If you like simple games, games you can grasp in a shor amount of time, this might not be for you (I think of it as exact opposite of Lost cities - less stressful, more complex), but if you think it is for you, you might need some time to persuade other people to be patient for the first 5 or 6 games. 

EDIT: It is quite MPS and I tend to play more interactive games, but the 100+ cards still give you a lot to choose from even if solitary. Doesn't overstay it's welcome.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I had been curious about this game because of comparisons I had heard between it, Eminent Domain, and Glory to Rome. I had been hesitant to try it based on its intimidating iconography, but felt draw to it because of the space theme and how well-like this game is,

Having played it, I can definitely see the appeal to people that like to develop combo-engines. I do like games that are more aesthetically pleasing, and I just feel that Eminent Domain is an improvement over RftG in both aesthetics and game-play as you choose which actions to take to build your deck rather than hoping to draw cards that further your strategy in RftG. 

The two aspects that prevent me from really liking Race for the Galaxy, is 1) I don't want to have to learn a foreign language just to play a game (the iconography) and 2) your strategy is really dependent on the cards you draw, and if you can't draw the right ones, you'll lose.

RATING: 7
Initial impression: I'm excited. I do like San Juan and I hear this is a more gamer's version of that. My first two games were interesting exploratory forays into the strategy and it looks like there's some potential.

I kept hearing about the iconography being a big barrier, but I think that's mostly hype. It takes 10 minutes to learn and you have a card that interprets everything anyway.


(5 plays): This game looks good. I've seen several different paths to victory and it plays fast--two things I look for in a game like this. 8.

8 plays: Hmmm... this is starting to feel a little more repetitive than I had guessed it would. I'm already wondering if this needs the expansion. Also, there is a fair amount of luck--I find that when I've picked a strategy it sometimes works, and sometimes I just don't get the cards to carry that one out. Still enjoy it overall, but finding it hard to rate. Now a 7.

I do enjoy playing Race ... maybe the best game I have ever played    (I was raised on card games)To me the mechanics of the game are flawless, you control what you can do and use others anticipated actions to your advantage. There is more here than a simple card game.

What I find so amazing is that every game is different from the previous hundred...the sign of a brilliant design.

RATING: 9.25
#38 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

This was another early edition to my collection of designer board games. I still remember trying to learn it myself and being completely confused. We just tried to make sure we were actually playing correctly, there wasn't any room left to actually think about strategy. I recall it was my third play where it finally clicked, and I was like 'OH. I should base my role selection around what I think he's going to choose!" I do like Roll for the Galaxy even better these days, but this game will always have a place in my collection. It's just excellent.

Acquired: 2011 - Louisville Game Shop
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Can always be convinced to play this with 2 or 4 players. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sometime ago, several designers were asked to submit designs for a card version of Puerto Rico. I belive that this was a rejected submission that has subsequently been redeveloped into a new game.

Update: I have finally played the game and yes, it is very much an SJ derivative. Only this time, everyone gets their own set of role cards to choose from. There's much more to the game because of the many different effects the cards have on gameplay. There are also additional 'role' cards that lead to more varied strategies etc.

However, someone Tom L has managed to make the SJ experience even more solitaire. The agony of selecting roles is lost as players are essentially fiddling with their own tableau of cards. Plus the symbols and text...oh my. Expect to spend a few games just to get around what the symbols mean and how they interact. Also, this might be me, but the graphics aren't appealing at all. They remind me games released in the mid-90s when PC rendered 3D effects were popular (Princess Ryan's Star Marines anyone?).

Left me a little cold. I'm hoping that future expanions allow player to interact more. For example: it seems logical for a military world to try to take over other players' worlds etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not very fun, but very strategic.

RATING: 6
Based on one four-player game. I think it would take another play or two to develop a strategy. I could also see where knowledge of the cards might effect your strategic planning.

Edit: After playing dozens of games against AI, I've decided that this game requires that you study and learn every card in the deck, which isn't fun for me. I'd rather play San Juan.

Edit: After playing scores of games against AI, I've finally figured out how to play. I kind of like it now, but a game shouldn't take that many plays to figure out.

RATING: 9

The Gathering Storm
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Race for the Galaxy was one of the first designer games that I purchased when I was getting back into board gaming in early 2011.  Some might call Race for the Galaxy (RftG) "Puerto Rico: The Card Game," but it's better than that and many other card games after have started to utilize the multi-use card mechanism of the game.  I'm not very good at the game, but really like it and wish I could play it more oftwen.  Sadly, it has only managed to hit the table one or two times at my game group and I suspect that this is due to the [i]perceived[/i] learning curve for the iconology prevents people.  In reality, the iconology in 7 Wonders if just as bad, if not worse, and I think people just hearing about all of symbols in RftG have scared them away before they even try the game once. In reality, most people pick up all of the iconography during the first game and then want to play again right away.  Hopefully, I can convince my group to play this game again in the future. Otherwise, it may just get a lot of solo play.

SOLO PLAY:   Luckily, the Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm expansion enables solo game play by providing a unique robot AI player. The robot AI works very well and offers a challenging opponent. I have only manged to win once against the robot so far, but the biggest win is that I'm able to play RftG solo and get value more from the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Ahh, RftG. One of those games you can play again and again yet never truly master. The core is good enough to play and be happy with for many sessions, and with any luck Rio Grande designed a great alternate pathway for the game's universe to follow.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Create an intersteller empire one card at a time, with both economic and military paths to victory.  Somehow shares the "build a machine within the framework of the game" aspect with Dominion.  Only downside is fiddly iconography; useful once you've learned the game but a barrier to new players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Easily setup, quick to play, yet deep, rich, and rewarding - Race for the Galaxy is always a welcome at my table.

RATING: 9

I feel bad saying this as I really like sci-fi; part of me feels as though I shouldn't rate this game so low but hey, If I avoid a game because I don't enjoy playing it then I need to be honest with myself and rate it for what I think. I give this game a 6.

EDIT: 11/17/2012; I recently was re-introduced to RftG again and with some gentle guidance I can safely say that this is now one of my favorite games. Bumped my rating up to a 9.

RATING: 7

Maybe the role selection may get better as I play more but right now I enjoy role selection of San Juan better.

I also like the simplicity of San Juan, but much prefer 6 buildings in Race with more diversity and added bonus'.  I also like the consume ( shipping) aspect of Race.

So over all I prefer the game that is somewhat in between the two.  Maybe Race with San Juan like role selection might be better for me :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a fantastic game, probably the most played in our collection, and it plays the handy-dandy role of screening potential gamers. There is a learning curve, and an experienced player can really murder an inexperienced player, which is one of the game's strengths. Things can go 2 ways on a first play:
[b]A)[/b] It excites a new player and they want to jump to the challenge and learn the in ands outs of a challenging game! Woohoo! Obviously these are the people you want to play with.
[b]B)[/b] The write-off gamer complains about the (childishly simple) iconography, poops in the ol' diapers about how badly they lost, and never ever wants to play again. Many spoiled self-entitled gamers want to be able to master a game on their first play, which I would argue is one of the bad side-effects of BGG. "Kids these days" (and yes I'm wagging my boney finger from my rocking chair) spend more time pissing around on BGG and expanding their ridiculous gaming collections than actually enjoying the things they have.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
I finally played this today, and got three games in.  I had read the rules and introduced it to four new players.  Three of them had played San Juan previously.  I have never played San Juan, but I felt pretty comfortable playing Race for the Galaxy after having read the rules twice.  The only person who seemed to have a hard time catching on (after the first game) was the player who had never played San Juan before.  All in all though, I would say this game isn't as difficult to get as some think it is.

I think the game itself is brilliant.  It is amazingly deep, and I imagine it will take dozens of plays before I have a strong grasp of how to play all the different strategies.  It's a good thing it plays in about 30 minutes :o)  And after you're done with one game, you want to start another.  For new players I think focusing on the military strategy is the easiest route to victory.  It's the easiest to manage, as you're basically just trying to get a strong military in order to play worlds for free, thus scoring large junks of points every settlement phase.  The only other thing you need to take care of is card drawing, but it's secondary.  Once you start to understand the game better, then the production strategies will start to become more clear and prove viable vs. the the simple military method.

This is an outstanding new game and I may raise my rating of 9 higher, depending on further plays.

*****

11-30-09
I just recently got the computer version and have played a lot of games in the last few days.  This game is seriously addicting (even vs just AI; which isn't too bad), and I'm raising my rating from a 9 to a 9.2.

RATING: 8.5
A truly superb card-game. It does take a few plays to fathom what's happening, however repeated play unveils greater and greater depth of strategy and complexity. How well you are able to deal with 'bum' hands has a lot to do with how flexible your strategy is and how well you know the cards.

There will of course be those games where your opponent simply pulls the 'perfect' set of cards to execute a particular strategy, but the game is 15 minutes long right? Play another one! Believe me, you'll want to.

RATING: 7
IMT_04/16
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My estimation of this game continues to rise as I play. After a first play, I rated it a 6 or 7, but the more I play it the more I like it. My greatest complaint in the beginning was that there was not enough direct competition for my taste, and I missed the tension that comes with that competition. Another multi-player solitaire game, I thought. But I persisted, and began to see how different strategies could be pursued. I decided that RftG is something of a multi-player solitaire - but a very good one! Inspired by Puerto Rico, I can't help but compare it to that game. Race is certainly a more streamlined version of PR, taking the role selection, the goods, and the buildings/crops from that game. I confess that I *really* like the hidden information aspect of Race, though, which is not present in PR. Race for the Galaxy has also cut set-up time and the fiddle factor by using only two kinds of components: cards and VP chips. As a believer in simplicity, I like this!

There is in fact considerable player interaction in this game. It comes in the form of studying your opponent's tableau AND the sequence of phases your opponent has chosen over the past few rounds. Doing these two things will give you some idea of what she will do next, and excelling at the game requires a solid grasp of the opponent's motivations. This element of psychological study and deduction enhances the game considerably. (In PR, players take turns choosing available roles. In Race, players (blind to the others) choose any role they like.) Would I like more direct interaction with other players? Yes. But it's a small gripe. Other downsides: medium-steep learning curve - you will have to play a few throw away games to "get it"; also, I wonder about the viability of multiple strategies. I won't be able to answer my wonderings without more play, though.

Race for the Galaxy blends theme and mechanisms rather beautifully though, and that is an element of game design I both admire and enjoy tremendously. The art is also gorgeous and evocative, and the theming/art brings to mind certain science fiction memes such as Star Wars, Star Trek, David Brin's notion of Uplift, and more. This material is seamlessly integrated into the game in a way that adds atmosphere for science fiction fans, as you can play the "Imperium" and try to subdue Rebel worlds, or try to settle a lot of "Uplift" worlds and focus on Gene goods. The game also plays pretty fast once you grasp how to play, and that's really important to us given our schedule. We can actually get a game in after the kids go to bed, which isn't true of all our favorites.

Update: upgraded to a 9 after many plays. The game improves considerably once players have some familiarity with the deck. The heart of the game's strategy, in my estimation, lies in the role of the 6-cost developments. In Puerto Rico, these are the "big" buildings which give you VP bonuses at the end. Race does a better job of implementing this idea, and I am looking forward to those expansions! I can't wait to have the Uplift strategy, for instance, fleshed out by more cards. Aside: Race does boast some CCG elements, which we really like. But I have noticed that new players can get frustrated by the fact that cards in the tableau affect the game in so many different ways.

I like how the different strategic routes unfold over time in this game, both my awareness of routes to victory and my strategy in any given game. On the whole question of "Is there enough player interaction?": although I LOVE games which are highly confrontational and allow players the opportunity to crap on their neighbors (just look, I rate go a 10!), I find the structuring of a successful tableau in Race for the Galaxy very fulfilling. In many ways, the game really is a race, a race to make sure the game ends when YOU have the most points. The interaction in Race amounts to a psychological estimation of what your opponents are going to do, but the game doesn't strive to be a paragon of interaction. That's okay - this doesn't prevent it from being a fun and outstanding strategy game.

Update: Now rated a 10, well over 100 plays. I am really looking forward to the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Eid av Bodil

RATING: 9

RATING: 3.5
Played a few times - I just didn't see this as a great game.  Felt like a form of San Juan in space, but would rather just play San Juan.

The guessing game of role selection favors the experienced player and I just don't want to spend more time playing this game to become experienced.  

There are many complex rules and each card has it's own special ability (which is fine in most cases) but unless you're familiar with each special ability you spend a lot of time staring at your cards blankly thinking "WTF should I do here" while experienced opponents blast through.

Lowered from 3 to show I would rather play this than chess, but would rather play anything 3 and higher than this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.1679
Less than two months or something on the market and this game is already ranked #39 as the greatest game EVER on Boardgamegeek!  Come on.  Let's get some perspective!  Seven months or so on the market and now it's #11!

I'm told that the game is quite similar to the game San Juan which is the card game version of Puerto Rico -- what will permanently be the #1 game on Boardgamegeek unless several people eventually re-rate the game.  I've never played Puerto Rico, and I've never played Magic.

It seemed difficult for me to learn the game whether it was one o'clock in the morning or not.  I liked the space theme, but it certainly seems to violate the Joe Steadman rule of "Where's the conflict?"  The game could use some Mag-Blast type warfare...

I played it again.  I don't think this one is going to be a favorite unless I devote a lot of time to it.  That's the same problem I with Tigris & Euphrates, but this one has several different cards to unravel.  

I think this is a game that you need to learn in the two-player version.  I'm usually not a fan of playing multi-player games with two players, but I think that is probably the best way to learn this one, unless a player is very comfortable with a game like San Juan or Magic.  However, I'm not a big fan of cards with lots of little symbols with different numbers and colors...

RATING: 4
I don't know... it's not that I underestimate the depth or don't understand why people like this, but so far this game just makes me feel "indifferent." As someone who likes to get really into my games that's basically the kiss of death for me. I doubt the motivation is there for me to want to really learn it and play into it

Personal biases (along with sleep deprivation) probably  negatively impacted my first play of this too... after hearing so much about it's "multiplayer solitaire" gameplay this was never really a game on my radar and so I didn't really go into it with the same open mind that I give to most games I've never played.

After playing it, the claims of multiplayer solitaire are overstated -- you DO play the other players at the table, because you set yourself up to leech off of their expected actions to fuel your combos. Reminds me of the video game "Puzzle Fighter" in that regard. I love double-blind selection and the intense mind games it introduces when all players understand a game, so that aspect of the game is appreciated.

But that form of interaction, alone, is not strong enough here for me to consider this an interactive game... at least not enough of the type of interaction that I crave.

Ultimately the game doesn't seem like it's for me, because other than the double-blind mind games I really don't think I care for the other aspects of the gameplay at all -- draw a bunch of cards to enable you to put into play a combo that will win you the game, basically. Is there more? Probably -- I've only played once!

(4 Design + 0 Enjoyment)

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Race for the Galaxy is a extremely elegant, hand-management game. The cards represent everything from settled planets to manufactured resources, and even serve as the currency. Multi-use cards are one of my favorite mechanisms and this game really forces players to decide how best to use the cards they have. The action selection mechanism is also quite ingenious as it allows everyone to piggy-back on someone else's choice with a reduced effect. An intuitive player can maximize the actions of other players to pull off some impressive combinations. I enjoy the game best with two players using the advanced rules, as it makes for some very thrilling races that are over in 15-20 minutes. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Of all the games I've ever tried, "Race For the Galaxy" (plus expansions) is my all-time favourite. It is clever, modular, satisfying, quick, with countless ways to win, almost zero downtime - and it looks gorgeous.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I would really like to give this a better rating, but I have two very distinct problems with the game.  

One, The learning curve is tough (especially trying to wrap your head around all those icons), this I can get over.  

Two, There is virtually no player interaction other than trying to gauge what other actions players are going to select.  I won't deny that trying to figure out their move and plan for it isn't actually a big part in the game, but man there really isn't anything else going on between players. Normally the multiplayer solitaire would knock this game down to a 6 for my tastes, but the engine building is so intriguing here that I just want to play it again and again.  I'm really hoping that there will be more interaction in the expansions.

It's a pretty fantastic puzzle.

FYI, I like this much more than San Juan.

UPDATE: The more I play this game, the more that I understand how to take advantage of other people's strategies - banking on other players actions, that I expect that they will take.  This game is great.  My only issue after multiple plays is that the Uplift is tough to do anything with, and the Military strategy is too draw dependent.  The expansion massages both of these issues.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I was intimidated by Race for my first 3 or 4 plays.  Only now do I feel like I understand the cards enough to adopt a strategy.  This game feels like it has tremendous staying power.  The only thing I don't like is playing this game with true simultaneous action.  If you play that way, then you are truly playing multi-player solitaire, and you have to trust each player to interpret all rules 100% correctly.  I much prefer to play a "moderated" game where each player processes their action by announcing what they are doing in turn.  This only slightly lengthens the game, but vastly improves the social investment and game experience in my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very sweet card-based economic game. The only weakness is a lack of interaction in my point of view, besides that a very smooth and fast gameplay after a couple of games.

RATING: 7
I've played it a whole lot now.  At first I loved it, and then I just liked it.  I think the the bit that soured me slightly on it that eventually cropped up is that it really is a race.  If you treated as a civilization building game or a deep strategic game, you will lose.  The goal is to win fast, not build lots of stuff and get lots of points.  It's the card game equivalent of a real-time strategy "twitch" game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Better than San Juan, but vastly overrated. Very luck-driven, so that most of the time, among players of like experience, the result is determined more by the cards than by anything else. Each expansion adds both niftiness and luck; I advise adding them one at a time.

Occasionally a 2p game will be close and exciting. Most of the time, though, the winner is clear after the second or third turn. After that, the loser is just playing to be polite. The game would be much improved by the use of a doubling cube or similar convention.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2-4 Players
Best 2,4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Race for the Galaxy is by far my favorite game. You don't necessarily need to be a space junkie to enjoy this game. The game is built around a turn structure where players choose what action they want to take. Whatever any players choose will determine what turns will occur that round. Not every turn will occur each round. Players receive a bonus for whatever card they choose. It makes it interesting when trying to predict what cards other players will choose. The cards work beautifully together, but this game can be a little intimidating to a novice gamer. Save this for some saltier dogs.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think it still lacks the variety of strategies to win, so expansions should work not on introducing the new mechanics, but allowing more interesting and complex roles.

RATING: 10
My first 10. I thought it would be a 10 from the first time I played it, and I've finally upgraded it to a 10 after my 13th play. This game offers so much depth, so many different ways to strategize. Reading your opponents and guessing what they'll pick is vital, and you can piggyback off that nicely. I love this game every time I play it, whether it's stand-alone or solo with the expansion. I just can't get enough of it.

Edit 17.09.16: Still the best game ever, after probably over 200 plays. So many games on the app vs the Keldon AI (probably 7 per week since it came out) and on boardgamearena. Always great.

RATING: 7.5
