=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
An excellent strategic card game... I think the action mechanics and use of the cards as currency is extremely inspired. The space theme fits this very well, and can be something of a brain-burner at times (which I like). It's rather fulfilling to set up a good economic engine, then just watch that engine go to town. Games are quick too, allowing multiple plays in one session to try out different strategies. Lots of complaints about the iconography (and I admit, I was intimidated at first), but they became pretty intuitive after just a couple of plays. My one complaint is that iconography makes it hard to bring non-gamers into the fold. Overall, I'll be enjoying this one for a long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
extremely re-playable; a game that probably needs to be played a lot to fully appreciate; arcs give different game-play experiences while sharing mechanisms; wonderful tableau building experience in a short time; Race is a game I grew to love... I'll never understand the complaints about the iconography or supposed complexity - it's one of those 'easy to learn hard to master' games - anyone who has played other strategy games should have no problem with the icons or game-play mechanisms

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Have played this game more than any other. Actually, I have kind of burnt out on it - but only briefy! I like playing this even more than its venerable ancestor, Puerto Rico. Part of the reason it makes it to the table so much is that it packs such an enormous amount of quality gaming into such a short time frame. It is chock full of tactical considerations, very difficult choices, strategy, the right amount of luck (for a shortish card game), a fun production engine, outguessing your opponent, etc. etc. Yes, the iconology seems impenetrable at first, and impossible for casual gamers - but not true! I taught this game to my very reluctant girlfriend (reluctant to learn Race, not reluctant to be my girlfriend, that is...) and now she begs me to play it! Its just one of those games that every single gamer should learn and try out - the only critisism some may have is that the luck level is too high, and you either get the card you need to win, or you don't. I personally do not like high luck games very much, but I have to say that there is so much in this game to mitigate the luck factor. Most gamers who find the luck too annoying may have just not played enough to unravel all the complexity yet. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a fantastic game! If you want a quick playing game with loads of strategy, this is it! (How rare of a combination is that?) Plus it takes hundreds of plays to really plumb the depth of it. So go buy it right now!

And don't be scared off by the icons: after you've played the game once or twice, the icons will all be clear to you. And you'll find them much quicker to read than text ever could be.

(When introducing new players, I've found it helpful to cover some rudiments of strategy: military strategy, development strategy, produce-consume strategy, trade-trade-trade strategy. And be sure that new players play a full game in less than 45 minutes: more games = more fun. It's not worth trying to optimize play your first several games--just enjoy the experience of exploring this new universe.)

I'm still willing to give this more of a chance, but I'm beginning to think that this game is just not for me.

RATING: 8
Занимательная карточная игра, по своей механике напоминающая Пуэрто-Рико и немного Цитадели: игроки выбирают себе роли в каждом раунде, которые применяются ко всем игрокам, но выбравшему дают бонус, таким образом зарабатываются победные очки и выкладываются карты своего кусочка космического пространства: планеты, улучшения, миры и т. п.. По сути - это красивый вдумчивый пасьянс с очень небольшим взаимодействием игроков. Чтобы выигрывать, надо "прощупать" несколько стратегий и найти свои. Игра занимает около получаса, правила просты в освоении, а механика предоставляет множество вариантов. За малое взаимодействие снял пол балла из своей максимальной оценки)), а карты даже в оригинальном издании не так плотны, какк хотелось бы. Итого: 5 баллов игрушке, Исполнению: 5 баллов.

RATING: 9.5
I know that people love this game, but it's another card game where you build up your system using several cards with lots of writing on them.  Difficult learning curve and it seemed to me to be a bunch of people playing solitaire at the same time.  I'm sure that there is some depth, which is why people like it, but to me, there are better games out there that also include some good player interaction.

UPDATE: It certainly has grown a little bit on me, but it's just not something that I enjoy and would like to seek out.  I think that the card synergy just doesn't really grab me in this game.

UPDATE #2: Being surrounded by so many fans of the game, I keep having to play it.  It's grown on me, and the iconography and learning curve is finally past me.  I still think it's a little too solitairish to get much higher than this, but it does have some great depth.

UPDATE #3: Continue to like it more and more. Lots of great decisions in such a little package and over such a short duration.

UPDATE #4: Well, I've come full circle on this, and it simply is one of my favorite games now. I enjoy having to think what's going on with my opponent, and the challenge is in getting your engine going quickly, as the game really does move quickly, especially with 2.

RATING: 6
I'll never be a fan of the sterile space theme, but I'm warming up to the abstraction behind it. Race for the Galaxy is both hard to learn and worth the investment as it becomes more interactive and more enjoyable with more plays. There are many paths to victory, but you have to use your brain even after you've settled on which one to take. It's San Juan's deeper, more mature counterpart. I have to say, though, that I prefer Glory to Rome in the engine-building genre. Race is a lot tamer by comparison.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Similar to SJ but adds complexity (more options, more cards, more interactions) and a better theme (and very nice artwork) while INCREASING game speed (simultaneous role selection). Especially good as a 2-player game: each person chooses 2 roles (so the game plays faster), and it's easier to keep track of what the other person is doing. The iconography is tough, at first: there are a LOT of icons. But they do a remarkably good job of summarizing the relevant rules for every card.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For new players, choices are not obvious and you usually end up not being as efficient with your actions. With a few plays you see how your endgame is set up by your early game choices. After this, this game is excellent. Every choice is levied out especially when there are 5 players due to the increased amounts of discards. If not for how seemingly difficult it is for some to pick it up I would rank this higher.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
When I first bought the game, it was due to 2 reasons. It was highly portable and it had a great theme of creating your own galaxy. Far far away... or maybe not.

When I started playing, I thought it depends on what you draw so much that you have to be lucky. Since then I played tons of games and bought The gathering storm expansion. And it's not that much luck dependent at all, it's a lot of strategy. Knowing the possible cards in the deck doesn't hurt, but I have a very very very bad memory, so that's not an option. Still I know roughly what is in the deck and now... wow... when I play with my friend who is into strategic games (purely strategic), we're having a blast. Usually the games end really close, there's no huge gap between us. And he's starting to outplay me which makes me want to play even more to refine my strategy.

There is luck present in the game, but once you figure out some advanced strategies for the game, you beat new players without much effort even if they're "lucky" in the card draws. And knowing your oponent brings another level of strategy, trying to guess what they'll do so you can take advantage of their actions during your turn (like betting on them playing certain action that you need so that you can play other actions that even more boost your position). On the other hand your oponent is probably doing the same thing.

Really enjoy this one, it's an awesome game. And the theme is just great adition to already great experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

Also it packs a lot of game into a relatively short playing time, and nicely evokes the theme, whether you are building a military powerhouse, a merchant empire, or a technologically advanced civilization.

RATING: 8.5
Race for the galaxy kicks galactic ass! I can think of no better way to describe it. But I'll try....in race for the galaxy you kick ass and win, or you don't kick ass and you lose. Pretty simple right? Wrong! You think exploring and settling new worlds is easy? You think developing technologies on a universal scale and brokering alien goods is some kind of silly game? Well its not! Well, i mean it IS  a game, but its not silly! Nor is it easy, but it is a whole lot of fun.There is a ton of stuff going on in this game, and it can be a galactic pain in the ass to teach, but once you understand it the game plays quick and easy.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game was daunting at first because of all the symbols but once you know what they do and play through a few games they're all pretty easy to understand and you can get through games pretty quickly.  I like the mechanic of choosing which phases are played out and getting a bonus for your chosen phase a la Puerto Rico.  My favorite change from the Puerto Rico formula though is that all phases are chosen and played concurrently instead of each player picking in an order and being the only person who can pick that role/phase so you're not stuck in a position where your board stagnates because other players are locking you out of necessary bonuses and lines of play you need all because of bad board position.

I still love this game but Roll for the Galaxy has completely replaced it.  I like Roll just a little bit more and I don't see the need to keep both.

It actually plays rather fast so you can easily play several times in a row (which we did) which is a help to really get into the game since there are a lot of symbols to take in when you learn it first (and don't always want to check the cheat sheet). Like it a lot, eager to play more, but yeah, it is a bit tough to learn when it hits you the first time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Issues I have with the game:
1. Feels like multiplayer solitaire - prefer more direct interaction. Little incentive to keep a close eye on opponent's cards.
2. Comes across too short for a game of such depth - feel unsatisfied at the end of each game.
3. Steep learning curve - tough to get casual players into the game and for them to be even somewhat competitive.
4. Once familiar with the general strategies, card draw seems to be a key factor to success amongst seasoned players. I like a degree of luck in the game but at times this comes across overly random.
5. Playing according to cards obtained sometimes lead to mechanical choices (e.g. Consume - 2x VP / Produce in a 2-player game).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Can't stop wanting to play this game.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Race for the Galaxy is a hugely popular sci/fi-themed hybrid of a card game and an action selection game in which all players can utilize all actions chosen by the other players and vice versa. As such, it is a game that is quick to play at the same time as it provides the players with a ton of considerations to keep in mind when choosing their action. While wanting to maximize one's own efficiency by utilizing other player(s) action choice(s), one must also make sure not to provide other players with the actions they want to use the most. Sadly, the game is hugely determined by the players luck of the draw, which in this kind of game limits the potential fun factor a lot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Although similar to San Juan, they don't necessarily appeal to the same people.  SJ is a lighter game, easier to pick up and play casually.  RftG is meatier, requires more focus, and is probably harder to play just once every couple of months, which is how I enjoy San Juan.  It's quicker and more balanced than Glory to Rome, though I like the latter more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
We play this a lot (2-player, 2 actions each) and love it. It's also really compact, so it travels with us.  Play all the expansions and will get AA.

RATING: 10
I'm obsessed with this game. It's like San Juan, but better. The simultaneous play helps it move along quickly, and the use of cards as goods instead of separate pieces (a la San Juan) means that setup is a breeze and there's not a bunch of little pieces to lose. I'm not really sure why I like this so much, but I do. It's hard to make sense of at first, as there are a lot of rules and details to consider, but it's well worth sticking it out through the first two games. After all, the games are pretty quick.

RATING: 2
A very quick-playing, but extremely deep and complex game.  I love Race for the Galaxy because it seems like Puerto Rico distilled down to a pure form that both moves along at a good clip and introduces some well thought out randomness that ensures the game does not become easily solved.  The only problem I found with the game is that it is very complex to teach others how to play effectively.  Most people I tried to play with gave up because I always won since I know how to play and have read the rules while they are still trying to figure out what the symbols mean and how the cards interact.  This meant I eventually ended up with nobody to play against.  I couldn't convince anyone else to try reading the rules first to see if that helps, either.

UPDATE:  After a few more plays, I now loathe this game.  I just can't get past how uninteresting it is once you learn how to play it effectively enough.  No thanks.

RATING: 10
The learning curve is quite steep due to all the symbols you need to memorize, but once you're there, the game is a blast. It's pretty quick and portable for a game this deep. I strongly recommend the "RftG for Kids" manual to learn the game (in the files page of the game here at BGG). Caveat: not a lot of player interaction

EDIT 2018/01/11: After being hesitant for a long time, finally went for the full package and added in BoW with all rules. I still think takeovers are a little meh, but the're not very frequent so they don't usually get in the way; and prestige is much more interesting than I thought, and not so complicated as it seems. Also, we have kind of a regular group now, so I went from "very good game" to "I love love LOVE this game".

Expansions: The Gathering Storm, Rebel vs. Imperium, Brink of War.

RATING: 7

It's like a competitive solo strategy game, and I think it's just great fun.  All our games come really, really close.  There IS a great deal of luck in what kinds of cards you get, but theres also a lot of strategy in how you choose to sort of plan out your galaxy.  I don't know, it might not be for everyone, but my friends like it a lot, and so do I.  Can't wait to try the expansions!

RATING: 10
A very deep, complex, tactical and strategical science-fiction card game.

The complexity and depth makes it hard to learn but that's also one of it's advantages. It's worth getting engaged into it. 

The theme fits very well, the design is also ok, although some pictures are too dull. Regardless, it still has a very good atmosphere and science-fiction fans will definitely like it. I have no problem with the icons whatsoever.

Again an oversized box. The game could easily fit a box third this size. I guess it might be too big even for all three expansions.

I did not log plays with Keldon's AI

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[RGG 07 edition] {Galaxy; simultaneous-action, hand management; scalable} Race for the Galaxy is an original game for its phase selection mechanic.  The game flow is intuitive enough to learn it easily even though it takes some times to understand the cards and icons.  I don't think it's a multi-solitaire game; one must lose even if he doesn't pay attention on what other players are doing.  It has multifaceted strategies.  Early game plan is quite important and decisions are somewhat constrained with early card draws; thus, getting more cards at early game is quite important.  The playing time, 45 mins per game, is very good - it's never boring.  The point that prevents me from rating it higher is the lacks of theme - players just too focus on reading the symbols, not the cards.  I enjoy each game quite much.

The components are so-so: standard MtG card size with moderately thick cardstock.  The illustration is typical CCG style.  I wish the VP chips were larger.  The player aid is handy.  However, the box is horribly large than necessary.  In addition, they should provide goods marker, rather than using the playing cards.  Using playing goods just senselessly increase the luck of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Christmas present 2008

RATING: 7.5
Fast paced
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I waver on race.  It's a really decent resource-machine-building game, but there are some niggling problems with it that keep it from being any sort of sworn-by-favorite for me.  

First and foremost--and I'm aware of the few vehement fans who will chomp at the bit regarding this statement--there is not much interaction in RftG.  Let's go ahead and compare it to San Juan, since such a comparison is inevitable; the role-drafting in SJ gives enough interaction that I can't effectively play the whole game with my eyes solely on my own cards.  With RftG, I can certainly benefit from looking at my competitors' setups, both to attempt to mind-read what phase they will play and also to know what cards to keep from them.   But in the end, I can do a decent job solely from staring at my own setup--in my group, I generally do just this, since the game goes by too quickly for me to pick up everyone's cards and examine them to understand what they're doing.

Which leads to the second and third problems: the vast variety of cards that are too hard to distinguish for a casual player, and the iconography.  The latter is actually sort of enjoyable for me, but poses such a large learning barrier for new players that it makes RftG much less of a game I'd introduce to people than San Juan, where all the cards say clearly what they do.  The former is a particular problem for me; I've played RftG over a dozen times, but only know what a handful of worlds and buildings do by name.  San Juan only has a couple dozen buildings, and I could tell you what most of them do off the top of my head, and I've only played SJ one more time than RftG.  This makes it so other players can't just announce "I built New Epsilon" and I will immediately know what they're doing.  Supposedly the iconography should help with this, but I find that realistically, it's too much trouble to figure out what my opponents are doing except in a two player game.

All that said, RftG is enjoyable.  I particularly think it's a good, 15-20 minute 2-player game, since you have more control over phases in this game and can pay more attention to your opponent.  I think if I played RftG several dozen times and was intimately familiar with all the cards, I'd find it's a much more interactive game, but I find that necessary time-investment a bit of a minus.  I'm hoping that the Gathering Storm expansion, with its ability to aggress on opponents, will help with this problem without making the military strategy too powerful.  We'll see.

In the end, RftG is a decent game, but I prefer San Juan and since I own the latter, I don't have a great drive to get Race. 

COLORBLINDNESS NOTE: I personally find the Rare Element-brown and the Gene Element-green quite hard to distinguish, especially their windfalls.

ADDITIONAL NOTE ADDED AFTER ORIGINAL COMMENT: Oh god why can't I stop playing?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 8.25
Great game, but having a small set of planets that can produce and consume can set you up for a quick victory that no one can come back from just by spamming product and consume * 2 VP.

If it was a little more balanced on the whole consume * 2 VP the game would be higher, but it is still a VERY good game.

EDIT: After having played over a few hundred games, I feel that the game is TOO fast if most of the players go a consume produce strategy. I feel that the game needs to have a larger set VP cap. Like 16 per player or something. 

Or better yet, change the Consume * 2 VP to something that can only be used on two or three locations, not EVERY consuming VP location.

Hopefully these issues will be gone with the new Search ability -- giving thematic card sets a chance of being viable against a heavy produce/consume strat.

RATING: 8

A first it's difficult to know which cards are worth holding on to and which ones to discard but this becomes more apparent with repeated plays and as you understand the possibilities on offer you begin to realize that there's far more depth to the gameplay than you'd expect from a solely card-based game. It's another game I feel that could do with an improved re-write of the rulebook as it's not as clear as it could be, especially when considering that this is actually a pretty simple game to play. A very well designed game though with a lot of replay value. Recommended, especially with the expansion sets.

RATING: 9
Played 10+ times. This is pretty awesome!  It may be a bit more lucky than San Juan because there are more big 6 cost developments and no doubles.  If you get one that works for you on the last turn and can afford it you can get a big point swing.  On the other hand if you get one early and can get it played they usually have good bonuses that help push you towards a cohesive combination of buildings. 
Update: It's definitely more lucky than San Juan because there are more big victory buildings and more combinations so there is a higher chance that you'll get cards that don't work together or won't get the big building you want.  As a result, it feels more tactical and fluid.  Again though, you are in control of the end of the game and you can take actions to overcome a bad hand.  You definitely have to be aware of what other people are doing and how quickly the game may end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Race for the Galaxy is a tableau building, card game.  You draw and play your cards which represents either developments or worlds.  Each card generally has a cost to play the card, a victory point value and possibly some abilities that help you play or draw cards, or gain victory points.  Once a player has 12 (or more) cards in his tableau, the game ends and the victory points are tallied to determine the winner.

There is generally little direct player interaction.  Generally, the interaction is determining what phase your opponents may be choosing.  The game round has 5 phases.  At the beginning every player secretly chooses which phase will occur in that round.  If no one chooses a particular phase, it does not occur that round.  Part of the strategy is to pick a phase you need and anticipating another player will pick a different phase you also need this round.

The interaction is generally very subtle.  For the most part it is literally a race to get as many victory points as possible by the time someone gets 12 cards in his tableau.  One of the expansions does allow players to attempt to take a card from an opponent, but this ability is rather limited.  Expansions also have mechanics where you compete for victory point prizes called goals.  One one player may get one of these goals and some goals can be taken by other players after one player acquires one.

I really like this game because for the most part, you are gathering pieces to build up your tableau.  Your tableau will ideally enable you to play more expensive cards that net you the most VP's.  For the most part, there is little ability to disrupt another player.  The only thing you really control is how fast you end the game.  Sometimes, you have to try to end the game before someone else can make a big play for huge points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game gets a bad reputation for iconography, but I think this is blown way out of proportion.

I have found that my success depends a lot on the cards that I happen to draw.  However, I think this is more of my lack of skill than it is a problem of the game.

RATING: 5

But Race for the Galaxy is more Multiplayer Solitaire (and no, I don't consider this a bad thing necessarily) than San Juan is, as there is less player interaction (Sure the role selection can give you a little, but it's not forced like it is in San Juan).

They are both different games, and I like them for different reasons.

RATING: 9
I love this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really love this game, the more I play the more I like it.

- It's perfect for 2 players, but it also works perfectly fine with any other number of people (up to 4 with the base game, 5 with the first expansion and 6 with the first two).

- It's a short game, but it isn't a filler. I mean, you can play it in 30 minutes, but it does involve strategic decisions. Most of the time the one who played better wins.

- It can be played, more or less, in any place. I usually play with my wife in a 3-person sofa, you don't require more space for 2-player games.

- It's relatively easy to explain. I'm really surprised about the reviews saying that the game is complicate! I've explained to different people, both gamers and non-gamers. I play with them two or three turns with open hands, and everybody (even 9 years-old boys) got it! You then show the player reference with the sign summary, and they can play. OK, the first game take longer, since players should read the text in the cards, consult the reference, etc., but they feel they're playing from the first game.

- It can be anything from a light-medium to a medium-heavy game. It depends on the time you need to make a decision. You should always consider the opponents situation before making any decision (if every player only considers his situation, the game becomes a solitaire where the luckiest player wins). However, if you prefer a lighter game, you can play it without "counting the probability of seen a military rebel word if I explore +5 and sell the green good". As long as everybody takes a similar time, the game works.

- It's incredibly replayable. With a hundred of different cards, you'd really need a lot of games to burn it! It's really a masterpiece of playtesting.

- Even though the game is short, you have to change your strategy several times. You're constantly drawing cards, and every one of them would be useful. You have to decide which ones you want to use, which ones you want to save from later and which ones you use to pay.

- Incredible art. The game is really a race. The images brings you in the galaxy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
M:
K: 9
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Rating for the hole series

When you play for the first time it seems complicated, but after few plays you will see all the icons are easy.

At the beginning you try only a "clear strategy" (all brown, or only produce-consume, or anly military) and seek for the 6-dev to your strategy. Then you will see, you strategy mustbe not clear. You must have not many points, you must have more than your opponents. Very important is to control the end of the game. New players are often suprised that the game ends.

The game has a fantastic replaybility. As more you play, you see more connections between the cards. The game is fast (ca. 30 minutes), but you have many choices. 

The cards, are cards and money, so you must choose, what cards you want pla and what will be only money. What action you want to play? You should try to play actions, that gives something only you, and benifit from other players actions.

RATING: 7.5
Early Comment:  Will appeal to the same people San Juan appeals to.  I like it.  But everyone around me likes San Juan too much and want to play it all the time.  I have to keep turning down games because sometimes I like to play something else.  I am worried that Race will go down the same hole in quite a short time.

Additional Comment:  I have now played this over 100 times and yes, those around me keep wanting to play it some more.  However, I think it has considerably more replay value than San Juan and it is good as a 2 player game in the lunch hour.

I went through a phase of finding that it was too much affected by the luck of the card draw, but have now learned to accept gracefully that some hands are just too good or no good.  This happens sufficiently infrequently that it does not break the game.

RATING: 9
2015 20x5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I find myself fascinated by the way the cards work together to form a sci-fi theme. I enjoyed setting up my 'empire' a lot more than trying to beat someone else's empire, mainly because there seemed little I could do to slow down other players. Just go with a strategy and hope for the best while keeping your options open to take advantage of any good cards that come along. Love the artwork and the card theme, but I suspect that I'll eventually end up with a 'fixed' favourite strategy.

Surprisingly, it feels a lot like Puerto Rico, even more so than San Juan! Your final VPs are scored by adding your 'built' cards and your VP tokens. The game ends when someone 'builds' their 12th card, or when VPs run out. You produce 'goods' and 'ship' them for VPs. You sort of end up with the same strategies, except that you have to rely on cards that are in your hand, instead of on a Common Building Board. And you can't really block someone else who's 'shipping' a lot, simply try to outrun them by building/shipping more. In that respect, I prefer Puerto Rico.

29-Feb-07: It's weird, I can't seem to get this game out of my head. There always seems to be yet another strategy I should try based on the cards that turn up. I just played 4 games of this in a row last night, and I found myself enjoying it. My comment about not being able to slow down opponent stands, but in a way, this is nullified by the way you should try to 'leech' off the actions of other players. I find myself thinking, "Man, if I knew so-and-so was going to Settle, I'd Produce instead, thus getting everything I want to happen in 1 turn instead of 2." I think I'm going to have to get this game now. Upped my rating to 8.

17-Mar-08: Introduced this game to my wife and she loves it. We play with our Carcassonne scoreboard to keep track of the current score, so that we can see how far apart we are in terms of points. We feel it emphasizes the 'race' aspect of the game.

11-Sep-08: 8.0 -> 8.5 One of the few games I'm actually looking forward to picking up the expansion for.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Need to get more into this. Feels like it will be great fun.  This game has a steep learning curve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's own game, but also what San Juan should have been. Lots of possibilities, and a big enough hand size that you can hold cards for the future without automatically losing.

Maybe too many options. This is a game I think I might like better if I studied it to know the options. But I don't like it enough to study the options. Circular logic, certainly. I doubt the expansion will improve my feeling for the game; the expansion is so late, the time for it being a viable product may have passed.

I've been playing the computer AI version. The base game plays well, but is not that evocative. Put in all the options, and I love the theme. However, the expanded game comes down to who gets the most synergy--luck of the draw. I would be interested to try starting with a 6 point development instead of a planet.

The dice game may be good as it will prevent cards from being unavailable.

I'd really like to see this game go back to being a low luck board game, luck-wise like PR, but I wouldn't want to see a PR clone.

RATING: 6
I'm not a fan of card games, but Race for the Galaxy won me over anyway. You can focus on so many different things, but you also have to go with your cards and change your strategy if necessary. Because of all the choices, the game isn't too much about luck.

I love space theme in everything, but in this case the theme is mainly the pictures on the cards. I don't get sucked into the theme at all when playing this. Maybe I would rate it 10, if I did.

You need to play it a couple of times and then a couple more, before you can really appreciate it. First games are a bit confusing and don't seem so great. Play more, it's worth it.

RATING: 7.5
07 APR 2009 - Played @ GameStorm 11 - First game I played at the convention! Was volunteering at the game library and it was slow, so we played this game. I had heard it can be difficult to pick up. You really have to just play it to 'get it' I think. The symbols take some getting used to, but I really like the mechanic of using cards for both the resources and the money and you have to decide which to trash and which to add to your layout. I can see why this game is addicting and so popular. However, I don't see myself playing this a lot right now but will definitely be willing to play again when asked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
In a similar vein as San Juan (cards are used for nearly every purpose, except keeping track of VPs), but better. World and Developments can often influence more than just one action or phase of the game. Actions are also simultaneous and can be the same as other players. The theme is very well done and the card's ability really matches the theme on each card. The cards have great artwork and very high quality. I especially like that this game is short-ish, yet interesting. 

And yet, I rate this well below the norm. Why? Because I can tell whether I'm in or WAY out of the game by the time I've played 4 cards. If you get down by that point, its nearly impossible to recover - making this game pointless... I also discovered Glory to Rome, which I prefer for this style of game.

**2017 Update. I've been playing this a lot on iOS. I'm enjoying it more than I have previously, because I can play a 2-player game in about 5 minutes. Against the hard AI - what I said before still holds true. After about 4 cards played, you have a pretty good idea if you are going to win or not. My rating is holding (BASE GAME ONLY)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent game. Rules are very interesting (although I think they are inspired from Puerto Rico, at least partly).

It has a lot of replayability since there is a lot of cards and strategies.

Not so easy to explain it to people as they get lost with all the symbology. Even if that symbology is very good at all, it's just a lot. So don't expect people not used to card game to get it fast. I would recommend the game fore more experience players.

It's also a game with not so much interaction, at least at a first glance (with experience you have to look at what your opponents do).

I'd say it's the kind of game you learn to appreciate and its value grows as you play (+ tons of expansions !)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This game is quite similar to San Juan, which happens to be one of my favorite games.  I like the theme of San Juan more than the space theme of Race For the Galaxy, but there is a lot that I like about this game as well.  The simultaneous action selection is excellent, and it makes you feel more in control.  You can try to predict what others need to determine what is best for yourself.  There are a lot of cards in this game, so each game plays out quite differently.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
There is so much I can say about this game and how much I freaking love it, but I'll try and keep it short. Firstly, super engaging. Secondly, it doesn't fall into the trap that a lot of card games do - randomness with a lack of control. Nope, you can 'explore' to look for more cards, or build your engine to draw even more, the sky is the limit. And the tough decision making brought about by having your own cards as your resources for constructing settlements and developments, wow, what a great mechanic that pushes the play to really think about their actions. Simultaneous play is also nice, and whoa do I like those 'sixers' as we call them (the 6 cost developments that score you specialised points) because they hone you in on a particular strategy.

RATING: 10
A deeper offering than San Juan, but using some of the same basic mechanics. The added depth is a true enhancement rather than pasted-on extra complexity, and works seamlessly within the system. The theme and mechanics meld together far better here than in San Juan, and the new layers of strategy are a delight. The artwork is gorgeous. Now firmly ensconced in my pantheon of favorite card games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I own it, but prefer playing online. Used to be genie, then it was flex, now it is board game arena and I did not enjoy the Keldon AI version as much, it is too good and the network feature does not work for me. I play once in awhile on the 3pm Friday tournament of just the base game. It is a real challenge!
Online systems handle all the details of the powers and makes it easier to compare your situation to your opponents, and provides quality opponents at any time day or night.

In person, I find it complicated to assess other's positions - online I can understand their powers, and know their number of cards, chips left, etc. Also, handling the extra "role" cards is not a great design. I use a modified version of the magnetic selectors.

I have played the base game the most and be competitive in almost any game, even one that looks lost.
I do not love the expansions, but I love one thing especially about them. Before I know any of them really well, there is a joy and excitement in seeing a new crazy card and crazy combo. 

I love games like this, because I can mostly do my own thing, but outguessing my opponent can secure the win. This is also an awesome feature of other favorites including Innovation and Glory to Rome. See the RftG Sommelier review that recommends other similar types of games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Expansions: Alien 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Rating based on one play.  Take San Juan, add a second building round, and give all of the players roles to choose simultaneously.  Change the art to (admittedly very nice) outer space drawings and add a bunch of barely decipherable symbols to the cards.  Now you have Race for the Galaxy.

I played my game of this at the RGG booth at Essen 2007, Scott Tepper taught.  The other players seemed to love the game, but it's obviously not for me.

RATING: 8
[i][u]Race for the Galaxy Standalone PC version - Keldon.net[/u]
2010 - 55(18)[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A solid game.  It is a bit Puerto Rico-esk, in that each player chooses a phase and all the players play each chosen phase with the phase bonus going to the player(s) that chose it.  Unlike Puerto Rico, though, you choose your phases in secret and reveal them all at the same time.  This is a cool aspect that adds suspense.  I like that it offers a lot of tough choices and there a lot of paths to victory.  I've played many times now and have not been disappointed and the game has been well received by my gaming group.  Also, the two player game, which has some minor yet impactful rule changes, is excellent.  I probably like the two player game better than the 3-4 player game.  I also like the game length; it plays fairly quickly. Also, the idea of using instructive icons on the cards instead of text seemed a bit odd to me at first but now they seem very intuitive and I prefer them over text on the cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Fantastic game that currently only supports 2-4 players. The expansions will each add another player. Being a card game, RftG has a significant luck factor that I am not sure is mitigable with smart play. However, the game plays quickly, so if you have one bad game, you can always go for a 2nd game or 3rd or ... More enjoyable with more players since more ends up happening each round and the little interaction there is increases slightly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Race for the Galaxy is as overwrought as San Juan was elegant.  Both are good, but Race goes off the deep-end with complexity.  It's beautiful but the iconography is cryptic, and that belies the bigger problem: almost everything in Race feels like an exception to a principle cited elsewhere. If the whole thing is an exception, what am I really playing here?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This sci-fi game packs a lot of decisions into a small time frame. The base game has strategic pathing, phase timing, and forces you to think about your card flow. I prefer the game with 3 or 4 (as opposed to 2 player). Scoring is tight enough where games are pretty close.

Expansion adds balance to Production Strategies through Goals.
Second Expansion adds more tension and bolsters Exploration.
Third Expansion kinda killed this game for me. Close games are rare now and prestige cards are highly sought after.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game is a great game once you learn the rules, the cards, and a couple of stradegies. It has great replay ability. The theme is great but a bit geeky. It is very difficult to get non-gamers intrested due to the theme and how many rules/icons you have to learn before you play. Once you know the icons/rules everything is a breeze and the game moves very quickly with almost no down time, mostly due to the simulitanous action selection. It's a bit pricey for essentially a deck of cards, but this game does not feel rushed. In fact it really feels very balanced. It also scales great with anywhere from 2-4 players. It's a solid medium weight game and not a gateway game. The only thing lacking is player interaction or a screw your neighbor factor. It is possible to have four people playing and be so intesly into the game, that nobody says a word untill the game ends.

RATING: 8
The first game where the actual game time is even less then what is said on the box. This game is really fast-moving and quite enjoyable. From the diversity and the possibilities it is very close to Agricola, the gameplay itself comes very close to San Juan. Plus: despite all the different cards and their different advantages and despite all those little icons you have to keep in mind to know when and and what advantages they bring you, this is a very intuitive game. Besides it comes with one of the most stunning artworks I've seen in a game. Normally I'd think that 30 euros is simply too much for a card game, but the art makes it worth every cent. Honestly, this is art. 

This game has gotten me. I am thinking about it all the time with a constant urge of wanting to play it again combined with a strong craving for the expansion.
----------------
Update: While still a remarkable game,I played if often enough (vs.AI) that it's really all about the start hand you get dealt and what to make of it. And there are start hands that are far worse than others, especially if you play against experienced players or a "cruel" AI. Hence the downgrade! Same goes for the expansions

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I love a good deck builder, but have to say I feel this one is wildly over-rated. It has original mechanics, but do they make the game more enjoyable? Sci-Fi shouldn't be a hard theme to capitalize on, but honestly, this game felt very, very dry... Card traits are usually sumarized with what amounts to checkmarks or +1s, making alterations to the basic actions you already take. While there is some connection between this mechanic and theme, it still breaks the game down to boring math... This card increases your ability to buy military cards and gives extra draw (but not keep) in the draw and discard action, this card increases the value of this color of resource created by this planet... The fact that those cards are Military Expedition and Earth's lost colony feel... window-dressing, rather than coloring what you're doing into a narrative. In the end it all breaks down into a big math-pile that doesn't excite before one player locks the other out from winning fairly suddenly. Additionally, one of the core mechanics, resources and their production/exchange/sale, besides being the most math based and bland of them all, is fairly complicated to learn, and even once mastered, it feels like an annoying distraction/blindside Achilles heel you adapt to 
rather than a valid strategy to build towards, and is tediously time consuming and dull from the other players perspective. I suggest finding a different, better title in the same vein, like                                                                                                                     
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
So much depth in this one!  I've given up logging my Keldon's AI plays, because I play it almost every day, it seems.  There's an initial learning curve (some people get it really fast, others take a while) and it sucks to be a new player at a table with veterans.  But once you're in, man, it keeps you entertained!
My only real criticism of the game is that some strategies clearly dominate others.  If you're playing Alpha Centauri and draw Mining League and Mining Conglomerate in your opening hand, you're sort of a fool not to pursue a rare element strategy.  But most times you'll have several potentially viable options competing for your attention.  This game is often about making hard choices -- it really is a race, and there isn't time to do everything you'd like to do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Three and a half years and it finally got to table.  Very, very; good game so far.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.49
Race for the Galaxy is another creation of the design that went into San Juan (Tom Lehmann contributed to SJ, but did not get a box credit as he did with RftG).  Tom has had several years to perfect his design and this game shows it.  There are more strategies, more tricks to generate points, and more options each turn (instead of being frozen out of a role as in SJ, a player picks from their hand of action cards every turn).  The result is in many ways a much deeper game--but at a price of being accessible to casual gamers.  Rftg is a "gamers game".  It can take many plays to master the intricacies, and figuring out the icons (even with a player aid) can be maddening at times.  A great design, but one with a few flaws.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
[b]The Gathering Storm[/b]

I like that there's a lot of depth, multiple paths to victory, and, if you're playing with experienced players, the gameplay is very fast.

Finally, I like the challenge of adapting your strategy to the cards you have, and (likewise) adjusting said strategy if your followup cards don't cooperate.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game wins the award for the most unintelligible rules ever written. However, the game is quite intuitive so as long as you can get someone to explain the rules to you (or watch a video explanation like I did) so this isn't too much of a problem. You need to play the game a few times to get a feel for the different strategies and the game becomes more fun as you learn the various cards. Initial rating of 7.

10 plays: I'm reasonably familiar with the game basics now, but I'm not sure I'm enjoying the game any more than before. Stays at 7.
20 plays: Nothing new to add. Remains at 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

However, with the Gathering Storm expansion that allows me to play it solo, I play this game at least once per week, if not more often.  I think it is just fantastic.  There are two mechanics that I love in games: action/role selection with a follow for other players, and cards as resources.  The marriage of those two in this game is BRILLIANT.  Right now it sits in my Top 10, and might just stay there for a good, long while.

RATING: 9
Way too much iconography to be enjoyable with new players, but it's a very fun game with experienced players.

Fast turns even though there's tons of decisions to make each turn. Cards that have a dual function of 'money', the chosen actions of other players, and random card draws make for a continually changing strategy.

I find it much more enjoyable than Roll for the Galaxy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm enjoying this immensely with my wife. A lot of options and plenty of fun choices. I do, however, wish that I wasn't looking forward to the expansion quite as much as I am.

UPDATE after 30 plays: This is getting better and better. I find more viable strategies all of the time. Two days ago I won with 6 cards in my tableau (diversified economy, no 6-developments, alien, gene, and novelty goods (no rare), and a score of 38). At the end I was like, "I can't believe that worked!"

UPDATE after 44 plays: Increased rating to 10. This game really is outstanding. I really do always want to play it. And I really don't expect that to change. Sure there is an investment, sure it's kind of random, sure you might consider it a little pricey, but it's worth it. If I owned 5 games that offered this much of a return on my investment (time learning and money), I wouldn't need to buy another game for the rest of my life (I was born in 1981 so it could be quite a while). The replayability is huge. There are many 'true' paths to victory. Gameplay is deep, fast, and satisfying. And skill is WAY more important than any luck factor in determining the winner.

Still playing new strategies on plays 26 and 27 - seems like this one has some staying power!

UPDATE: With about 100 plays of RftG (several are logged under their expansion instead of the base game), I still feel like I'm new to the game.  The people I tend to play with all have much more experience with the game and are more familiar with individual cards and strategies, so I don't win much.  I feel much less certain about what angle to take with certain hands, so it's hard to know when I've played well.  It's still very fun to try to put things together, though.

RATING: 8.25
Great card game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The Good: A very well-put-together game, with some clever ideas and many different strategies balanced with each other.
The Bad: The cards are filled with icons that are difficult to keep straight -- after at least 6 games, I still have to look things up in the rule book repeatedly.  I picked up Agricola and Caylus with no trouble at all, so I think it means something when I say that THIS is the only one in recent years that has been complex enough to put me off.  This is especially frustrating for a game this short:  You need to have your strategy developed within a few turns, so you can race for the endgame.  And because everyone's cards have a mix of different abilities, it's difficult to keep track of what everyone else has done.  I end up just focusing on my own strategy and hoping that no one else is getting too far ahead (and just trusting that everyone is interpreting their own cards correctly).

I enjoy playing it from time to time, as long as it's not too often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
My wife and I both loved San Juan as our preferred 2p game. I gave this one a try because the mechanics are similar and the theme is more interesting to me. The result is that this immediately usurped San Juan. This is a great game with an amazing amount of depth for being nothing more than cards. The iconography was confusing at first (as it is for many), but after our first game we both felt very comfortable playing. The games are quick enough that we can easily get in 3 games in one sitting.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Possibly the most replayable game ever. It certainly is for me. I've played it hundreds of times face to face. Thousands if I include games against Keldon's wonderful AI.

For a card game with, depending on the number of expansion used, a large number of cards and some proneness to running in streaks I'm always amazed by just how skill based this game really is. And how it rewards repeat play and thoughtful analysis. There seems to be clearly delineated levels of skill in this game. There are folks out there I can beat most of the time, some who I just trade games with and others still who can beat me just about every time out.

It's also amazing just how different this game is at 2 players versus 3 and then again at 4+. 3er is the most challenging, interactive mode requiring that players skillfully anticipate and use their opponents' phase calls to their advantage and deny those they're hoping for.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've lately been calling it "The Game You Have to Play Twice".  I almost have to play it just to get the desire out of my system.  My core gaming group loved San Juan back when it first came out, but I think we eventually tired it out when we realized there are really only good 2 paths to victory.  Race retains the same fun of San Juan, but feels so much more expanded.  Also, the simultaneous role choosing adds an aspect I really like; having to read your opponents to try to gain the most advantage for yourself.  My favorite move is to play Consume (Trade) when I have no goods out and get someone else to play Settle for my windfall world.  Good times!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A quick, thematic hand management/engine building game.

The game flows extremelly well and hits a golden middle in complexity/depth. This results in a fun, highly addictive game with minimum downtime. The theme works very well which is a feat really, while the feeling of accomplishment/growth dominates. Simultaneous action selection is perfectly implemented.

Interaction is subtle and rather low, and revolves around taking advantage of your enemies' needs and rushing the game to end. Now this sounds more interesting than it really is, as the game is just barely above the multiplayer solitaire level. In addition your random starting planet defines your available strategies and this is restricting, though thematic. Finally there is some luck in this game, but it is certainly not dominating. The neccessary iconography/complexity makes this a gamers game and difficult to introduce to new players. Not all strategies are equal, some are harder without equal reward.

Despite its flaws I like this game. It's both fun and fast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game who's mechanical brilliance is matched only in how totally it fails to convey any of its theme. The Gamer's game of 2007 and thus played to death by everyone, it still holds up today.

RATING: 10
Rating up to 10 with Gathering Storm expansion (I'd probably give it a 9 on its own because it's not quite as balanced without the expansion).  While there is something to be said for the simplicity of San Juan I have, after a number of plays, come to prefer Race for the Galaxy of the two Puerto Rico derived card games.  There is a learning curve for all the iconography, but if you power through the first two games, it becomes a very fast play that is highly addictive.  I think it plays slightly better with 2 or 4 than with 3, but is still great at any number.  

After playing with the Gathering Storm expansion I now consider that to be a critical addition to the game.  It not only provides a great deal more variety in starting worlds but does some crucial balancing of the strategies in the game (mainly by helping others and diluting the blue and brown production strategies that are a bit overpowered in the base game).

Rating by number of players:
2 players:  10
3 players:  9
4 players:  10

RATING: 7
What I like:

-A good quick fun game. Even though it's short, it still feels satisfying and fulfilling. It doesn't sacrifice strategy for this either. This is usually very hard to accomplish. 


What I dislike:
-Action selection where you are dependent upon what others do. I don't want to spent my whole game primarily looking and guessing what you might do and try to plan for that. It's fun to some extend, but this mechanic is just too much.
-The symbols are a pain to learn and teach. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Its better than San Juan.  Thats not saying much for me because I dislike San Juan.  The unique cards and the simultaneous action selection are a nice change.  My opinion of the game is improving as the icons are making more sense.  The last game took on a different flavor as a quick rush strategy was employed(barely successfully).  I am enjoying it right now, but I do wonder how many plays it will hold up.  I can't see this being as endlessly replayable as many do, but I hope it holds more than the 10 plays San Juan held up for me.

It took 4 plays before the light bulb clicked and I could put together a strategy.  

I played this game as a teaching session with open hands and slow slow play.  It took 1.5 hours, but my opponent figured out the game well enough to tie me in the second matchup.  This game really showed how rich and deep the hand management is in the game.  The role selection(at least in the non advanced game) is mostly trivial, but the richness of the hand management saves it.  That is the biggest difference for me in this game vs. San Juan.  San Juan's role selection is roughly similar, but the hand management in San Juan was far less situational and good cards are always good cards.  RFTG incorporates different values for the cards for the strategy one is incorporating.  Some cards are usual strong plays, very few are never strong plays, and most are situational good plays which just makes me happy. I strongly dislike San Juan after I "figured" it out, but I am still enjoying Race after my meager 50 plays.

There is just so much to explore.  The strategy of maximizing each of the 6 point development cards, each resource specialization, multi resource specialization, rushing with military, and developments.  Slower military, plus hybrids, plus things I have not even thought of yet..
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Gotta say it...I like Glory to Rome so much better.

RATING: 4

These card games are both just boring to me.  Hand management and card combinations are not mechanics that interest me, and they're not any quicker than board games, so I'd generally just rather be playing a board game instead.

RATING: N/A
I can see how this game is enjoyable for many people.  Unfortunately I desire at least moderate player interaction in a game, and this requires absoutely none.  The single interactive factor of the entire game is trying to figure out what other phases of the game that the other players will allow you to take advantage of.  Otherwise, it's one large game of solitaire, trying to build an interesting combo on your own side of the table.  It's not a BAD game, it's just not at all interactive.

RATING: 8.5
Reacting to your draw in the early game is key, no point hoping that your strategy for military will work out just because you started with a military advantage. Also reading your opponent and judging which stages they will play this turn is important.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A blast to play and always seems to be competitive.

Tough to figure out on the first play, but then it is all biscuits and gravy from there.

Fast gameplay, lots of ways to win, cool theme. My favorite thing about the game is how the cards "make sense."  The stats aren't arbitrary, and sort of tell a little story.  For example, Old Earth produces nothing but can consume at a rapid rate, while the Expedition Force allows you to explore faster and adds military strength to your empire.  

The only thing that really takes points off from me is the tough entry-point for people who haven't played this kind of game before.  The game has its own "vocabulary", and the symbols of the cards take some getting used to. I also wish there was more player interaction, but it is a minor gripe at this point.  

The Advanced Two-Player variant in the manual is excellent, and I highly reccomend it once you're familiar with the basic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
These types of card games aren't my favorite genre, but this is fun enough.  Learning the iconography is a bit of a learning curve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

4 plays - last March 2010

RATING: 10

Extremely steep learning curve in my opinion but once we got it we have had a blast playing together. Amazingly fun game with lots of strategy to try out and room to improve ones game. Definitely need an experienced player to help you learn this one though, seriously it will make it much easier than to just jump in on your own.

RATING: 4
Tanga. First impression is that it's boring. Seems to be Puerto Rico with worse bits, less player interaction, and a big dose of random card draws.

And the theme is weak. How are robots a "planet" to settle? The goods are represented by putting cards face down on top of a planet card of one of four colors, which felt abstract, giving me trouble in trying to memorize what any of them were and what their relative worth was.

RFTG feels like a parody of simplistic bottleneck management euros, where you're typically concerned with short-term calculations and tactics. The random card draws ensure it can't be much more than this.

You want to know why it is called "Race" for the Galaxy, play the game, after about 7 cards in you will be saying oh mann am I going to have enough turns to get there...

RATING: 9.5
This game has a very steep learning curve.  The rule book does not help this at all and the cheat sheet looks like something from an engineering textbook.  However, once you get past that and the icons start making sense, and the game 'clicks', all the 'work' learning it pays off.  

This is easily in my top ten games of all time.  I think it especially shines as a two player although 3 and 4 are also nice.  I love the theme, the options, the card decisions, the race aspect.  

It is called a multi-player solitaire game by some which I can kind of understand, but really suggests that when they play those players don't look at all at what other players are doing or are likely to do on their turn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wonderful deck-building card game that I prefer over Dominion and indeed Puerto Rico from which this game derives. If you haven't played Puerto Rico or San Juan then the learning curve to begin with is rather high; indeed, we struggled with the rules to begin with but after a few plays it all becomes straight forward. I enjoy the amount of chance involved in finding cards in the deck; sometimes you may not see one certain card for many plays as cards are used as buildings, currency and goods. Interaction is very minimal also, however this is something our group actually likes. Downtime is usually quite low because people take their turns at the same time. However, I feel the 2-player variant is the best way to play this game as being able to play two actions a turn does make the game feel more snappy and enjoyable. Especially with the expansions the deck can get rather large and cumbersome to shuffle, which is why our group play a variant where we do not shuffle the starting worlds back in - how come this is not a variant rule in the game?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played on BGA

RATING: 6
I'm glad I did not buy this game.  (All my friends own it.)  I've played it maybe 10-15 times now, and although I liked it the first 3-5 plays, it has become very boring to me.  The "race" aspect is the problem.  You just feel like you have to play a card too often to keep up with the other players.  San Juan had the same issue, but for some reason it was not as much of a problem for me.
I'm not saying this is bad, it's just that I'd rather play Glory To Rome, or to a lesser degree, San Juan.
I'm hopeful that the 5-player expansion will make this more fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There are so many options and so many combos. The gameplay is short, and once you've learned the game, it's easy. It works great for 2 players. What more could I want?

I'm tempted to push this rating above a 9, which I've only done with one other game - Dominion. I need to get another several plays in before making that decision. I wanted to wait until I had about 30 plays under my belt before deciding to raise the rating. I decided not to raise my rating above a 9. Here's why:

Luck. There are some unstoppable combos if someone gets lucky draws. By the same coin, luck can hose you pretty bad on your card draws. Military can be TOO powerful if someone draws all of it. Free worlds? What's not to like? Especially if they're alien military worlds...

If luck didn't feel like such a powerful force in this otherwise tactically pleasing game, I might raise my rating. Additionally, I've found that nobody requests this game because it's too mentally taxing to learn, especially during lunch breaks at work, when the players want to relax.

On the other hand, this has become one of (if not THE) my wife's favorite games. She always wants to play. I tell the guys at work that they'll enjoy it once they play a bunch, but the trick is getting them to reach that level...

UPDATE: I don't think I like this quite as much as I once did, but it's still fun. I have just as much fun with San Juan. I think it bothers me that RftG has some very obvious power-strategies (alien, military) that are much easier to accomplish than other strats (blue stuff).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After 20 games I still find this very addictive and amazing game.

Only downside is that this isn't a easy game to learn. But once you have learnt it's pretty fast game to play. About 20 minutes / 2 player game.

My favourite game right now.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Intellectually pristine. A dizzying richness of choice to build an interlocking tableau that once in a while is exquisite (ie: superb strategy, lovely metagame) or it's more a brain suck-candy of rapid torrent of micro decisions that collapses into an ending just in time. Or both. It nails something difficult to describe.

I tried hard not to like it, I shouldn't if I tick off the things that get me charged up about card & boardgames. I held off giving not a 10, ranging between 5 and 9, back & forth. I should not love it. Well, it's fantastic. Even it's aesthetics & backstory work, theres a shiny intelligence & adult mind in it's maker that shows through, and that carries through in every expansion, which are not corruptions but stay true to it's brilliant ideas & riffs off of them. It grows on you & after years now is a growing classic of original design. Even it's sci-fi theme is done artfully rather than childishly, usually stuff like this turns me off (I'm not a space opera nor hard science-fi, more Gene Wolfe or M. John Harrison type of guy).

I haven't played with goals; straight 2-player advanced only. So truly there's much more for me to know in terms of modulating it's pace. Even with 100s of plays.

*

The solo robot is terrific tho fiddly, I wish there was a different way to do it & maybe I need to invent my own metronome to play solo (it's worth getting that dialed in, this would be the best solo card game ever if this could be perfected, but damned if I know how). I do not play computer games, nor all these solo apps coming out these days, except a bit of cribbage to catch up my skills & shake off rust. But Keldon's AI & this intelligent & endlessly re-playable game are utter crack. That form is likely best stayed away from truthfully, theres nothing worse than a face hypnotized by a screen, but this one is either worth it or the worse crack ever invented & it will destroy civilization. It's that good.

RATING: 8.5
Terrific game. Iconography is very clean. Learning curve is steep-- it's not a hard game to learn how to play, but hard to learn how to play well. Not only do you need to build up an engine to get points/build cards, but you have to work on running down the game's "clock" while you're still ahead. A whole lot of game in a very short space. The two-player experienced game is my preferred version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Best 2-3p
30m
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Based on 2 player experiences only:

I love, love, love RFTG.  And so does my wife.  When we first bought the game, and she was relatively new to tabletop gaming, there was clearly no expectation that this would become a staple.  The theme was a bit of a turnoff to her, and I prefer high fantasy to sci-fi, but this didn't matter.  

The game is similar to San Juan, another one of our favorites, but certainly has a lot of depth/complexity that San Juan has without much more time involved.  Both are great games and it depends on our mood.  San Juan is easy to bring out over breakfast or a cup of coffee; RFTG is better for an evening after the kids go to bed. 

2 player is the way to go in this!

Some complain about the iconography; I would disagree.  It's really very simple to figure out, and for the one or two icons that I would agree are.. less than clear, the game comes with a good guide to answer your question.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this game.  I love managing the chaos and luck of the draw.  I love finding the synergies of cards in my hand with those on the table.  I love the quick play.  I'd rather play RftG than just about anything else.  This game is a 10.  

The 1st expansion makes the game even better.  It provides better balance between build and consume strategies, adds more variety in starting, and adds the extra complexity of goals.  Too bad I cannot rate it an 11!

I have become less enamoured with the goals.  It seems that they add further randomness to the game.  For instance, the most military goal strongly favors a military strategy, but if I never see the approprite cards, that goal is inaccessible.  There is already high variability in strategies based on the cards seen, and this exacerbates the problem, making too otherwise equivalent strategies unequivalent because of their ability to reach the randomly drawn goals.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun game but brutal to teach.  Seems pretty deep but I have not been eager to invest the time.

RATING: 9
Tentative rating after six plays (expected to rise after more). The game has a lot going for it: Many ways to score, great combo-possiblities, very little downtime due to simultaneous actions. It's like a gamer's version of San Juan. Unfortunately, I do not care for the artwork -- it is rather dull, especially when compared to most of the CCGs out there. Or even, again, San Juan. The times I played with more than two players, I did like it a bit better btw. 
Finally, I had an experienced gameplayer give up half through a game because the icons still confused him. Learning curve can be steep for some.
UPDATE: My 14 year old son did not have any difficulty grasping the rules. We now play with the 2-player variant for experienced players as well as the cards from the first expansion. After all these years I return to this game and find it to be better than most new games I recently played. Very addictive!

RATING: 5
My first play of this was an utter disaster. I was taught by someone who had only previously played once before; which meant that she had no idea what all the icons meant and didn't understand all the cards.

A second teaching game wouldn't happen till a year later, and finally understanding all the icons, it was a curious experience. I've since played it numerous times against the AI, losing miserably as I tried to come to grasp with the strategies. 

It's been an interesting journey but not something entirely enjoyable. The AI is good, which has made it quite a steep learning curve but I keep wondering where the fun is. Sure it's entertaining when I win against the AI, but there are times I feel like I've been lucky. Drawing that 6 cost development card, or 7 cost military planet just in the nick of time to secure a win. The most thematic part of this game is the military strategy; everything else is a bit of a wash. 

What's the difference between this game and Innovation which I really enjoy? The fact that in Innovation, almost every ability is broken in the right circumstances and you set yourself up to take advantage of the cards that are coming up - the cards coming up are set within a band of varying effects. You can't do that in Race for the Galaxy, you set yourself up and sometimes you get there, sometimes you don't. It's a real lack of control.

Would I recommend this game? Sure? It's okay. 

At least noone can say I didn't give this game a fair shake.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this game for its combination of high complexity and short length. It condenses the economic engine-building experience of a longer eurogame into a playing time of half an hour - it never outstays its welcome like, say, Ora et Labora. 

Despite the "multiplayer solitaire" criticism that has often been leveled against it, the game does have quite a bit of interaction in deducing what phases your opponent will select and leeching off of them. RftG really does feel like a race, with each player rushing to force the end of the game while they're ahead. The tension is palpable.

Elegant, fast, and extremely re-playable. Highly recommended.

Edit: I've just about stopped recording my plays of this - there are too many, too often. Upped to a ten.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Takes all the best elements of Puerto Rico and adds a decent amount more. Best short-length game for multiple people out there today.

RATING: 10

Only negatives:

- tough for newbie/non-gamers to learn
- some may be turned off by the lack of direct player interaction

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
Love this game.  Hits this very special niche where it is easy to play any time in any mood.  Even when brain dead after work.  Once you learn the system it becomes quick and easy to play.  Yet the card variety offers so much depth that you can still find new strategies and combos.  Each game plays very differently.  So much replayability in this game.  It takes about 5 games to learn how all of the system interact and another 5 to learn how to manipulate them and to start figuring out the good cards.  Please push through this learning curve.  There is a very beautiful game underneath.

RATING: 8
Quick setup. Lots of strategic depth. Lots of viable ways to win. Feels like Puerto Rico "light", better than San Juan. Less turn-based, because everyone is essentially playing at the same time..so games go quickly. Can turn around three 2player games in an hour. Highly recommended and it just gets better with the expansions! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Pros: simultaneous action selection mechanic, hand management with tableau building, variable strategies with moderate degree of luck, engine building, quick playtime

Cons: limited winning strategies that consistently perform, other strategies situational and luck-dependent, no direct player interaction; confusing iconography when learning the game

A great strategy card game for those who enjoy building engines. Can be a little fiddly to simultaneously manage your hand, your action card pool, and your tableau--that combined with a fairly steep learning curve as one gets to know individual cards and strategies (not to mention the iconography!) may turn one off from this game. However, if you can get past that in the initial dozen plays (and those plays go fast!), you will find a rewarding game. My experience is mostly limited to two-player games, though, so I cannot comment on the higher player counts. Regardless, it is a well-balanced game that has just the right amount of luck for my tastes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A quick play after you get a few games under your belt. Like Shogun, it seems like you are just getting yourself organized when the game is over. That's the interesting part: you have to decide what you are doing and not get sidetracked by other strategies and paths of development. Each draw of cards can lead you to rethink what your grand plan is. On the other hand, you have to stay somewhat flexible and diversified because you may never get the cards you need to win the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Very solid card game that takes a bit of time to learn the mechanics and much more time to learn every card and the relative strengths they offer.  As a result, it is a particularly effective game when all or almost all players are new to it and can continue to play it multiple times as they all learn and adapt and try new strategies.  Gameplay during learning is vastly different from when comfortable.  Comfortable players can finish a game in about 10 minutes.

RATING: 10
This and San Juan are my only 10s. Of these, RftG is the "hot" game, but generally I'd choose which to play based on who I was playing with. I have taught SJ to new players (including non-gamers) and in general they understood and enjoyed it from the outset, whereas RftG is harder to get into.  Also, while I agree that the (unexpanded) RftG is far from "multiplayer solitaire", I do find role selection in SJ to be more pleasingly interactive.

Update: it's now more than a year now since I last played San Juan, while RftG I have played A Lot. Dominion is now also a 10.

RATING: 9
Race for the Galaxy plays fast (with a little experience) and rewards flexibility. The game provides agonising choices on what to keep and what to discard. It's a great game with play as a warm up, in between games or to wind down, and plays equally well with any numbers of people.

The downside is the iconography which occasionally turns people off, and makes each person's first game a state of constant confusion.
