RATING: 10
Yes, it do remind me to San Juan.
Compared to it, it lacks the option to choose the timing of the actions (exploring is always before settling, for example).

But it adds so much to San Juan, that I prefer it to it nevertheless:
- different strategies (compared to the common guild hall)
- different production "buildings" (production/windfall worlds)
- great icons to see the abilities of cards on one glance

Maybe this one goes down for me after a dozens plays more, but I doubt it.

RATING: 9.5
Excellent card game.  So many ways to play and so many ways to win.  This is one of the only games in which I like the random element.  Adaptability is everything in this game, and the game gives you the tools to implement new adaptations in strategy.  Even though the cards eventually sway the tide, more often than not, your success will be because of an ability and insight to ride that tide, instead of being swept under.  Bonus points for not being a CCG (although numerous expansions slightly detracts from this bonus).  This is probably the highest score I will ever give to a card game, and it is richly deserved.

RATING: 10
Favorite game of all time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
San Juan in space with a whole lot of stuff going on.  This is another Puerto Rico card game re-themed for space.  Cards are everything except VPs.  In this game they actually added counters for victory points and running out is one of the end game conditions.  You buy/conquer planets (producers) or developments (buildings).  Goods are consumed for cards and/or victory points.  You get to select a single game phase (trade) and you get the bonus for that phase.  A major difference is multiple people can select the same game phase.  There's a ton of stuff going on and lots of decisions to be made.  I fully expect this game will advance to a 10 with further play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yikes, I've "invested" quite a bit of time playing this game and all it's expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
To be fair to this game, I really don't care for it's inspiration ([gameid=3076]), so this game was fighting an uphill battle from the start if I was ever going to like it.  The people who like this game seem to want to play it all the time, but I have yet to see anything but the driest of efficiency engines.  Pick stuff that benefits you and not others, railroad yourself into a very artificial strategy based on an artificially constrained role-selection mechanism, and basically stay far away from any kind of thematic ties. I was hoping that the space theme would show through somehow, even though this was a VP engine game.  My hope was in vain.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Having played San Juan, learning the basic flow of this game was a little easier than I expected after a quick view of the cards and the player aid.   This will be a staple at our game store group for a long time.  Quick game play, scales well from 2 to 4 players, most people like it and will play it.  It has a "bushy" decision tree and can seem overwhelming at first, however kind of like a foreign language - once you can decipher the symbols on the cards easily the game plays much easier and strategy can develop a little easier.  I still don't "get" the consume trade and consume x 2 as much as I should.

RATING: 9.5
I can already tell that my wife and I will be able to enjoy this game for many years to come. The iconography was certainly daunting at first, but I feel like the player aids and the rulebook do a fantastic job of distilling it into relatively easy-to-understand pieces. The array of potential winning combinations seems boundless. While the game isn't as thematic as some of the other games in our collection, I definitely appreciated the artwork, and I enjoyed some of the humorous touches (Galactic Resort, anyone?). An extremely pleasing addition to our collection.

RATING: N/A

 

[Played 11 times]

Nice game, but it has no place for me. If I want a game full of different cards with endless interactions, I've Magic. If I want a similar idea, but with simpler execution (thus more accessible to newbies), I've San Juan. "Race for the Galaxy" is a sort of middle ground I simply do not need.

Extremely light interaction and quite long learning curve due to the many cards and the abstruse myriads of symbols (that also failed to make it language independent, since there's text here and there too!).

The sci-fi theme and the bland artwork do nothing for me as well.
Pricey.

UPDATE: tried again (two year later) and it felt a needlessly overcomplicated San Juan.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent card game with deep strategy involved and various paths towards victory. Very convenient that all the card actions are drawn as symbols and very short descriptions right on the cards themselves. It might be useful to keep a spreadsheet at your hands with all the mweanings/explanations of the various symbols for ease of play. Otherwise the game plays really fast and is very interactive. One play may last around 20 minues for 2 - 3 players once you know all the rules.

Of course the play time will increase with other expansions icnluded (e.g. "Rebel vs Imperial"). It will also add to the strategic variation and complexity of the game.

All in all this is one of my most favorite games I have. I like the "RftG" better than "Dominion". It's really, really fun to play. And the fact that you see your empire growing right in fron of your eyes just makes you feel more powerful and dnagerous... Choose who you want to be - builder, alien, military or anything else or a combination of everything.

RATING: 9
UPDATED: Gave the game another chance using a tutorial video and the Keldon AI after putting it up for trade. Once I got past my incomprehension and the offputting cards, I love it.

I bought RftG as a gift for my husband and wish I hadn't. We mostly play two-player and I'd rather play anything else. It simply wasn't fun.

I found it hard to learn due to confusing/odd icons and unthematic mechanics. When I learned how to play, it felt surprisingly non-interactive. I'm sure there is some way to use the action selection mechanic (you select an action each turn and your opponent does the same one) to screw your opponent. I was too bored to find it.

The card stock is thin, the box was disappointingly empty of content, and the art is ugly.

RATING: 10
exceptional card game. my initial impressions of this game when i had first played it at a board game night were rather indifferent almost negative. it seemed abstract the theme seemed detached and i could not shake the feeling that no one knew what they where doing. months later, without having another opportunity to play the game, i got it! it all became clear in hindsight. the mechanics are a masterwork the symbols are excellent and clear the theme fits and welcomes you into a world of possibilities. i believe this is an all time great. atleast for me. very much enjoy finding a "mature" game of this nature.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Worst "game" I have ever played. Avoid at all cost.
"You need to play it 10-20 times before you get it and can start to enjoy it".
No I won't - I'll just play some other, good, actual games 10-20 times. Rubbish.

FreeCell + Rock-Paper-Scissors with boring generic sci-fi theme. Extremely solitaire, random and obscure. Essentially just a puzzle trying to get the most out of a random sequence of cards with the absolute only "interaction" being looking at the other players' played cards and number of cards in hand to guess which of the 5 roles they choose to get you an extra free action. Absolutely nothing you do affects other players except that they cannot get the cards you have played (and "my best action would be X but my opponents may guess that that so I will do Y, instead"). Assuming equally skilled players, the winner will simply be the one who draws the best, random cards. Add to that poorly designed, unnecessarily obscure iconography which makes the game directly hostile to new/casual players; and the need to learn the hundreds of different cards and card combinations to do well. As a solitaire, smartphone app or PC game, it could be an alternative time-killer/waster to FreeCell etc. It is a puzzle, not a game. AVOID!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Explore, Settle, Develop, Trade, Consume, or Produce? Which do you need the most? Which of Earth's former colonies will be most successful at settling the galaxy, now that JumpDrive exists? RATING: 8.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
On the one hand, it is similar enough to San Juan to keep my interest.  On the other hand, it's overly complicated on the first play, and it's possible for newbs to flounder through the first game to get a grasp of exactly how the game flows.  It's not as intuitive as San Juan, mainly due to its complexity, but the shine becomes apparent even before that first game is over.  By the second and third games, the strategies start to reveal themselves.  After more plays, you can fly through the turns like you're passing through a yield sign instead of a stop sign.  It's a little bit like peeling an onion, though without the crying.

Well ... depending on the game group, there MIGHT be crying.

If you're playing 2-player, it's almost necessary to play with the advanced selection cards.  There's enough of a game for two with the basic roles,  but it really improves when you include the subtlety of multiple actions each turn.

Speaking of subtleties, the interaction in this game is such.  The player who can best read the others and anticipate what they will do on a given turn will play the better game, as will the player who understands that consumption is a required action.  Players who aren't afraid to force others to sell their goods before they're ready will play the better game, as well.

12 plays: 2 players
10 plays: 2 players (advanced game)
19 plays: 3 players
12 plays: 4 players
3 plays: 5 players

-----

Base game
Brink of War
Gathering Storm
Rebel vs. Imperium

RATING: 5
The best thing about this game is that it's short.

The random selecting of which phases you're allowed to vote for is a terrible mechanic and simply shouldn't exist.  Doesn't make any sense that one player could randomly have their 2 duplicate cards discarded and another player could lose the ability to trade or vote for production, or both.

Aside from that, there's not really any connection to the other players aside from the vote on phases, so it feels a lot like every player is in a game of solitaire and then at the end you see who got the best card draw.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In Race for the Galaxy, players build galactic civilizations by game cards that represent worlds or technical and social developments.
\13\\13\
Each turn each player chooses one action, but the others will share in the actions chosen, each player secretly and simultaneously chooses one of seven different action cards and then reveals it. Only the selected phases occur. For these phases, every player performs the phase’s action, while the selecting player(s) also get a bonus for that phase.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is awesome! I love just how many decisions the designers managed to cram into such a relatively short playtime. The key here is that even though there are tons of difficult decisions, everyone is playing simultaneously. The result is that the game is compact and wonderfully diverse. My only gripe is that it's a real pain to teach this to casual gamers - even stuff like Agricola is more accessible. Still, once the learning is over, this is an amazing game that I hope to be playing many years into the future.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Fast game that is also great for 2 players. The first couple of plays you have to get used to the different icons and after that you can start exploring which strategies there are to win this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Race for the Galaxy is one of those rare games in which each play is better than the last. The icon system is a well documented nightmare (I still feel like there had to be better way) but once you clear that hurdle, its depth of strategy is astounding. It borrows a ton of mechanics from San Juan, (So many in fact, that learning Race for the Galaxy is much easier if you are familiar with it's little brother...) yet develops them so fully that it becomes a completely different (and better) game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a great game in its own right; I know many people who have played this and loved it without experiencing Puerto Rico. However, I did play both PR and SJ before this, so it's hard for me to think of this independently of them. There are some things I think it does better than PR; I like how quickly it plays, how you're never totally barred from taking the action you desperately need, and how the theme resonates a bit more (at least for me). On the other hand, every few games you get someone who starts out strong and fizzles because the cards they need just don't come (also a weakness in SJ, but not PR) and the iconography is really difficult for non-gamers to decipher (particularly military vs. non-military placements). Still, it's a lot of fun, and the more I play it, the more I appreciate the strategies, which is always better than the other way around.

Update: That last sentence was true for a while, but it got a bit stale eventually. I feel like the production strategy is too strong unless you get a really great military hard. Still not a bad game, but no longer one I'd seek out when there are better options.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Vroenis Masters Award winner.

2 - [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/5p/user/Vroenis]5 players[/url] (with expansion).
Teaching: 45 - 75 minutes. 
Mastery: 30 - 45 minutes. 
Medium box.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geektag.php?tags=embassy_%26_outpost&username=Vroenis&action=usertags]Embassy_&_Outpost[/url] 

Simultaneous action selection. 
Card drawing. 
Hand management.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/cards_as_currency/user/Vroenis]Cards as currency[/url]. (Cards function as both usable features & expendable resources). 
Tableau building. 
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/race/user/Vroenis]Race[/url] to get 12 cards down or all VP tokens. 
Medium weight (initially heavy). 
Low-medium theme application.
Low player interaction. 
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/theme_sci-fi/user/Vroenis]Sci-fi theme[/url].

Fair warning, a person's first game of RFTG is punishingly cruel & barely makes sense. Nevertheless, one game is usually enough to see the brilliant dynamic hiding behind all those hieroglyphics. In short order, there's a moment when everything clicks & those hieroglyphics make absolute sense.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pretty empty box, but linen-textured cards and nice player aids.  A clear improvement on San Juan, throwing in a little Puerto Rico as well.  The simultaneous selection is rich but not time-consuming.  Card variety is great, as are plenty of "hooks" for new powers (as befits a CCG lineage), where I'm sure the expansion will bring the game into its own.  I kind of wish the developments weren't duplicated.  Love the vastly more interesting (than SJ) 6-cost devs.

Draw luck can hit pretty hard early on.  It's an uphill climb if you simply can't take advantage of your strengths, esp. if your opponents don't suffer similarly.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a great, fast game.  The symbology presents a bit of a learning curve, but if you've played Puerto Rico, San Juan or a similar game, it should make sense pretty quickly.

Regarding the theme, I really don't understand the complaints that it is pasted on here.  Sure, it is a game that could be rethemed with some work.  But every card's abilities fit perfectly with its title, the artwork is great, and there are some very clear examples of theme-driven mechanics, most notably, the settle/military dichotomy.  I think it's a great theme, very well executed, and clearly drove aspects of the game's development rather than being pasted on after the fact.

(If you're looking to waste a little time, check out the the little app+AI for this game.  It's great.  I've played several zillion games against it now...)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
[i]Outstanding. Always want to play, expect this will never change.[/i]

Race for the Galaxy is my favourite game of all time. I played the base game 3000+ times and it's always exciting. I'd rather play the original than the new dice version. Unlike many other engine building games, I find it neither dry nor repetitive. The opportunity cost of each choice makes the game engaging and challenging.

RATING: 9
The depth to game length ratio is over the roof here, this is definitely the most complex and intricate economic card game I've ever played. Works beautifully in an advanced 2-player mode (in fact this is where it really shines). The iconography may be daunting at first, but once you understand the language of the game everything becomes a second nature. I love the card management and engine building aspect of this game, it's a great puzzle.

Another big plus for me is the unique artwork on every card - this really helps the theme come through.

[b]/update, February 2018:[/b] "Objectivelly speaking" it's a 10, I've downgraded it to a 9 just because I'm a little burnt out on it after countless online plays. I need a break from this game (it's still a masterpiece in its genre though).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Thank you slow shipping person!  Initial day - Played five straight games in about four hours,  including two teaching sessions (taught by me, who'd only read the rules online beforehand).  Everyone loved it,  and so did I!  Fast, Strategic = Maximal fun-to-gaming time ratio.  In my mind,  equivalent to Puerto Rico and San Juan combined - and would much rather play this than either!  The rating would continue to rise, but it's already at 10 :)Empire building/resource management game in less than an hour - start with minimal abilities but with high power escalation curve.  Diverse strategies to convert money (cards) into points - building an economic engine and point-scoring engine in the process.See my Nitpicker's guides for more details, but in short:  Beautiful art (empty box).  VP chips could be bigger.  Initial curve involves absorbing lots of symbols,  but the payout is a balanced game with incredible strategic depth and multiple paths to victory.  The subtle interaction between players is a bit of a relief - "downstream from the newbie" or "pick on the player" is pretty much gone, and the game is pure racing.I've played this game more than any other game I've bought in 2007 (and I bought it late Nov 2007).  Remains a tough cookie to teach, and everyone finds it a bit overwhelming the first time,  but most are willing to go for the rematch. Or three.  I'm still making mistakes teaching it - gotta remember to not try to teach it from my head.  Head always forgets critical bits.I've put the action cards in hard plastic sleeves.  The main deck has started getting a bit sticky,  so I've tentatively put the rest of the cards in clear soft sleeves.  The deck is a little larger,  trickier to shuffle and it can slip if not stacked carefully, but it seems about as easy to play with as before.Jay said spring 2008 for the expansion!  Woohoo!The Wish List:  Bigger - larger VP chips,  larger (say Blue Moon sized) cards with larger text (and text on all cards explaining powers).  I love the icons,  but the decoder sheet is definitely rough on newbies.

RATING: 7
Really enjoyable, fast game. I've played it a lot at this point (20+ games) and I've decided that I can't keep both this one and San Juan and San Juan wins between them for my money. The main reason for this is that RftG feels more like a solitaire game with the phase selection mechanism, whereas with San Juan when it's your turn you are able to select something that makes sense for you over others (you can kind of do this in RftG and good play means selecting correctly, but I find a lot of the time we are just playing in parallel instead of "against" each other). Now that I feel I've explored the strategy space I am kind of done unless I buy into the expansions, and I don't think it's really good enough to do that.

RATING: 7
This was originally on my wish list for Essen and then dropped off as I had read it was like a more complex san juan. But after having the pleasure of seeing the game and having Tom Lehman (patiently) teach it to us. It immediately shot to my must buy list. Initially the number of icons on the cards, and trying to form any viable strategy on my first game, my head was in a spin, plus we took a lot longer than we would to play once familiarity sets in. While I probably don't recommend it for casual gamers, for the gamers among us, I had a blast! The artwork is stunning, there's a myriad of decisions, and quite frankly, blows san juan right outta the water! I'm looking forward to my next play, with the rating expected to rise.
UPDATE: After purchasing a copy and further plays, it's gone up a point. There are many many different ways to win, plays very quickly, scales well. This game *has* to be one of the most played, wonderful games in the last 5 years IMO. Don't be surprised if it makes the coverted 10 list.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There is a one-game learning curve to get the mechanics down, and as they say, a lifetime to learn the strategies.  :-)  One of the favorites for gaming night, because games usually are less than an hour (so we often get two in!), and also because it's fun.

One possible downside: little interaction.  Everyone minds their own tableau, so it's solitaire played in a group.

On the plus side, it has a perfect blend of randomness and strategy, and no single strategy always works, so players must adapt to the cards they are dealt.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Race for the Galaxy's simultaneous selection of roles guarantees that the game has much less player interaction than San Juan.

Thumbs up for the theme.  Thumbs down for a space game where players ignore each other completely until someone wins.  In my first (and last) play, I was twenty minutes into the game before I realized that I hadn't looked at my opponents' playing areas even once.

Oh, and I won because I played a powerful point-generating building. Sigh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played lots of times (with 2 to 4 players - or 5 with a prototype of an expansion). As a fan of San Juan, a former Magic player, and an occasional SF reader, I suppose that I am one of the main targets for this game. The simultaneous action selection makes a large difference with San Juan, although of course one still wants to benefit as much as possible from other players' actions. There is a fair number of strategies, or rather bits of strategies which have to be combined (depending of course on your card draws) in order to win the game. Replayability is very good, and scalability as well (the advanced variant for 2 players adding some more subtlety). Additionally, the artwork is great, which is certainly not needed to make a great game, but definitely doesn't hurt.

RATING: 6
Race can be a very tough game to teach new players with all its symbols. However, once everyone gets a grasp of the rules this game will be the go-to quick game for a long time. Decently balanced game with a good amount of luck and strategy makes most game feel fair and close. Recommend buying at least one of the expansions to keep the game fresh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Race for the galaxy is a real race:
Fast, furious, full of outguessing and outmaneuvering of your opponents. At times it can be a bit unpredictable but good player will enjoy fighting against the odds and will be able to benefit from opponents actions. 

You need a strategy and you need to adopt your strategy to a given situation. Making good tactical decisions is a must but without developing a strong strategy it will not win you many games. 

Bottom line: 0.5-1h full of decisions and galactic empire building.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Took me some time to get the various icons down, but the player aid was a great support for me. It was clear from the first games that I didn't have a feel for the right tempo, as I lost those games by about ~10-15 points or so.

I like how you can profit from phase selections other player chose (Something I also like in Puerto Rico) and I like that some have multiple options (like observation having 2 options available, one for keeping more cards while another for searching more deeply for a particular card). I also like the challenge of deciding which cards to discard to play another, or when Exploring a getting nice cards as alternative to what you intended to do.

It seems that foreknowledge of the available cards can help a lot, especially that you know you can search for a particular card or know that you can stop looking for a particular card. Therefore I think experience players have quite the advantage over new player, which might explain the point gap I experienced myself in my first games. Therefore you might want to play more dumb when doing a game with new people the first time if they can get demoralized by this aspect of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
{ P - 2 3 [4] 5 }

Some huge downsides - the luck imbalance of repeatedly drawing cards, excessively solitaire, and the anticipation of opponents' actions (gambling) is somewhat mitigated by fun synergy, great flavor, and wide variance.

Addendum, 1/17/10: Cranked out another hundred or so head-to-head plays (roughly 2-3 minutes per game, just in case that sounded like I was in hibernation) with the Keldon Necropolis A.I. and unfortunately affirmed my inkling that Race is even more of a drawfest than previously thought. Two actions per turn with two players is preferred to avoid bluff, double-bluff annoyances like finagling out a windfall world and hoping an opponent's anticpatory Consume Trade doesn't ruin your plans but said "advanced rules" allow for repeated Consume x2, Produce turns, which can end the game as early as turn 4-5. (e.g. Earth's Lost Colony + Alien Toy Shop, or Alpha Centauri / Ancient Race + any production world + Tourist World) Barring absurd heavy infrastructure draws (perfect military, settling with Replicant/Terraforming Robots, developing with Public Works, Interstellar Bank, Investment Credits), the game is pretty much a matter of lucking into superior production capacity and brutalizing your opponent with Consume x2, Produce. This process ends games so quickly that "traditional" draws with an even split between infrastructure and produce will not routinely see those magic turns 7-8 where exponential expansion doubles their score to the 40-50 range. Alpha Centauri and Ancient Race are the best starting worlds because they are essentially production worlds +3 cards. Specifics:

[b]Banned / Shitlist / Free Win Cards / Whatever[/b]: Alien Toy Shop, Galactic Federation, Terraforming Guild

[b]Second Tier[/b]: Lost Species Ark World, New Earth, Galactic Studios, Tourist World, Galactic Trendsetters, Diversified Economy, Consumer Markets, Mining Conglomerate

[b]Mostly Unplayable[/b]: Export Duties, Trade League, Black Market Trading World, Research Labs

Addendum, 7/12/10: Prestige for the Galaxy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I am in the camp of those who love this game. I had no trouble picking up the iconography... nor do I have an issue with the fact that you can not directly effect/interfere with your adversaries cards. Good players will beat inexperienced players - skill is required - plus knowing the cards (all players) makes for a much better game as the players deal with their hands and try to optimize their strategies. Player choices of roles impact on other players... you always have to adjust - dodge and weave - in reaction to role selection - and try to guess what other may do as you select roles. Good challenging game with LOTS of replay value. San Juan with big hairy balls.

EDIT - lowered rating. Since the computer version came out with its excellent AI I rarely play this F2F anymore. Still an excellent game but i dont really bring it to the table anymore.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Another modern great card game, not a deck construction, instead it's all about choosing actions and the cards to play in every precise moment,it has a lot of thinkig and strategy, a really complex card game with equal opportunities to all the players. And you have interaction, not directly, but you can't forget the others are playing. It has a little luck factor when you draw a card, but it's not so important. 

Otro gran juego moderno de cartas, no de construcción de mazos, en vez de eso es todo acerca de elegir acciones y las cartas que jugarás en cada momento preciso, requiere pensar y tiene un montón de estrategia, un juego realmente complejo con iguales oportunidades para todos los jugadores. Y tienes interacción, no directamente, pero no puedes olvidarte de que los demás juegan. Tiene un pequeño factor de suerte a la hora de robar cartas, pero no es relevante.

RATING: 7.5
Wow! First game last night was the most fun I've ever had in my life!  I wonder if I could get a game going this evening...

[Update] My days have become vast empty tracts of interstellar time between games of "Race for the Galaxy".

Once, during the first few days, one of my daughters heard me recruiting other players, saying "...it's only about 20 minutes long..." She interrupted: Dad its more like 45 minutes."What?" I thought, "that's not possible!" Anyway it doesn't matter; when can we play again?

[Some months later] Okay I'm finally ready to be reasonable about this rating, and I've taken it down a whole integer. It's not as interactive as Dominion, and that really restricts the range of prospective opponents.  Also, lots of friends find the theme alien (figuratively).  So this isn't going to be in the same pantheon as Dominion

[Another Update]  And up the rating goes again. (I've moved it around between 7 and 9.)  I think most BGG people can agree this is an unqualified classic.  And we've been playing it for so many years with such an array of players that it really deserves its status. One of my all-time favourites.

Much better than I thought it would be. I was completely lost the first game, both in trying to decrypt all the icons and in trying to fashion some sense out of the order-of-operations of all the moving parts. That first game was incredibly challenging to form a strategy and feel like I was making any good decisions... Then the lightbulb went off with the second game, which I enjoyed a great deal. Now I can appreciate the attention to detail and design in integrating all those icons and the interwoven abilities and keyword triggers. Clever, fun and great for lunch-time gaming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

+: very fast (and therefore fast to pick up, though it's not easy to learn from the rulebook)
+: others having AP affects game length in a small way
+: many ways of victory
-: steep learning curve so first plays can take long: everyone needs to read and understand each card they're handed
-: quite some randomness through luck with cards (but this can be reduced)
-: expansion needed ($) for interaction: steal planets
-: expansion needed ($) for 5+

RATING: 5
[b]NO PLAYER INTERACTION. NO BATTLES. VERY POOR ICONS.[/b]

Yeah, I know it's a "race" game. Economic snowball game. Pah! This space cardgame was a HUGE wasted opportunity for an all-conquering space opera experience. Maybe it can't ever be what it wasn't designed to be...

Then why, now, are they adding all the interesting bits in endless expansions? Because they know I'm right!

Too little, too late. At least, for me.

Admirable themic ideas ruined by actual gameplay and iconography.
It has won awards for design, you say?
I say: if you have to look up endlessly what an icon means then it's useless as an icon. That's a simple fact.

I don't want to have to play a game a half-dozen times before I, and everyone around the table, knows what the hell they're doin' without having to glance at a crib sheet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I was worried for a long time that Race for the Galaxy would play too similar to San Juan to offer a different experience.  I'm glad that isn't the case.  Beyond a couple of shared mechanics, Race of the Galaxy is a much richer and deeper game in every way.  The initial learning curve is fairly steep, especially since many of the icons and symbols aren't very intuitive, which will require you to refer back to the player aide (which was very well made) very often.

There are plenty of strategies to employ as there are a wide variety of different combinations between the cards.  The simultaneous action selection felt cumbersome at times (especially those prone to AP), but I really like the choices offered as well as the opportunity to bluff your opponents.

Race for the Galaxy is a great game with lots of depth, and I would go as far to say that why play San Juan with you have this.

Update #1: Highest score ever achieved was tonight at 62, it was a combination of Alien world and Military strength.  This has to be the best synergy I've tried, even better than the consume x2/produce engine (which was 43).

Update #2: While I have been playing this a lot, it's all due to the request by others.  I myself, while enjoy the game, will most likely never ask to play since I prefer to try new stuff instead.  The scores haven't been consistent, in fact, I'm at an all-time low at the moment.  The randomness of the draw just hasn't been kind to me, and although it doesn't bother me per se, it does reaffirm the negative feeling that there are just a lot of useless cards once you've decided on a strategy.  I know it's unavoidable in a game with shared deck, but nevertheless it still seem like a poor design.

Update #3: For some reason the 2-player variant felt pretty different and in some instances even more strategic.  It did sort of breathed new life into the game for me, and I think would be something I don't mind playing at all (usually I avoid stuff restricted to just 2-player, having only one opponent isn't very appealing for me).

Update #4: Took off 0.5 from my original rating as of 4/8/08.  I will still play it when it is requested, and I do find that my strategies are more refined.  However, the game plays pretty much the same time after time.  It is inevitable as a non-collectible card game, and I do not see any viable variant to make the experience different.  I'm not sure if that will cause the score to further devalue as time goes on, but the newness to it has definitely wore off.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is, as many have said, a more intricate cousin of San Juan.  I'm itching to play it some more, but I currently have some concerns about how opportunistic (namely, luck of the draw) it might be.  Examples:  I mined for cards a lot, and throughout the whole game, drew merely two - yes, two - cards that could provide military.  So, clearly, I couldn't pursue military.  I drew only two cards that could provide genes, and one of those was exclusively a windfall planet.  I had two shots at alien tech, one at novelty, and enough rare elements cards to do some stuff with them.  In other words, I had constant tough decisions, but I had extremely little choice about what I could pursue.  It seemed that the best strategy was to specialize in something, and cash in on that; however, what if you end up with a smattering of everything?  Remember, I was drawing a good number of cards, thanks in part to my developments - little thanks to my poor production potential.

Nonetheless, I suspect that with experience, you see clearer paths through the chaos.  I yearn for that experience.

RATING: 9.5

Update:  I play this about once a week now with a buddy of mine.  He has mentioned that it might be his favorite game of all time.  To me that is quite the statement after only a handful of plays, but I won't deny that I enjoy it.  I still feel like I have just scratched the surface with this one.

Update:  I had been dreading teaching this to my in-laws.  My brother-in-law bought it for them without knowing much about it.  I was worried because of all the icons.  It actually went well.  They still struggle with it though.

GG: Best Card Game-2008

MC-2007

RATING: 7
Intriguing. The rules are very simple, but the iconography makes it difficult to teach - and play for the first time. The icons are clear, but feel like a mess at first. Newbies catch on fast, though. The game can be fast and has a high random factor, but there is strategic depth and awesome combinations. More than anything, there's always a need to play one more game. Very addictive. Bad luck with card draws suck, of course, but card games are like that I suppose.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Our new favourite 2-player game – fast, science fiction and (brilliant) economy – a rare and perfect blend. One can really appreciate the design so I don't see why the designer tends to be a bit sensitive and hot-headed when polemicizing on BGG. I would even go as far as to say that this is the greatest game design-wise I ever encountered, although that would probably be unfair since it is a derivation of sort from San Juan/Puerto Rico. Also – hadn't had any problems with symbols and teaching, didn't even had card-specific dilemmas as was the case with Android Netrunner.

I could play this one whole night - such a perfect game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After 100+ Plays: Well, I've played this over 100 times now before finally getting around to rating it, so I think my opinion is pretty firm by now.  I was unimpressed after my first play, thinking a would prefer to stick with San Juan.  Once I finally got used to the symbols and the flow of the game, I began to really love it.  It was my most played game of 2008, and will almost certainly be my most played game of 2009.  Every game begins with a choice of strategic paths, and the more you play the more nuanced the strategy becomes.  It's not just a choice of military or production, but of choosing from the many flavors of those two main branches. 

After 500+ Plays: This has remained one of my absolute favorites.  The expansions are excellent, and a crucial element in my continuing to play with such regularity.  As long as quality expansions continue to be released I'm happy to play this about 100 times a year.  But, even if they stopped making expansions, I see myself playing around 50 games a year for the foreseeable future.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
There are a lot of good things to be said about this game. However, the main flaw, which keeps this game from being played at our table is the possible imbalance - or "phase 10" dilemma. 

We had a number of games, where one or two players just had lucky draws in the very beginning of the game, while others just didn´t get the cards that matched their basic strategy for a few turns. The bad part about this: it is very unlikely to catch up on a slow start during the course of the game, making the outcome very predictable. And it just takes away too much, when half of the players mentaly leave the game early, because there is hardly any chance of winning for them. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've played less than 1000 games of RftG, so I'm probably not yet qualified to form an opinion. At least that's the perception from many people who are so serious into this game. While that's obviously tongue-in-cheek, it points to something important about it. After 100s of plays, it is still exciting and fresh. Like a game like 7 Wonders the iconography can turn people off, but after this is internalized, it quickly becomes wonderful. I think it plays best with the 2-player advanced rules where each person chooses two roles, but up to 4 will be great. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
Puerto Rico. But short. And with cards. Okay, so I've never played Puerto Rico, but this is awesome. Luck might come to bite you, but the better player usually wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played this game a few times with my girlfriend's, mom's, husband's, brother's, nephew and his wife, and loved every game. It moves really fast, and feels really close and intense to the very end when you're never quite sure who's going to win. Will play any chance I get. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We purchased this game because it came highly recommended from a friend who really knew their stuff when it comes to games. However, it looked much more complicated than most of what we had been playing (Ticket to Ride, Pandemic, etc.) so it sat on the shelf for a while. When we finally got around to trying it out, we were a bit daunted at first but ended up picking up the rules far faster than we thought we would and Race for the Galaxy is now one of our favorite games! There are tons of layers of strategy to this game and many ways that you can play it.

RATING: 8
В эту игру очень хочется научиться играть. Ничего не понимаешь, тупишь, а потом... постепенно... начинаешь осознавать - ага, победные очки, ага, товары надо обменивать на них в свой ход, ага, много строить не нужно, ага, оптимизировать 2 и 3 фазы надо в начале игры только... ага... ага... 

9 Игра нравится всё больше и больше. Так получилось, что играл после знакомства с Доминионом. Доминион в один прекрасный момент надоедает - см ниже почему. Она пока что - нет. Единственный минус - не для девочек.

8.05 Слишком гиковая игра, а с гиками можно поиграть и во много других игр.

RATING: N/A
[b]Retrospective[/b]:

When I first purchased this game in 2009 I was naïvely expecting it to be something else, perhaps a confrontational game similar to Magic: The Gathering. This probably explains why I had such a hard time explaining it to everyone. Fast forward to 2017 after playing San Juan and more Euros since 2009 and suddenly it just made sense. While I think it's mechanically better than San Juan, it just isn't as thematically appealing to me. I'll have to play it again to be able to score it properly.

RATING: 9
Excellent card game with a great flavor, good art and a brisk pace. Might not be ideal for you if you're always playing with a different group since the icons (while excellent) take some getting used to.

Own the first two expansions (I never liked all that war nonsense - it's too complicated for what it adds).

RATING: 10
Excellent balance, deep gameplay, many paths to victory, always interesting stuff to do or consider, great theme and art, eminently replayable. And quick. Only downside might be the low level of interaction, but you do have to pay attention to your opponents' strategies and adapt accordingly.

RATING: N/A
Objetivo: construir el más próspero y poderoso imperio de la galaxia. Las cartas pueden ser utilizadas para construir investigaciones/mundos, como dinero o como bienes para consumir o vender. Cuando alguien tenga 12 cartas en su imperio termina la partida.
